              - text: "<h2 id=\"2025-in-review\">2025 in Review<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#2025-in-review\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>What a year 2025 has been! I published 24 blog posts covering a wide range of topics from cloud-native technologies to AI experiments, and even some personal reflections. Here are the key themes and highlights from my blogging year:</p> <h3 id=\"cloud-native-and-devops\">Cloud-Native and DevOps<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#cloud-native-and-devops\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>This was a major focus area for me in 2025, not really surprising as I moved into a DevOps role this year, with deep dives into modern infrastructure:</p> <ul> <li><a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/learning-kubernetes/\"><strong>Learning Kubernetes</strong></a> - Started my journey into container orchestration and shared my beginner experiences</li> <li><a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/deploying-hugo-with-helm/\"><strong>Deploying Hugo with Helm</strong></a> - Deployed this very blog to Kubernetes using Helm charts</li> <li><a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/kubernetes-and-letsencrypt/\"><strong>Kubernetes and Let&rsquo;s Encrypt</strong></a> - Tackled SSL certificate management in Kubernetes</li> <li><a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/nagios-monitoring-with-docker/\"><strong>Monitoring with Nagios Docker</strong></a> - Explored monitoring solutions in containerized environments</li> </ul> <h3 id=\"net-and-development\">.NET and Development<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#net-and-development\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>My bread and butter continues to be .NET development, with several posts exploring new features and tools:</p> <ul> <li><a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/blazor-and-dotnet10/\"><strong>Blazor and .NET 10</strong></a> - Covered breaking changes, fixes, and new features in the latest .NET release</li> <li><a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/adding-elasticsearch-with-aspire/\"><strong>Adding Elasticsearch with .NET Aspire</strong></a> - Integrated search capabilities using Aspire</li> <li><a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/what-is-new-in-aspire-9.2/\"><strong>Aspire 9.2</strong></a> - Explored the latest Aspire release</li> <li><a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/central-package-management-with-nuget/\"><strong>NuGet Central Package Management</strong></a> - Streamlined dependency management</li> <li><a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/whats-new-csharp/\"><strong>What&rsquo;s New in C#</strong></a> - Covered the latest language features</li> <li><a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/exceptions/\"><strong>Exceptions</strong></a> - Best practices for error handling</li> </ul> <h3 id=\"observability-and-monitoring\">Observability and Monitoring<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#observability-and-monitoring\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>Understanding what&rsquo;s happening in production became a key theme:</p> <ul> <li><a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/getting-started-with-opentelemetry/\"><strong>Getting Started with OpenTelemetry</strong></a> - Made observability easy with modern tracing</li> <li><a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/adding-opentelemetry-logs-to-grafana/\"><strong>OpenTelemetry Logs</strong></a> - Extended observability to include logging</li> <li><a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2025/setting-up-grafana/\"><strong>Setting up Grafana</strong></a> - Built dashboards for monitoring</li> </ul> <h3 id=\"cloud-platforms\">Cloud Platforms<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#cloud-platforms\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <ul> <li><a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/merge-two-projects-into-one/\"><strong>Merging Two Projects into One</strong></a> - Shared my experience consolidating codebases</li> </ul> <h3 id=\"ai-and-creativity\">AI and Creativity<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#ai-and-creativity\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <ul> <li><a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/fun-with-ai/\"><strong>Fun with AI</strong></a> - Explored ChatGPT&rsquo;s image generation capabilities</li> <li><a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/using-ai/\"><strong>Using AI</strong></a> - Practical applications of AI in daily work</li> <li><a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/mandelbrot-set/\"><strong>Mandelbrot Set</strong></a> - A fun mathematical exploration</li> </ul> <h3 id=\"professional-development\">Professional Development<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#professional-development\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <ul> <li><a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/pragmatic-programmer/\"><strong>The Pragmatic Programmer</strong></a> - Book review of this classic software development book</li> <li><a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/the-hacker-ethic/\"><strong>The Hacker Ethic</strong></a> - Reflections on developer culture and values</li> <li><a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/stepping-outside-my-comfort-zone/\"><strong>Stepping Outside Your Comfort Zone</strong></a> - Personal growth and career development</li> <li><a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/volunteering-at-ndc-london/\"><strong>Volunteering at NDC London</strong></a> - My experience at this major .NET conference</li> <li><a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/periodic-table-of-devops-15c7/\"><strong>Periodic Table of DevOps 2025</strong></a> - A visual guide to the DevOps ecosystem</li> </ul> <h3 id=\"fun-projects\">Fun Projects<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#fun-projects\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <ul> <li><a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/festive-naughty-or-nice-checker/\"><strong>Festive Naughty or Nice Checker</strong></a> - A seasonal AI-powered fun project</li> </ul> <p>Thank you to everyone who read, commented, and shared my posts throughout the year. Your engagement and feedback mean the world to me!</p> <h2 id=\"2025-by-the-numbers\">2025 by the Numbers<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#2025-by-the-numbers\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <ul> <li><strong>24 blog posts</strong> published</li> <li>Major topics: Kubernetes, .NET, OpenTelemetry, AI</li> <li>New skills acquired: Helm, Kubernetes, observability tools</li> <li>Conferences attended: NDC London (as a volunteer) and DDD North</li> <li>Submitted content to <a href=\"https://festivetechcalendar.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">https://festivetechcalendar.com</a> </li> </ul> <h2 id=\"goals-for-2026\">Goals for 2026<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#goals-for-2026\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>Looking ahead to 2026, I&rsquo;m excited to build on this momentum. Here are my blogging and technical goals:</p> <h3 id=\"content-goals\">Content Goals<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#content-goals\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <ul> <li><strong>Publish at least 24 posts</strong> - Maintain the pace from 2025</li> <li><strong>Deep dive into AI/ML</strong> - Go beyond experimentation to practical implementations</li> <li><strong>More hands-on tutorials</strong> - Provide step-by-step guides that readers can follow along with</li> </ul> <h3 id=\"technical-skills\">Technical Skills<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#technical-skills\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <ul> <li><strong>Master Kubernetes</strong> - Move from beginner to intermediate proficiency</li> <li><strong>Advanced observability</strong> - Implement comprehensive monitoring across distributed systems</li> <li><strong>Cloud-native patterns</strong> - Explore microservices, event-driven architectures, and service mesh</li> <li><strong>AI integration</strong> - Build practical AI-powered features into applications</li> <li><strong>Platform engineering</strong> - Create better developer experiences and internal platforms</li> </ul> <h2 id=\"walking\">Walking<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#walking\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>At the end of 2024 I made the following goal:</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-txt\" data-lang=\"txt\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>2024 took an unusual turn. In June, I walked a half marathon across the Peak District, and since then, </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>I have been doing lots of walks. Walking is good for my physical and mental health, </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>so I intend to do more of it in 2025. I have a 5k scheduled for January, </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>which should be lots of fun as it is around the wildlife park. </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Well I enjoyed my walk in January 2025, which then led to two 10k walks (in July and September) and a 7.5k night walk (in Blackpool to see the Illuminations). This led me to explore <a href=\"https://www.parkrun.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">parkrun</a> and I completed my 8th run this morning. I say run, not walk as I am slowly becoming more of a runner and less of a walker.</p> <p>So my goal here is to keep doing this, as I am so far enjoying getting out and about.</p> <h2 id=\"what-would-you-like-to-see\">What Would You Like to See?<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#what-would-you-like-to-see\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>I&rsquo;d love to hear from you! What topics would you like me to cover in 2026? Are there specific technologies, patterns, or problems you&rsquo;d like to see explored?</p> <p>Drop a comment below, reach out on social media, or send me a message. Your feedback helps shape the content direction for the year ahead.</p> <p>Here&rsquo;s to a fantastic 2026 filled with learning, building, and sharing! üöÄ</p>"

              - text: "<p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"Festive Tech Calendar\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2025/festive-tech-calendar.png\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"817\" height=\"545\" /> </p> <h2 id=\"introduction\">Introduction<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#introduction\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>I&rsquo;m excited to be taking part in this year&rsquo;s <a href=\"https://festivetechcalendar.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Festive Tech Calendar</a> , a community-driven advent calendar showcasing amazing technical content throughout December. Make sure to check out the other excellent posts created by developers from around the world!</p> <p>In this festive tutorial, we&rsquo;ll build a fun &ldquo;Naughty or Nice&rdquo; checker using Microsoft&rsquo;s Semantic Kernel and .NET. This playful AI-powered tool analyzes text descriptions and delivers a verdict on whether someone has been naughty or nice this year‚Äîperfect for adding some holiday cheer to your portfolio! Whether you&rsquo;re new to AI integration or looking to explore Semantic Kernel, this beginner-friendly guide will walk you through creating a complete working application from scratch. By the end, you&rsquo;ll have a deployable web app and understand how to integrate large language models into your .NET projects.</p> <h2 id=\"my-take-on-ai\">My Take on AI<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#my-take-on-ai\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>Before diving into code, I want to share a quick perspective on using AI in development. While building this demo, I used <a href=\"https://github.com/copilot\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">GitHub Copilot</a> to transform a basic UI into something more festive.</p> <p>Starting with a simple, functional interface:</p> <p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"boring looking application\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2025/before.png\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"1487\" height=\"347\" /> </p> <p>After a few prompts to Copilot, I had a Christmas-themed demo with loading spinners and festive icons:</p> <p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"Christmas version\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2025/after.png\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"1128\" height=\"432\" /> </p> <p>Could I have coded this myself? Absolutely. But I&rsquo;d rather focus my energy on the backend Semantic Kernel integration than wrestling with CSS animations. <strong>This is where AI shines‚Äîhandling the tedious parts so you can focus on the interesting problems.</strong></p> <h3 id=\"the-reality-check\">The Reality Check<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#the-reality-check\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>That said, AI isn&rsquo;t magic:</p> <ul> <li><strong>Hallucinations happen</strong> - I&rsquo;ve lost time chasing incorrect suggestions, so don&rsquo;t retire your search engine just yet</li> <li><strong>Ownership questions remain</strong> - Who owns AI-generated code? This is still being figured out</li> <li><strong>It&rsquo;s a tool, not a replacement</strong> - AI augments developers; it doesn&rsquo;t replace critical thinking</li> </ul> <p>My approach: Use AI as a productivity multiplier, but always verify, understand, and own what you ship.</p> <h2 id=\"what-is-semantic-kernel\">What is Semantic Kernel?<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#what-is-semantic-kernel\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>Semantic Kernel is an open-source SDK from Microsoft that makes it easy to integrate AI models into your .NET applications. It allows you to use large language models (LLMs) for tasks like text analysis, summarization, and more.</p> <h2 id=\"project-overview\">Project Overview<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#project-overview\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>We&rsquo;ll create a simple web app that:</p> <ul> <li>Accepts a name or short description of someone&rsquo;s behaviour</li> <li>Uses Semantic Kernel to analyze the input</li> <li>Returns a festive verdict: Naughty or Nice</li> </ul> <h2 id=\"prerequisites\">Prerequisites<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#prerequisites\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <ul> <li>.NET 10 (I am not using any .NET 10 specific features so could probably be rewritten with older versions)</li> <li>Semantic Kernel (NuGet package)</li> <li>An OpenAI API key - ‚ö†Ô∏è <strong>Note</strong>: API usage costs ~$0.01-0.05 per request</li> </ul> <h3 id=\"openai-and-costs\">OpenAI and Costs<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#openai-and-costs\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>For this example I have used an OpenAI API Key. This is not free, however while writing this example I have only spent a few pounds in tokens. For more information about OpenAI head over to <a href=\"https://platform.openai.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">https://platform.openai.com/</a> </p> <p>For this reason I have not provided a live demo, (I don&rsquo;t want you all using my API key), and no API keys are included in my example code.</p> <h2 id=\"step-1-setting-up-the-project\">Step 1: Setting Up the Project<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#step-1-setting-up-the-project\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>Create a new Blazor Web App:</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>dotnet new blazor -n NaughtyOrNiceChecker </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>cd NaughtyOrNiceChecker </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Install the required NuGet packages: (Microsoft.SemanticKernel.Connectors.OpenAI Version 1.67.1 as I write this)</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>dotnet add package Microsoft.SemanticKernel.Connectors.OpenAI </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Add your OpenAI configuration to appsettings.json:</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-json\" data-lang=\"json\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>{ </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">&#34;OpenAI&#34;</span>: { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">&#34;Key&#34;</span>: <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;your-api-key-here&#34;</span>, <span style=\"color:#75715e\">// Head over to https://platform.openai.com/settings/organization/api-keys </span></span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">&#34;Model&#34;</span>: <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;gpt-5&#34;</span> <span style=\"color:#75715e\">// I am using gpt-5 but feel free to experiment with other models </span></span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>} </span></span></code></pre></div><p>üîí <strong>Security</strong>: Never commit API keys to GitHub. Use user secrets or environment variables.</p> <p>The code for my project can be found on GitHub at <a href=\"https://github.com/funkysi1701/FestiveTechCalendar2025\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">https://github.com/funkysi1701/FestiveTechCalendar2025</a> .</p> <h2 id=\"step-2-integrate-semantic-kernel\">Step 2: Integrate Semantic Kernel<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#step-2-integrate-semantic-kernel\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>Configure Semantic Kernel to use your LLM provider (OpenAI). In the <code>Program.cs</code> file you will see the following code, this loads the OpenAI key and model from your <code>appsettings.json</code> config file, and allows it to be used by Semantic Kernel.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> key = builder.Configuration.GetValue&lt;<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span>&gt;(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;OpenAI:Key&#34;</span>); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> model = builder.Configuration.GetValue&lt;<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span>&gt;(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;OpenAI:Model&#34;</span>); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">if</span> (!<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span>.IsNullOrEmpty(key)) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>{ </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> builder.Services.AddOpenAIChatCompletion( </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> modelId: model ?? <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">throw</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> ApplicationException(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;Missing OpenAI Config&#34;</span>), </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> apiKey: key </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> ); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>} </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>builder.Services.AddKernel(); </span></span></code></pre></div><h2 id=\"step-3-create-the-blazor-component\">Step 3: Create the Blazor Component<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#step-3-create-the-blazor-component\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>Create a new file <code>Components/Pages/NaughtyOrNice.razor</code>:</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>@page <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;/naughty-or-nice&#34;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>@inject Kernel _kernel </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>@rendermode InteractiveServer </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>&lt;PageTitle&gt;Naughty or Nice Checker&lt;/PageTitle&gt; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>&lt;h3&gt;<span style=\"color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010\">üéÖ</span> Naughty or Nice Checker&lt;/h3&gt; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>&lt;div class=<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;card&#34;</span>&gt; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> &lt;div class=<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;card-body&#34;</span>&gt; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> &lt;input @bind=<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;input&#34;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> placeholder=<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;Describe their behavior...&#34;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> class=<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;form-control mb-3&#34;</span> /&gt; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> &lt;button @onclick=<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;CheckStatus&#34;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> class=<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;btn btn-primary&#34;</span>&gt; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> Check Status </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> &lt;/button&gt; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> @if (!<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span>.IsNullOrEmpty(response)) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> &lt;div class=<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;alert alert-@alertClass mt-3&#34;</span>&gt; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> &lt;h4&gt;@response&lt;/h4&gt; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> &lt;/div&gt; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> &lt;/div&gt; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>&lt;/div&gt; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>@code { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">private</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span> childsName = <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;&#34;</span>; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">private</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span> response = <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;&#34;</span>; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">private</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span> alertClass =&gt; response == <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;Naughty&#34;</span> ? <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;danger&#34;</span> : <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;success&#34;</span>; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">private</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">bool</span> isLoading = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">false</span>; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">public</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">async</span> Task CheckStatus() </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> isLoading = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">true</span>; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">await</span> InvokeAsync(StateHasChanged); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> response = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span>.Empty; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">try</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> input = (childsName).Trim(); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">if</span> (<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span>.IsNullOrEmpty(input)) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">return</span>; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">using</span> var cts = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> CancellationTokenSource(TimeSpan.FromSeconds(<span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">30</span>)); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> prompt = <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;You are Santa&#39;s assistant. Given the child&#39;s name or short description, &#34;</span> + </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;decide if they are Naughty or Nice for Christmas. &#34;</span> + </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;Respond only with one word: Naughty or Nice. &#34;</span> + </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;No punctuation, no explanation. Input: {{$input}}&#34;</span>; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> classifyFunc = _kernel.CreateFunctionFromPrompt(prompt); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> aiResponse = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">await</span> _kernel.InvokeAsync( </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> classifyFunc, </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span>() </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#a6e22e\"> [&#34;input&#34;]</span> = input </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> }, </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> cts.Token </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> ); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> text = aiResponse.GetValue&lt;<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span>&gt;()?.Trim(); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#75715e\">// Normalize and enforce strict output</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">if</span> (<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span>.Equals(text, <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;naughty&#34;</span>, StringComparison.OrdinalIgnoreCase)) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> response = <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;Naughty&#34;</span>; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">else</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">if</span> (<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span>.Equals(text, <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;nice&#34;</span>, StringComparison.OrdinalIgnoreCase)) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> response = <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;Nice&#34;</span>; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">else</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#75715e\">// Fallback: default to Naughty to avoid leaking other content</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> response = <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;Naughty&#34;</span>; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">finally</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> isLoading = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">false</span>; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">await</span> InvokeAsync(StateHasChanged); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>} </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Note: The _kernel is injected automatically because we registered it in Program.cs with builder.Services.AddKernel().</p> <h2 id=\"step-4-crafting-the-perfect-prompt\">Step 4: Crafting the Perfect Prompt<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#step-4-crafting-the-perfect-prompt\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>Getting AI to return exactly what you want requires iteration. I&rsquo;ll walk you through my prompt engineering journey from verbose outputs to production-ready responses.</p> <h3 id=\"iteration-1-too-verbose\">Iteration 1: Too Verbose<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#iteration-1-too-verbose\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> aiResponse = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">await</span> _kernel.InvokePromptAsync( </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">$&#34;You are a tool to help Santa identify if children have been naughty or nice. &#34;</span> + </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">$&#34;Has {input} been naughty or nice this year?&#34;</span>, </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> cancellationToken: cancellationToken.Token </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>); </span></span></code></pre></div><table> <thead> <tr> <th>Input</th> <th>Output</th> </tr> </thead> <tbody> <tr> <td>Santa</td> <td>Short answer: Nice. Why: - Spreads joy and generosity globally - Works hard with his team, treats elves and reindeer well - Answers letters and keeps promises (on-time deliveries) Minor demerits (lighthearted): - Excess cookie consumption - Occasional chimney soot prints Verdict: Firmly on the Nice List. Want a fun ‚ÄúOfficial Nice Report‚Äù for Santa you can share?</td> </tr> <tr> <td>Darth Vader</td> <td>Not exactly a child, but Santa checks everyone. Darth Vader‚Äôs record this year includes Force-choking subordinates and aiding Imperial oppression‚Äîfirmly Naughty. Mitigating note: he did protect his son and turn against the Emperor, which earns a small mercy. Final verdict: Naughty list (with a tiny redemption candy cane).</td> </tr> <tr> <td>James</td> <td>I don‚Äôt have access to Santa‚Äôs list or personal data, so I can‚Äôt say for sure about James. But I can help you decide with a quick Naughty/Nice check: Score each item: - Kind and helpful to family/classmates most of the time? (Yes +2, Sometimes +1, No 0) - Tells the truth and takes responsibility? (Yes +2, Sometimes +1, No 0) - Apologizes and makes things right after mistakes? (Yes +2, Sometimes +1, No 0) - Respects rules and others (no bullying or deliberate harm)? (Yes +2, Sometimes +1, No 0; deduct 2 if there‚Äôs repeated serious harm) - Does generous things (sharing, chores, helping the community)? (Yes +2, Sometimes +1, No 0) Totals: - 8‚Äì10: Nice List - 5‚Äì7: Mostly Nice (keep it up) - 2‚Äì4: Mixed (needs a December boost) - 0‚Äì1 or repeated serious harm: Naughty-for-now (with room to improve) If James needs a boost: make amends where needed, do one unprompted kindness or chore daily, be honest about mistakes right away, and share/donate something or help someone weekly. Share a few examples of James‚Äôs year and I‚Äôll help you make the call.</td> </tr> <tr> <td>Skeletor</td> <td>Verdict: Naughty. Why: - Repeated attempts to conquer Eternia and seize Castle Grayskull - Habitual scheming, lying, and bullying his own minions - Frequent unleashing of dangerous magic on innocents Path back to the Nice List: - Call a truce with He-Man and protect Eternia for a season - Return stolen artifacts and undo harmful spells - Treat his minions fairly and do a few good deeds without expecting power in return</td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <p>This is far too wordy, I really just want a Naughty or Nice response.</p> <h3 id=\"iteration-2-constraining-the-output\">Iteration 2: Constraining the Output<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#iteration-2-constraining-the-output\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>Then I tried:</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> aiResponse = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">await</span> _kernel.InvokePromptAsync( </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">$&#34;Given the following description, decide if the person is Naughty or Nice for Christmas. &#34;</span> + </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">$&#34;Respond only with &#39;Naughty&#39; or &#39;Nice&#39;. &#34;</span> + </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">$&#34;Description: {input}&#34;</span>, </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> cancellationToken: cancellationToken.Token </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>); </span></span></code></pre></div><table> <thead> <tr> <th>Input</th> <th>Output</th> </tr> </thead> <tbody> <tr> <td>Santa</td> <td>Nice</td> </tr> <tr> <td>Darth Vader</td> <td>Naughty</td> </tr> <tr> <td>James</td> <td>Nice</td> </tr> <tr> <td>Skeletor</td> <td>Naughty</td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <p>This is better but every name I tried is giving me a Nice, so let&rsquo;s see if we can try something a bit more clever. However if instead of only including a name, we include some naughty or nice actions we get some interesting results.</p> <table> <thead> <tr> <th>Input</th> <th>Output</th> </tr> </thead> <tbody> <tr> <td>Santa delivered some presents</td> <td>Nice</td> </tr> <tr> <td>Darth Vader destroyed Alderaan</td> <td>Naughty</td> </tr> <tr> <td>James tidied his room</td> <td>Nice</td> </tr> <tr> <td>Skeletor got cross with Evil Lynn</td> <td>Naughty</td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <h3 id=\"version-3-non-ai-approach-plugin-example\">Version 3: Non-AI Approach (Plugin Example)<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#version-3-non-ai-approach-plugin-example\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>This version demonstrates Semantic Kernel&rsquo;s plugin system without using AI. While it doesn&rsquo;t actually help Santa (it just generates a hash-based result), it shows how you can integrate traditional .NET code into Semantic Kernel workflows.</p> <p><strong>Why show this?</strong> To illustrate that Semantic Kernel isn&rsquo;t just for AI‚Äîyou can mix AI calls with regular code execution in the same pipeline.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> aiResponse = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">await</span> _kernel.InvokeAsync( </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> pluginName, </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;GenerateHash&#34;</span>, </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> KernelArguments </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#a6e22e\"> [&#34;input&#34;]</span> = input </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>); </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This version invokes a semantic kernel plugin function called GenerateHash. The function itself is defined in a separate class with a KernelFunction attribute, it is really simple just generates a hash from the input string. This is just an example of how you can call .NET code from Semantic Kernel. The kernel function requires an extra line to wire up correctly I have placed this in the OnInitialized method.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">protected</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">override</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">void</span> OnInitialized() </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>{ </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> rngPlugin = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> ExamplePlugin(); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> _kernel.ImportPluginFromObject(rngPlugin, pluginName); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>} </span></span></code></pre></div><div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">public</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">class</span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">ExamplePlugin</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>{ </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#a6e22e\"> [KernelFunction]</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">public</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">int</span> GenerateHash(<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span> input) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">if</span> (input == <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">null</span>) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">throw</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> ArgumentNullException(nameof(input)); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> hash = input.GetHashCode(); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">return</span> hash &gt; <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">0</span> ? <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">0</span> : <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">1</span>; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>} </span></span></code></pre></div><h3 id=\"final-version-production-ready-implementation\">Final Version: Production-Ready Implementation<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#final-version-production-ready-implementation\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>My last example is very similar to Version 2 but let&rsquo;s have a look at it.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> prompt = <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;You are Santa&#39;s assistant. Given the child&#39;s name or short description, &#34;</span> + </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;decide if they are Naughty or Nice for Christmas. Respond only with one word: Naughty or Nice. &#34;</span> + </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;No punctuation, no explanation. Input: {{$input}}&#34;</span>; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> classifyFunc = _kernel.CreateFunctionFromPrompt(prompt); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> aiResponse = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">await</span> _kernel.InvokeAsync( </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> classifyFunc, </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span>() </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#a6e22e\"> [&#34;input&#34;]</span> = input </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> }, </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> cancellationToken.Token </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> ); </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Here we have a bit more error checking to make sure we have entered a valid string before calling OpenAI. This time we use the CreateFunctionFromPrompt method to pass in a prompt, we then invoke the prompt along with the string that has been entered.</p> <p>This time we check for naughty or nice in the response before returning that to the user, if neither is returned we return Naughty.</p> <p>This works quite well if we enter a more descriptive input.</p> <table> <thead> <tr> <th>Input</th> <th>Output</th> </tr> </thead> <tbody> <tr> <td>Santa delivered some presents</td> <td>Nice</td> </tr> <tr> <td>Darth Vader destroyed Alderaan</td> <td>Naughty</td> </tr> <tr> <td>James tidied his room</td> <td>Nice</td> </tr> <tr> <td>Skeletor got cross with Evil Lynn</td> <td>Naughty</td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <p>As you can see if we describe the actions of someone we can categorize them as naughty or nice, which is basically what Santa does, so this tool should be a great help to him.</p> <p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"Is Santa Naughty or Nice?\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2025/working-naughty-nice.png\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"1169\" height=\"618\" /> </p> <h3 id=\"comparing-all-versions\">Comparing All Versions<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#comparing-all-versions\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <table> <thead> <tr> <th>Version</th> <th>Approach</th> <th>Pros</th> <th>Cons</th> <th>Use Case</th> </tr> </thead> <tbody> <tr> <td>1</td> <td>Open-ended prompt</td> <td>Rich explanations</td> <td>Too verbose</td> <td>Learning/debugging</td> </tr> <tr> <td>2</td> <td>Constrained output</td> <td>Concise</td> <td>Needs context</td> <td>Simple classifications</td> </tr> <tr> <td>3</td> <td>Hash-based (no AI)</td> <td>No API costs</td> <td>Not intelligent</td> <td>Plugin example only</td> </tr> <tr> <td>4</td> <td>Validated prompts</td> <td>Reliable, safe</td> <td>More code</td> <td>Production</td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <h2 id=\"conclusion\">Conclusion<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#conclusion\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>In this tutorial, we built a festive AI-powered application using Semantic Kernel and .NET. Here&rsquo;s what we accomplished:</p> <ul> <li>‚úÖ Integrated OpenAI with Semantic Kernel in a Blazor app</li> <li>‚úÖ Learned prompt engineering through iteration (4 versions!)</li> <li>‚úÖ Implemented proper error handling and output validation</li> <li>‚úÖ Created a fun, interactive holiday application</li> </ul> <p>I have tried to highlight some of the different ways that you can use Semantic Kernel that you could use in your own projects. Some of my examples could be accomplished without the use of Semantic Kernel, for example randomly generating Naughty and Nice doesn&rsquo;t need AI, however hopefully you can see that getting results from AI can then be augmented using traditional .NET code to execute other functions.</p> <h3 id=\"key-takeaways\">Key Takeaways<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#key-takeaways\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <ul> <li><strong>Prompt engineering matters</strong> - Notice how Version 4&rsquo;s explicit instructions produced better results</li> <li><strong>Validation is essential</strong> - Always sanitize LLM outputs before displaying to users</li> <li><strong>Keep it simple</strong> - Complex doesn&rsquo;t mean better (Version 3&rsquo;s random approach was overkill)</li> </ul> <h3 id=\"cost-considerations\">Cost Considerations<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#cost-considerations\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>During development, I spent only a few pounds on API tokens. For production:</p> <ul> <li>Use Azure OpenAI for predictable pricing</li> <li>Implement caching for common queries</li> <li>Set up rate limiting to prevent abuse</li> </ul> <h3 id=\"deployment-options\">Deployment Options<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#deployment-options\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>This Blazor app can be deployed to:</p> <ul> <li><strong>Azure Static Web Apps</strong> (free tier includes 2 custom domains)</li> <li><strong>Azure App Service</strong> (full .NET hosting)</li> <li><strong>Docker containers</strong> (run anywhere)</li> </ul> <h3 id=\"next-steps\">Next Steps<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#next-steps\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>Want to extend this project? Try:</p> <ul> <li>Add a database to track naughty/nice history</li> <li>Implement user authentication</li> <li>Deploy to Azure Static Web Apps</li> <li>Add more context (age, location) for better AI decisions</li> </ul> <p>Happy coding and Merry Christmas! üéÑ</p> <hr> <p><strong>References:</strong></p> <ul> <li><a href=\"https://github.com/microsoft/semantic-kernel\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Semantic Kernel GitHub</a> </li> <li><a href=\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/semantic-kernel/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Microsoft Semantic Kernel Docs</a> </li> <li><a href=\"https://platform.openai.com/docs/api-reference\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">OpenAI API</a> </li> <li><a href=\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-services/openai/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Azure OpenAI</a> </li> </ul>"

              - text: "<h2 id=\"whats-new-in-net-10\">What‚Äôs New in .NET 10?<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#whats-new-in-net-10\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>.NET 10 was released this week and it is full of awesome new features. Check it out at <a href=\"https://dotnet.microsoft.com/download/dotnet/10.0\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">.NET Download</a> , there is also a new version of <a href=\"https://visualstudio.microsoft.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Visual Studio</a> which you should also check out.</p> <p>I quickly upgraded my .NET projects to take advantage of the new version, but my Blazor WebAssembly (Wasm) project encountered the following error in the browser console:</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-txt\" data-lang=\"txt\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>System.NotSupportedException: net_http_synchronous_reads_not_supported </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> at System.Net.Http.BrowserHttpReadStream.Read(Byte[] buffer, Int32 offset, Int32 count) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> at System.IO.DelegatingStream.Read(Byte[] buffer, Int32 offset, Int32 count) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> at System.IO.StreamReader.ReadBuffer(Span`1 userBuffer, Boolean&amp; readToUserBuffer) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> at System.IO.StreamReader.ReadSpan(Span`1 buffer) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> at System.IO.StreamReader.Read(Char[] buffer, Int32 index, Int32 count) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> at Newtonsoft.Json.JsonTextReader.ReadData(Boolean append, Int32 charsRequired) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> at Newtonsoft.Json.JsonTextReader.ReadData(Boolean append) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> at Newtonsoft.Json.JsonTextReader.ParseValue() </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> at Newtonsoft.Json.JsonTextReader.Read() </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> at Newtonsoft.Json.JsonReader.ReadAndMoveToContent() </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> at Newtonsoft.Json.JsonReader.ReadForType(JsonContract contract, Boolean hasConverter) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> at Newtonsoft.Json.Serialization.JsonSerializerInternalReader.Deserialize(JsonReader reader, Type objectType, Boolean checkAdditionalContent) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> at Newtonsoft.Json.JsonSerializer.DeserializeInternal(JsonReader reader, Type objectType) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> at Newtonsoft.Json.JsonSerializer.Deserialize(JsonReader reader, Type objectType) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> at Newtonsoft.Json.JsonSerializer.Deserialize[MyResult](JsonReader reader) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> at MyAPI.Client.MyClient.&lt;ReadObjectResponseAsync&gt;d__57`1[[MyAPI.Client.MyResult, MyAPI.Client, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=null]].MoveNext() </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> at MyAPI.Client.MyClient.MyAsync(MyRequest body, CancellationToken cancellationToken) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This error was getting thrown on a Blazor Wasm page when it tried to make a call to my API. This worked fine in .NET 9 so my suspicion was this might be a breaking change.</p> <p>The list of new features for .NET 10 can be found <a href=\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/core/release-notes/aspnetcore-10.0?view=aspnetcore-9.0\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">.NET 10 Release Notes</a> </p> <h2 id=\"httpclient-response-streaming-breaking-change-in-blazor\">HttpClient Response Streaming: Breaking Change in Blazor<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#httpclient-response-streaming-breaking-change-in-blazor\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>I found the following new feature which I suspect is related to my issue:</p> <p>HttpClient response streaming enabled by default</p> <p>In prior Blazor releases, response streaming for HttpClient requests was opt-in. Now, response streaming is enabled by default.</p> <p>This is a breaking change because calling <code>HttpContent.ReadAsStreamAsync</code> for an <code>HttpResponseMessage.Content</code> (<code>response.Content.ReadAsStreamAsync()</code>) returns a <code>BrowserHttpReadStream</code> and no longer a <code>MemoryStream</code>. <code>BrowserHttpReadStream</code> doesn&rsquo;t support synchronous operations, such as <code>Stream.Read(Span&lt;Byte&gt;)</code>. If your code uses synchronous operations, you can opt-out of response streaming or copy the <code>Stream</code> into a <code>MemoryStream</code> yourself.</p> <p>To opt-out of response streaming globally, use either of the following approaches:</p> <p>Add the &lt;WasmEnableStreamingResponse&gt; property to the project file with a value of false:</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-xml\" data-lang=\"xml\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#f92672\">&lt;WasmEnableStreamingResponse&gt;</span>false<span style=\"color:#f92672\">&lt;/WasmEnableStreamingResponse&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Set the DOTNET_WASM_ENABLE_STREAMING_RESPONSE environment variable to false or 0.</p> <p>To opt-out of response streaming for an individual request, set <code>SetBrowserResponseStreamingEnabled</code> to false on the <code>HttpRequestMessage</code> (<code>requestMessage</code> in the following example):</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>requestMessage.SetBrowserResponseStreamingEnabled(<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">false</span>); </span></span></code></pre></div><p>For more information, see HttpClient and HttpRequestMessage with Fetch API request options (Call web API article).</p> <h2 id=\"how-to-fix-the-streaming-issue-in-blazor\">How to Fix the Streaming Issue in Blazor<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#how-to-fix-the-streaming-issue-in-blazor\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>To test out if this was the culprit I added <code>&lt;WasmEnableStreamingResponse&gt;false&lt;/WasmEnableStreamingResponse&gt;</code> to my csproj file and sure enough this fixed my issue.</p> <p>Do check out the docs for a complete list of new features and any other potential breaking changes. <a href=\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/core/release-notes/aspnetcore-10.0?view=aspnetcore-10.0\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">.NET 10 Release Notes</a> </p>"

              - generic [ref=e360]: <description>
              - text: <p>DevOps has transformed the way teams build, deploy, and manage software. Over the years, the tools we use have evolved rapidly‚Äîsome have become industry standards, while others have faded away or emerged to solve new challenges. In this post, I revisit the concept of a &ldquo;Periodic Table of DevOps&rdquo; to compare the landscape in 2016 with 2025, highlight key changes, and reflect on what these shifts mean for developers, IT professionals, and organizations embracing modern workflows.</p> <p>The periodic table lists all the chemical elements and groups them together based on some key properties. In 2016 I found an article about the <a href="https://xebialabs.com/periodic-table-of-devops-tools/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">periodic table of DevOps</a> and wrote a blog <a href="https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2016/periodic-table-devops/">post</a> about it.</p> <h3 id="periodic-table-of-devops-tools-2025">Periodic Table of DevOps Tools 2025<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#periodic-table-of-devops-tools-2025"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h3> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="Periodic Table of DevOps 2025" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2025/periodic-table-devops-2025.png" loading="lazy" width="1386" height="879" /> </p> <h3 id="periodic-table-of-devops-tools-2016">Periodic Table of DevOps Tools 2016<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#periodic-table-of-devops-tools-2016"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h3> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="Periodic Table of DevOps 2016" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2016/periodic-table-of-devops-v2.png" loading="lazy" width="4896" height="2734" /> </p> <p>I thought it might be interesting to see what tools are still in use, and what are new.</p> <h2 id="source-control">Source Control<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#source-control"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p>Git, the most popular source control system, is on both charts, in 2016 it was at position 3, and in 2025 it is at 2. GitHub, the most widely used web-based git repository, is also on both charts, moving from 1 to 10. Bitbucket (now owned by Atlassian) was a hosted git repository I used to use and is still on the chart, moving from 11 to 36. Subversion, a source control system I started my career with, has vanished off the chart in 2025. Not really a surprise due to the popularity of git now.</p> <h2 id="cloud-platforms">Cloud Platforms<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#cloud-platforms"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p>In 2016 we had a whole column of Cloud Platforms, including Rackspace and OpenShift, in 2025 this has been reduced to the big three (Azure, AWS and GCP) plus OpenShift.</p> <h2 id="containerization">Containerization<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#containerization"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p>In 2016 we had a column of tools like Docker, Docker Swarm and Kubernetes. In 2025 there are far more tools in this space, with the addition of tools like Helm and the various ways you can host containers on cloud platforms (like Azure AKS).</p> <h2 id="build-and-deploy-tools">Build and Deploy tools<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#build-and-deploy-tools"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p>In 2016 Azure DevOps was still called Team Foundation Server, so this has spread out into the various ways you can use Azure DevOps, such as Pipelines and Code. Also since 2016 GitHub Actions has appeared on the market.</p> <p>In 2016 I was also dabbling with TeamCity, this is no longer used that much so isn&rsquo;t on the chart in 2025. Jenkins is still around on both charts.</p> <h2 id="comms-tools">Comms Tools<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#comms-tools"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p>In 2025 Slack and MS Teams are the go-to tools for communicating with distributed teams, Slack was around in 2016, but Teams wasn&rsquo;t a thing back then.</p> <h2 id="new-tools">New Tools<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#new-tools"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p>New tools for monitoring like Grafana have appeared; back in 2016 I was exclusively using Application Insights from Azure.</p> <h2 id="conclusion--key-takeaways">Conclusion & Key Takeaways<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#conclusion--key-takeaways"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p>The DevOps landscape has changed dramatically over the past decade. Some tools have stood the test of time, while others have faded or emerged to meet new challenges. Here are the key takeaways:</p> <ul> <li><strong>Git remains the backbone of source control</strong>, with platforms like GitHub and Bitbucket continuing to thrive.</li> <li><strong>Cloud platforms (Azure, AWS, GCP) have become central</strong>, reflecting the shift to cloud-native development and operations.</li> <li><strong>Containerization and orchestration (Docker, Kubernetes, Helm) are now essential</strong>, enabling scalable, flexible deployments.</li> <li><strong>Monitoring and collaboration tools have evolved</strong>, with newcomers like Grafana and MS Teams joining established solutions.</li> <li><strong>Legacy tools are disappearing</strong>, showing the importance of adaptability in tech.</li> </ul> <p>As DevOps continues to evolve, staying curious and open to new tools is key. The periodic table analogy reminds us that the right mix of technologies can empower teams to build, deploy, and manage software more effectively. What tools will shape the next decade? Only time will tell.</p>

              - generic [ref=e425]: <description>
              - text: "<h2 id=\"the-mandelbrot-set-beauty-chaos-and-mathematical-art\">The Mandelbrot Set: Beauty, Chaos, and Mathematical Art<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#the-mandelbrot-set-beauty-chaos-and-mathematical-art\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"The Mandelbrot set\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/mandelbrot.png\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"800\" height=\"600\" /> </p> <p>The Mandelbrot set is one of the most iconic images in mathematics‚Äîa mesmerizing swirl of fractal patterns, infinite complexity, and unexpected beauty. But what exactly is the Mandelbrot set, and why has it captured the imagination of mathematicians, artists, and curious minds alike?</p> <h2 id=\"what-is-the-mandelbrot-set\">What Is the Mandelbrot Set?<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#what-is-the-mandelbrot-set\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>At its core, the Mandelbrot set is a collection of complex numbers. It‚Äôs defined by a simple equation, but the results are anything but simple. The definition is:</p> <blockquote> <p>A complex number <strong>c</strong> is in the Mandelbrot set if, when you start with <strong>z = 0</strong> and repeatedly apply the function <code>z = z¬≤ + c</code>, the value of <strong>z</strong> remains bounded (does not go to infinity), no matter how many times you iterate.</p> </blockquote> <p>In other words, for each point <strong>c</strong> on the complex plane, you check: if you keep plugging it into this formula, does it stay small, or does it spiral out of control? If it stays small forever, it&rsquo;s in the Mandelbrot set.</p> <h2 id=\"from-simple-formula-to-stunning-images\">From Simple Formula to Stunning Images<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#from-simple-formula-to-stunning-images\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>The real magic happens when you visualize the Mandelbrot set on a computer. Each point in the complex plane is coloured based on whether it belongs to the set or how quickly it escapes to infinity. The result is a black, bulbous shape surrounded by intricate, infinitely detailed patterns that resemble swirling galaxies, seahorses, or lightning bolts‚Äîthe Mandelbrot set and its &ldquo;fractal boundary.&rdquo;</p> <p>Zooming in on the edge reveals ever more complexity, with shapes that are reminiscent of the original set at different scales. This property, a form of self-similarity, is a hallmark of fractals.</p> <h2 id=\"why-is-the-mandelbrot-set-important\">Why Is the Mandelbrot Set Important?<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#why-is-the-mandelbrot-set-important\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>The Mandelbrot set is more than just a pretty picture. It‚Äôs a window into the world of <strong>complex dynamics</strong> and <strong>chaos theory</strong>. The set‚Äôs boundary is infinitely complex, showing how simple mathematical rules can generate unexpected and beautiful complexity.</p> <p>It also has deep implications in mathematics:</p> <ul> <li><strong>Fractals:</strong> The Mandelbrot set is the most famous example of a fractal‚Äîa shape that shows similar, though not identical, patterns at every scale.</li> <li><strong>Chaos Theory:</strong> It illustrates sensitive dependence on initial conditions, where tiny changes can lead to drastically different outcomes.</li> <li><strong>Complex Numbers:</strong> It brings to life the beauty of complex numbers, which are usually abstract concepts in math classes.</li> </ul> <h2 id=\"the-mandelbrot-set-in-art-and-culture\">The Mandelbrot Set in Art and Culture<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#the-mandelbrot-set-in-art-and-culture\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>Thanks to its stunning visuals, the Mandelbrot set has become a cultural icon. It‚Äôs inspired digital art, music, and even jewellery. It also serves as a symbol for how complexity and order can emerge from simple rules, a concept that resonates in fields from biology to computer science.</p> <h2 id=\"try-it-yourself\">Try It Yourself<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#try-it-yourself\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>Many websites and software tools let you explore the Mandelbrot set interactively. Try zooming in and discover new shapes and patterns emerging at every level. It‚Äôs a fantastic way to experience the intersection of math, art, and chaos.</p> <h2 id=\"final-thoughts\">Final Thoughts<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#final-thoughts\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>I have been fascinated by fractals since I was young. I remember seeing them generated on a <a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2021/back-to-basic/\">Lynx computer</a> and the process was slow, one pixel at a time, after a few hours you would see a complete Mandelbrot set. More recently I have looked at generating them in the browser (using .NET&rsquo;s Blazor WebAssembly technology), and the image at the start of this post took only a few seconds to generate.</p> <p>I&rsquo;ve also created an <a href=\"https://mandelbrot.funkysi1701.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">interactive Mandelbrot set generator</a> . It&rsquo;s a work in progress, but you can already generate a set and zoom in using the buttons at the top or by clicking with your mouse. I plan to add more features in the coming weeks.</p> <p>The Mandelbrot set reminds us that even the simplest equations can produce infinite complexity and beauty. It stands as an enduring inspiration‚Äîproof that mathematics is not just about numbers, but about wonder, creativity, and the endless possibilities hidden within the fabric of reality.</p>"

              - generic [ref=e490]: <description>
              - text: "<h2 id=\"the-hacker-ethic-principles-that-shaped-the-digital-age\">The Hacker Ethic: Principles That Shaped the Digital Age<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#the-hacker-ethic-principles-that-shaped-the-digital-age\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>When most people hear the word ‚Äúhacker,‚Äù they imagine shadowy figures breaking into computer systems. But the original meaning of ‚Äúhacker‚Äù is far richer, rooted in curiosity, creativity, and a set of values that have profoundly shaped technology and culture. This philosophy, known as the <strong>hacker ethic</strong>, remains a powerful force driving innovation and openness in our digital world.</p> <h2 id=\"what-is-the-hacker-ethic\">What Is the Hacker Ethic?<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#what-is-the-hacker-ethic\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>The term ‚Äúhacker ethic‚Äù was popularized by Steven Levy in his book <em>Hackers: Heroes of the Computer Revolution</em> (I have just finished listening to the audio version and highly recommend it). The book describes a set of beliefs and practices developed by early computer enthusiasts at places like MIT, Stanford, and the Homebrew Computer Club. Far from criminality, the hacker ethic is about playful exploration, sharing knowledge, and questioning limits.</p> <img src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/images/hacker.jpg\" alt=\"Hackers: Heroes of the Computer Revolution\" width=\"300\" height=\"400\" class=\"img-fluid float-end ms-2\" /> <h2 id=\"the-core-principles\">The Core Principles<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#the-core-principles\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>The hacker ethic can be distilled into several key tenets:</p> <h3 id=\"1-access-to-computers-should-be-unlimited-and-total\">1. Access to Computers Should Be Unlimited and Total<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#1-access-to-computers-should-be-unlimited-and-total\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>Hackers believe that information and tools for learning should be open to all. They value environments where curiosity is encouraged and barriers to entry are low. This spirit led to the creation of open-source software, free educational resources, and collaborative online communities.</p> <h3 id=\"2-all-information-wants-to-be-free\">2. All Information Wants to Be Free<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#2-all-information-wants-to-be-free\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>While not advocating for stealing proprietary data, hackers champion the free flow of information. They believe that sharing code, knowledge, and discoveries accelerates progress and empowers individuals. This principle underlies movements like open data, Creative Commons, and Wikipedia.</p> <h3 id=\"3-mistrust-authoritypromote-decentralization\">3. Mistrust Authority‚ÄîPromote Decentralization<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#3-mistrust-authoritypromote-decentralization\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>Hackers are skeptical of gatekeepers and centralized control. They prefer systems that empower individuals and distribute power. This mindset has influenced everything from peer-to-peer networks to blockchain technology.</p> <h3 id=\"4-hackers-should-be-judged-by-their-hacking-not-bogus-criteria\">4. Hackers Should Be Judged by Their Hacking, Not Bogus Criteria<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#4-hackers-should-be-judged-by-their-hacking-not-bogus-criteria\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>Hackers value skill, creativity, and contribution over credentials or status. In hacker culture, what matters is what you build, solve, or improve‚Äînot your job title, age, or background. This meritocratic ideal helped shape the egalitarian ethos of the internet.</p> <h3 id=\"5-you-can-create-art-and-beauty-on-a-computer\">5. You Can Create Art and Beauty on a Computer<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#5-you-can-create-art-and-beauty-on-a-computer\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>Hackers see computers not only as tools, but as canvases for creativity. From elegant code to digital art, they celebrate the artistry inherent in technology and design.</p> <h3 id=\"6-computers-can-change-your-life-for-the-better\">6. Computers Can Change Your Life for the Better<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#6-computers-can-change-your-life-for-the-better\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>Hackers believe in the transformative potential of technology. They see computers as instruments of empowerment, education, and community‚Äîtools that can solve meaningful problems and improve lives.</p> <h2 id=\"why-the-hacker-ethic-matters-today\">Why the Hacker Ethic Matters Today<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#why-the-hacker-ethic-matters-today\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>The hacker ethic is alive in open-source communities, maker spaces, and digital activism. It challenges us to question closed systems, embrace sharing, and use technology for good. In a world increasingly shaped by algorithms and artificial intelligence, the hacker ethic reminds us that human creativity, curiosity, and collaboration are still at the heart of progress.</p> <p>After listening to the book, it&rsquo;s clear that many of today&rsquo;s security problems stem from this ethic. Early computers and software were built by design without security in mind. The hackers featured in the book strongly disliked passwords and locks; they believed information and systems should be open to all. I had incorrectly assumed this was merely an oversight, or that security wasn&rsquo;t considered necessary at the time.</p> <p>The growth of open source software can clearly be seen as an extension to the sharing of code started by these early hackers, instead of looking in a drawer for paper tape containing the code you want to improve, we go to GitHub, but the principle is the same.</p> <h2 id=\"final-thoughts\">Final Thoughts<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#final-thoughts\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>The hacker ethic is far more than a technical mindset‚Äîit‚Äôs a philosophy of openness, empowerment, and playful problem-solving. By understanding and embracing these principles, we can build a digital future that is more inclusive, innovative, and free.</p> <p>The more I think about my career with computers, the more I identify as a hacker rather than a programmer or any other job title. I started hacking together simple web pages, I then hacked away at networks and Active Directory, now I hack at .NET and Kubernetes.</p> <p>Sponsored Link: <a href=\"https://amzn.to/49NwGHF\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Hackers: Heroes of the Computer Revolution (book)</a> </p>"

            - generic [ref=e511]:

                - text: ">"
              - text: Helm
