                - text: ">"
              - text: Cloudflare
              - generic [ref=e537]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e538]:
              - generic [ref=e539]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e540]: term="DevOps"
                - text: ">"
              - text: DevOps
              - generic [ref=e541]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e542]:
              - generic [ref=e543]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e544]: term="Security"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Security
              - generic [ref=e545]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e546]:
              - generic [ref=e547]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e548]: term="Automation"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Automation
              - generic [ref=e549]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e550]:
              - generic [ref=e551]: <description>
              - text: "<p>I have blogged before about how cool <a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2018/lets-encrypt-is-awesome/\">Let&rsquo;s Encrypt</a> is for getting your web things running under https. However I have just got myself a local kubernetes cluster and it is super easy to spin up new web services with SSL certs.</p> <p>The basic instructions can be found <a href=\"https://www.slingacademy.com/article/how-to-set-up-ssl-with-lets-encrypt-in-kubernetes/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">here</a> but let&rsquo;s look at what was involved.</p> <p>First of all lets get Cert Manager installed on kubernetes.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>kubectl apply -f https://github.com/cert-manager/cert-manager/releases/download/v1.18.1/cert-manager.yaml </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Once the cert manager pods are up, you need to create an issuer which communicates with the lets encrypt API. The first code snippet uses the lets encrypt staging environment to avoid any API limits, the second uses production and uses the cloudflare API to authorize SSL requests.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-yaml\" data-lang=\"yaml\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#f92672\">apiVersion</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">cert-manager.io/v1</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#f92672\">kind</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">ClusterIssuer</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#f92672\">metadata</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">name</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">letsencrypt-staging</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#f92672\">spec</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">acme</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">server</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">https://acme-staging-v02.api.letsencrypt.org/directory</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">email</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">your-email@example.com</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">privateKeySecretRef</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">name</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">letsencrypt-staging</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">solvers</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> - <span style=\"color:#f92672\">http01</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">ingress</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">ingressClassName</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">nginx</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-yaml\" data-lang=\"yaml\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#f92672\">apiVersion</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">cert-manager.io/v1</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#f92672\">kind</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">ClusterIssuer</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#f92672\">metadata</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">name</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">letsencrypt-prod</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#f92672\">spec</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">acme</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">server</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">https://acme-v02.api.letsencrypt.org/directory</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">email</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">your-email@example.com</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">privateKeySecretRef</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">name</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">letsencrypt-prod</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">solvers</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> - <span style=\"color:#f92672\">dns01</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">cloudflare</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">apiTokenSecretRef</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">key</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">api-key</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">name</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">cloudflare-api-token-secret</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">email</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">your-email@example.com</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now that is all configured all I need to do is update my helm chart and any pod I like can have a sub domain of funkysi1701.com with a lets encrypt SSL cert.</p> <p>This is a section from my helm chart which defines the domain name to use and what issuer to use for the certificate.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-yaml\" data-lang=\"yaml\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#f92672\">ingress</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">enabled</span>: <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">true</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">className</span>: <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;nginx&#34;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">annotations</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">cert-manager.io/cluster-issuer</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">letsencrypt-prod</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">devHost</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">helloworld-dev.funkysi1701.com</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">testHost</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">helloworld-test.funkysi1701.com</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">tls</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> - <span style=\"color:#f92672\">secretName</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">helloworld-dev.funkysi1701.com</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">hosts</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> - <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">helloworld-dev.funkysi1701.com</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> - <span style=\"color:#f92672\">secretName</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">helloworld-test.funkysi1701.com</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">hosts</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> - <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">helloworld-test.funkysi1701.com</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>All I need to do now is add similar code like this to every helm chart I publish and my pod will request a SSL certificate. The only manual step I have is to set up a DNS record pointing to the IP address of my cluster for any domain I want to use.</p> <h2 id=\"conclusion\">Conclusion<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#conclusion\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>Setting up Let&rsquo;s Encrypt with Kubernetes and Cert Manager has made it incredibly easy to secure my web services with SSL certificates. With just a few YAML configurations and some simple Helm chart updates, I can automatically provision and renew certificates for any subdomain I need. This approach not only saves time but also ensures my services are always protected with up-to-date encryption. If you&rsquo;re running Kubernetes, I highly recommend giving Cert Manager and Let&rsquo;s Encrypt a try for hassle-free SSL management.</p>"
              - generic [ref=e552]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e554]: </item>

              - generic [ref=e608]: <description>
              - text: "<p>Stepping outside my comfort zone doesn‚Äôt come naturally to me. I‚Äôm happiest behind my laptop, but every now and then, I know it‚Äôs important to try something new. This year, my family and I decided to do just that‚Äîand it turned out to be one of our most memorable weeks ever. Curious about what happens when you swap routine for adventure? Read on!</p> <h2 id=\"introduction\">Introduction<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#introduction\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>This week was our family holiday. Normally, we‚Äôd book a cottage somewhere nice and explore at our own pace. But this often leads to disagreements‚Äîeveryone wants something different, and sometimes the places we visit aren‚Äôt as exciting as we hoped (especially for two kids aged 7 and 9 who get bored easily).</p> <p>This time, we chose a different path: a family adventure holiday with <a href=\"https://www.highadventureholidays.co.uk/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">High Adventure</a> . The itinerary was packed: climbing, caving, hiking, water sports, archery, zip wires, and countless other activities. All meals, accommodation, equipment, and expert instructors were included, making it feel both safe and exciting.</p> <p>I‚Äôll admit, I was anxious before we set off. I‚Äôm not an adventurous person‚ÄîI like <a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2024/charity-hike\">walking</a> , but I‚Äôd never tried anything like this. My nine-year-old son was dreading it, while my more adventurous seven-year-old was quietly excited. I worried that if the kids hated it, it would be a waste of money. But as soon as we arrived, those fears melted away.</p> <h2 id=\"saturday\">Saturday<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#saturday\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>We arrived on Saturday afternoon and were shown to our room. My only real complaint from the whole week: the room was tiny. With two bunk beds and four of us plus a week‚Äôs worth of clothes, it was a challenge to keep things tidy. Thankfully, the rest of the facility was spacious, and our room was right next to the games room‚Äîa bonus.</p> <p>Dinner was served at 6pm every evening, always a home-cooked meal. While I enjoyed the food, my fussy eaters weren‚Äôt always convinced, but there was usually something for everyone. We met the other family we‚Äôd be doing activities with.</p> <p>After dinner, we explored the Games Room and took on the Labyrinth‚Äîa tight, dark maze constructed under the floor. Helmets were required! I found it a bit tight, but my boys absolutely loved it.</p> <h2 id=\"sunday\">Sunday<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#sunday\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <img src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/images/abseiling.jpg\" alt=\"Abseiling\" width=\"250px\" style=\"padding-right: 15px; \" align=\"left\"/> <p>Every day began with a cooked breakfast and a make-your-own sandwich station for lunch. Sunday morning kicked off with climbing and abseiling. I‚Äôd never climbed before, so I was surprised‚Äîand proud‚Äîto make it all the way to the top of the 8-meter wall. My boys didn‚Äôt quite reach the top, but they pushed themselves higher than I expected. Abseiling was fun too, and a great way to come down after the climb.</p> <p>After lunch, we tried archery. I‚Äôd done it once before at my boys‚Äô Scout group, but it took a while to hit the target consistently. Then came bushcraft: foraging for wood, using a knife to make kindling, and lighting a fire with a ferrocerium rod. My nine-year-old and I managed to get a fire going‚Äîdefinitely a memorable moment, especially when we roasted marshmallows.</p> <p>The evening‚Äôs activity was Nightline: a blindfolded obstacle course. This was a bit much for me, but the boys loved it. My job was to guide them through the course, describing what to climb over, under, or through, and when to stop.</p> <h2 id=\"monday\">Monday<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#monday\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>Monday started with a walk up the hill to Wainman‚Äôs Pinnacle and some ‚Äúweaseling‚Äù through the rocks‚Äîa favourite for the boys, especially since they‚Äôd done it before with Scouts. I skipped most of the weaseling but enjoyed the walk.</p> <p>In the afternoon, it was time for high ropes and a zip wire. We were safely roped in at all times, but stepping off a high ledge still required a leap of faith. My eldest was nervous and had to climb down at first, but after watching me try, he gave it another go‚Äîand loved it. That‚Äôs what this week was about: encouraging all of us to try new things.</p> <p>The evening activity was Eggbert: designing a contraption to protect an egg dropped from a height. We worked as a family, but failed to consider that the weight would flip the egg so it landed the wrong way up. Oops! We didn‚Äôt win, but it was great fun seeing everyone‚Äôs creative designs.</p> <h2 id=\"tuesday\">Tuesday<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#tuesday\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <img src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/images/caves.jpg\" alt=\"Caving\" width=\"250px\" style=\"padding-left: 15px; \" align=\"right\" /> <p>Tuesday was our first full day offsite. The instructors drove us in a minibus to the Yorkshire Three Peaks area, where we explored underground caves. Wearing cave suits, wellies, and helmets, we were ready for adventure. I foolishly thought I wouldn‚Äôt need a change of clothes‚Äîturns out, crawling through water-filled tunnels means your wellies fill up fast! I wasn‚Äôt the biggest fan of being soaked, but the boys loved climbing and sliding through the narrow passages. We finished the day with ice cream and hot chocolate in Settle‚Äîa well-deserved treat.</p> <p>That evening, we tried circus skills and gathered around a campfire. The boys were entertained for ages, trying juggling and balance activities. I didn‚Äôt master anything, but I enjoyed relaxing by the fire with my wife and the other parents.</p> <h2 id=\"wednesday\">Wednesday<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#wednesday\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>By Wednesday, tiredness was catching up with me! We tackled a five-mile walk around Malham Cove, taking in stunning views and great weather. The route included Gordale Scar and Janet‚Äôs Foss, a lovely waterfall where many people swam or paddled. We hadn‚Äôt brought towels, but that didn‚Äôt stop my boys from getting soaked. It‚Äôs a holiday‚Äîwhy not?</p> <p>Wednesday evening was supposed to be a parents‚Äô night off, but we had to cut it short due to a family emergency.</p> <h2 id=\"thursday\">Thursday<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#thursday\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>Thursday was water sports day, but we decided on a quieter option and visited Haworth instead. The town is famous for the Bront√´ sisters, and we enjoyed its picturesque streets, a museum, and a play area for the kids‚Äîa great way to wind down after so much activity.</p> <p>The final evening was a quiz night, complete with questions about the week‚Äôs adventures.</p> <h2 id=\"friday\">Friday<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#friday\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>Friday was going-home day, but not before one last challenge: orienteering. As a former university orienteering club member, I couldn‚Äôt resist joining in!</p> <h2 id=\"conclusion\">Conclusion<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#conclusion\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>This week was truly about stepping outside my comfort zone and embracing new experiences. From climbing and caving to bushcraft and zip lines, every activity challenged me and helped me grow. I discovered that pushing your boundaries can be both exciting and rewarding‚Äîand creates memories that last a lifetime. If you ever get the chance to try something new, even if it feels a bit daunting, I highly recommend taking the leap. You might just surprise yourself!</p>"
              - generic [ref=e609]: </description>

              - text: Deploying My Blog to Kubernetes with Helm Charts
              - generic [ref=e619]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e620]:
              - generic [ref=e621]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2025/deploying-hugo-with-helm/
              - generic [ref=e622]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e623]:
              - generic [ref=e624]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e625]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e626]:
              - generic [ref=e627]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 26 May 2025 20:00:00 +0000
              - generic [ref=e628]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e629]:
              - generic [ref=e630]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2025/deploying-hugo-with-helm/
              - generic [ref=e631]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e632]:

                - generic [ref=e634]: term="Kubernetes"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Kubernetes
              - generic [ref=e635]: </category>

                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e638]: term="Helm"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Helm
              - generic [ref=e639]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e640]:
              - generic [ref=e641]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e642]: term="DevOps"
                - text: ">"
              - text: DevOps
              - generic [ref=e643]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e644]:
              - generic [ref=e645]:
                - text: <category

                - text: ">"
              - text: Hugo
              - generic [ref=e647]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e648]:
              - generic [ref=e649]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e650]: term="Blog"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Blog
              - generic [ref=e651]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e652]:
              - generic [ref=e653]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e654]: term="Deployment"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Deployment
              - generic [ref=e655]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e656]:
              - generic [ref=e657]: <description>
              - text: "<p>Helm allows you to package your Kubernetes resources, manage configuration, and deploy updates with a single command.</p> <p>In this post, I‚Äôll share how I used Helm to deploy my Hugo blog, making it easy to manage updates and spin up new environments. Full disclosure: My blog currently runs on an Azure Static Web App, but now that I know how to deploy to a Kubernetes cluster, I have the option to switch if needed.</p> <h2 id=\"why-use-helm\">Why Use Helm?<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#why-use-helm\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>Helm is the package manager for Kubernetes. It lets you:</p> <ul> <li><strong>Template</strong> your Kubernetes YAML files for reuse and configuration.</li> <li><strong>Version</strong> your deployments for easy rollbacks.</li> <li><strong>Share</strong> your charts with others or use community charts.</li> </ul> <h2 id=\"creating-a-helm-chart-for-hugo\">Creating a Helm Chart for Hugo<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#creating-a-helm-chart-for-hugo\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>First, I scaffolded a new Helm chart:</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-sh\" data-lang=\"sh\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>helm create hugo-blog </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This creates a directory structure with templates for deployments, services, and ingress.</p> <h3 id=\"customizing-the-chart\">Customizing the Chart<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#customizing-the-chart\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>I edited <code>values.yaml</code> to set my image and service details:</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-yaml\" data-lang=\"yaml\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#f92672\">image</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">repository</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">mydockerhubusername/hugo-blog</span> <span style=\"color:#75715e\"># Docker image repository</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">tag</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">latest</span> <span style=\"color:#75715e\"># Use the latest tag for the image</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">pullPolicy</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">IfNotPresent</span> <span style=\"color:#75715e\"># Pull the image only if it‚Äôs not already present</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#f92672\">service</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">type</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">NodePort</span> <span style=\"color:#75715e\"># Expose the service on a specific port</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">port</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">80</span> <span style=\"color:#75715e\"># Internal port for the service</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">nodePort</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">30081</span> <span style=\"color:#75715e\"># External port for accessing the service</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><h3 id=\"deploying-the-blog\">Deploying the Blog<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#deploying-the-blog\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>To deploy the blog, I ran:</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-sh\" data-lang=\"sh\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>helm install my-hugo-blog ./hugo-blog </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Helm rendered the templates and created the necessary Kubernetes resources.</p> <h3 id=\"updating-the-blog\">Updating the Blog<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#updating-the-blog\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>When I rebuild and push a new Docker image, I can upgrade my deployment with:</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-sh\" data-lang=\"sh\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>helm upgrade my-hugo-blog ./hugo-blog </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This triggers a rolling update in Kubernetes.</p> <h3 id=\"creating-a-docker-image-of-my-blog\">Creating a Docker Image of my Blog<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#creating-a-docker-image-of-my-blog\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>This all assumes that I have a container image of my Hugo blog. Creating this was half the work.</p> <p>I had been using a docker-compose file to build my blog; however, this doesn&rsquo;t copy my files into the container it creates a volume to share my files with the container. I needed a Dockerfile that would copy my source code into a container and then save it into a container registry.</p> <p>This is the Dockerfile I created. As you can see, it is a two-stage build. First, it takes the Hugo base image, copies my files into it, and builds Hugo. Then the NGINX web server is run, and the default web port 80 is exposed.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-Dockerfile\" data-lang=\"Dockerfile\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\"># Step 1: Build the Hugo site</span><span style=\"color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010\"> </span></span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">FROM</span> <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">floryn90/hugo:0.119.0</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">AS</span> <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">builder</span><span style=\"color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010\"> </span></span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010\"> </span></span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\"># Set working directory inside the container</span><span style=\"color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010\"> </span></span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">WORKDIR</span> <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">/src</span><span style=\"color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010\"> </span></span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010\"> </span></span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\"># Copy site files to the container</span><span style=\"color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010\"> </span></span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">COPY</span> . .<span style=\"color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010\"> </span></span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010\"> </span></span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\"># Build the Hugo site</span><span style=\"color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010\"> </span></span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">RUN</span> hugo --minify --config config.toml<span style=\"color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010\"> </span></span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010\"> </span></span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\"># Step 2: Serve with nginx</span><span style=\"color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010\"> </span></span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">FROM</span> <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">nginx:alpine</span><span style=\"color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010\"> </span></span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010\"> </span></span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\"># Remove the default nginx static files</span><span style=\"color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010\"> </span></span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">RUN</span> rm -rf /usr/share/nginx/html/*<span style=\"color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010\"> </span></span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010\"> </span></span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\"># Copy the generated site from the builder stage</span><span style=\"color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010\"> </span></span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">COPY</span> --from<span style=\"color:#f92672\">=</span>builder /src/public /usr/share/nginx/html<span style=\"color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010\"> </span></span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010\"> </span></span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\"># Expose port 80</span><span style=\"color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010\"> </span></span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">EXPOSE</span> <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">80</span><span style=\"color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010\"> </span></span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010\"> </span></span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\"># Start nginx</span><span style=\"color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010\"> </span></span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">CMD</span> [<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;nginx&#34;</span>, <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;-g&#34;</span>, <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;daemon off;&#34;</span>]<span style=\"color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010\"> </span></span></span></code></pre></div><h2 id=\"benefits\">Benefits<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#benefits\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <ul> <li><strong>Repeatable Deployments:</strong> Easily spin up new environments.</li> <li><strong>Configuration Management:</strong> Override values for different clusters or environments.</li> <li><strong>Easy Updates:</strong> Upgrade with a single command.</li> </ul> <h2 id=\"conclusion\">Conclusion<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#conclusion\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>Helm charts have made deploying my Hugo blog to Kubernetes a seamless and efficient process. With features like templating, versioning, and easy updates, Helm is a must-have tool for Kubernetes deployments.</p> <p>If you‚Äôre managing static sites or microservices, give Helm a try and see how it can simplify your workflow!</p> <p>Have you used Helm for static sites or blogs? Share your experience in the comments below!</p>"
              - generic [ref=e658]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e660]: </item>

            - generic [ref=e697]:
              - generic [ref=e698]:

            - generic [ref=e705]:
              - generic [ref=e706]: <description>
              - text: "<p>I know nothing (or very little) about Kubernetes. It is high time I do something to learn more about it. Kubernetes is a powerful tool for managing containerized applications, and it&rsquo;s becoming a must-have skill for developers and DevOps engineers. In this blog, I&rsquo;ll share my journey as a beginner exploring Kubernetes, from running a simple Grafana pod to understanding the basics of <code>kubectl</code>. Let&rsquo;s dive in!</p> <h2 id=\"what-is-kubernetes\">What is Kubernetes?<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#what-is-kubernetes\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>Kubernetes is an open-source container orchestration platform that automates the deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications. If you want to run your containerized applications, you probably want to learn Kubernetes.</p> <p>I have worked at least two companies so far in my career that have made use of Kubernetes to run their microservice architecture. Let&rsquo;s take a look at how to use it.</p> <h3 id=\"why-learn-kubernetes\">Why Learn Kubernetes?<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#why-learn-kubernetes\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>Kubernetes is widely used in modern software development for:</p> <ul> <li><strong>Microservices</strong>: Manage and scale multiple services independently.</li> <li><strong>CI/CD Pipelines</strong>: Automate deployments and rollbacks.</li> <li><strong>Scalability</strong>: Handle traffic spikes by scaling pods up or down.</li> </ul> <h2 id=\"docker-desktop\">Docker Desktop<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#docker-desktop\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p><a href=\"https://www.docker.com/products/docker-desktop/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Docker Desktop</a> is a tool for running containers, but it also allows running of Kubernetes.</p> <p>I am not going to talk through installing docker desktop and getting a Kubernetes cluster set up, for that check out the <a href=\"https://docs.docker.com/desktop/features/kubernetes/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">documentation</a> however I found it very straightforward.</p> <h2 id=\"kubectl\">kubectl<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#kubectl\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>kubectl is the command line tool for doing everything with Kubernetes.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-powershell\" data-lang=\"powershell\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>kubectl version </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This prints out basic version information, if this works you know Kubernetes must be working.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-powershell\" data-lang=\"powershell\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>kubectl config get-contexts </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>kubectl config use-context docker-desktop </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This command allows you to switch contexts, to use with docker desktop you want to use the docker-desktop context. At work we have dev and test contexts that can be selected in a similar way.</p> <ul> <li><strong>Context</strong>: A Kubernetes context is a set of access parameters for a cluster. It allows you to switch between different clusters or environments (e.g., dev, test, production).</li> </ul> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-powershell\" data-lang=\"powershell\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>kubectl get all </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This gives you a list of everything that is running in the default namespace, pods, services, deployments etc For a complete list, you can add the &ndash;all-namespaces flag.</p> <ul> <li><strong>Namespace</strong>: A namespace is a way to organize resources in a Kubernetes cluster, providing isolation between different projects or teams.</li> </ul> <h2 id=\"hello-world\">Hello World<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#hello-world\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>Now what is the equivalent of &ldquo;Hello World&rdquo; for Kubernetes? I think getting a container to run in Kubernetes is a pretty good test.</p> <p>Open up VS Code and create a yaml file called grafana.yaml</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-yaml\" data-lang=\"yaml\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#f92672\">apiVersion</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">v1</span> <span style=\"color:#75715e\"># Specifies the API version for the resource</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#f92672\">kind</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">Pod</span> <span style=\"color:#75715e\"># Defines the resource type as a Pod</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#f92672\">metadata</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">name</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">grafana</span> <span style=\"color:#75715e\"># The name of the pod</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#f92672\">spec</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">containers</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> - <span style=\"color:#f92672\">name</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">grafana</span> <span style=\"color:#75715e\"># The name of the container</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">image</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">grafana/grafana:12.0.0</span> <span style=\"color:#75715e\"># The container image to use</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">ports</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> - <span style=\"color:#f92672\">containerPort</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">3000</span> <span style=\"color:#75715e\"># The port exposed by the container</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This file uses the Grafana container image, which I am familiar with (see <a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2025/setting-up-grafana/\">my previous blog posts</a> ) It&rsquo;s default port is 3000 which you can see is defined in this file.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-powershell\" data-lang=\"powershell\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>kubectl apply <span style=\"color:#f92672\">-f</span> grafana.yaml </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This deploys a pod, using the above yaml file.</p> <p>You can run the following to find out more about the pod.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-powershell\" data-lang=\"powershell\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>kubectl describe pod grafana </span></span></code></pre></div><p>From what I have discovered so far, Kubernetes runs in its own network. So going to localhost:3000 won&rsquo;t work. But you can use port forward to get round this issue.</p> <ul> <li><strong>Port-Forwarding</strong>: This allows you to access a pod&rsquo;s service on your local machine by forwarding a port from the pod to your localhost.</li> </ul> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-powershell\" data-lang=\"powershell\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>kubectl port-forward pod/grafana <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">3000</span><span style=\"color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010\">:</span><span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">3000</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now if I try http://localhost:3000/login I see the login page for the Grafana container. A pretty good first test of using Kubernetes.</p> <h2 id=\"whats-next\">Whats next?<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#whats-next\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>I want to replace my local deployment of containers that is currently using a docker compose file with Kubernetes. I also want to learn more about <a href=\"https://helm.sh/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Helm charts</a> as I believe these are an excellent way of packaging up changes to Kubernetes.</p> <p>Have you tried running a pod in Kubernetes? What challenges did you face, and how did you overcome them? Share your thoughts in the comments below!</p>"
              - generic [ref=e707]: </description>

              - generic [ref=e723]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e724]:

              - generic [ref=e726]: </pubDate>

              - generic [ref=e755]: <description>
              - text: "<h2 id=\"what-is-opentelemetry\">What is OpenTelemetry?<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#what-is-opentelemetry\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>OpenTelemetry is an open-source observability framework that provides a unified way to collect, process, and export telemetry data such as <strong>traces</strong>, <strong>metrics</strong>, and <strong>logs</strong>. It is designed to help developers monitor and debug distributed systems by providing insights into application performance and behavior.</p> <p>With OpenTelemetry, you can instrument your applications to gain visibility into how requests flow through your system, identify bottlenecks, and troubleshoot issues effectively.</p> <h2 id=\"why-use-opentelemetry\">Why Use OpenTelemetry?<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#why-use-opentelemetry\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>Here are some key benefits of using OpenTelemetry:</p> <ol> <li><strong>Unified Observability</strong>: Collect traces, metrics, and logs using a single framework.</li> <li><strong>Vendor-Neutral</strong>: Export telemetry data to any backend, such as Azure Monitor, Grafana, or Prometheus.</li> <li><strong>Standardized APIs</strong>: Use consistent APIs and SDKs across multiple programming languages.</li> <li><strong>Extensibility</strong>: Easily extend OpenTelemetry to meet your specific observability needs.</li> <li><strong>Community-Driven</strong>: Backed by a large and active open-source community.</li> </ol> <h2 id=\"key-components-of-opentelemetry\">Key Components of OpenTelemetry<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#key-components-of-opentelemetry\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>OpenTelemetry consists of the following core components:</p> <ol> <li><strong>Traces</strong>: Capture the lifecycle of a request as it flows through your system. Traces help you understand dependencies and latency.</li> <li><strong>Metrics</strong>: Collect numerical data, such as request counts, CPU usage, and memory consumption, to monitor system health.</li> <li><strong>Logs</strong>: Record discrete events, such as errors or state changes, to provide additional context for debugging.</li> </ol> <h2 id=\"setting-up-opentelemetry-in-net\">Setting Up OpenTelemetry in .NET<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#setting-up-opentelemetry-in-net\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>Here‚Äôs how you can get started with OpenTelemetry in a .NET application:</p> <h3 id=\"step-1-install-the-required-nuget-packages\">Step 1: Install the Required NuGet Packages<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#step-1-install-the-required-nuget-packages\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>Run the following commands to install the OpenTelemetry libraries:</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>dotnet add package OpenTelemetry </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>dotnet add package OpenTelemetry.Extensions.Hosting </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>dotnet add package OpenTelemetry.Exporter.Console </span></span></code></pre></div><h3 id=\"step-2-configure-opentelemetry-in-your-application\">Step 2: Configure OpenTelemetry in Your Application<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#step-2-configure-opentelemetry-in-your-application\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>Add the following code to your Program.cs or Startup.cs file:</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">using</span> OpenTelemetry; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">using</span> OpenTelemetry.Trace; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">using</span> OpenTelemetry.Metrics; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> builder = WebApplication.CreateBuilder(args); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\">// Add OpenTelemetry tracing and metrics</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>builder.Services.AddOpenTelemetry() </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> .WithTracing(tracerProviderBuilder =&gt; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> tracerProviderBuilder </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> .AddAspNetCoreInstrumentation() </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> .AddHttpClientInstrumentation() </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> .AddConsoleExporter(); <span style=\"color:#75715e\">// Export traces to the console</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> }) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> .WithMetrics(metricsProviderBuilder =&gt; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> metricsProviderBuilder </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> .AddAspNetCoreInstrumentation() </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> .AddRuntimeInstrumentation() </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> .AddConsoleExporter(); <span style=\"color:#75715e\">// Export metrics to the console</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> }); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> app = builder.Build(); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>app.MapGet(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;/&#34;</span>, () =&gt; <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;Hello, OpenTelemetry!&#34;</span>); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>app.Run(); </span></span></code></pre></div><h3 id=\"step-3-run-your-application\">Step 3: Run Your Application<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#step-3-run-your-application\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>Start your application and observe the telemetry data in the console. You‚Äôll see traces and metrics being logged as requests are processed.</p> <h2 id=\"aspire-and-how-to-view-telemetry\">Aspire and how to view Telemetry<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#aspire-and-how-to-view-telemetry\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>If your .NET code is .Net 8 or higher you can use Aspire which configures OpenTelemetry for free! Check out <a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2024/aspire\">Getting started with .Net Aspire</a> . Once Aspire is setup, you will be able to see Logs, Traces and Metrics in the Aspire Dashboard.</p> <p>Another popular way to view your data is Grafana, where you can create custom dashboards. I have talked about adding <a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2025/opentelemetry-logs/\">Logs</a> to Grafana recently.</p> <p>There are lots of other ways to view your data, like Application Insights, DataDog, Jaeger, New Relic and many more.</p> <p>But you are not tied to one solution, you can send your data to more than one of these if you wish.</p> <h2 id=\"conclusion\">Conclusion<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#conclusion\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>OpenTelemetry simplifies observability by providing a unified framework for collecting traces, metrics, and logs. Whether you&rsquo;re building microservices, monitoring distributed systems, or debugging performance issues, OpenTelemetry is a powerful tool to have in your arsenal.</p> <p>Start using OpenTelemetry today and gain deeper insights into your applications!</p> <p>Have you tried OpenTelemetry? Share your experiences and tips in the comments below!</p>"

          - generic [ref=e758]: </item>

              - generic [ref=e812]: <description>
              - text: "<p>.NET Aspire 9.2 is here, bringing exciting new features to simplify infrastructure visualization. Whether you&rsquo;re managing microservices or exploring Docker-based architectures, this release makes it easier than ever to create detailed infrastructure diagrams with minimal effort. Let‚Äôs dive into the highlights and see how you can use these tools to streamline your workflow.</p> <p>For details of what .NET Aspire is, check out my <a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2024/aspire\">post</a> from last year. For the official announcement see <a href=\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/aspire/whats-new/dotnet-aspire-9.2\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">What&rsquo;s new in .NET Aspire 9.2</a> </p> <p>My favourite feature from this release is the ability to quickly and easily spin up infrastructure diagrams like this:</p> <p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"Aspire Diagram\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/aspire-9.2.jpg\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"764\" height=\"675\" /> </p> <p><em>An example infrastructure diagram created using .NET Aspire 9.2.</em></p> <p>I also created one last week for my blog about <a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2025/opentelemetry-logs/\">Grafana</a> :</p> <p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"Grafana Example\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/grafana-loki-arch.png\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"811\" height=\"593\" /> </p> <h2 id=\"so-what-code-is-needed-to-create-one-of-these-diagrams\">So what code is needed to create one of these diagrams?<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#so-what-code-is-needed-to-create-one-of-these-diagrams\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <ol> <li>Open Visual Studio and create a new project of type &ldquo;.NET Aspire App Host&rdquo;</li> <li>Edit the Program.cs and add docker containers for anything you want to display on the diagram</li> <li>The syntax for this is is shown in my Grafana example:</li> </ol> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> builder = DistributedApplication.CreateBuilder(args); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\">// Add a .NET application container</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> dotnet = builder.AddContainer(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;dotnet-application&#34;</span>, <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;anyimage&#34;</span>) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> .WithHttpEndpoint(port: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">80</span>, targetPort: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">80</span>); <span style=\"color:#75715e\">// Expose HTTP port 80</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\">// Add a Loki container for log aggregation</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> loki = builder.AddContainer(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;loki&#34;</span>, <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;grafana/loki&#34;</span>, <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;3.4.3&#34;</span>) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> .WithHttpEndpoint(port: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">3100</span>, targetPort: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">3100</span>); <span style=\"color:#75715e\">// Expose HTTP port 3100</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\">// Add an Alloy container for telemetry processing</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> alloy = builder.AddContainer(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;alloy&#34;</span>, <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;grafana/alloy&#34;</span>, <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;v1.8.1&#34;</span>) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> .WithHttpEndpoint(port: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">12345</span>, targetPort: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">12345</span>, name: <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;UI&#34;</span>) <span style=\"color:#75715e\">// Expose UI</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> .WithHttpEndpoint(port: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">4317</span>, targetPort: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">4317</span>, name: <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;gRPC&#34;</span>) <span style=\"color:#75715e\">// Expose gRPC</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> .WithHttpEndpoint(port: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">4318</span>, targetPort: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">4318</span>, <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;http&#34;</span>); <span style=\"color:#75715e\">// Expose HTTP</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\">// Add a Grafana container for visualization</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> grafana = builder.AddContainer(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;grafana&#34;</span>, <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;grafana/grafana&#34;</span>, <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;11.6.0&#34;</span>) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> .WithHttpEndpoint(port: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">3000</span>, targetPort: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">3000</span>); <span style=\"color:#75715e\">// Expose HTTP port 3000</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\">// Define relationships between containers</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>dotnet.WithReferenceRelationship(alloy); <span style=\"color:#75715e\">// Logs flow from .NET app to Alloy</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>alloy.WithReferenceRelationship(loki); <span style=\"color:#75715e\">// Logs flow from Alloy to Loki</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>loki.WithReferenceRelationship(grafana); <span style=\"color:#75715e\">// Logs flow from Loki to Grafana</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>builder.Build().Run(); </span></span></code></pre></div><p>The parameters for <strong>AddContainer()</strong> are a name that gets displayed on the diagram, the docker image name, and the tag. The tag is optional and it will use latest if omitted. For my Grafana example, the first docker container I added is for any dotnet application. I can use any docker image for this, as all I want is a container labelled &ldquo;dotnet-application&rdquo;. The <strong>.WithHttpEndpoint</strong> is for public ports to be displayed so you can see how communication is flowing between containers.</p> <p><strong>.WithReferenceRelationship()</strong> is how you define what calls what. So dotnet.WithReferenceRelationship(alloy) adds an arrow pointing from my dotnet application to alloy, suggesting that open telemetry logs flow from my application to alloy. You can also add calls in both directions by adding alloy.WithReferenceRelationship(dotnet) this will change the arrow to point in both directions.</p> <p>At my work we use a microservice architecture so I thought it might be fun to try and map out what calls what:</p> <p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"Work Architecture\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/work.PNG\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"2622\" height=\"1869\" /> </p> <p><em>A simplified view of a microservices architecture at work (service names anonymized).</em></p> <p>I made a start mapping a few of our services, but this doesn&rsquo;t cover everything and I have replaced the names of the services so no commerical secrets can be identified. I was surprised at how complex the system is.</p> <h3 id=\"real-world-applications\">Real-World Applications<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#real-world-applications\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>The ability to generate infrastructure diagrams is invaluable for:</p> <ul> <li><strong>Microservices Architecture</strong>: Visualize how services interact and identify bottlenecks.</li> <li><strong>Debugging</strong>: Quickly understand communication flows to troubleshoot issues.</li> <li><strong>Documentation</strong>: Create up-to-date diagrams for team collaboration and onboarding.</li> </ul> <h2 id=\"conclusion\">Conclusion<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#conclusion\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>.NET Aspire 9.2 makes it easier than ever to create detailed infrastructure diagrams, saving time and improving collaboration. Whether you&rsquo;re managing microservices or exploring Docker-based architectures, these tools can help you visualize and optimize your systems. Give it a try and see how it can enhance your workflow!</p> <p>Have you tried .NET Aspire 9.2? What features are you most excited about? Share your thoughts and experiences in the comments below!</p>"

          - generic [ref=e815]: </item>

              - generic [ref=e822]: <title>
              - text: Integrating OpenTelemetry Logs with Grafana Using Loki and Alloy
              - generic [ref=e823]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e824]:
              - generic [ref=e825]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2025/opentelemetry-logs/
              - generic [ref=e826]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e827]:
              - generic [ref=e828]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e829]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e830]:
              - generic [ref=e831]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 14 Apr 2025 20:00:00 +0000
              - generic [ref=e832]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e833]:
              - generic [ref=e834]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2025/opentelemetry-logs/
              - generic [ref=e835]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e836]:

              - text: Grafana

              - text: Loki
              - generic [ref=e847]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e848]:

                - text: <category

              - text: Alloy

              - text: Logging

                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e858]: term="Monitoring"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Monitoring
              - generic [ref=e859]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e860]:
              - generic [ref=e861]:

              - text: Docker
              - generic [ref=e863]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e864]:

              - text: DotNet
              - generic [ref=e867]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e868]:

            - generic [ref=e872]:
              - generic [ref=e873]: <description>
              - text: "<p>Logs are a critical part of monitoring and debugging modern applications. By integrating OpenTelemetry logs with Grafana using Loki and Alloy, you can centralize your log data, making it easier to analyze and monitor your .NET applications. In this blog, I&rsquo;ll walk you through the setup process and share how these tools work together to streamline log aggregation and visualization.</p> <p>I have blogged about <a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2025/setting-up-grafana/\">Grafana</a> before but until now I haven&rsquo;t added logs to Grafana let&rsquo;s have a look at how that works.</p> <p>My dotnet application makes use of OpenTelemetry. I have been sending this telemetry to an Aspire Dashboard running in Docker. This allows me to view logs, metrics and traces.</p> <p>Grafana has several tools that can help with logs.</p> <ul> <li><strong>Loki</strong>: A log aggregation system designed to store and query logs from applications and infrastructure.</li> <li><strong>Alloy</strong>: An OpenTelemetry collector that processes and forwards telemetry data.</li> <li><strong>OpenTelemetry</strong>: A set of APIs, libraries, and tools for collecting and exporting telemetry data like logs, metrics, and traces.</li> </ul> <p>I am using Alloy to collect OpenTelemetry from my application and send it to Loki, The logs in Loki can then be read by Grafana.</p> <h2 id=\"setting-up-loki-and-alloy-with-docker-compose\">Setting Up Loki and Alloy with Docker Compose<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#setting-up-loki-and-alloy-with-docker-compose\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>To start off let&rsquo;s add Alloy and Loki to my docker compose file.</p> <h3 id=\"docker-compose-configuration\">Docker Compose Configuration<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#docker-compose-configuration\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>The <code>docker-compose.yml</code> file defines the services for Loki and Alloy. Here&rsquo;s what each section does:</p> <ul> <li><strong>Loki</strong>: Runs the Loki container on port 3100 and uses a local configuration file.</li> <li><strong>Alloy</strong>: Runs the Alloy container, exposing ports for receiving telemetry data and processing logs.</li> </ul> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-docker-compose.yml\" data-lang=\"docker-compose.yml\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\"># Docker Compose configuration for Loki and Alloy</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">command</span>: -<span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">config.file=/etc/loki/local-config.yaml</span> <span style=\"color:#75715e\"># Specifies the configuration file for Loki</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">alloy</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">image</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">grafana/alloy:v1.8.1</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">container_name</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">monitoring_alloy</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">ports</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> - <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">12345</span>:<span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">12345</span> <span style=\"color:#75715e\"># HTTP server for Alloy</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> - <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">4317</span>:<span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">4317</span> <span style=\"color:#75715e\"># gRPC endpoint for OpenTelemetry</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> - <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">4319</span>:<span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">4318</span> <span style=\"color:#75715e\"># HTTP endpoint for OpenTelemetry</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">volumes</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> - <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">./config.alloy:/etc/alloy/config.alloy</span> <span style=\"color:#75715e\"># Mount Alloy configuration</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">command</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">run --server.http.listen-addr=0.0.0.0:12345 --storage.path=/var/lib/alloy/data /etc/alloy/config.alloy</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">depends_on</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> - <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">loki</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Here is the config file for Alloy.</p> <pre tabindex=\"0\"><code class=\"language-alloy.config\" data-lang=\"alloy.config\">otelcol.receiver.otlp &#34;default&#34; { http {} grpc {} output { logs = [otelcol.processor.batch.default.input] } } otelcol.processor.batch &#34;default&#34; { output { logs = [ otelcol.exporter.otlphttp.loki.input, ] } } otelcol.exporter.otlphttp &#34;loki&#34; { client { endpoint = &#34;http://loki:3100/otlp&#34; } } </code></pre><h3 id=\"how-the-components-work-together\">How the Components Work Together<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#how-the-components-work-together\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <ol> <li><strong>Application Logs</strong>: The .NET application generates logs and sends them to Alloy on port 4317.</li> <li><strong>Alloy Processing</strong>: Alloy processes the logs and forwards them to Loki on port 3100.</li> <li><strong>Loki Storage</strong>: Loki stores the logs, making them available for querying.</li> <li><strong>Grafana Visualization</strong>: Grafana connects to Loki as a data source, allowing you to visualize and analyze the logs.</li> </ol> <p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"Architecture Diagram\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/grafana-loki-arch.png\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"811\" height=\"593\" /> </p> <h3 id=\"handling-aspire-dashboard-logs\">Handling Aspire Dashboard Logs<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#handling-aspire-dashboard-logs\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>By default, sending logs to Alloy and Loki means Aspire Dashboard will no longer receive them. To resolve this, you can configure the <code>AddOpenTelemetryExporters</code> method in your .NET application to send logs to multiple destinations.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-Extensions.cs\" data-lang=\"Extensions.cs\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">if</span> (useOtlpExporter) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>{ </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#75715e\">// The following lines enable the OTLP exporter (requires the OpenTelemetry.Exporter.OpenTelemetryProtocol package)</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> builder.Services.AddOpenTelemetry() </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> .WithLogging(logging =&gt; logging.AddOtlpExporter(options =&gt; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> options.Endpoint = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> Uri(builder.Configuration[<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;OTEL_EXPORTER_OTLP_ENDPOINT&#34;</span>]); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> })) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> .WithLogging(logging =&gt; logging.AddOtlpExporter(options =&gt; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> options.Endpoint = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> Uri(builder.Configuration[<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;GrafanaExporter&#34;</span>]); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> })) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> .WithMetrics(metrics =&gt; metrics.AddOtlpExporter(options =&gt; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> options.Endpoint = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> Uri(builder.Configuration[<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;OTEL_EXPORTER_OTLP_ENDPOINT&#34;</span>]); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> })) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> .WithTracing(tracing =&gt; tracing.AddOtlpExporter(options =&gt; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> options.Endpoint = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> Uri(builder.Configuration[<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;OTEL_EXPORTER_OTLP_ENDPOINT&#34;</span>]); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> })); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>} </span></span></code></pre></div><p>If I update the AddOpenTelemetryExporters method in my Extensions.cs file in my .Net Aspire ServiceDefaults project, I can get my logs (or traces/metrics) to be sent to as many different places as I want. In my case I am sending to Allot and Aspire Dashboard.</p> <h2 id=\"conclusion\">Conclusion<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#conclusion\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>Integrating OpenTelemetry logs with Grafana using Loki and Alloy provides a powerful solution for centralized log aggregation and monitoring. This setup simplifies debugging and enhances visibility into your application&rsquo;s behaviour. If you haven&rsquo;t tried it yet, give it a go and let me know your thoughts in the comments!</p>"
              - generic [ref=e874]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e876]: </item>

              - generic [ref=e926]: <description>
              - text: "<h2 id=\"fun-with-ai\">Fun with AI<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#fun-with-ai\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>AI tools like <a href=\"https://chatgpt.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">ChatGPT</a> are evolving rapidly, and their creative capabilities are nothing short of amazing. Recently, I decided to test its image generation features with a fun and quirky prompt. The results? A personalized action figure concept that blew my mind! Let me walk you through the process and share the results.</p> <p>I used the following prompt:</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-txt\" data-lang=\"txt\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>Draw an action figure toy of the person in this photo. </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>The action figure should be full-figure and displayed in its original blister pack packaging. </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>On top of the box is the name of the toy &#34;Software Developer&#34; across a single line of text. </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>In the blister pack packaging, next to the figure, show the toy&#39;s accessories, </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>including a Microsoft laptop, </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>cup of coffee, </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>the Visual Studio app, </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>GitHub app, </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>and the Azure app. </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>There should be a label on the corner of the box that says &#34;Limited Edition&#34;. </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>This figure should look like a premium toy and everything should be inside the plastic! </span></span></code></pre></div><table border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" > <tr style=\"border-width:0px 0px 0px 0px\"> <td style=\"border-width:0px 0px 0px 0px\"> and I supplied the following image: </td> <td style=\"border-width:0px 0px 0px 0px\"> and this is the result: </td> </tr> <tr style=\"border-width:0px 0px 0px 0px\"> <td style=\"border-width:0px 0px 0px 0px\"> <img src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/images/ndc-simon.jpg\" alt=\"A picture of me as the source image\" width=\"300\" height=\"400\" class=\"img-fluid\" /> </td> <td style=\"border-width:0px 0px 0px 0px\"> <img src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/images/ai-version-of-me.png\" alt=\"AI generated version of me\" width=\"300\" height=\"400\" class=\"img-fluid\" /> </td> </tr> </table> <p>Pretty cool, right? Well I can&rsquo;t take the credit for the prompt, It comes from <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/posts/amyru_out-of-all-the-chatgpt-image-generation-capabilities-activity-7312549043610521601-BPqJ?utm_source=share&amp;utm_medium=member_desktop&amp;rcm=ACoAAAOBLj4B-Ls737kwBrHA1oRvkACb_CoRCQw2X0v1gk7q4r3w8Q9x5a6b0h4j2c1nqZz7g&amp;lipi=urn%3Ali%3Apage%3Ad_flagship3_profile_view_base_post_primary%3B5JdYtG6mQeKx%2FfWl8V9jNQ%3D%3D\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Amy Ru</a> on LinkedIn.</p> <p>Have you tried ChatGPT&rsquo;s image generation features? What creative prompts have you used? Share your experiences in the comments below!</p>"
              - generic [ref=e927]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e929]: </item>

              - text: Automation
              - generic [ref=e977]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e978]:

              - generic [ref=e981]: </category>
