          - generic [ref=e1300]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e1301]:
            - generic [ref=e1302]:
              - generic [ref=e1303]: <title>
              - text: Adding Elasticsearch with .Net Aspire
              - generic [ref=e1304]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e1305]:
              - generic [ref=e1306]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2025/adding-elasticsearch-with-aspire/
              - generic [ref=e1307]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e1308]:
              - generic [ref=e1309]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e1310]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e1311]:
              - generic [ref=e1312]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 20 Jan 2025 20:00:00 +0000
              - generic [ref=e1313]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e1314]:
              - generic [ref=e1315]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2025/adding-elasticsearch-with-aspire/
              - generic [ref=e1316]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e1317]:
              - generic [ref=e1318]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e1319]: term="Elasticsearch"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Elasticsearch
              - generic [ref=e1320]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e1321]:
              - generic [ref=e1322]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e1323]: term="DotNet"
                - text: ">"
              - text: DotNet
              - generic [ref=e1324]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e1325]:
              - generic [ref=e1326]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e1327]: term="Aspire"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Aspire
              - generic [ref=e1328]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e1329]:
              - generic [ref=e1330]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e1331]: term="Search"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Search
              - generic [ref=e1332]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e1333]:
              - generic [ref=e1334]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e1335]: term="Indexing"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Indexing
              - generic [ref=e1336]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e1337]:
              - generic [ref=e1338]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e1339]: term="Development"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Development
              - generic [ref=e1340]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e1341]:
              - generic [ref=e1342]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e1343]: term="Tech"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Tech
              - generic [ref=e1344]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e1345]:
              - generic [ref=e1346]: <description>
              - text: "<p>A few weeks ago I talked about <a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2024/aspire/\">.Net Aspire</a> , well lets take a look at how we can use it with Elasticsearch. Elastic search is a powerful search engine that can be used to index and search data. It is built on top of Lucene and provides a powerful way to search through your data.</p> <p>Aspire allows dependencies like elasticsearch to be added to a project programmatically. Lets look at how this can work.</p> <p>Add this nuget package to your AppHost project (as of writing this is a preview package):</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-xml\" data-lang=\"xml\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#f92672\">&lt;PackageReference</span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">Include=</span><span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;Aspire.Hosting.Elasticsearch&#34;</span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">Version=</span><span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;9.0.0-preview.5.24551.3&#34;</span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">/&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>In your AppHost project, add the following code to your <code>Program.cs</code> file:</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> elasticsearch = builder </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> .AddElasticsearch(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;elasticsearch&#34;</span>); </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now if you run your project it will add an elasticsearch containter to your project. A common way to administer elasticsearch is to use Kibana. You can add this to your project by adding the following code to your <code>Program.cs</code> file:</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> kibana = builder </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> .AddContainer(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;kibana&#34;</span>, <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;kibana&#34;</span>, <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;8.15.3&#34;</span>) <span style=\"color:#75715e\">// Add Kibana from the image kibana, and tag 8.15.3 and give it a name kibana</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> .WithReference(elasticsearch) <span style=\"color:#75715e\">// Add a reference to the elasticsearch container</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> .WithEndpoint(<span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">5601</span>, <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">5601</span>); <span style=\"color:#75715e\">// Expose a port so you can connect</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now if you run your project you will have an elasticsearch and kibana container running. You can access kibana by going to <code>http://localhost:5601</code>, and elasticsearch by going to <code>http://localhost:9200</code>.</p> <h2 id=\"troubleshooting-kibana\">Troubleshooting Kibana<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#troubleshooting-kibana\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>However when I do that I get the error <code>Kibana server is not ready yet</code>. Looking at the kibana container logs, I see the following error:</p> <pre tabindex=\"0\"><code class=\"language-log\" data-lang=\"log\">2025-01-19T21:42:13 [2025-01-19T21:42:13.558+00:00][WARN ][plugins.security.config] Generating a random key for xpack.security.encryptionKey. To prevent sessions from being invalidated on restart, please set xpack.security.encryptionKey in the kibana.yml or use the bin/kibana-encryption-keys command. Unable to retrieve version information from Elasticsearch nodes. security_exception </code></pre><p>This is due to the security settings in Elasticsearch. To fix this, you can turn off this security feature by enabling an environment variable:</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> elasticsearch = builder </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> .AddElasticsearch(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;elasticsearch&#34;</span>) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> .WithEnvironment(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;xpack.security.enabled&#34;</span>, <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;false&#34;</span>); </span></span></code></pre></div><p>As Aspire is only running locally, this is fine, but in a production environment, you would want to secure your Elasticsearch and Kibana instances.</p> <h2 id=\"using-elasticsearch-in-your-project\">Using Elasticsearch in Your Project<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#using-elasticsearch-in-your-project\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>Now that you have Elasticsearch added to your project, how can you use it? In the .NET project that wants to connect and interact with Elasticsearch, you can add the following NuGet package:</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-txt\" data-lang=\"txt\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>Aspire.Elastic.Clients.Elasticsearch (version 9.0.0-preview.5.24551.3 as of writing) </span></span></code></pre></div><p>In the <code>Program.cs</code> file of your .NET project you can add the following code:</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>builder.AddElasticsearchClient(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;elasticsearch&#34;</span>); </span></span></code></pre></div><p>No need to specify any complex connection strings or settings, Aspire will handle all of that for you.</p> <p>This is pretty much all of the Aspire specific code you need, but lets have a quick look at indexing some data and returning it with a search. Elastic Search has extensive <a href=\"https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/client/net-api/current/examples.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">documentation</a> on how to do this with the dotnet libraries.</p> <p>To index some data you can use the following code:</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">await</span> _client.Indices.CreateAsync(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;searchindex&#34;</span>, cancellationToken); <span style=\"color:#75715e\">// Create an index called searchindex</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> documents = context.Episode.ToList(); <span style=\"color:#75715e\">// Get the documents you want to index from Entity Framework or any other source</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">await</span> _client.IndexManyAsync(documents, index: <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;searchindex&#34;</span>, cancellationToken); <span style=\"color:#75715e\">// Index the documents into the searchindex index</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>ElasticsearchClient can be injected in via dependency injection, again no need to specify any connection strings or settings.</p> <p>To search for data you can use the following code:</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#75715e\">// Create a search request with a wildcard query which searches in the title field of your indexed documents.</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> searchRequest = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> ESSearchRequest(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;searchindex&#34;</span>) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> From = <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">0</span>, </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> Size = <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">10</span>, </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> Query = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> WildcardQuery(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;title&#34;</span>) { Value = <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">$&#34;*{SearchQuery}*&#34;</span> }, </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> }; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#75715e\">// Execute the search request and get the response.</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> response = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">await</span> _client.SearchAsync&lt;Episode&gt;(searchRequest, cancellationToken); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">if</span> (response.IsValidResponse) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#75715e\">// Return the documents from the response.</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">return</span> response.Documents.ToList(); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span></code></pre></div><h2 id=\"conclusion\">Conclusion<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#conclusion\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>By following these steps, you can successfully integrate Elasticsearch and Kibana into your .NET Aspire project. This setup allows you to leverage powerful search and analytics capabilities in your application. Remember to secure your instances in a production environment to ensure data safety.</p>"
              - generic [ref=e1347]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e1349]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e1350]:
          - generic [ref=e1353]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e1354]:
            - generic [ref=e1355]:
              - generic [ref=e1356]: <title>
              - text: Simplifying Dependency Management with NuGet Central Package Management
              - generic [ref=e1357]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e1358]:
              - generic [ref=e1359]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2025/nuget-central-package-management/
              - generic [ref=e1360]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e1361]:
              - generic [ref=e1362]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e1363]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e1364]:
              - generic [ref=e1365]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 13 Jan 2025 20:00:00 +0000
              - generic [ref=e1366]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e1367]:
              - generic [ref=e1368]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2025/nuget-central-package-management/
              - generic [ref=e1369]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e1370]:
              - generic [ref=e1371]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e1372]: term="NuGet"
                - text: ">"
              - text: NuGet
              - generic [ref=e1373]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e1374]:
              - generic [ref=e1375]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e1376]: term="PackageManagement"
                - text: ">"
              - text: PackageManagement
              - generic [ref=e1377]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e1378]:
              - generic [ref=e1379]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e1380]: term="DotNet"
                - text: ">"
              - text: DotNet
              - generic [ref=e1381]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e1382]:
              - generic [ref=e1383]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e1384]: term="Development"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Development
              - generic [ref=e1385]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e1386]:
              - generic [ref=e1387]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e1388]: term="DevOps"
                - text: ">"
              - text: DevOps
              - generic [ref=e1389]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e1390]:
              - generic [ref=e1391]: <description>
              - text: "<p>Managing dependencies in .NET projects can become complex, especially when dealing with multiple projects that share common packages. NuGet Central Package Management (CPM) is a feature that simplifies this process by allowing you to manage package versions centrally.</p> <h2 id=\"what-is-nuget-central-package-management\">What is NuGet Central Package Management?<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#what-is-nuget-central-package-management\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>NuGet Central Package Management allows you to define and manage package versions in a central location, rather than specifying them individually in each project file. This approach ensures consistency across projects and simplifies the process of updating package versions.</p> <h2 id=\"setting-up-central-package-management\">Setting Up Central Package Management<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#setting-up-central-package-management\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>To get started with Central Package Management, follow these steps:</p> <ol> <li> <p><strong>Create a Directory.Packages.props File</strong>: This file will contain the central package version definitions. Create this file in the root directory of your solution.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Define Package Versions</strong>: In the <code>Directory.Packages.props</code> file, define the package versions you want to manage centrally. For example:</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-xml\" data-lang=\"xml\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#f92672\">&lt;Project&gt;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">&lt;PropertyGroup&gt;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">&lt;ManagePackageVersionsCentrally&gt;</span>true<span style=\"color:#f92672\">&lt;/ManagePackageVersionsCentrally&gt;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">&lt;/PropertyGroup&gt;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">&lt;ItemGroup&gt;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">&lt;PackageVersion</span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">Include=</span><span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;Newtonsoft.Json&#34;</span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">Version=</span><span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;13.0.1&#34;</span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">/&gt;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">&lt;PackageVersion</span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">Include=</span><span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;Serilog&#34;</span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">Version=</span><span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;2.10.0&#34;</span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">/&gt;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">&lt;PackageVersion</span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">Include=</span><span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore&#34;</span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">Version=</span><span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;9.0.0&#34;</span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">/&gt;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">&lt;PackageVersion</span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">Include=</span><span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.SqlServer&#34;</span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">Version=</span><span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;9.0.0&#34;</span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">/&gt;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">&lt;/ItemGroup&gt;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#f92672\">&lt;/Project&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div></li> <li> <p><strong>Update all your csproj files</strong>: In each project file (<code>.csproj</code>), remove the version number information:</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-xml\" data-lang=\"xml\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#f92672\">&lt;ItemGroup&gt;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">&lt;PackageReference</span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">Include=</span><span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;Newtonsoft.Json&#34;</span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">/&gt;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">&lt;PackageReference</span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">Include=</span><span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;Serilog&#34;</span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">/&gt;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">&lt;PackageReference</span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">Include=</span><span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore&#34;</span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">/&gt;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">&lt;PackageReference</span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">Include=</span><span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.SqlServer&#34;</span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">/&gt;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#f92672\">&lt;/ItemGroup&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div></li> </ol> <h2 id=\"benefits-of-central-package-management\">Benefits of Central Package Management<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#benefits-of-central-package-management\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>Using Central Package Management offers several benefits:</p> <ul> <li><strong>Consistency</strong>: Ensures that all projects use the same package versions, reducing the risk of version conflicts.</li> <li><strong>Simplified Updates</strong>: Updating a package version in the central file automatically updates it across all projects.</li> <li><strong>Reduced Maintenance</strong>: Simplifies the process of managing package versions, especially in large solutions with many projects.</li> </ul> <p>If for any reason you want to disable Central Package Management, you can set the <code>ManagePackageVersionsCentrally</code> property to <code>false</code> in the <code>Directory.Packages.props</code> file, or in the csproj file if you only want to disable for a single project.</p> <h2 id=\"conclusion\">Conclusion<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#conclusion\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>NuGet Central Package Management simplifies the process of managing package versions across multiple projects in a .NET solution. By defining package versions in a central file, you can ensure consistency, simplify updates, and reduce maintenance efforts. Give it a try in your next .NET project to experience the benefits firsthand.</p> <p>For more information, visit the <a href=\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/consume-packages/Central-Package-Management\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">official NuGet documentation</a> .</p>"

          - generic [ref=e1399]:
            - generic [ref=e1400]:
              - generic [ref=e1401]: <title>
              - text: Setting Up Nagios Monitoring with Docker
              - generic [ref=e1402]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e1403]:
              - generic [ref=e1404]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2025/monitoring-with-nagios-docker/
              - generic [ref=e1405]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e1406]:
              - generic [ref=e1407]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e1408]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e1409]:
              - generic [ref=e1410]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 06 Jan 2025 20:00:00 +0000
              - generic [ref=e1411]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e1412]:
              - generic [ref=e1413]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2025/monitoring-with-nagios-docker/
              - generic [ref=e1414]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e1415]:

                - generic [ref=e1417]: term="Nagios"

              - text: Nagios

            - generic [ref=e1419]:

              - text: Docker
              - generic [ref=e1422]: </category>

                - generic [ref=e1425]: term="Monitoring"

              - text: Monitoring
              - generic [ref=e1426]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e1427]:
              - generic [ref=e1428]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e1429]: term="SysAdmin"
                - text: ">"
              - text: SysAdmin
              - generic [ref=e1430]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e1431]:
              - generic [ref=e1432]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e1433]: term="DevOps"
                - text: ">"
              - text: DevOps
              - generic [ref=e1434]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e1435]:
              - generic [ref=e1436]:

                - text: ">"
              - text: NetworkMonitoring

            - generic [ref=e1439]:
              - generic [ref=e1440]: <description>
              - text: "<p>A long time ago in my SysAdmin days, I was a big fan of <a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2014/i-love-nagios/\">Nagios</a> . Recently, I decided to revisit it and see if I could run it in a Docker container to monitor my local network. This guide will walk you through the process of setting up Nagios monitoring using Docker.</p> <h2 id=\"finding-a-docker-image-for-nagios\">Finding a Docker Image for Nagios<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#finding-a-docker-image-for-nagios\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>First, we need to find a suitable Docker image for Nagios. The <a href=\"https://hub.docker.com/r/manios/nagios\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">manios/nagios</a> image looks like it should do the job.</p> <h2 id=\"running-the-nagios-docker-container\">Running the Nagios Docker Container<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#running-the-nagios-docker-container\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>The basics of running this container are as follows:</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>docker run -d --name nagios -p 8080:80 manios/nagios </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This command will pull the Nagios image from Docker Hub and run it in a container, mapping port 80 in the container to port 8080 on your host machine.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>docker run -d --name nagios <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">\\ </span></span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> -v /path-to-nagios/etc/:/opt/nagios/etc/ <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">\\ </span></span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> -v /path-to-nagios/var:/opt/nagios/var/ <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">\\ </span></span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> -v /path-to-nagios/ssmtp.conf:/etc/ssmtp/ssmtp.conf <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">\\ </span></span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> -v /path-to-custom-plugins:/opt/Custom-Nagios-Plugins <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">\\ </span></span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> -p 8080:80 <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">\\ </span></span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> manios/nagios </span></span></code></pre></div><p>I prefer running via docker compose, which looks like this:</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-yaml\" data-lang=\"yaml\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">nagios</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">image</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">manios/nagios:latest</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">container_name</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">monitoring_nagios</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">ports</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> - <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">8081</span>:<span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">80</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">restart</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">always</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">volumes</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> - <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">./nagios/localhost.cfg:/opt/nagios/etc/objects/localhost.cfg</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> - <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">./nagios/windows.cfg:/opt/nagios/etc/objects/windows.cfg</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> - <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">nagios_data:/opt/nagios/var/</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">environment</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> - <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">NAGIOSADMIN_USER=nagiosadmin</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> - <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">NAGIOSADMIN_PASS=nagiosadmin</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> - <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">NAGIOS_TIMEZONE=UTC</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> - <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">NAGIOS_WEB_USER=nagiosadmin</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> - <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">NAGIOS_WEB_PASS=nagiosadmin</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><h2 id=\"accessing-the-nagios-web-interface\">Accessing the Nagios Web Interface<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#accessing-the-nagios-web-interface\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>Once the container is running, you can access the Nagios web interface by navigating to http://localhost:8080 in your web browser. You should see the Nagios login page.</p> <h2 id=\"configuring-nagios\">Configuring Nagios<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#configuring-nagios\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>To configure Nagios, you&rsquo;ll need to edit the configuration files located in the container. You can do this by accessing the container&rsquo;s shell:</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>docker exec -it nagios /bin/bash </span></span></code></pre></div><p>From here, you can navigate to the Nagios configuration directory and make the necessary changes:</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>cd /opt/nagios/etc </span></span></code></pre></div><h2 id=\"adding-hosts-and-services\">Adding Hosts and Services<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#adding-hosts-and-services\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>To monitor your local network, you&rsquo;ll need to add hosts and services to the Nagios configuration. This involves editing the configuration files and adding each host and service you want to monitor.</p> <p>I have added a few extra hosts to the localhost.cfg file to monitor my router, and a few other devices on my network. I have also added a Volume to store the nagios data, so after a restart of the container the data is still there.</p> <p>Lets have a look at how hosts and services are defined in the config files.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-cfg\" data-lang=\"cfg\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">define host{</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">use linux-server</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">host_name router</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">alias router</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">parents localhost; Hosts that this host is dependent on </span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">address 192.168.2.1; IP Address or DNS name of the host</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-cfg\" data-lang=\"cfg\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">define service{</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">use local-service,graphed-service</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">host_name localhost, router</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">service_description PING</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">check_command check_ping!100.0,20%!500.0,60%</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>When making changes to your config files it is useful to check the config is valid. To do this with the docker file you can run the following command:</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>docker exec -it mynagioscontainer bin/nagios -v etc/nagios.cfg </span></span></code></pre></div><p>It may have been 10 years since I last looked at Nagios, but the UI hasn&rsquo;t changed much. Host are checked if they are Up or Down, and every Host can have a number of services associated with it and this are checked if they are Up or Down.</p> <p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"Nagios UI\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/nagios.png\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"1605\" height=\"702\" /> </p> <h2 id=\"conclusion\">Conclusion<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#conclusion\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>By following these steps, you can set up Nagios monitoring using Docker to keep an eye on your local network. Nagios is a powerful tool for network monitoring, and running it in a Docker container makes it easy to deploy and manage. Happy monitoring!</p>"

          - generic [ref=e1443]: </item>

              - generic [ref=e1476]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e1477]:
              - generic [ref=e1478]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2024/end-of-year/

            - generic [ref=e1486]:

              - text: PersonalGrowth
              - generic [ref=e1508]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e1509]:

              - text: Conferences

                - text: ">"
              - text: UserGroups

            - generic [ref=e1517]:
              - generic [ref=e1518]: <description>
              - text: <p>It is that time of year again, time to reflect on the year that has passed and look forward to the year ahead. As with many years 2024 has been a mixed bag, some good stuff, and some not so good stuff. I did not make any goals at the start of 2024, but I am going to fix that for 2025.</p> <p>Goals for 2025</p> <ul> <li>Blog Posts</li> <li>More Learning</li> <li>Drink More Water and Do More Walks</li> <li>Attend Conferences and User Groups</li> </ul> <h3 id="blog-posts">Blog Posts<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#blog-posts"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h3> <p>For most of the year, I have <strong>not</strong> been writing blog posts. However, the Scottish Summit conference reignited my blogging spark, and I have written seven posts since then. My goal is to write one post a week. I am sure I will miss the odd week, but the important thing is not to miss two in a row.</p> <h3 id="more-learning">More Learning<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#more-learning"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h3> <p>Being a developer is a constant journey of learning, and I have not done enough of that this year. During December, I completed a few challenges from <a href="https://adventofcode.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Advent of Code</a> , and I hope to do more of them. I have also discovered <a href="https://exercism.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Exercism</a> and started working through the C# track. I am sure there will be more opportunities to learn new things in 2025.</p> <h3 id="health">Health<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#health"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h3> <p>2024 took an unusual turn. In June, I walked a <a href="https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2024/charity-hike">half marathon across the Peak District</a> , and since then, I have been doing lots of walks. Walking is good for my physical and mental health, so I intend to do more of it in 2025. I have a 5k scheduled for January, which should be lots of fun as it is around the wildlife park. On the same topic, I want to drink more water. Not sure how I am going to accomplish this as I am easily distracted by the current developer problem, instead of thinking about my health.</p> <h3 id="conferences-and-user-groups">Conferences and User Groups<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#conferences-and-user-groups"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h3> <p>I want to attend a conference or user group once a month in 2025. Conferences and user groups are great places to meet people, learn new things, and be encouraged by the community. I have signed up as a volunteer for NDC London in January, and DDD North is back in February. I am sure I will be able to fill the other months with events soon enough as well.</p> <h2 id="what-happened-in-2024">What Happened in 2024<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#what-happened-in-2024"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p>I did something in 2024 that I thought I would never do. I signed up for a half marathon hike across the Peak District for charity. This was an amazing achievement for me, involving lots of training walks and raising over ¬£600 for charity.</p> <p>My attendance at conferences and user groups has been a bit light this year. However, I did attend the Scottish Summit in October, which rekindled my blogging. I also attended DDD North with a couple of my work colleagues, which was great as usual.</p> <p>Family life has kept me busy this year and has been my focus for much of the year. Next year, I want the focus to shift more to my work and career. I attended a couple of code club sessions with my eldest son, and it was great to see his skills develop. Like me, he wanted to help others with the coding exercise.</p>

              - text: "<p>Creating pull requests is part of the development process when working with version control systems like Git. Pull requests allow developers to propose changes to a codebase and collaborate with team members to review and merge those changes.</p> <p>When you have long running branches, it can be challenging to keep them up to date with the main branch. This is where automatic pull requests come in. Automatic pull requests are a way to automate the process of updating long running branches with changes from the main branch. For my example I am going to automate creating PRs (Pull Requests) from the development branch to the main (or master) branch. This means if I update my develop branch with a new feature or bug fix, a PR will be created to merge those changes into the main branch.</p> <p>I am going to look at two ways of doing this, one for GitHub and one for Azure DevOps.</p> <h3 id=\"github\">GitHub<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#github\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>GitHub Actions are the way to automate tasks in your GitHub repository. You can create workflows that run on specific triggers, such as when a pull request is created or when code is pushed to a specific branch. Create a new GitHub action with the following code in it:</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-yml\" data-lang=\"yml\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#f92672\">name</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">Auto PR</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#f92672\">on</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">push</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">branches</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> - <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">develop</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#f92672\">jobs</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">create-pr</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">runs-on</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">ubuntu-latest</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">steps</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> - <span style=\"color:#f92672\">name</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">Check out repository code</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">uses</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">actions/checkout@v4</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">with</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">fetch-depth</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">0</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">ref</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">develop</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> - <span style=\"color:#f92672\">name</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">create pull request</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">run</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">gh pr create -B main -H develop --title &#39;Merge develop into main&#39; --body &#39;Created by GitHub action&#39;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">env</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">GITHUB_TOKEN</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This action will run when code is pushed to the develop branch. It will then check out the code from the develop branch and create a pull request to merge the changes into the main (or master) branch. It does have a flaw in that it will generate an error if the PR already exists, but as the PR already exists, it is not a big problem.</p> <p>This action uses the GitHub CLI to create the PR. For more information on the GitHub CLI, see the <a href=\"https://cli.github.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">GitHub CLI documentation</a> . The gh pr create command creates a pull request with the specified title and body. There is also a gh pr edit command, so combining the two could be used to update the PR if it already exists.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-yml\" data-lang=\"yml\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#f92672\">run</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">gh pr create -B main -H develop --title &#39;Merge develop into main&#39; --body &#39;Created by GitHub action&#39; || gh pr edit -B main --title &#34;Merge develop into main&#34; --body &#39;Created by GitHub action&#39;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><h3 id=\"azure-devops\">Azure DevOps<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#azure-devops\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>Azure DevOps has a similar feature to GitHub Actions called Azure Pipelines. You can create pipelines that run on specific triggers, such as when code is pushed to a specific branch. For Azure DevOps I have a powershell scripts that does most of the work, lets have a look at it:</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-powershell\" data-lang=\"powershell\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">param</span> ( </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> [Parameter(<span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">Mandatory</span>=$true)][<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span>]$repoName, </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> [Parameter(<span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">Mandatory</span>=$true)][<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span>]$sourceBranch, </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> [Parameter(<span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">Mandatory</span>=$true)][<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span>]$targetBranch, </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> [Parameter(<span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">Mandatory</span>=$true)][<span $repositoryResponse.id <span style=\"color:#75715e\"># Extract the repository GUID</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\"># Now construct the project URL using the repository GUID</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>$projectUrl = <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;</span>$apisUrl<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">/git/repositories/</span>$repoGuid<span </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>$targetBranchRef = <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;refs/heads/</span>$targetBranch<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;</span> </span></span><span </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>$body = @{ </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;itemVersion&#34;</span> = @{ </span></span><span </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;versionType&#34;</span> = <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;branch&#34;</span> </span></span><span </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>$commitResponse = Invoke-RestMethod -Uri $diffUrl -Method POST -Headers $headers -Body $body </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\"># Step 4: Check if there are any changes between the branches</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">if</span> ($commitResponse.count <span style=\"color:#f92672\">-gt</span> <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">0</span>) { </span></span><span style=\"color:#e6db74\">.&#34;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>} <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">else</span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> Write-Output <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;No changes between </span>$sourceBranch<span style=\"color:#e6db74\"> and </span>$targetBranch<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">.&#34;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">return</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>} </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\"># Check for existing active pull requests between source and target branches</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>$encodedSourceBranchRef = [<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">System.Web.HttpUtility</span>]::UrlEncode($sourceBranchRef) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>$encodedTargetBranchRef = [<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">System.Web.HttpUtility</span>]::UrlEncode($targetBranchRef) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>$checkPrUrl = <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;</span>$projectUrl<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">/pullrequests</span>$apiVersionQs<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&amp;searchCriteria.status=active&#34;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>Write-Output <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;Checking for existing active pull requests between </span>$sourceBranch<span style=\"color:#e6db74\"> and </span>$targetBranch<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>$existingPrs = Invoke-RestMethod -Method GET -Headers $headers -Uri $checkPrUrl </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">if</span> take the first one if multiple exist</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> $pullRequestId = $existingPr.pullRequestId </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> Write-Output <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;An active pull request already exists between </span>$sourceBranch<span style=\"color:#e6db74\"> and </span>$targetBranch<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">.&#34;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> Write-Output <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;Pull Request ID: </span>$pullRequestId<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> Write-Output <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;##vso[task.setvariable variable=prId]</span>$pullRequestId<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">return</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>} </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\"># Create a Pull Request</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>$pullRequestUrl = <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;</span>$projectUrl<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">/pullrequests</span>$apiVersionQs<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>$pullRequest = @{ </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;sourceRefName&#34;</span> = <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;</span>$sourceBranchRef<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;targetRefName&#34;</span> = <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;</span>$targetBranchRef<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;title&#34;</span> = <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;</span>$prTitle<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;description&#34;</span> = <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;</span>$prDescription<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>} </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>$pullRequestJson = ($pullRequest | ConvertTo-Json -Depth <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">5</span>) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>Write-Output <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;Sending a REST call to create a new pull request from </span>$sourceBranch<span style=\"color:#e6db74\"> to </span>$targetBranch<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\"># REST call to create a Pull Request</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>$pullRequestResult = Invoke-RestMethod -Method POST -Headers $headers -Body $pullRequestJson -Uri $pullRequestUrl </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\"># Ensure the pull request ID exists</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">if</span> (<span style=\"color:#f92672\">-not</span> $pullRequestResult.pullRequestId) { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">throw</span> <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;Pull request creation failed. No pull request ID returned.&#34;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>} </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>$pullRequestId = $pullRequestResult.pullRequestId </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>Write-Output <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;Pull request created. Pull Request Id: </span>$pullRequestId<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>Write-Output <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;##vso[task.setvariable variable=prId]</span>$pullRequestId<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This makes use of the Azure DevOps REST API to create a PR. The script takes in the repository name, source branch, target branch, PR title and PR description as parameters. It then checks if there are any changes between the source and target branches, and if there are, it creates a PR. If there is already an active PR between the two branches, it will output the PR ID and not create a new PR. This script can be run as a step in an Azure DevOps pipeline.</p> <p>My pipeline has a step that looks a bit like:</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-yml\" data-lang=\"yml\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> - <span style=\"color:#f92672\">task</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">PowerShell@2</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">displayName</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">Create PR</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">condition</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">eq(variables[&#39;Build.SourceBranch&#39;], &#39;refs/heads/develop&#39;)</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">inputs</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">targetType</span>: <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#39;inline&#39;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">script</span>: <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#39;build/CreatePR.ps1 -repoName ProjectX -sourceBranch develop -targetBranch main -prTitle &#34;Release $(Build.Number.Major).$(Build.Number.Minor).x&#34; -prDescription &#34;Dev to Prod&#34;&#39;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">env</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">SYSTEM_ACCESSTOKEN</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">$(System.AccessToken)</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>I only run this step on the develop branch, and you can see I supply all the parameters that are defined in my powershell script. I include the System.AccessToken so the step has permission to do the creation of the PR, and can get details of my Azure DevOps setup and where to make the REST API calls to.</p>"
              - generic [ref=e1568]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e1570]: </item>

              - text: MachineLearning

            - generic [ref=e1619]:
              - generic [ref=e1620]: <description>
              - text: "<p>AI is everywhere at the moment, from chatbots to code completion tools like GitHub Copilot. Here are some common AI and Copilot terms with explanations.</p> <h2 id=\"common-ai-and-copilot-terms\">Common AI and Copilot Terms<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#common-ai-and-copilot-terms\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <h3 id=\"artificial-intelligence-ai\">Artificial Intelligence (AI)<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#artificial-intelligence-ai\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>Artificial Intelligence (AI) refers to the simulation of human intelligence in machines that are programmed to think and learn like humans. AI can be used for various applications, including natural language processing, image recognition, and decision-making. AI systems are designed to perform tasks that typically require human intelligence, such as visual perception, speech recognition, decision-making, and language translation.</p> <ul> <li><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Wikipedia: Artificial Intelligence</a> </li> </ul> <h3 id=\"machine-learning-ml\">Machine Learning (ML)<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#machine-learning-ml\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>Machine Learning (ML) is a subset of AI that involves the use of algorithms and statistical models to enable machines to improve their performance on a specific task through experience. ML algorithms learn from data and make predictions or decisions without being explicitly programmed. Machine learning is used in a variety of applications, such as email filtering, fraud detection, and recommendation systems.</p> <ul> <li><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_learning\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Wikipedia: Machine Learning</a> </li> </ul> <h3 id=\"natural-language-processing-nlp\">Natural Language Processing (NLP)<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#natural-language-processing-nlp\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>Natural Language Processing (NLP) is a field of AI that focuses on the interaction between computers and humans through natural language. NLP enables machines to understand, interpret, and generate human language, making it possible for AI systems to communicate with users in a more natural way.</p> <ul> <li><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_language_processing\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Wikipedia: Natural Language Processing</a> </li> </ul> <h3 id=\"github-copilot\">GitHub Copilot<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#github-copilot\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>Copilot is an AI-powered code completion tool developed by GitHub in collaboration with OpenAI. It uses machine learning models to provide code suggestions and autocompletions based on the context of the code being written. Copilot helps developers write code faster and with fewer errors by offering relevant code snippets and completing lines of code as they type. It supports a wide range of programming languages and can be integrated into popular code editors like Visual Studio Code.</p> <ul> <li><a href=\"https://docs.github.com/en/copilot/about-github-copilot\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">GitHub Copilot: Docs</a> </li> <li><a href=\"https://github.com/features/copilot\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">GitHub Copilot</a> </li> </ul> <h3 id=\"retrieval-augmented-generation-rag\">Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG)<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#retrieval-augmented-generation-rag\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) is a technique that combines retrieval-based and generation-based approaches to improve the performance of AI models in tasks such as question answering and text generation. RAG involves retrieving relevant documents or information from a large corpus and using that information to generate more accurate and contextually relevant responses.</p> <h3 id=\"large-language-models-llm\">Large Language Models (LLM)<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#large-language-models-llm\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>Large Language Models (LLM) are a type of AI model that is trained on vast amounts of text data to understand and generate human language. These models, such as GPT-3, are capable of performing a wide range of language tasks, including translation, summarization, and question answering. LLMs leverage deep learning techniques to capture the nuances of language and provide highly accurate and contextually relevant outputs.</p> <ul> <li><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Language_model\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Wikipedia: Language Models</a> </li> </ul> <h3 id=\"generative-pre-trained-transformer-gpt\">Generative Pre-trained Transformer (GPT)<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#generative-pre-trained-transformer-gpt\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>Generative Pre-trained Transformer (GPT) is a type of large language model developed by OpenAI. GPT models, such as GPT-3, are pre-trained on a diverse range of internet text and fine-tuned for specific tasks. GPT models are known for their ability to generate coherent and contextually relevant text, making them useful for applications such as chatbots, content creation, and code generation.</p> <h3 id=\"deep-learning\">Deep Learning<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#deep-learning\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>Deep Learning is a subset of machine learning that involves the use of neural networks with many layers (deep neural networks) to model complex patterns in data. Deep learning has been particularly successful in tasks such as image and speech recognition, natural language processing, and game playing.</p> <h3 id=\"neural-networks\">Neural Networks<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#neural-networks\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>Neural Networks are a series of algorithms that attempt to recognize underlying relationships in a set of data through a process that mimics the way the human brain operates. Neural networks consist of layers of interconnected nodes (neurons) that process input data and generate output.</p> <h3 id=\"reinforcement-learning-rl\">Reinforcement Learning (RL)<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#reinforcement-learning-rl\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>Reinforcement Learning (RL) is a type of machine learning where an agent learns to make decisions by taking actions in an environment to maximize a cumulative reward. RL is commonly used in applications such as robotics, game playing, and autonomous systems.</p> <h3 id=\"computer-vision\">Computer Vision<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#computer-vision\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>Computer Vision is a field of AI that enables machines to interpret and understand visual information from the world, such as images and videos. Computer vision techniques are used in applications such as facial recognition, object detection, and image classification.</p> <h3 id=\"generative-adversarial-networks-gans\">Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs)<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#generative-adversarial-networks-gans\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) are a class of neural networks used for generating new data samples that are similar to a given training dataset. GANs consist of two networks: a generator that creates new data samples and a discriminator that evaluates the authenticity of the generated samples. GANs are used in applications such as image synthesis, data augmentation, and style transfer.</p> <h3 id=\"positronic-brain\">Positronic Brain<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#positronic-brain\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>The Positronic Brain is a fictional technological concept created by science fiction writer Isaac Asimov. It is a highly advanced artificial brain used in robots, enabling them to process information, make decisions, and exhibit behaviors similar to human intelligence. The concept of the Positronic Brain is central to Asimov&rsquo;s Robot series, where it serves as the foundation for the robots&rsquo; cognitive functions and adherence to the Three Laws of Robotics. Star Trek&rsquo;s Commander Data had a positronic brain as well.</p> <p>For more information on the Positronic Brain, you can refer to the following sources:</p> <ul> <li><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Positronic_brain\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Wikipedia: Positronic Brain</a> </li> <li><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_series\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Isaac Asimov&rsquo;s Robot Series</a> </li> </ul>"
              - generic [ref=e1621]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e1623]: </item>

          - generic [ref=e1628]:
            - generic [ref=e1629]:
              - generic [ref=e1630]: <title>
              - text: Top Electricity Consuming Devices in Your Home
              - generic [ref=e1631]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e1632]:
              - generic [ref=e1633]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2024/top-electricity-devices/
              - generic [ref=e1634]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e1635]:
              - generic [ref=e1636]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e1637]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e1638]:
              - generic [ref=e1639]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 02 Dec 2024 20:00:00 +0000
              - generic [ref=e1640]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e1641]:
              - generic [ref=e1642]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2024/top-electricity-devices/
              - generic [ref=e1643]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e1644]:
              - generic [ref=e1645]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e1646]: term="Electricity"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Electricity
              - generic [ref=e1647]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e1648]:
              - generic [ref=e1649]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e1650]: term="SmartPlugs"
                - text: ">"
              - text: SmartPlugs
              - generic [ref=e1651]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e1652]:
              - generic [ref=e1653]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e1654]: term="HomeAssistant"
                - text: ">"
              - text: HomeAssistant
              - generic [ref=e1655]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e1656]:
              - generic [ref=e1657]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e1658]: term="EnergyMonitoring"
                - text: ">"
              - text: EnergyMonitoring
              - generic [ref=e1659]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e1660]:
              - generic [ref=e1661]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e1662]: term="PowerConsumption"
                - text: ">"
              - text: PowerConsumption
              - generic [ref=e1663]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e1664]:
              - generic [ref=e1665]: <description>
              - text: <p>I have been wondering what devices in my house use the most electricity. I have a smart meter which tells me how much electricity I am using, but it doesn&rsquo;t tell me what devices are using the most electricity.</p> <p>Recently I purchased 12 of these <a href="https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B09VP5KNWM?ref=ppx_yo2ov_dt_b_fed_asin_title" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">ANTELA Smart Plugs</a> (they come in packs of 4 so it hasn&rsquo;t broken the bank). They are straightforward to set up, you plug them into your power socket and plug your device you want to monitor into them, after that you connect to the wifi and can turn the device off/on and see how much power/current/voltage they are using. I have integrated them into Home Assistant and after about a day of usage I can reveal the following findings:</p> <ul> <li>2 x Monitors attached to my Laptop. As I write this they are only using about 30W of power between them.</li> <li>Microwave - I cooked a potato and it used 1.2kWh of power.</li> <li>Washing Machine - Peaks at about 2kW of power, plus the cycle takes some time to complete.</li> <li>Laptop - Laptop charger, looks to be using about 37W of power.</li> <li>Kettle - A massive electricity hog, only runs for a short time but reaches 2.9kW of power.</li> <li>My Routers/Switches/Servers - My home network has a few devices on it like Raspberry Pi&rsquo;s, a linux and windows server and a network switch etc. Between them they are using about 32W of power. Not a lot but it is on 24-7.</li> <li>Fridge - I have a fridge freezer, it uses about 72W of power.</li> <li>TV (and firestick) - This is a surprisingly large amount of power. TV is on quite a lot and is using 110W of power. There are other devices which contribute to this value, however when off the TV is still using 10W of power. I am assuming its age is a big factor.</li> <li>Tumble Dryer - Again no surprises that this is a big electricity user, it peaks at 2.3kW of power and as it runs for a good couple of hours or so, is a big contributor to my electricity.</li> <li>Dishwasher - I have put the dishwasher on a few times today and it peaks at 2.2kW of power.</li> </ul> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="Electricity Usage" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/elec-usage.png" loading="lazy" width="701" height="445" /> </p> <p>I am not able to monitor 100% of my electricity usage, things like lights, my boiler and anything else wired directly in, won&rsquo;t have a plug and I can&rsquo;t monitor in this way. However over the last month or so I can see what is using the most electricity.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="Electricity Usage" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/elec-usage2.png" loading="lazy" width="1537" height="435" /> </p> <p><a href="https://octopus.energy/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Octopus Energy</a> who supply my energy have an agile tariff, which means the price of electricity changes every half hour depending on demand. I want to move the heavy usage of electricity to cheaper parts of the day, so I can save money.</p> <p>If you want to support me do check out my <a href="https://www.funkysi1701.com/referral-links">referral links</a> we could both get ¬£50 if you sign up with Octopus Energy to supply your energy.</p> <h2 id="now-how-did-i-get-this-all-setup">Now how did I get this all setup?<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#now-how-did-i-get-this-all-setup"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p>1 - Plug a smart plug into a power socket and start measuring power. The app &ldquo;Smart Life&rdquo; is used to connect to the smart plug and get the power readings and is available in the Android store.</p> <p>2 - Integrate each smart plug into Home Assistant. The integration you need is the <a href="https://www.home-assistant.io/integrations/tuya" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Tuya</a> integration. A User Code from the Smart Life app is needed to add to Home Assistant.</p> <p>3 - The Voltage, Power and Current sensors are all defaulted to off in Home Assistant, so you need to go and enable these, once that is done you can see the power usage in Home Assistant.</p> <p>4 - Now you have Watts, Amps and Volts in Home Assistant but the Energy section of Home Assistant requires Wh or KWh. To get this you need to use the Integral helper to get the amount of time that the device is on for. Go to Add Integration and search for Integral (helper)</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="Electricity Usage" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/elec-usage3.png" loading="lazy" width="611" height="917" /> </p> <ul> <li>Name is the user friendly name of the device.</li> <li>Metric prefix is the unit of measurement, in this case KWh.</li> <li>Time of Unit is Hours</li> <li>Entity is the sensor that is measuring the power usage.</li> <li>Integration method use Left Riemann sum</li> <li>Precision is the number of decimal places, so fine to use 0 here.</li> <li>Max Sub Interval is 5 minutes</li> </ul> <p>This gives you an extra sensor in Home Assistant which is the energy usage of the device. In my case in kWh.</p> <p>5 - Go to your Energy Dashboard in Home Assistant and go to Energy Configuration. Add the new sensor to the Individual Devices section and you can see the energy usage of the device over time.</p> <p>The accuracy is not brilliant, sometimes it looks like I have used more energy in my devices than my smart meter says I have used in total. However it is a good indicator of what is using the most electricity in your house. Leave it running for a few days, you may have to tweak the Integral helper settings to get the best results.</p> <p>The <a href="https://community.home-assistant.io/t/added-tuya-smart-plugs-where-is-the-energy-monitoring/356746/16" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Home Assistant Forums</a> are great for getting this sort of thing setup, I have found a lot of useful information on there.</p>
              - generic [ref=e1666]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e1668]: </item>
