              - generic [ref=e1722]: <description>
              - text: "<h2 id=\"what-is-net-aspire\">What is .Net Aspire?<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#what-is-net-aspire\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>.Net Aspire is a comprehensive set of tools, templates, and packages designed to simplify the development of cloud-native applications using .Net. It focuses on building observable, production-ready apps by providing a consistent and opinionated set of <a href=\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/aspire/get-started/aspire-overview\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">tools and patterns</a> .</p> <p>The key features of .Net Aspire:</p> <ul> <li>Orchestration: Enhances the local development experience by simplifying the management of your app&rsquo;s configuration and interconnections. It helps with app composition, service discovery, and connection string management.</li> <li>Integrations: Offers NuGet packages for commonly used services like Redis and Postgres, ensuring they connect consistently and seamlessly with your app.</li> <li>Tooling: Comes with project templates and tooling experiences for Visual Studio, Visual Studio Code, and the .Net CLI to help you create and interact with .Net Aspire projects.</li> </ul> <p>Overall, <a href=\"https://devblogs.microsoft.com/dotnet/introducing-dotnet-aspire-simplifying-cloud-native-development-with-dotnet-8/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">.Net Aspire</a> aims to improve the experience of building .Net cloud-native apps by providing a robust framework for developing distributed applications.</p> <p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"Aspire\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/aspire-ga-what-is-aspire.png\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"1400\" height=\"895\" /> </p> <h2 id=\"getting-started-with-net-aspire\">Getting started with .Net Aspire<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#getting-started-with-net-aspire\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>I touched on .Net Aspire last week, when I talked about what was new in <a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2024/dotnet9\">dotnet 9</a> , but let&rsquo;s walk through an example.</p> <p>Lets say you have a simple application. It has a Blazor web front end, it communicates with a .Net API and that API retrieves data from a SQL Server database. Before Aspire came along I would create a docker compose file and configure ports so the FE could call the API, and add connection strings so the API could access the database.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-docker-compose.yml\" data-lang=\"docker-compose.yml\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#f92672\">services</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">Api</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">image</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">${DOCKER_REGISTRY-}api</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">container_name</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">api</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">ports</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> - <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">12345</span>:<span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">80</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> - <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">44338</span>:<span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">443</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">networks</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> - <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">my-network</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">build</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">context</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">.</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">dockerfile</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">API/Dockerfile</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">depends_on</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> - <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">sqlserver</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">Ui</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">image</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">${DOCKER_REGISTRY-}ui</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">container_name</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">ui</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">ports</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> - <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">44330</span>:<span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">443</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">networks</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> - <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">my-network</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">build</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">context</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">.</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">dockerfile</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">UI/Dockerfile</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">environment</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> - <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">APIPath=http://Api:80</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">sqlserver</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">image</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">${DOCKER_REGISTRY-}sql</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">container_name</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">sql</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">volumes</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> - <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">sqlvol:/var/opt/mssql</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">ports</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> - <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;5432:1433&#34;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">networks</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> - <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">my-network</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">build</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">context</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">.</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">dockerfile</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">Database/Dockerfile</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>As you can see from this docker compose file, there is a lot of specifying ports and other plumbing to get these three parts of my system to work together.</p> <p>Now in Visual Studio, right-click on the API project and select add <strong>.Net Aspire Orchestrator Support</strong> this will add two new Visual Studio projects to the solution, AppHost and ServiceDefaults.</p> <ul> <li>AppHost is where you configure what service depends on what, you can configure all sorts of different dependencies, like databases (sql server, mysql, postgres etc), rabbitmq, redis and many others.</li> <li>ServiceDefaults is where you configure the defaults for your services, like how opentelemetry should be configured, or how logging should work.</li> </ul> <p>Now right click on the Blazor project and select the same option to get that wired up as well.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-program.cs\" data-lang=\"program.cs\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> builder = DistributedApplication.CreateBuilder(args); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>builder.AddProject&lt;Projects.UI&gt;(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;ui&#34;</span>); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>builder.AddProject&lt;Projects.API&gt;(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;api&#34;</span>); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>builder.Build().Run(); </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Your Program.cs file inside your AppHost project will look something like this now, with both your API and UI/Blazor projects referenced.</p> <p>There is one more component we need to wire up, but we don&rsquo;t have a project to right click on for the database. It is fairly straightforward to do, update it to look like the following:</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-program.cs\" data-lang=\"program.cs\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> builder = DistributedApplication.CreateBuilder(args); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> sqldb = builder.AddSqlServer(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;sql&#34;</span>) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> .WithDataVolume(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;sql-data&#34;</span>) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> .AddDatabase(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;Context&#34;</span>, <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;Project&#34;</span>); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> api = builder.AddProject&lt;Projects.API&gt;(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;api&#34;</span>) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> .WaitFor(sqldb) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> .WithReference(sqldb); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>builder.AddProject&lt;Projects.UI&gt;(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;ui&#34;</span>) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> .WaitFor(api) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> .WithReference(api); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">await</span> builder.Build().RunAsync(); </span></span></code></pre></div><p>You also need to install a couple of nuget packages. <strong>Aspire.Hosting.SqlServer</strong> and <strong>Aspire.Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.SqlServer</strong> the second one is because my project is using Entity Framework. Lets look at what we have, we are defining a SQL Server called sql, with a data volume called sql-data, and a database called Project, which we can refer to as Context. We then configure API to reference the sql server we have just configured, and wait for sql server to be ready before starting the API. Next the Blazor project depends on the API and will wait for that to be ready before starting. Pretty powerful stuff.</p> <p>OK lets look at the API project, what do I need to configure in my connectionstrings? Not much, Aspire will fill all of this in for you.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-appsettings.json\" data-lang=\"appsettings.json\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;ConnectionStrings&#34;</span><span style=\"color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010\">:</span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">&#34;Context&#34;</span>: <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;&#34;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span></code></pre></div><p>In your API project, your Program.cs will need a nuget package <strong>Aspire.Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.SqlServer</strong> and the following line, and no need for any pulling config and passing in connection strings.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-program.cs\" data-lang=\"program.cs\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>builder.AddSqlServerDbContext&lt;Context&gt;(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;Context&#34;</span>); </span></span></code></pre></div><p>One more clever thing we can do with Aspire is seed some data into my database before starting the project. Update the code that sets up your database in the AppHost project as follows.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-program.cs\" data-lang=\"program.cs\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> sqldb = builder.AddSqlServer(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;sql&#34;</span>) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> .WithBindMount(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;./sqlserverconfig&#34;</span>, <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;/usr/config&#34;</span>) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> .WithBindMount(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;../API/data/sqlserver&#34;</span>, <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;/docker-entrypoint-initdb.d&#34;</span>) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> .WithEntrypoint(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;/usr/config/entrypoint.sh&#34;</span>) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> .WithDataVolume(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;sql-data&#34;</span>) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> .AddDatabase(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;Context&#34;</span>, <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;Project&#34;</span>) </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Add a sqlserverconfig folder inside your AppHost project and add the following two files. I have found entrypoint.sh being a bit picky with its line endings (windows vs linux)</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-entrypoint.sh\" data-lang=\"entrypoint.sh\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\">#!/bin/bash </span></span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\"># Adapted from: https://github.com/microsoft/mssql-docker/blob/80e2a51d0eb1693f2de014fb26d4a414f5a5add5/linux/preview/examples/mssql-customize/entrypoint.sh</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\"># Start the script to create the DB and user</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>/usr/config/configure-db.sh &amp; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\"># Start SQL Server</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>/opt/mssql/bin/sqlservr </span></span></code></pre></div><div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-configure-db.sh\" data-lang=\"configure-db.sh\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\">#!/bin/bash </span></span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\"># set -x</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\"># Adapted from: https://github.com/microsoft/mssql-docker/blob/80e2a51d0eb1693f2de014fb26d4a414f5a5add5/linux/preview/examples/mssql-customize/configure-db.sh</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\"># Wait 60 seconds for SQL Server to start up by ensuring that</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\"># calling SQLCMD does not return an error code, which will ensure that sqlcmd is accessible</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\"># and that system and user databases return &#34;0&#34; which means all databases are in an &#34;online&#34; state</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\"># https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/relational-databases/system-catalog-views/sys-databases-transact-sql?view=sql-server-2017</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>dbstatus<span style=\"color:#f92672\">=</span><span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">1</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>errcode<span style=\"color:#f92672\">=</span><span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">1</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>start_time<span style=\"color:#f92672\">=</span>$SECONDS </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>end_by<span style=\"color:#f92672\">=</span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">$((</span>start_time <span style=\"color:#f92672\">+</span> <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">60</span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">))</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>echo <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;Starting check for SQL Server start-up at </span>$start_time<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">, will end at </span>$end_by<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">while</span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">[[</span> $SECONDS -lt $end_by <span style=\"color:#f92672\">&amp;&amp;</span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">(</span> $errcode -ne <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">0</span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">||</span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">(</span> -z <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;</span>$dbstatus<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;</span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">||</span> $dbstatus -ne <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">0</span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">)</span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">)</span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">]]</span>; <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">do</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> dbstatus<span style=\"color:#f92672\">=</span><span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;</span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">$(</span>/opt/mssql-tools18/bin/sqlcmd -h -1 -t <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">1</span> -U sa -P <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;</span>$MSSQL_SA_PASSWORD<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;</span> -C -Q <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;SET NOCOUNT ON; Select SUM(state) from sys.databases&#34;</span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">)</span><span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> errcode<span style=\"color:#f92672\">=</span>$? </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> sleep <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">1</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">done</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>elapsed_time<span style=\"color:#f92672\">=</span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">$((</span>SECONDS <span style=\"color:#f92672\">-</span> start_time<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">))</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>echo <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;Stopped checking for SQL Server start-up after </span>$elapsed_time<span style=\"color:#e6db74\"> seconds (dbstatus=</span>$dbstatus<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">,errcode=</span>$errcode<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">,seconds=</span>$SECONDS<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">)&#34;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">if</span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">[[</span> $dbstatus -ne <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">0</span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">]]</span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">||</span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">[[</span> $errcode -ne <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">0</span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">]]</span>; <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">then</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> echo <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;SQL Server took more than 60 seconds to start up or one or more databases are not in an ONLINE state&#34;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> echo <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;dbstatus = </span>$dbstatus<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> echo <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;errcode = </span>$errcode<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> exit <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">1</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">fi</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\"># Loop through the .sql files in the /docker-entrypoint-initdb.d and execute them with sqlcmd</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">for</span> f in /docker-entrypoint-initdb.d/*.sql </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">do</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> echo <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;Processing </span>$f<span style=\"color:#e6db74\"> file...&#34;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> /opt/mssql-tools18/bin/sqlcmd -S localhost -U sa -P <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;</span>$MSSQL_SA_PASSWORD<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;</span> -C -d master -i <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;</span>$f<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">done</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>The second BindMount line mounts a folder inside your API project, so add a data folder with a subfolder called sqlserver. Inside that add a sql script called init.sql. Put all your CREATE DATABASE and CREATE TABLES sql commands inside this. And if everything works you will have a seeded DB ready to test your application with.</p> <h2 id=\"conclusion\">Conclusion<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#conclusion\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>This is just a few things I have done with Aspire. Go check out the docs on <a href=\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/aspire/get-started/aspire-overview\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">MS learn</a> or the some of the sessions from <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fiePiEc1qcU&amp;list=PLdo4fOcmZ0oXeSG8BgCVru3zQtw_K4ANY&amp;index=2\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">dotnet conf</a> .</p>"

              - generic [ref=e1787]: <description>
              - text: <p>Every November it is like Christmas for .NET developers, as Microsoft releases the next version of .NET. This year is no different, and we have version 9 of .NET to play with. This release is packed with new features and improvements across the board.</p> <p>If you haven&rsquo;t already head on over to the <a href="https://dotnet.microsoft.com/download/dotnet/9.0" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">dotnet website</a> and download the latest version.</p> <p>Also we get a brand new version of Visual Studio, which is always a good thing, so head on over to the Visual Studio <a href="https://visualstudio.microsoft.com/downloads/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">website</a> and download the latest version (or the Preview version if you want to test what is coming out next).</p> <p>Back when .Net 7 came out I wrote a <a href="https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2022/dotnet7/">post</a> about what you needed to fix to get the latest version working with your existing code. However this time around the upgrade is really smooth.</p> <h2 id="nuget-audit">NuGet Audit<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#nuget-audit"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p>Back in .Net 8 NuGet Audit was introduced which told you if any of your packages had security vulnerabilities. This has been improved in .Net 9, and now defaults to tell you about transitive dependencies. This is a great feature, but if you would prefer to keep .Net 8&rsquo;s functionality you can add the following to your project (*.csproj) file.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" style="color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;"><code class="language-xml" data-lang="xml"><span style="display:flex;"><span> <span style="color:#f92672">&lt;NuGetAuditMode&gt;</span>direct<span style="color:#f92672">&lt;/NuGetAuditMode&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><h2 id="net-aspire">.Net Aspire<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#net-aspire"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p>Released just after .Net 8 .Net Aspire is a suite of tools to help develop microservices. Gone are the days of specifying ports and connection strings for your services, Aspire can handle this all programmatically.</p> <p>Aspire adds two new projects to your solution. AppHost and ServiceDefaults.</p> <ul> <li>AppHost is where you configure what service depends on what, you can configure all sorts of different dependencies, like databases (sql server, mysql, postgres etc), rabbitmq, redis and many others. It is open source so the community are busy adding everything you could possibly need.</li> <li>ServiceDefaults is where you configure the defaults for your services, like how opentelemetry should be configured, or how logging should work. Microsoft have thought hard about this and come up with some opinionated defaults, but you can change these to suit your needs.</li> </ul> <p>Starting the AppHost project will start up the Aspire Dashboard where you can start/stop containers, view logs and see the health of your services. This is primarily a devlopment tool, but there are some deployment tools, however I have not explored these much yet. More details about Aspire can be found <a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/aspire/get-started/aspire-overview" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">here</a> </p> <h2 id="blazor">Blazor<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#blazor"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p>I have been using Blazor since the first previews in the .Net 3.1 days. It has come a long way since then, and now with .Net 9 it is even better.</p> <p>There has been some optimization of the delivery of static assets. To take advantage of this improvement, replace the following line in your Program.cs file.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" style="color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;"><code class="language-csharp" data-lang="csharp"><span style="display:flex;"><span> app.MapStaticAssets(); <span style="color:#75715e">//Add this line</span> </span></span><span style="display:flex;"><span> app.UseStaticFiles(); <span style="color:#75715e">//Remove this line</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>.Net 9 will then cache your static assets ang give them a unique filename. This will allow the browser to cache the files for longer, and only download them when they have changed. This will speed up your site and reduce the amount of data transferred.</p> <p>In your razor pages use code similar to this:</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" style="color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;"><code class="language-html" data-lang="html"><span style="display:flex;"><span>&lt;<span style="color:#f92672">link</span> <span style="color:#a6e22e">rel</span><span style="color:#f92672">=</span><span style="color:#e6db74">&#34;stylesheet&#34;</span> <span style="color:#a6e22e">href</span><span style="color:#f92672">=</span><span style="color:#e6db74">&#34;@Assets[&#34;</span><span style="color:#a6e22e">bootstrap</span><span style="color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010">/</span><span style="color:#a6e22e">bootstrap</span><span style="color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010">.</span><span style="color:#a6e22e">min</span><span style="color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010">.</span><span style="color:#a6e22e">css</span><span style="color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010">&#34;]&#34;</span> /&gt; </span></span><span style="display:flex;"><span>&lt;<span style="color:#f92672">link</span> <span style="color:#a6e22e">rel</span><span style="color:#f92672">=</span><span style="color:#e6db74">&#34;stylesheet&#34;</span> <span style="color:#a6e22e">href</span><span style="color:#f92672">=</span><span style="color:#e6db74">&#34;@Assets[&#34;</span><span style="color:#a6e22e">app</span><span style="color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010">.</span><span style="color:#a6e22e">css</span><span style="color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010">&#34;]&#34;</span> /&gt; </span></span><span style="display:flex;"><span>&lt;<span style="color:#f92672">link</span> <span style="color:#a6e22e">rel</span><span style="color:#f92672">=</span><span style="color:#e6db74">&#34;stylesheet&#34;</span> <span style="color:#a6e22e">href</span><span style="color:#f92672">=</span><span style="color:#e6db74">&#34;@Assets[&#34;</span><span style="color:#a6e22e">BlazorSample</span><span style="color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010">.</span><span style="color:#a6e22e">styles</span><span style="color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010">.</span><span style="color:#a6e22e">css</span><span style="color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010">&#34;]&#34;</span> /&gt; </span></span></code></pre></div><h2 id="ai">AI<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#ai"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p>It will have not escaped your notice that AI is everywhere, and it is no different with .Net. I saw some very impressive demos at the <a href="https://www.dotnetconf.net/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">.Net Conf</a> online conference. I encourage you to check our the videos. But to summarize Microsoft have added a bunch of abstractions to make it easier to write code to talk to the different AI models, I haven&rsquo;t played about with AI much yet, but I am tempted to give it a go.</p> <h2 id="sql-management-studio">SQL Management Studio<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#sql-management-studio"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p>I have not used SQL Management Studio for a while as I have trying out Azure Data Studio. However a new Preview of SQL Server Management Studio is now <a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/ssms/ssms-21/release-notes-21?view=sql-server-ver16" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">avaliable</a> . This version is 64bit and is based on Visual Studio engine, it even shares the same installer.</p> <h2 id="conclusion">Conclusion<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#conclusion"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p>This is only a small taste of the new features in .Net 9. Go check out .Net Conf to learn more or check out some of the links I have shared above.</p>

              - generic [ref=e1798]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e1799]:
              - generic [ref=e1800]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2024/strategy-pattern/

              - generic [ref=e1803]: <author>

              - generic [ref=e1804]: </author>

              - generic [ref=e1806]: <pubDate>

              - generic [ref=e1807]: </pubDate>

              - generic [ref=e1809]: <guid>

              - generic [ref=e1810]: </guid>

              - text: designpatterns

            - generic [ref=e1815]:
              - generic [ref=e1816]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e1817]: term="architecture"
                - text: ">"
              - text: architecture
              - generic [ref=e1818]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e1819]:

              - text: "<h2 id=\"understanding-the-strategy-design-pattern\">Understanding the Strategy Design Pattern.<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#understanding-the-strategy-design-pattern\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>In the world of software development, design patterns are essential tools that help developers solve common problems in a standardized way. One such pattern is the <strong>Strategy Design Pattern</strong>. This pattern is particularly useful when you need to define a family of algorithms, encapsulate each one, and make them interchangeable. Let&rsquo;s dive into what the Strategy Design Pattern is, why it&rsquo;s useful, and how you can implement it in your projects.</p> <h3 id=\"what-is-the-strategy-design-pattern\">What is the Strategy Design Pattern?<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#what-is-the-strategy-design-pattern\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>The Strategy Design Pattern falls under the category of behavioural design patterns. It enables an algorithm&rsquo;s behaviour to be selected at runtime. Instead of implementing a single algorithm directly, code receives run-time instructions as to which in a family of algorithms to use.</p> <h3 id=\"why-use-the-strategy-design-pattern\">Why Use the Strategy Design Pattern?<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#why-use-the-strategy-design-pattern\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>The primary benefits of using the Strategy Design Pattern include:</p> <ol> <li><strong>Flexibility</strong>: It allows you to change the algorithm or strategy being used without altering the code that uses the algorithm.</li> <li><strong>Reusability</strong>: By encapsulating algorithms separately, you can reuse them across different parts of your application.</li> <li><strong>Maintainability</strong>: It promotes cleaner code by adhering to the Single Responsibility Principle, making your code easier to maintain and extend.</li> </ol> <h3 id=\"how-to-implement-the-strategy-design-pattern\">How to Implement the Strategy Design Pattern<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#how-to-implement-the-strategy-design-pattern\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>Let&rsquo;s break down the implementation of the Strategy Design Pattern with a simple example. Suppose we are developing a flight simulator that supports multiple flying methods (e.g., Flapping like a bird, Jet Engine powered, and Warp Speed).</p> <h4 id=\"step-1-define-the-strategy-interface\">Step 1: Define the Strategy Interface<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#step-1-define-the-strategy-interface\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h4> <p>First, we define an interface that all payment strategies will implement.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">public</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">interface</span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">IFlyingStrategy</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>{ </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">void</span> Fly(); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>} </span></span></code></pre></div><h4 id=\"step-2-implement-concrete-strategies\">Step 2: Implement Concrete Strategies<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#step-2-implement-concrete-strategies\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h4> <p>Next, we create concrete classes that implement the IPaymentStrategy interface.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">public</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">class</span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">Bird</span> : IFlyingStrategy </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>{ </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">public</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">void</span> Fly() </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> Console.WriteLine(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;Flying like a bird&#34;</span>); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>} </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">public</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">class</span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">Plane</span> : IFlyingStrategy </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>{ </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">public</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">void</span> Fly() </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> Console.WriteLine(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;Flying using 21st century aviation fuel&#34;</span>); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>} </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">public</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">class</span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">StarShip</span> : IFlyingStrategy </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>{ </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">public</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">void</span> Fly() </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> Console.WriteLine(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;Flying using warp engines&#34;</span>); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>} </span></span></code></pre></div><h4 id=\"step-3-create-the-context-class\">Step 3: Create the Context Class<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#step-3-create-the-context-class\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h4> <p>The context class uses a IFlyingStrategy to perform the payment.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">public</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">class</span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">FlyContext</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>{ </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">private</span> IFlyingStrategy _flyingStrategy; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">public</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">void</span> SetPaymentStrategy(IFlyingStrategy flyingStrategy) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> _flyingStrategy = flyingStrategy; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">public</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">void</span> Fly() </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> _flyingStrategy.Fly(); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>} </span></span></code></pre></div><h4 id=\"step-4-use-the-strategy-pattern\">Step 4: Use the Strategy Pattern<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#step-4-use-the-strategy-pattern\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h4> <p>Finally, we use the FlyContext to fly with different strategies.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">class</span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">Program</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>{ </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">static</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">void</span> Main(<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span>[] args) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> FlyContext context = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> FlyContext(); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> context.SetPaymentStrategy(<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> StarShip()); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> context.Fly(); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> context.SetPaymentStrategy(<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> Plane()); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> context.Fly(); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> context.SetPaymentStrategy(<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> Bird()); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> context.Fly(); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>} </span></span></code></pre></div><h3 id=\"conclusion\">Conclusion<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#conclusion\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>The Strategy Design Pattern is a powerful tool that promotes flexibility, reusability, and maintainability in your code. By encapsulating algorithms and making them interchangeable, you can easily extend and modify your application without disrupting existing functionality. Whether you‚Äôre dealing with payment processing, flying machines, sorting algorithms, or any other scenario requiring dynamic behaviour, the Strategy Design Pattern can help you write cleaner and more efficient code.</p>"
              - generic [ref=e1825]: </description>

              - generic [ref=e1844]: </pubDate>

              - generic [ref=e1861]: <description>
              - text: <p>Code Clubs are free, welcoming spaces designed to introduce young people to the exciting world of programming and digital skills. Today, I had the pleasure of taking my son‚Äîan absolute coding enthusiast‚Äîto one of these sessions, held at Leeds Central Library.</p> <p>The club was hosted in a cozy room on the top floor of the library. Walking in, I expected rows of computers set up for traditional coding exercises. Instead, we found mysterious white lines taped onto the floor. Curious to find out what they were for, we soon learned they were meant to guide robots that the children would be programming. The instructor handed out iPads and small spherical robots known as Spheros, and the children were tasked with programming the robots to follow the lines.</p> <p>The iPads were preloaded with easy-to-use software that felt familiar to those who&rsquo;ve used Scratch, a popular block-based coding language. By simply dragging and dropping blocks of code, the kids controlled the robots‚Äô movements. Each &ldquo;move&rdquo; block had three variables‚Äîdirection, speed, and duration‚Äîthat the children could adjust to guide the robot along the lines.</p> <p>It was a great hands-on learning experience. My son and I faced a bit of trial and error to figure out which way the robot saw as &ldquo;forward,&rdquo; but soon enough, our Sphero was gliding smoothly along the first line. As we went along, we added &ldquo;pause&rdquo; blocks between movements, which made the robot stop before changing direction, adding a nice rhythm to its journey along the lines.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/20241102_104220.jpg" loading="lazy" width="854" height="384" /> </p> <p>Once the main task was completed, there was time for the kids to explore other features. We experimented with different commands, making a smile or frown appear on the robot‚Äôs LED display, while others programmed their Spheros to zip around the room, flashing lights and making playful noises.</p> <p>The club meets every two weeks, and both my son and I left feeling thrilled with the experience. We‚Äôre already looking forward to the next session!</p> <p>If you&rsquo;re interested in finding a Code Club near you check out <a href="https://codeclub.org/en/find" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">https://codeclub.org/en/find</a> , alternatively, <a href="https://codeclub.org" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">https://codeclub.org</a> has lots of resources to explain what code clubs are all about.</p>
              - generic [ref=e1862]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e1864]: </item>

          - generic [ref=e1868]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e1869]:
            - generic [ref=e1870]:
              - generic [ref=e1871]: <title>
              - text: Scottish Summit 2024
              - generic [ref=e1872]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e1873]:
              - generic [ref=e1874]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2024/scottishsummit/
              - generic [ref=e1875]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e1876]:
              - generic [ref=e1877]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e1878]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e1879]:
              - generic [ref=e1880]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 28 Oct 2024 18:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e1881]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e1882]:
              - generic [ref=e1883]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2024/scottishsummit/
              - generic [ref=e1884]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e1885]:
              - generic [ref=e1886]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e1887]: term="conference"
                - text: ">"
              - text: conference
              - generic [ref=e1888]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e1889]:
              - generic [ref=e1890]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e1891]: term="microsoft"
                - text: ">"
              - text: microsoft
              - generic [ref=e1892]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e1893]:
              - generic [ref=e1894]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e1895]: term="community"
                - text: ">"
              - text: community
              - generic [ref=e1896]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e1897]:
              - generic [ref=e1898]: <description>
              - text: "<p>Scottish Summit 2024 took place in Aberdeen on October 18th and 19th at the P&amp;J Live Arena, and I was fortunate enough to attend.</p> <h2 id=\"friday\">Friday<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#friday\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>The first full day of the conference, Friday the 18th, began with the unmistakable sound of bagpipers welcoming attendees at the venue‚Äîan echo of the 2022 event that reminded us all of the conference&rsquo;s Scottish roots. Registration was quick and seamless; all I needed was my QR code ticket to receive a unique lanyard made of seed paper‚Äîperfect for planting flowers in the spring.</p> <p>Scott Hanselman was the keynote speaker, and I spotted him mingling with other attendees. I almost asked him for a selfie but decided against it. His keynote, titled &ldquo;AI: Hero or Villain,&rdquo; was compelling. He demystified ChatGPT, explaining that it‚Äôs not magic but rather a product of machine learning, using mathematics to predict the next word in a sentence.</p> <p>Next, MVP Vesa Nopanen delivered his talk on &ldquo;Supercharge Your Teams Meetings.&rdquo; I picked up some valuable tips, particularly the importance of adding notes and agendas to enhance meeting effectiveness.</p> <p><img src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/images/GaKpRZ3WIAAFsIW.jpg\" style=\"padding-right: 7px\" align=\"left\" /> Following that, a couple of the Scottish Summit organizers discussed the technology behind the event. They explained how they used Stripe for payments, integrating it with Power Automate and Power Pages. I found this particularly interesting for a charity event; it demonstrated a commitment to learning while keeping costs manageable.</p> <p>The next session explored what it means to be a modern full-stack software developer, focusing on integrating Power Apps with traditional web development. As someone new to Power Apps, I learned that starting with it can be beneficial, filling gaps with .NET or conventional web development as needed.</p> <p>I then attended a session on public speaking. Although I‚Äôve never given a talk at a conference, hearing about others&rsquo; journeys was encouraging and prompted me to consider my own potential in this area.</p> <p>The final session of Friday featured Microsoft‚Äôs Sarah Lean, who shared how her hobbies‚Äîspecifically curling‚Äîhave influenced her work life. This talk made me reflect on my own hobbies and their impact on my professional journey.</p> <p>The evening wrapped up with a drag cabaret, which exceeded my expectations. Several brave community members dressed up and participated in the show, all in support of the conference&rsquo;s charity, TIE.</p> <h2 id=\"saturday\">Saturday<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#saturday\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>Saturday kicked off with a dive into the world of wizards and D&amp;D in a session titled &ldquo;Securing the Realm: DM-less D&amp;D with Azure AI.&rdquo; This practical talk demonstrated how AI can be utilized in running D&amp;D games, discussing essential guardrails and effective AI prompts.</p> <p>Another engaging talk, &ldquo;Community - It Just Makes Sense,&rdquo; highlighted the tech community&rsquo;s role in career development. I realized that I‚Äôve only just scratched the surface of community involvement, and I‚Äôm eager to explore it further.</p> <img src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/images/GaP4xTOW0AA6VHI.jpg\" style=\"padding-left: 7px\" align=\"right\" /> <p>Sarah Lean returned to discuss KQL (Kusto Query Language), which Application Insights uses for querying data. Although I&rsquo;ve encountered KQL before, learning more about it was fascinating.</p> <p>The &ldquo;Ask the Azure Experts&rdquo; panel featured four Azure MVPs and Sarah Lean, who answered questions about Azure migration and cost management, sharing numerous helpful insights.</p> <p>&ldquo;Who&rsquo;s Afraid of a Little Ole Copilot?&rdquo; presented by Dona Sarkar and her colleagues, was a captivating exploration of how Copilots function within the Microsoft ecosystem. It featured various speakers I had encountered throughout the conference, demonstrating the interactivity of Microsoft‚Äôs services, from Purview to Responsible AI. It was a fun and enlightening way to close the conference.</p> <p>Saturday evening featured a pub quiz and the UK Community Awards ceremony, where dedicated community members were recognized for their hard work. Our quiz team, led by MVP Vesa Nopanen and humorously named &ldquo;Vogon Poets,&rdquo; finished 14th‚Äîcomplete with silly hats. It was a delightful opportunity to socialize with teammates and was one of the highlights of the conference.</p> <h2 id=\"conclusion\">Conclusion<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#conclusion\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>In summary, Scottish Summit 2024 was an exceptionally well-organized conference. As a .NET developer, I found a limited number of directly relevant sessions, but the true value lay in the community. I reconnected with familiar faces and met new friends, especially during the pub quiz.</p> <p>I left feeling inspired to become more involved in the community and participate in future events. The sessions on public speaking, community engagement, and hobbies underscored the importance of soft skills in the tech world.</p> <p>And yes, I caught a glimpse of Scott Hanselman, which was quite a thrill!</p> <img src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/images/GaKSNJeXwAA-xyr.jpg\" style=\"padding-right: 7px\" align=\"left\" />"
              - generic [ref=e1899]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e1901]: </item>

          - generic [ref=e1905]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e1906]:
            - generic [ref=e1907]:
              - generic [ref=e1908]: <title>
              - text: Funky Si walks a half marathon
              - generic [ref=e1909]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e1910]:
              - generic [ref=e1911]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2024/charity-hike/
              - generic [ref=e1912]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e1913]:
              - generic [ref=e1914]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e1915]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e1916]:
              - generic [ref=e1917]: <pubDate>
              - text: Sun, 18 Feb 2024 11:00:00 +0000
              - generic [ref=e1918]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e1919]:
              - generic [ref=e1920]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2024/charity-hike/
              - generic [ref=e1921]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e1922]:
              - generic [ref=e1923]: <description>
              - text: <p>On June 8th I will walk 13 miles near Bakewell in the Peak District to raise ¬£250 (or more) for Cancer Research. To sponsor me click <a href="https://fundraise.cancerresearchuk.org/page/funkysi1701" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">fundraise.cancerresearchuk.org/page/funkysi1701</a> , to find out more about the event go <a href="https://www.cancerresearchuk.org/get-involved/find-an-event/big-hike/big-hike-peak-district" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">www.cancerresearchuk.org/get-involved/find-an-event/big-hike/big-hike-peak-district</a> </p> <h2 id="so-why-am-i-doing-this">So why am I doing this?<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#so-why-am-i-doing-this"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <img src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/images/fsi-hike-route.png" alt="Hike Route" width="400px" style="float:left;padding-right:8px" /> I am a Software Developer in my day to day life, which does not involve a lot of physical activity. I have become very lazy. Doing a half marathon is completely outside of my comfort zone and is not at all a me thing to do. <p>However last year I realised my mental health was starting to degrade. I have a family which keeps me very busy, I am facing lots of challenges with this, other members of my family have mental health issues which is starting to have a knock on affect on me.</p> <p>I mentioned some of these challenges to a friend who suggested I join a walking group which was helping people with mental health problems. I went along and to my surprise I really enjoyed myself, the people were friendly and I enjoyed the walk in the countryside. After this I went out and bought some proper walking shoes</p> <p>I went to the next one, and the next one and each time I enjoyed myself. I must admit that after these walks it tired me out due to my unfit nature, but it was worth it as for a few hours I wasn&rsquo;t thinking about the 101 problems that I had no solutions for.</p> <p>Fast forward to about a week ago, an advert for this charity walk popped up on facebook. I took a look at it and I started thinking. The 10k was a similar distance I had done on one of my walks, so I could easily do that. What if I could raise some money for a charity and go for a fun walk? For the next few days I kept thinking about it. Eventually I booked it. My thinking was if I am going to do something for charity I need to push myself outside of my comfort zone. I would never manage a full marathon, but what about a half marathon?</p> <p>So tomorrow I start training, every day or so I walk for about 40 minutes, I will probably post some updates on my <a href="https://fundraise.cancerresearchuk.org/page/funkysi1701" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">charity page</a> as no doubt I will struggle to keep going.</p> <p>Please if you can think about donating, and give me some encouragement I think I am going to need it.</p>
              - generic [ref=e1924]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e1926]: </item>

              - text: "<h2 id=\"trek-ranks-174-top-5-ensemble-episodes\">Trek Ranks #174: Top 5 Ensemble Episodes<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#trek-ranks-174-top-5-ensemble-episodes\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>I was recently invited onto the <a href=\"https://www.trekranks.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">TrekRanks</a> podcast.               - text: <h2 id="2024">2024<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#2024"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <table> <thead> <tr> <th>Event/Talk</th> <th>Date</th> <th>Location</th> </tr> </thead> <tbody> <tr> <td>Yorkshire Azure</td> <td>19 November 2024</td> <td>York</td> </tr> <tr> <td>Code Club</td> <td>16 November 2024</td> <td>Leeds Library</td> </tr> <tr> <td><a href="https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2024/codeclub">Code Club</a> </td> <td>2 November 2024</td> <td>Leeds Library</td> </tr> <tr> <td>Scottish Summit</td> <td>17-19 October 2024</td> <td>Aberdeen</td> </tr> <tr> <td>DDD North</td> <td>2 March 2024</td> <td>Hull</td> </tr> </tbody> </table>

          - generic [ref=e1993]:
            - generic [ref=e1994]:
              - generic [ref=e1995]: <title>
              - text: Make API calls from Visual Studio or Visual Studio Code
              - generic [ref=e1996]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e1997]:
              - generic [ref=e1998]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2023/make-api-calls-from-visual-studio/
              - generic [ref=e1999]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e2000]:
              - generic [ref=e2001]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e2002]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e2003]:
              - generic [ref=e2004]: <pubDate>
              - text: Sun, 19 Nov 2023 22:50:00 +0000
              - generic [ref=e2005]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e2006]:
              - generic [ref=e2007]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2023/make-api-calls-from-visual-studio/
              - generic [ref=e2008]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e2009]:
              - generic [ref=e2010]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e2011]: term="VisualStudio"
                - text: ">"
              - text: VisualStudio
              - generic [ref=e2012]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e2013]:
              - generic [ref=e2014]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e2015]: term="API"
                - text: ">"
              - text: API
              - generic [ref=e2016]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e2017]:
              - generic [ref=e2018]: <description>
              - text: "<p>It is that exciting time of year where Microsoft announce a new version of .Net (Version 8 this time) and Visual Studio. There have been lots of announcements which I am still digesting, but one that caught my eye was a new window in Visual Studio that shows all your API endpoints.</p> <p>The new window is called <strong>Endpoint Explorer</strong> and can be added from the menu <strong>View &gt; Other Windows &gt; Endpoint Explorer</strong>.</p> <p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"Endpoint Explorer\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/endpoint-explorer.png\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"400\" height=\"434\" /> </p> <p>If you right click on one of the endpoints you can view the code or send a request. It works with minimal APIs or standard MVC APIs. If you select send a request a .http file will be created, this is a feature that has been in Visual Studio for a while but I haven&rsquo;t taken much notice.</p> <p>The syntax for writing these API calls is fairly simple</p> <pre tabindex=\"0\"><code>GET {{Catalog.API_HostAddress}}/api/v1/catalog/items </code></pre><p>Or something more complex, this one is a POST with a body and a header. This is how you might call APIs which require authentication. Just include a header with your auth token.</p> <pre tabindex=\"0\"><code>POST {{Catalog.API_HostAddress}}/api/v1/catalog/items Accept: application/json { &#34;name&#34;: &#34;Test&#34;, &#34;description&#34;: &#34;Test&#34;, &#34;price&#34;: 1.99, &#34;pictureFileName&#34;: &#34;test.png&#34;, &#34;pictureUri&#34;: &#34;https://picsum.photos/200/300&#34; } </code></pre><p>You can also set up various variables at the top of your .http files by prefixing with an @, by default you get one that defines your base URL, but you can add more.</p> <p>eg @variable = value</p> <p>Full docs of how you use .http files can be found <a href=\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/core/test/http-files?view=aspnetcore-8.0\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">here</a> </p> <p>A hyperlink above each API call in your .http file is labelled Send request. This initiates the API call and your window splits in half with the right hand side displaying the response.</p> <p>The response has four tabs, a nicely json formatted response, a raw response, a headers tab and a request tab.</p> <p>Now you will notice an env box underneath your file tabs, where the method dropdown is in a normal c# class file. It took me a while to figure out how to setup environments, but you can add a file that contain environment specific config, like base URL for test/prod/dev etc.</p> <p>This blog post tells me about it <a href=\"https://devblogs.microsoft.com/visualstudio/safely-use-secrets-in-http-requests-in-visual-studio-2022/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">here</a> but the main thing is you need to add a json file called <strong>http-client.env.json</strong> and create some json like this:</p> <pre tabindex=\"0\"><code> &#34;local&#34;: { &#34;Api_HostAddress&#34;: &#34;http://localhost:44338&#34; }, &#34;dev&#34;: { &#34;Api_HostAddress&#34;: &#34;https://dev.example.com&#34; }, &#34;test&#34;: { &#34;Api_HostAddress&#34;: &#34;https://test.example.com&#34; }, &#34;prod&#34;: { &#34;Api_HostAddress&#34;: &#34;https://prod.example.com&#34; } </code></pre><p>Other environment specific variables can be added in the same way. Now you can easily call your API in different environments without having to change the URL each time.</p> <h2 id=\"but-what-about-vs-code\">But what about VS Code?<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#but-what-about-vs-code\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>Well it turns out that VS Code has a similar feature, but it is not enabled by default. You need to install the <a href=\"https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=humao.rest-client\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">REST Client</a> extension. Once installed you can create a .http file and start making API calls. The syntax is very similar to Visual Studio.</p> <p>VS Code has a similar concept of environments. Go to Extensions &gt; REST Client &gt; Extension Settings and click on Edit in settings.json. Add the same settings we used with VS to your settings.json file. You can now switch environments from the command palette &ldquo;Rest Client: Switch Environment&rdquo; and select the environment you want to use.</p> <p>You can make use of the response of one API call in the request of another.</p> <pre tabindex=\"0\"><code>### 1st API Call # @name login POST {{Catalog.API_HostAddress}}/api/v1/identity/login Content-Type: application/json { &#34;user&#34;: &#34;username&#34;, &#34;password&#34;: &#34;password&#34; } ### 2nd API Call GET {{Catalog.API_HostAddress}}/api/v1/catalog/items Authorization: Bearer {{login.response.body.token}} Content-Type: application/json </code></pre><p>The last feature of VS Code I want to mention is that it can make GQL calls.</p> <pre tabindex=\"0\"><code>POST {{Catalog.API_HostAddress}}/graphql X-REQUEST-TYPE: GraphQL Content-Type: application/json Authorization: Bearer {{login.response.body.token}} query ($name: String!, $owner: String!) { repository(name: $name, owner: $owner) { name fullName: nameWithOwner description diskUsage forkCount stargazers(first: 5) { totalCount nodes { login name } } watchers { totalCount } } } { &#34;name&#34;: &#34;vscode-restclient&#34;, &#34;owner&#34;: &#34;Huachao&#34; } </code></pre><p>Sorry postman but I think I have a new favourite tool for making API calls.</p>"
              - generic [ref=e2019]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e2021]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e2022]:

              - generic [ref=e2047]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e2048]: term="PatrickStewart"
                - text: ">"
              - text: PatrickStewart
              - generic [ref=e2049]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e2050]:
              - generic [ref=e2051]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e2052]: term="Goals"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Goals
              - generic [ref=e2053]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e2054]:
              - generic [ref=e2055]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e2056]: term="JoseHernandez"
                - text: ">"
              - text: JoseHernandez
              - generic [ref=e2057]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e2058]:
              - generic [ref=e2059]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e2060]: term="continuousimprovement"
                - text: ">"
              - text: continuousimprovement
              - generic [ref=e2061]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e2062]:
              - generic [ref=e2063]: <description>
              - text: "<img src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/images/patrick-stewart.jpg\" width=\"400px\" style=\"float:left;padding-right:8px\" /> <p>Recently I have been reading the first few chapters of Patrick Stewart&rsquo;s Memoir, <a href=\"https://www.amazon.co.uk/Making-It-So-A-Memoir/dp/B0C3VXDSGR/ref=sr_1_1\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Making It So: A Memoir</a> . In it he tells the story of his early life. I find it fascinating that very early on it is quite clear he had a life goal. Become the best actor Patrick Stewart can be.</p> <p>Yes, there are other things in his life but this is what motivates much of what he does. At 12 he went on an 8 day residential drama course, where he met with like minded people that encourage him. So much that he continued to meet with them years after that course finished to grow his skills as an actor. This is something I would encourage everyone to do, find your tribe, find like minded people that will encourage you to grow and learn.</p> <p>After school he couldn&rsquo;t see a future in acting professionally so took a job at a newspaper. However when his job interfered with his acting in amateur dramatic groups, it caused him to reassess his priorities and he began saving to go to drama school. While at drama school he continued to improve and grow his acting skills. He has a singular vision in these early years to become an actor, and within a few weeks of finishing his training he had a job as an actor at a theatre. I have got up to the point where he is about to go on a world tour with a theatre group. During his first few jobs he continues to work on his acting skills. There is no doubt in my mind that this sense of continuous improvement helped mold Patrick Stewart into the actor we know today. While I am not a actor, I often think about continuous improvement, how can I be better at what I do.</p> <img src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/images/million-miles.jpg\" width=\"400px\" style=\"float:right;padding-left:8px\" /> <p>A film I saw recently has a similar tale of a singular vision. <a href=\"https://www.amazon.co.uk/Million-Miles-Away-Michael-Pe%C3%B1a/dp/B0CC7MQFVD/ref=sr_1_1\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">A Million Miles Away</a> tells the story of Jose Hernandez, a man that wanted to be an Astronaut and applied to NASA 12 times (he was rejected 11 times!) He started life as a migrant farm worker, (so similar to Patrick Stewart who also grew up in poverty). He did everything in his power to achieve his goals, and didn&rsquo;t give up.</p> <p>Jose Hernandez, when facing failure looked at those that had got into NASA. What did they have that he didn&rsquo;t? He then worked on those areas to improve himself. He didn&rsquo;t give up, he kept going. He works on his fitness, he got a pilots license, he learns Russian.</p> <p>So what&rsquo;s my point. Have a Big Goal. It can be anything but it needs to be <strong>big</strong>. My big goal of becoming a developer was achieved many years ago, and since then I have done a fair amount of drifting through life. What I need to do is be more like Patrick Stewart and continue to improve my skills, everyday make myself a better developer. What problems am I facing, lets break them down into manageable goals and get them solved so I can move on to the next lot.</p>"
              - generic [ref=e2064]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e2066]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e2067]:
          - generic [ref=e2070]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e2071]:
            - generic [ref=e2072]:
              - generic [ref=e2073]: <title>
              - text: DDD East Midlands
              - generic [ref=e2074]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e2075]:
              - generic [ref=e2076]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2023/ddd-east-midlands/
              - generic [ref=e2077]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e2078]:
              - generic [ref=e2079]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e2080]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e2081]:
              - generic [ref=e2082]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 09 Oct 2023 00:00:00 +0000
              - generic [ref=e2083]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e2084]:
              - generic [ref=e2085]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2023/ddd-east-midlands/
              - generic [ref=e2086]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e2087]:
              - generic [ref=e2088]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e2089]: term="DotNet"
                - text: ">"
              - text: DotNet
              - generic [ref=e2090]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e2091]:
              - generic [ref=e2092]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e2093]: term="Community"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Community
              - generic [ref=e2094]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e2095]:
              - generic [ref=e2096]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e2097]: term="Conference"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Conference
              - generic [ref=e2098]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e2099]:
              - generic [ref=e2100]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e2101]: term="DDDEastMidlands"
                - text: ">"
              - text: DDDEastMidlands
              - generic [ref=e2102]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e2103]:
              - generic [ref=e2104]: <description>
              - text: <p>On Saturday 7th October I attended <a href="https://dddeastmidlands.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">DDD East Midlands</a> . It is a community run conference for Developers (the D&rsquo;s stand for Developer) and I had a great time, I have been to DDD North before but this was the first time going to Nottingham for a conference (I grew up in Nottingham, or a town not far from). As I have said before there is nothing quite like chatting over coffee or lunch with fellow Developers about the tech you are learning about, this was probably my favourite thing about conferences. Now on to the talks:</p> <h2 id="dungeons-dragons-and-developers">Dungeons, Dragons and Developers<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#dungeons-dragons-and-developers"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p><a href="https://twitter.com/Brunty" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Matt Brunt</a> gave an excellent keynote talk, comparing the role playing game Dungeons and Dragons with working on Software projects. A good D&amp;D game involves team work, very like a good Software Team. A team of all wizards isn&rsquo;t going to get you very far, the same way a team full of developers that excel at algorithms, won&rsquo;t be good at testing, talking to customers etc. A wizard that has a secret spell to defeat the Troll under the bridge, is almost as bad as a developer that hordes his knowledge and &ldquo;saves the day&rdquo; when things go wrong. Keeping connected with your team as you go out on your quest so no one gets lost is as important as keeping connected with your software team.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/F701q6xXEAAgZk3.jpg" loading="lazy" width="680" height="510" /> </p> <h2 id="microservice-mistakes">Microservice Mistakes<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#microservice-mistakes"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p><a href="https://twitter.com/DoesDotNet" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Matt Hunt</a> talked about microservice mistakes he had made.</p> <ol> <li>Long lived small teams</li> <li>Can&rsquo;t test by <strong>only</strong> interacting with the frontend</li> <li>Use events as well as API calls</li> <li>Need to be able to deploy independently of each other</li> <li>Have a specific reason for using microservices, a problem to solve</li> </ol> <h2 id="the-art-of-the-bad-code-review">The Art of the Bad Code Review<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#the-art-of-the-bad-code-review"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p>A 15 minute lightning talk with <a href="https://twitter.com/makitdev" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Martyn Kilbryde</a> A fun talk showing some examples of bad code reviews, a few takeaways from this:</p> <ul> <li>Explain what is being fixed with a link to the ticket</li> <li>Give specific, actionable feedback</li> <li>Balance the boy scout rule of leaving the code better than when you found it with do one thing rule</li> <li>Don&rsquo;t make assumptions -&gt; have a conversation instead</li> <li>Be helpful and constructive, not dismissive and negative</li> <li>Use a branch per ticket, don&rsquo;t tie them together</li> <li>Refer to the requirements</li> <li>No room for ego, code belongs to the team not an individual</li> <li>Avoid overly verbose comments</li> <li>Pragmatism is important</li> <li>If urgent, raise additional tickets with tech debt issues</li> <li>Challenge if necessary, but do so respectfully</li> <li>Don&rsquo;t do a piecemeal review</li> </ul> <h2 id="git-under-the-covers">Git Under the covers<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#git-under-the-covers"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p>Another 15 minute lightning talk with <a href="https://twitter.com/dracan" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Dan Clarke</a> This looked at the inner workings of git, this was fascinating as every part points at another part which is obviously part of the reason git is so powerful. It was quite technical and I am sure some of it went over my head.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/F71PCBEXsAA4_aJ.jpg" loading="lazy" width="1639" height="864" /> </p> <h2 id="this-talk-could-have-been-a-blog-post">This talk could have been a blog post<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#this-talk-could-have-been-a-blog-post"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p>Another 15 minute lightning talk with <a href="https://twitter.com/JamieTanna" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Jamie Tanna</a> . This was a good talk about the importance of blogging. He used the phrase <strong>blogumentation</strong>, now I have heard of this before but not its name. It is where you use your blog to document what you have learnt, it can be anything a new command or a new language or technology. This talk inspired me to write this blog post, Thank you Jamie. His blog can be found at <a href="https://www.jvt.me/posts/2023/10/07/why-blog/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">https://www.jvt.me/posts/2023/10/07/why-blog/</a> </p> <h2 id="how-to-create-the-conditions-where-happy-people-do-their-best-work">How to create the conditions where happy people do their best work<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#how-to-create-the-conditions-where-happy-people-do-their-best-work"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p><a href="https://twitter.com/paul_bailey_" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Paul Bailey</a> introduced the concept of Communities of Practice. Lots of the features of a Community of Practice I have heard of or been in teams that implement. <em>&ldquo;Communities of Practice are groups of people who share a concern or passion for something they do and learn how to do it better as they interact regularly&rdquo;</em></p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/F71n4uiWYAA4KHL.jpg" loading="lazy" width="2048" height="1536" /> </p> <h2 id="building-robots-for-complete-beginners">Building Robots for Complete Beginners<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#building-robots-for-complete-beginners"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p>Last talk of the day was my favourite (because it was about Robots) <a href="https://www.linkedin.com/in/mark4security/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Mark Goodwin</a> talked about building Robots using Rasbery Pi Pico (a microcontroller board), most of his examples used python. His demo can be found at <a href="https://github.com/computerist/robot-demos" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">https://github.com/computerist/robot-demos</a> This fascinated me as I have already dipped my toe into this area when playing with <a href="https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2022/microbit/">microbits</a> </p>
              - generic [ref=e2105]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e2107]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e2108]:
