              - generic [ref=e2115]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e2116]:
              - generic [ref=e2117]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2023/picard-season-three/
              - generic [ref=e2118]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e2119]:
              - generic [ref=e2120]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e2121]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e2122]:
              - generic [ref=e2123]: <pubDate>
              - text: Thu, 23 Feb 2023 00:00:00 +0000
              - generic [ref=e2124]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e2125]:
              - generic [ref=e2126]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2023/picard-season-three/

            - generic [ref=e2128]:
              - generic [ref=e2129]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e2130]: term="StarTrek"
                - text: ">"
              - text: StarTrek
              - generic [ref=e2131]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e2132]:
              - generic [ref=e2133]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e2134]: term="Podcast"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Podcast
              - generic [ref=e2135]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e2136]:
              - generic [ref=e2137]: <description>
              - text: "<p>Last night I had a bit of a chat about season 3 of Star Trek Picard.</p> <blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\"><p lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">Before <a href=\"https://twitter.com/hashtag/startrek?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">#startrek</a> <a href=\"https://twitter.com/hashtag/Picard?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">#Picard</a> S3ep2 airs this week; <a href=\"https://twitter.com/danielhuckfield?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">@danielhuckfield</a> Special Guest <a href=\"https://twitter.com/funkysi1701?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">@funkysi1701</a> and <a href=\"https://twitter.com/hitch_daniel?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">@hitch_daniel</a> chat about the first episode on the Nexus Nights spin-off show.<a href=\"https://t.co/Jyov53z7hC\">https://t.co/Jyov53z7hC</a></p>&mdash; The Temporal Trek Podcast(s) (@rider_coattail) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/rider_coattail/status/1628713326149570563?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">February 23, 2023</a></blockquote> <script async src=\"https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script> <p>Here is the episode I recorded: <a href=\"https://anchor.fm/daniel-peter-hitch/episodes/TTNN-Ep-36---PIC-S3ep1-Reaction-Chat-e1vdglo\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">TTNN Ep 36 - PIC S3ep1 Reaction Chat</a> </p> <p>Dan and Dan are joined by previous Temporal Trek guest Si Foster for a little chinwag over the return of PICARD for the final season.</p> <p>Badass Bev, Starships of Thesseus, love to loathe Captain Shaw, Predictions and More.</p> <p>It was great fun to record and I hope you enjoy giving it a listen., Hopefully I will be back at the end of the season to discuss the conclusion.</p>"
              - generic [ref=e2138]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e2140]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e2141]:
          - generic [ref=e2144]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e2145]:
            - generic [ref=e2146]:
              - generic [ref=e2147]: <title>
              - text: How much does it cost?
              - generic [ref=e2148]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e2149]:
              - generic [ref=e2150]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2023/how-much-does-it-cost/
              - generic [ref=e2151]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e2152]:
              - generic [ref=e2153]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e2154]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e2155]:
              - generic [ref=e2156]: <pubDate>
              - text: Sat, 04 Feb 2023 00:00:00 +0000
              - generic [ref=e2157]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e2158]:
              - generic [ref=e2159]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2023/how-much-does-it-cost/
              - generic [ref=e2160]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e2161]:
              - generic [ref=e2162]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e2163]: term="Azure"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Azure
              - generic [ref=e2164]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e2165]:
              - generic [ref=e2166]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e2167]: term="Website"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Website
              - generic [ref=e2168]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e2169]:
              - generic [ref=e2170]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e2171]: term="SideProject"
                - text: ">"
              - text: SideProject
              - generic [ref=e2172]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e2173]:
              - generic [ref=e2174]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e2175]: term="Costs"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Costs
              - generic [ref=e2176]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e2177]:
              - generic [ref=e2178]: <description>
              - text: <p>How much does it Cost to run my side projects? This is going to be an interesting look at my spending, hopefully it can show you can do a lot without breaking the bank!</p> <p>I have a personal Azure subscription that I pay for myself. I don&rsquo;t use anything connected to my work, as jobs change and I don&rsquo;t want to have to shift stuff if I change employers (which happened quite recently). I like Azure, and I like learning what I can do with it, so spending small amounts on a personal subscription is not a problem for me.</p> <p>This is how much Azure is costing me daily, I like to keep an eye on this chart fairly often so I can see if I get any increases, especially if I have added a new service.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/daily-costs.png" loading="lazy" width="1204" height="780" /> </p> <p>This is my monthly charges over the last few months. In Sept/Oct I switched from CosmosDB to Mongo DB Atlas as my database backend. Experience has told me that my biggest charge is data storage, websites are cheap but any database or storage is what tends to cost the most.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/monthly-costs.png" loading="lazy" width="1206" height="748" /> </p> <p>This website you are reading this on (assuming you are not on DevTo or Hashnode) is running Hugo which runs on an Azure Static Web App, the free tier so almost free. I have two of these, a production one and a test one. Source code is on Github (another free service), and auto deploys via Github actions. I have a load of images which I have stuffed in blob storage from when I used to run a wordpress site, the cost for file storage is minimal.</p> <p>I also have a service I built using Azure Functions and Static Web Apps which makes use of public APIs like (Twitter/Mastodon/GitHub etc), data for this is stored in the free tier of Mongo DB Atlas. I then use consumption tier Azure Functions and Free Static Web App to do stuff. The definition of what I have deployed is all setup in Pulumi, so I have identical environments for Dev/Test/Prod mostly because I can rather than it being business critical or getting a lot of traffic.</p> <p>I currently have 240Mb of data in my free MongoDb database, I have 512 Mb max storage to play with. I have plenty of data to play with at this tier, but I may investigate other options that involve storing less or what costs might be. I previously made use of cosmosDB, which was costing me between ¬£10-¬£20 per month, so not breaking the bank, but also cheaper to use MongoDB.</p> <p>Interrogating the Azure Cost Analysis tool reveals that my biggest cost is file storage (67p Prod, 101p Test and 93p Dev), I may investigate this a bit and see what is using this, but its not breaking the bank so I am pretty happy.</p> <p>So what else does it cost to run my things?</p> <p>My domains live on CloudFlare, I recently got a bill for ¬£8.04 for a couple of renewals for the next 12 months. But I am struggling to think what else costs me to run my digital things.</p>
              - generic [ref=e2179]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e2181]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e2182]:

            - generic [ref=e2214]:
              - generic [ref=e2215]:
                - text: <category

              - text: StarTrek
              - generic [ref=e2217]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e2218]:
              - generic [ref=e2219]:
                - text: <category

              - text: Mastodon
              - generic [ref=e2221]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e2222]:

                - text: <category

                - text: ">"
              - text: Tests
              - generic [ref=e2225]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e2226]:
              - generic [ref=e2227]: <description>
              - text: "<p>Another week has gone by so here is a rundown of my podcasts listenings&hellip;</p> <h2 id=\"hachyderms-kris-nova-on-running-a-mastodon-server\">Hachyderm‚Äôs Kris Nova on running a Mastodon Server<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#hachyderms-kris-nova-on-running-a-mastodon-server\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p><a href=\"https://hanselminutes.com/872/hachyderms-kris-nova-on-running-a-mastodon-server\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Hanselminutes episode 871</a> </p> <p>A great chat about how Hachderm grew as people moved from Twitter to Mastodon. You can find me on Hachyderm <a href=\"https://hachyderm.io/web/@funkysi1701\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">https://hachyderm.io/web/@funkysi1701</a> Hachyderm saw amazing growth in a short space of time, so great to hear how that impacted the service, which Kris Nova provides for free in her own time.</p> <h2 id=\"the-shipment\">The Shipment<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#the-shipment\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p><a href=\"https://podcasts.apple.com/gb/podcast/the-temporal-trek-podcast-season-3-episode-59-the-shipment/id1499160640?i=1000591042656\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">The Temporal Trek Season 3 episode 58</a> </p> <p>DanDan discuss the season 3 episode The Shipment, which sees Enterprise season 3 back on track, with a proper Star Trek story. But I can&rsquo;t believe Dan forgot to include the DanDan jingle its why I tune in each week.</p> <h2 id=\"trekranks-potpouri\">TrekRanks Potpouri<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#trekranks-potpouri\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p><a href=\"https://www.trekranks.com/trekranks-podcast\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">TrekRanks episode 150</a> </p> <p>This was a great show celebrating 150 shows, and was a lucky dip into all the 149 topics that have been chosen before. Jim was caught out by the guests this week as they went above and beyond finding answers for all possible shows that could be picked. As always some great picks reminding me why I love the show.</p> <h2 id=\"troy-hunts-weekly-update\">Troy Hunt‚Äôs Weekly Update<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#troy-hunts-weekly-update\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p><a href=\"https://www.troyhunt.com/weekly-update-327/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Weekly Update 327</a> </p> <p>I like listening to what Troy has been up to in the last week. (I am a bit behind as this show came out at Christmas time) Troy talks about Twitter and Elon Musk, and the LastPass data breach. I am a big fan of 1Password for my password manager but my employer uses LastPass</p> <h2 id=\"troy-vinson-learning-from-the-rackspace-security-breach\">Troy Vinson: Learning From the Rackspace Security Breach<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#troy-vinson-learning-from-the-rackspace-security-breach\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MsK5zaUogJ4\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Azure DevOps Podcast Episode 225</a> </p> <p>An interesting look at security and the recent rackspace incident. I used to be a big fan of Rackspace but in recent years I have been more interested in cloud offerings like Azure.</p> <h2 id=\"dr-gregory-kapfhammer-wants-to-stop-flaky-tests\">Dr. Gregory Kapfhammer wants to stop flaky tests<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#dr-gregory-kapfhammer-wants-to-stop-flaky-tests\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p><a href=\"https://hanselminutes.com/874/dr-gregory-kapfhammer-wants-to-stop-flaky-tests\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Hanselminutes episode 874</a> </p> <p>I am currently looking at fixing some flaky tests on a codebase I am not familiar with so this is a great podcast to listen to. The episode goes through common reactions to flaky tests, why tests get flaky and what to do about them.</p>"
              - generic [ref=e2228]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e2230]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e2231]:
          - generic [ref=e2234]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e2235]:
            - generic [ref=e2236]:
              - generic [ref=e2237]: <title>
              - text: What podcasts have I been listening to
              - generic [ref=e2238]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e2239]:
              - generic [ref=e2240]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2023/what-have-i-been-listening-to/
              - generic [ref=e2241]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e2242]:
              - generic [ref=e2243]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e2244]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e2245]:
              - generic [ref=e2246]: <pubDate>
              - text: Thu, 05 Jan 2023 00:00:00 +0000
              - generic [ref=e2247]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e2248]:
              - generic [ref=e2249]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2023/what-have-i-been-listening-to/
              - generic [ref=e2250]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e2251]:
              - generic [ref=e2252]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e2253]: term="Podcast"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Podcast
              - generic [ref=e2254]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e2255]:
              - generic [ref=e2256]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e2257]: term="Leadership"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Leadership
              - generic [ref=e2258]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e2259]:
              - generic [ref=e2260]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e2261]: term="OpenSource"
                - text: ">"
              - text: OpenSource
              - generic [ref=e2262]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e2263]:
              - generic [ref=e2264]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e2265]: term="StarTrek"
                - text: ">"
              - text: StarTrek
              - generic [ref=e2266]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e2267]:
              - generic [ref=e2268]: <description>
              - text: <p>I love listening to podcasts so I thought I would share what I have been listening to over the last few days.</p> <h2 id="source-open-vs-open-source-and-identityserver-with-dominick-baier-and-brock-allen">Source Open vs Open Source and IdentityServer with Dominick Baier and Brock Allen<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#source-open-vs-open-source-and-identityserver-with-dominick-baier-and-brock-allen"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p><a href="https://www.dotnetrocks.com/details/1824" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">.Net Rocks episode 1824</a> </p> <p>The creators of the open source project Identity Server which went commercial discuss the reasons for doing so. This was a very interesting discussion on the challenges of running open source projects and ways that they can be more maintainable. I have seen Twitter arguments on both sides about various products that have done this. It is a very nuanced problem, which I don‚Äôt know much about so interesting hearing what was involved.</p> <h2 id="growing-as-an-engineering-manager-with-taylor-poindexter">Growing as an Engineering Manager with Taylor Poindexter<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#growing-as-an-engineering-manager-with-taylor-poindexter"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p><a href="https://hanselminutes.com/871/growing-as-an-enginering-manager-with-taylor-poindexter" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Hanselminutes episode 871</a> </p> <p>A discussion about being an engineering manager, mentoring and growing and learning. I am not a manager and I don‚Äôt have people that report to me, however, I am a senior developer so anything that can help me improve on the leadership side of things is great. On a side note, I love how diverse the guests are on Hanselminutes, I often listen to people on this show I would never have heard of or known about if I just stuck to topics I know about.</p> <h2 id="top-5-scenes-at-a-table">Top 5 Scenes at a Table<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#top-5-scenes-at-a-table"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p><a href="https://www.trekranks.com/trekranks-podcast" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">TrekRanks episode 149</a> </p> <p>Star Trek for me has always been about positivity and Trek Ranks delivers this in spades. The concept, in case you don‚Äôt know, is to choose 5 episodes about the chosen topic, but it is really an excuse to talk about them! So what 5 scenes at a table would I choose?</p> <ol> <li>Undiscovered Country - Dinner with the Klingons. Klingons, Shakespeare, terrible table manners what is not to love about this scene</li> <li>Q Who - Scene in the observation lounge with Q and Guinan as they discuss how to respond to the newly discovered Borg</li> <li>Civil Defence - Scene in Ops between Garak and Dukat while the crew hide from an automated phaser firing at them, the best bit is when Duakt tried to leave and ends up trapped with the rest of the crew</li> <li>Mirror, Mirror - Scene where Bones realises that some things are the same in the mirror universe, the spot where he spilt acid</li> <li>Unification Part 2 - Spock, Picard and Data have been captured by Sela, and Sela comments that she doesn‚Äôt get to write many speeches, and then Data comments that maybe she would be happy doing another job</li> </ol>
              - generic [ref=e2269]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e2271]: </item>

              - text: <h2 id="2023">2023<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#2023"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <table> <thead> <tr> <th>Event/Talk</th> <th>Date</th> <th>Location</th> </tr> </thead> <tbody> <tr> <td>DevBoss</td> <td>16 November 2023</td> <td>Leeds</td> </tr> <tr> <td><a href="https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2023/ddd-east-midlands">DDD East Midlands</a> </td> <td>7 October 2023</td> <td>Nottingham</td> </tr> <tr> <td>SteelCon</td> <td>8 July 2023</td> <td>Sheffield</td> </tr> <tr> <td>Yorkshire Azure</td> <td>13 June 2023</td> <td>Leeds</td> </tr> <tr> <td>DevBoss</td> <td>20 April 2023</td> <td>Leeds</td> </tr> <tr> <td>dotnet York Machine Learning with ML.Net</td> <td>2 March 2023</td> <td>York</td> </tr> </tbody> </table>

          - generic [ref=e2300]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e2301]:
            - generic [ref=e2302]:
              - generic [ref=e2303]: <title>
              - text: 2022 What Happened?
              - generic [ref=e2304]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e2305]:
              - generic [ref=e2306]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2022/2022-what-happened/
              - generic [ref=e2307]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e2308]:
              - generic [ref=e2309]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e2310]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e2311]:
              - generic [ref=e2312]: <pubDate>
              - text: Sat, 31 Dec 2022 22:00:00 +0000
              - generic [ref=e2313]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e2314]:
              - generic [ref=e2315]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2022/2022-what-happened/
              - generic [ref=e2316]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e2317]:
              - generic [ref=e2318]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e2319]: term="Goals"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Goals
              - generic [ref=e2320]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e2321]:
              - generic [ref=e2322]: <description>
              - text: <p>As 2022 draws to a close its time to do my annual look back at what happened.</p> <p>I am going to talk a bit about my personal life as well as tech things, so if that is not your bag feel free to skip this post and read my more technical articles.</p> <ul> <li>January - I started the year <a href="https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2021/back-to-basic/">teaching my son to code</a> .</li> <li>February - I did some work on my website this year, and it is now using Hugo instead of wordpress.</li> <li>March - I was guest on a Star Trek <a href="https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2022/temporal-trek-podcast/">podcast</a> , hopefully a repeat appearance in the works very soon. I also passed an <a href="https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2022/aws-cloud-practitioner/">AWS exam</a> </li> <li>April - Lots of work with <a href="https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2022/scratch/">Scratch</a> with my boy</li> <li>June - <a href="https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2022/scottishsummit/">Scottish Summit</a> </li> <li>August - My boys birthday so some coding activities with his <a href="https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2022/microbit/">Microbit</a> </li> <li>October - I bought a second hand car and less than a week later it burst into flames, a scary event but no one hurt and everything has since been replaced/repaired.</li> <li>November - I lost my job</li> <li>December - Extended time with family for Christmas with a new job starting in January. I sat and narrowly missed passing AZ-204 (Developing Solutions for Azure). I attended <a href="https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2022/ddd-north/">DDD North</a> , I attended LeedsSharp and went on a virtual tour of a Microsoft Datacenter.</li> </ul> <p>I don&rsquo;t know what is in store for 2023 but I am sure it will be equally interesting. The first thing to get my head around is my new job.</p> <p>So onto my goals for 2023</p> <ol> <li>New job and get my head around all the new stuff I need to learn</li> <li>Celebrate 10 years of marriage and concentrate on family things</li> <li>Pass AZ-204 - It was such a close miss that I need to retry this</li> <li>More coding with my son, he got a laptop for Christmas and would be great to build on what he has learnt so far.</li> <li>Blog regularly - I doubled the number of blog posts from 2021, but it would be great to keep up the momentum with regular posts of what I am up to.</li> <li>I recently added an events page, so I need to go to some events. Events like DDD North and Scottish Summit are great, but so are local user groups so a mix of these would be great.</li> </ol> <p>Last year I had the following <a href="https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2022/2022-goals/">goals</a> </p> <ol> <li>Video - Not used my green screen yet, would be good to make some time to use this in 2023</li> <li>Conference - I attended Scottish Summit and DDD North, would be great to go to more like these this year as well</li> <li>Blog More - Yeah I achieved this, but lets keep doing this.</li> <li>Metrics - I have done little bits with this over the last year, but not a huge amount.</li> <li>My personal brand has improved this year as my blog relaunched on the Hugo platform, and I am very happy with its look, probably more I can do.</li> </ol>
              - generic [ref=e2323]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e2325]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e2326]:
          - generic [ref=e2329]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e2330]:
            - generic [ref=e2331]:
              - generic [ref=e2332]: <title>
              - text: DDD North
              - generic [ref=e2333]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e2334]:
              - generic [ref=e2335]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2022/ddd-north/
              - generic [ref=e2336]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e2337]:
              - generic [ref=e2338]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e2339]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e2340]:
              - generic [ref=e2341]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 05 Dec 2022 18:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e2342]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e2343]:
              - generic [ref=e2344]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2022/ddd-north/
              - generic [ref=e2345]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e2346]:
              - generic [ref=e2347]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e2348]: term="DotNet"
                - text: ">"
              - text: DotNet
              - generic [ref=e2349]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e2350]:
              - generic [ref=e2351]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e2352]: term="Azure"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Azure
              - generic [ref=e2353]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e2354]:
              - generic [ref=e2355]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e2356]: term="Community"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Community
              - generic [ref=e2357]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e2358]:
              - generic [ref=e2359]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e2360]: term="Conference"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Conference
              - generic [ref=e2361]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e2362]:
              - generic [ref=e2363]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e2364]: term="DDDNorth"
                - text: ">"
              - text: DDDNorth
              - generic [ref=e2365]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e2366]:
              - generic [ref=e2367]: <description>
              - text: <p>On Saturday 3rd December I attended <a href="https://www.dddnorth.co.uk/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">DDD North</a> . It is a community run conference for Developers (the D&rsquo;s stand for Developer) and I had a fab time there. Many conferences are going online which is great, however there is nothing quite like chatting over coffee or lunch with fellow Developers about the tech you are learning about, this was probably my favourite thing about the conference.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="DDD North" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/dddnorth-hull-developers-conference-2022.jpg" loading="lazy" width="800" height="600" /> </p> <p>The first talk I attended was &lsquo;.Net Minimal APIs&rsquo; by <a href="https://twitter.com/kev_bite" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Kevin Smith</a> . Kevin runs .Net user groups in York and Sheffield so I have heard him speak before. He went through some of the features of minimal APIs. I have briefly experimented with them in .Net 6, however from the sound of things the tech is much improved in .Net 7, with lots of improvements, so this is something I want to give another try.</p> <p>During the coffee break I managed to have a quick conversation with <a href="https://www.youtube.com/c/Elfocrash" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Nick Chapsas</a> . Nick has a YouTube channel that my colleagues at work have been sharing during our weekly knowledge share sessions. It was great to chat with someone that I have been watching on YouTube.</p> <p>The second talk was &lsquo;When microservices go bad&rsquo; by <a href="https://twitter.com/TechyChap" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Andy Clark</a> . This talk was a discussion of the different ways you can use <a href="https://github.com/App-vNext/Polly" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Polly</a> , Carl Franklin of .NetRocks fame has mentioned Polly a few times on the show, so this was a good talk to explain the different ways it can be used.</p> <p>The third talk was &lsquo;Don&rsquo;t put your messages in a bottle; Implement messaging patterns&rsquo; by <a href="https://twitter.com/egrootenboer" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Eldert Grootenboer</a> , he should have been joined by <a href="https://twitter.com/borzenko_lena" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Olena Borzenko</a> however she was unable to travel (didn&rsquo;t catch exactly why, I think she was from Ukraine or working in Ukraine and Visa&rsquo;s from that part of the world are a problem at the moment). This was a talk all about message queues and the patterns and practises you should implement. I don&rsquo;t know much about queues, having only recently started using AWS SQS messages recently so this was useful to put that work into context. The slides from this talk are available <a href="https://eldertnet-my.sharepoint.com/:p:/g/personal/eldert_eldert_net/EXbVxQpSzzNJmtvKNPjzSvYBSGfnLI7qC5U5Ia-PYCqioA?rtime=fIdK6wHX2kg" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">here</a> </p> <p>Lunch was next and the food was excellent. I found myself sitting with Jamie Taylor (from the Tabs and Spaces podcast), <a href="https://twitter.com/YorkshireTechy" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Craig Pickles</a> , <a href="https://twitter.com/chris_sainty" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Chris Sainty</a> and a few others. There was a fascinating discussion on Blazor, .Net and how Microsoft introduces new stuff. Really appreciate being able to listen in on such an interesting discussion.</p> <p>The fourth talk was &lsquo;Why don&rsquo;t people seem to be able to diagnose problems these days?&rsquo; by <a href="https://twitter.com/richardfennell" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Richard Fennell</a> . This was a fascinating walk through computer history and the challenges of finding where the problem is. The slides from this talk are available <a href="https://github.com/rfennell/Presentations/blob/main/Why%20don%27t%20people%20seem%20to%20be%20able%20to%20diagnose%20problems%20these%20days.pptx" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">here</a> </p> <p>The last talk was &lsquo;Empathy, Sympathy, and Compassion&rsquo; by <a href="https://twitter.com/podcasterJay" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Jamie Taylor</a> who I had met at lunch. This was a fascinating look at how we place barriers between ourselves as Developers and the users of the software. It expanded into ethics, code of conduct and doing good. The slides from this talk are available <a href="https://shorturl.at/mAMUZ" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">here</a> </p> <p>It was a great event so thank you <a href="https://twitter.com/dddnorth" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">DDD North</a> for all your hard work, I look forward to the next one. I have lots to go away and think about.</p>
              - generic [ref=e2368]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e2370]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e2371]:

              - generic [ref=e2406]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e2407]:
              - generic [ref=e2408]: <description>
              - text: "<p>This morning the client complains that the website is not working. I do some checking and I confirm that there is indeed an error.</p> <p>The error they are seeing is:</p> <pre tabindex=\"0\"><code>An unhandled exception occurred while processing the request. MsalServiceException: A configuration issue is preventing authentication - check the error message from the server for details. You can modify the configuration in the application registration portal. See https://aka.ms/msal-net-invalid-client for details. Original exception: AADSTS7000222: The provided client secret keys for app &#39;00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000&#39; are expired. Visit the Azure portal to create new keys for your app: https://aka.ms/NewClientSecret, or consider using certificate credentials for added security: https://aka.ms/certCreds. </code></pre><p>The fix for this is relatively simple, generate a new client secret in Azure AD and update the website config to make use of it.</p> <p>The problem is that this problem will reoccur in 3, 6, 12, 18 or 24 months, depending on what expiry date you set on the secret.</p> <p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"Add a client secret\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/AzureADSecret.png\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"572\" height=\"350\" /> </p> <p>A suggestion from twitter is that Logic Apps and Event Grid might help solve this problem. Lets see how this might work.</p> <p>Logic Apps have a consumption plan, so this kind of solution shouldn&rsquo;t break the bank as will only cost per run eg daily/weekly etc</p> <p>But first here is a powershell script that lists all the secrets that are due to expire in the next 30 days.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-powershell\" data-lang=\"powershell\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\">#secret expiration date filter (for example 30 days)</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>$LimitExpirationDays = <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">30</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\">#Retrieving the list of secrets that expires in the above range of days</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>$SecretsToExpire = Get-AzureADApplication -All:$true | ForEach-Object { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> $app = $_ </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> @( </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> Get-AzureADApplicationPasswordCredential -ObjectId $_.ObjectId </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> Get-AzureADApplicationKeyCredential -ObjectId $_.ObjectId </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> ) | Where-Object { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> $_.EndDate <span style=\"color:#f92672\">-lt</span> (Get-Date).AddDays($LimitExpirationDays) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } | ForEach-Object { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> $id = <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;Not set&#34;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">if</span>($_.CustomKeyIdentifier) { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> $id = [<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">System.Text.Encoding</span>]::UTF8.GetString($_.CustomKeyIdentifier) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> [<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">PSCustomObject</span>] @{ </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> App = $app.DisplayName </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> ObjectID = $app.ObjectId </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> AppId = $app.AppId </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> Type = $_.GetType().name </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> KeyIdentifier = $id </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> EndDate = $_.EndDate </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>} </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\">#Printing the list of secrets that are near to expire</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">if</span>($SecretsToExpire.Count <span style=\"color:#f92672\">-EQ</span> <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">0</span>) { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> Write-Output <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;No secrets found that will expire in this range&#34;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>} </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">else</span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> Write-Output <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;Secrets that will expire in this range:&#34;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> Write-Output $SecretsToExpire.Count </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> Write-Output $SecretsToExpire </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>} </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This works quite well, but I have to manually run it every so often. I have not found a way to automate this as I don&rsquo;t know how to get past the MFA that is configured on my Azure AD tenant.</p> <p>Now lets look at how a Logic App might help us. First of all we need somewhere to query the expiry dates, and Azure Key Vault is the ideal place to store them.</p> <p>Create a Key Vault if you don&rsquo;t already have one and add a new Secret. Manually add the Client Secret from Azure AD and give it a name you can identify it with. Tick the Set expiration date and save the expiry date of your secret.</p> <p>Now Create a Logic App, I am going to use Consumption, so it only costs you when it runs.</p> <p>Using the Logic Apps Designer, start with a Recurrence trigger. This lets you queue up your logic app on a schedule, I&rsquo;ve set mine to run every 30 days.</p> <p>Next run a Get Secret command from your Key Vault. Select the identifying name you saved the secret with earlier. This will retrieve the secret from the Key Vault, if you go into the settings you can hide the output as you are only really interested in the expiry date.</p> <p>I am doing a low tech solution for now, and just emailing myself the expiry date. It is easy to add the expiry date of the secret to an email.</p> <p>Later on I might add a bit more logic to only email myself when the expiry is less than 30 days, a reminder to create a new secret. When creating a new secret in Azure AD, I also need to add the secret and expiry date into Key Vault.</p> <p>At the very least this solution will give me an early warning of when my secrets are about to expire. It is possible to get my website to read information from Key Vault directly which I may well investigate.</p>"

          - generic [ref=e2415]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e2416]:
            - generic [ref=e2417]:
              - generic [ref=e2418]: <title>
              - text: Upgrading to .Net 7
              - generic [ref=e2419]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e2420]:
              - generic [ref=e2421]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2022/dotnet7/
              - generic [ref=e2422]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e2423]:
              - generic [ref=e2424]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e2425]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e2426]:
              - generic [ref=e2427]: <pubDate>
              - text: Sat, 01 Oct 2022 18:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e2428]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e2429]:
              - generic [ref=e2430]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2022/dotnet7/
              - generic [ref=e2431]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e2432]:
              - generic [ref=e2433]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e2434]: term="DotNet"
                - text: ">"
              - text: DotNet
              - generic [ref=e2435]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e2436]:
              - generic [ref=e2437]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e2438]: term="Blazor"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Blazor
              - generic [ref=e2439]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e2440]:
              - generic [ref=e2441]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e2442]: term="EFCore"
                - text: ">"
              - text: EFCore
              - generic [ref=e2443]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e2444]:
              - generic [ref=e2445]: <description>
              - text: "<p>I have a Blazor application that was built with .Net Core 3, and I have updated it to .Net 5 and later .Net 6 when those versions of were released. In November .Net 7 is released so I have been testing it with the .Net 7 previews.</p> <p>However for this update I encountered a few more issues than I remember from the other updates.</p> <h2 id=\"automapper\">Automapper<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#automapper\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>The first issue I encountered was with Automapper. My Unit tests failed with the following error</p> <pre tabindex=\"0\"><code>Error Message: System.ArgumentException : GenericArguments[0], &#39;System.Char&#39;, on &#39;T MaxFloat[T](System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable`1[T])&#39; violates the constraint of type &#39;T&#39;. ---- System.Security.VerificationException : Method System.Linq.Enumerable.MaxFloat: type argument &#39;System.Char&#39; violates the constraint of type parameter &#39;T&#39;. Stack Trace: at System.RuntimeType.ValidateGenericArguments(MemberInfo definition, RuntimeType[] genericArguments, Exception e) at System.Reflection.RuntimeMethodInfo.MakeGenericMethod(Type[] methodInstantiation) at AutoMapper.Internal.TypeDetails.&lt;&gt;c__DisplayClass25_1.&lt;GetPublicNoArgExtensionMethods&gt;b__10(MethodInfo extensionMethod) at System.Linq.Enumerable.WhereSelectArrayIterator`2.MoveNext() at System.Linq.Enumerable.ConcatIterator`1.MoveNext() at System.Linq.Enumerable.SelectManyIterator[TSource,TCollection,TResult](IEnumerable`1 source, Func`2 collectionSelector, Func`3 resultSelector)+MoveNext() at System.Linq.Enumerable.WhereSelectEnumerableIterator`2.MoveNext() at System.Linq.Enumerable.UnionIterator`1.GetNext() at System.Linq.Enumerable.UnionIterator`1.MoveNext() at System.Linq.Enumerable.ConcatIterator`1.MoveNext() at AutoMapper.Internal.TypeDetails.PossibleNames() at AutoMapper.Internal.TypeDetails.GetMember(String name) at AutoMapper.Configuration.Conventions.DefaultName.GetMatchingMemberInfo(TypeDetails sourceTypeDetails, Type destType, Type destMemberType, String nameToSearch) at AutoMapper.Configuration.Conventions.ParentSourceToDestinationNameMapper.GetMatchingMemberInfo(TypeDetails sourceTypeDetails, Type destType, Type destMemberType, String nameToSearch) at AutoMapper.Configuration.Conventions.DefaultMember.MapDestinationPropertyToSource(ProfileMap options, TypeDetails sourceTypeDetails, Type destType, Type destMemberType, String nameToSearch, List`1 resolvers, IMemberConfiguration parent, Boolean isReverseMap) at AutoMapper.Configuration.Conventions.MemberConfiguration.MapDestinationPropertyToSource(ProfileMap options, TypeDetails sourceType, Type destType, Type destMemberType, String nameToSearch, List`1 resolvers, Boolean isReverseMap) at AutoMapper.Configuration.Conventions.NameSplitMember.MapDestinationPropertyToSource(ProfileMap options, TypeDetails sourceType, Type destType, Type destMemberType, String nameToSearch, List`1 resolvers, IMemberConfiguration parent, Boolean isReverseMap) at AutoMapper.Configuration.Conventions.MemberConfiguration.MapDestinationPropertyToSource(ProfileMap options, TypeDetails sourceType, Type destType, Type destMemberType, String nameToSearch, List`1 resolvers, Boolean isReverseMap) at AutoMapper.ProfileMap.MapDestinationPropertyToSource(TypeDetails sourceTypeDetails, Type destType, Type destMemberType, String destMemberName, List`1 members, Boolean reverseNamingConventions) at AutoMapper.TypeMap..ctor(Type sourceType, Type destinationType, ProfileMap profile, Boolean isReverseMap) at AutoMapper.ProfileMap.BuildTypeMap(IGlobalConfiguration configurationProvider, ITypeMapConfiguration config) at AutoMapper.ProfileMap.Register(IGlobalConfiguration configurationProvider) at AutoMapper.MapperConfiguration.Seal() at AutoMapper.MapperConfiguration..ctor(MapperConfigurationExpression configurationExpression) at AutoMapper.MapperConfiguration..ctor(Action`1 configure) at System.RuntimeType.CreateInstanceDefaultCtor(Boolean publicOnly, Boolean wrapExceptions) ----- Inner Stack Trace ----- at System.RuntimeMethodHandle.GetStubIfNeeded(RuntimeMethodHandleInternal method, RuntimeType declaringType, RuntimeType[] methodInstantiation) at System.Reflection.RuntimeMethodInfo.MakeGenericMethod(Type[] methodInstantiation) </code></pre><p>At first I didn&rsquo;t realise it was an issue with Automapper and I started searching for breaking changes in dotnet 7. Eventually this lead to finding that a change to .Net had created an issue with version 11 of Automapper. The following github issues explains more about what was involved in fixing this.</p> <p><a href=\"https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/69119\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/69119</a> </p> <p><a href=\"https://github.com/AutoMapper/AutoMapper/pull/3999\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">https://github.com/AutoMapper/AutoMapper/pull/3999</a> </p> <p>This week <a href=\"https://github.com/AutoMapper/AutoMapper/releases/tag/v12.0.0\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">version 12</a> of Automapper was released and it fixed this issue for me.</p> <h2 id=\"code-coverage\">Code Coverage<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#code-coverage\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>My build includes the calculation of code coverage of my unit tests. For some reason this step was failing.</p> <pre tabindex=\"0\"><code> - task: DotNetCoreCLI@2 displayName: &#39;Running API Tests&#39; inputs: command: &#39;test&#39; arguments: &#39;--no-restore --no-build --configuration $(buildConfiguration) --runtime win-x64 /p:CollectCoverage=true /p:CoverletOutputFormat=opencover&#39; projects: &#39;Path To csproj file&#39; nobuild: true </code></pre><p>For .Net 6 this step would run my unit tests and include a section that looked a bit like this.</p> <pre tabindex=\"0\"><code>Calculating coverage result... Generating report &#39;D:\\a\\1\\s\\WhatEver\\coverage.opencover.xml&#39; +---------------------------+--------+--------+--------+ | Module | Line | Branch | Method | +---------------------------+--------+--------+--------+ | Something | 50.91% | 48.77% | 65.44% | +---------------------------+--------+--------+--------+ | Something.Core | 41.79% | 6.92% | 47.2% | +---------------------------+--------+--------+--------+ | Something.Core.Email | 96.55% | 50% | 100% | +---------------------------+--------+--------+--------+ +---------+--------+--------+--------+ | | Line | Branch | Method | +---------+--------+--------+--------+ | Total | 49.46% | 44.2% | 53.55% | +---------+--------+--------+--------+ | Average | 63.08% | 35.22% | 70.88% | +---------+--------+--------+--------+ </code></pre><p>However for .Net 7 the unit tests would pass but the coverage bit above would not run, and no visible errors to help me.</p> <p>Testing dotnet test locally I discovered that if I included the path and filename to the csproj file the coverage would not run, if I removed this it would work as per .Net 6. No idea why this was happening.</p> <p>I did some testing with the DotNetCoreCLI@2 task, but I couldn&rsquo;t get the coverage to work. However I was testing this locally via the command line so it was a simple thing to swap DotNetCoreCLI@2 for a command line step. After I did that the coverage started working again!</p> <p>Here is the command line step I added</p> <pre tabindex=\"0\"><code> - task: CmdLine@2 displayName: &#39;Running API Tests&#39; inputs: script: | &#34;C:\\Program Files\\dotnet\\dotnet.exe&#34; test --logger trx --results-directory D:\\a\\_temp --no-restore --no-build --configuration Release --runtime win-x64 /p:CollectCoverage=true /p:CoverletOutputFormat=opencover workingDirectory: &#39;$(Build.SourcesDirectory)/PathToWhereEver&#39; </code></pre><h2 id=\"sql-server-tables-with-triggers\">SQL Server tables with triggers<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#sql-server-tables-with-triggers\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>My build was all working so now time to test the application was working. But an error was being thrown if I tried to save any data to the SQL Server database.</p> <pre tabindex=\"0\"><code>Could not save changes because the target table has database triggers. Please configure your entity type accordingly, see https://aka.ms/efcore-docs-sqlserver-save-changes-and-triggers for more information. The target table &#39;Something&#39; of the DML statement cannot have any enabled triggers if the statement contains an OUTPUT clause without INTO clause. </code></pre><p>A nice error, as it gives me a link to the change and what to do to fix.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">protected</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">override</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">void</span> ConfigureConventions(ModelConfigurationBuilder configurationBuilder) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>{ </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> configurationBuilder.Conventions.Add(_ =&gt; <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> BlankTriggerAddingConvention()); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>} </span></span></code></pre></div><div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">public</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">class</span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">BlankTriggerAddingConvention</span> : IModelFinalizingConvention </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>{ </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">public</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">virtual</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">void</span> ProcessModelFinalizing( </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> IConventionModelBuilder modelBuilder, </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> IConventionContext&lt;IConventionModelBuilder&gt; context) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">foreach</span> (<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> entityType <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">in</span> modelBuilder.Metadata.GetEntityTypes()) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> table = StoreObjectIdentifier.Create(entityType, StoreObjectType.Table); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">if</span> (table != <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">null</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> &amp;&amp; entityType.GetDeclaredTriggers().All(t =&gt; t.GetDatabaseName(table.Value) == <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">null</span>)) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> entityType.Builder.HasTrigger(table.Value.Name + <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;_Trigger&#34;</span>); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">foreach</span> (<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> fragment <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">in</span> entityType.GetMappingFragments(StoreObjectType.Table)) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">if</span> (entityType.GetDeclaredTriggers().All(t =&gt; t.GetDatabaseName(fragment.StoreObject) == <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">null</span>)) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> entityType.Builder.HasTrigger(fragment.StoreObject.Name + <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;_Trigger&#34;</span>); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>} </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Adding the following to my DBContext allowed data to be saved even if triggers existed on my database.</p> <p>A longer term fix, should be to investigate if the triggers on the database are still needed and remove if not. From reading the docs, it sounds like a performance gain would be had after doing this!</p> <h2 id=\"conclusion\">Conclusion<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#conclusion\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>These are the issues I have encountered so far updating to .Net 7. A few more than for .Net 5 or 6. However so far I have managed to find a solution for all issues. I expect one more release candidate, with the final version of .Net 7 coming out in November.</p>"

          - generic [ref=e2453]:
