              - text: "Developer Weekly Update #003: Progress, Challenges, and Insights"
              - generic [ref=e3333]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e3334]:
              - generic [ref=e3335]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2020/weekly-update-003/
              - generic [ref=e3336]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e3337]:
              - generic [ref=e3338]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e3339]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e3340]:
              - generic [ref=e3341]: <pubDate>
              - text: Sat, 28 Nov 2020 00:00:00 +0000
              - generic [ref=e3342]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e3343]:
              - generic [ref=e3344]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2020/weekly-update-003/
              - generic [ref=e3345]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e3346]:
              - generic [ref=e3347]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3348]: term="OpenSource"
                - text: ">"
              - text: OpenSource
              - generic [ref=e3349]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3350]:
              - generic [ref=e3351]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3352]: term="PHP"
                - text: ">"
              - text: PHP
              - generic [ref=e3353]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3354]:
              - generic [ref=e3355]: <description>
              - text: <p>Been a quiet week, so wasn&rsquo;t expecting to have much to write on here, however a few things happened worth talking about.</p> <h3 id="my-first-pr">My First PR<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#my-first-pr"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h3> <p>A comment was made to me to do something with the postcodes that are in the system I am developing. Find out what projects have postcodes near each other, and that way work can be grouped together and reduce potential mileage costs of staff that need to visit these projects.</p> <p>A quick google search found <a href="https://postcodes.io/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">https://postcodes.io/</a> which has an API that returns nearby postcodes. It also has a C# wrapper <a href="https://github.com/markembling/MarkEmbling.PostcodesIO" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">https://github.com/markembling/MarkEmbling.PostcodesIO</a> </p> <p>A comparison of what was being returned from the wrapper and what the API said should be returned revealed that the distance between postcodes wasn&rsquo;t being returned.</p> <p>As the code was on GitHub I could easily see how easy or difficult it might be to add the missing bit of information. It was easy! So, I forked the repo and made the change. I published the change to a private NuGet repo in my Azure Dev Ops account. That way I could try my revised package to check it did what I wanted.</p> <p>I left a message on the GitHub project letting the owner know I had a potential fix for an issue. The project hadn&rsquo;t been updated in over a year, so the owner may not be interested, or the project may have been abandoned.</p> <p>I was in luck just 17 hours after I left a message the project owner said to create a Pull Request, which I did and shortly afterwards my code had been merged in and an updated version of the package existed in the public NuGet feed.</p> <p>I have been thinking about contributing to open source for a while. However, I had not seen a project I wanted to contribute to, or a problem that I knew how to fix until now that is.</p> <h3 id="php">PHP<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#php"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h3> <p>This week I had a call asking me if I knew PHP?</p> <p>I did, over ten years ago, before I got my first IT job, I spent time learning PHP and MySQL. I created a blog, and I also created a website for my Dad&rsquo;s camera club. The code I created back then was awful. No shared code, all the code was associated with the page, or sorts of bugs occurred and as time went by it became increasingly hard to update. The site was well liked but I eventually lost interest and moved on to learn other things.</p> <p>This call led to me talking with the head of IT, and later a couple of the developers who have since granted me access to the codebase of a project.</p> <p>I haven&rsquo;t had time to spend a lot of time looking at the code so far, however this is nothing like the PHP I had built before.</p> <p>The project makes use of the <a href="https://laravel.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">laravel</a> framework and the first file I opened had methods and classes, so apart from the syntax you could think you were looking at C#.</p> <p>Another thing that interested me was the project used docker containers, it has automated builds as well. Lots of modern programming ideas that I had some ideas about. I am looking forward to learning more about this project and how I might contribute to it.</p>
              - generic [ref=e3356]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e3358]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e3359]:

            - generic [ref=e3387]:
              - generic [ref=e3388]: <description>
              - text: "<p>I know Active Directory is fussy about clocks being in sync however not sure how todays issue happened.</p> <p>I run my docker compose file from Visual Studio and I get a weird error.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-txt\" data-lang=\"txt\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>SecurityTokenNotYetValidException: IDX10222: Lifetime validation failed. The token is not yet valid. ValidFrom: &#39;System.DateTime&#39;, Current time: &#39;System.DateTime&#39;. </span></span></code></pre></div><p>I deleted my containers, open and close Visual Studio a few times, nothing helps. Eventually I think to find out what the time is on my container. It has yesterday&rsquo;s date. What has happened here? Surely recreating containers would have caused them to have todays date? I reboot and everything is fine again.</p> <p>Turns out that it is a know issue, see <a href=\"https://thorsten-hans.com/docker-on-windows-fix-time-synchronization-issue\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">https://thorsten-hans.com/docker-on-windows-fix-time-synchronization-issue</a> I am using WSL2 and I have now changed back to using Hyper-V and the issue hasn&rsquo;t come back.</p> <p>Earlier in the week I spotted my build step was failing.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-yaml\" data-lang=\"yaml\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> - <span style=\"color:#f92672\">task</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">NuGetToolInstaller@0</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Swapping to the next version of the step is all I needed to do to fix it.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-yaml\" data-lang=\"yaml\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> - <span style=\"color:#f92672\">task</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">NuGetToolInstaller@1</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>My guess is that support was dropped for this earlier version or there is some other incompatability with .Net 5.</p>"
              - generic [ref=e3389]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e3391]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e3392]:
          - generic [ref=e3395]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e3396]:
            - generic [ref=e3397]:
              - generic [ref=e3398]: <title>
              - text: "Weekly Update #001"
              - generic [ref=e3399]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e3400]:
              - generic [ref=e3401]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2020/weekly-update-001/
              - generic [ref=e3402]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e3403]:
              - generic [ref=e3404]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e3405]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e3406]:
              - generic [ref=e3407]: <pubDate>
              - text: Sat, 14 Nov 2020 00:00:00 +0000
              - generic [ref=e3408]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e3409]:
              - generic [ref=e3410]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2020/weekly-update-001/
              - generic [ref=e3411]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e3412]:
              - generic [ref=e3413]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3414]: term="DotNet"
                - text: ">"
              - text: DotNet
              - generic [ref=e3415]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3416]:
              - generic [ref=e3417]: <description>
              - text: "<p>One of my favourite podcasts is Troy Hunts weekly update. In it he discusses stuff that he has been working on, plus some personal stuff. I am going to attempt to do something similar. It will probably take me a few of these before we get a look and feel that works.</p> <h4 id=\"monday\">Monday<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#monday\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h4> <p>A week off work, mainly to use it up before year end, plus want to get a few jobs around the house done.</p> <p>I did ask the following question on Twitter.</p> <blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\"><p lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">Hey <a href=\"https://twitter.com/hashtag/azurefamily?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">#azurefamily</a> and <a href=\"https://twitter.com/hashtag/dotnet?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">#dotnet</a> developers how do I get more involved in mentoring?</p>&mdash; Simon Foster (@funkysi1701) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/funkysi1701/status/1325742644014829568?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">November 9, 2020</a></blockquote> <script async src=\"https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script> <p>As a one person dev team, my biggest weakness is working with others so any ideas of how to change that are great.</p> <h4 id=\"tuesday\">Tuesday<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#tuesday\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h4> <p>Dotnet 5 is out! The latest version of dotnet is released by Microsoft and to celebrate there is <a href=\"https://www.dotnetconf.net/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">dotnetconf</a> to listen to. Due to time zones and family commitments, I haven&rsquo;t listened to an awful lot of it but I did see the keynote and loved the 3 Scott&rsquo;s chat.</p> <h4 id=\"wednesday\">Wednesday<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#wednesday\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h4> <p>My youngest son was 3 today, due to Coronavirus we didn&rsquo;t do much but we celebrated as a family, and he even had a zoom call.</p> <h4 id=\"thursday\">Thursday<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#thursday\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h4> <p>Blazor has a new feature <a href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/core/blazor/components/virtualization?view=aspnetcore-5.0\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Virtualize</a> where a list of items can only load the ones on screen. I have been trying to get this to work on my blog, works great running locally but not working in production yet.</p> <p>Think I know what might be happening. I use Cloudflare to do my SSL, as Custom SSL certs for the cheaper Azure Web Apps is not supported. Something in Cloudflare is caching or interfering.</p> <p><a href=\"https://zimmergren.net/solved-asp-net-core-blazor-web-sites-does-not-work-with-cloudflare-html-minification/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">https://zimmergren.net/solved-asp-net-core-blazor-web-sites-does-not-work-with-cloudflare-html-minification/</a> </p> <p>Turning off HTML minification fixed my issue!</p> <p>One additional thing I added to my Blog is the config page which details some of the config settings. I think this probably came from <a href=\"https://www.hanselman.com/blog/adding-a-git-commit-hash-and-azure-devops-build-number-and-build-id-to-an-aspnet-website\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">https://www.hanselman.com/blog/adding-a-git-commit-hash-and-azure-devops-build-number-and-build-id-to-an-aspnet-website</a> but it was a while ago when I first did this on another project.</p> <p>At the moment we have .net Version, Commit and Build links.</p> <p>The .Net Version is obtained from</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>@System.Runtime.InteropServices.RuntimeInformation.FrameworkDescription </span></span></code></pre></div><p>A few other bits of info can be obtained from System.Runtime.InteropServices.RuntimeInformation which I have included on the page for fun. There are probably security concerns with exposing all this info publicly so something to bear in mind if you try this.</p> <p>Build Info is passed to my code by a build step</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-yml\" data-lang=\"yml\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>- <span style=\"color:#f92672\">script</span>: <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#39;(echo $(Build.BuildNumber) &amp;&amp; echo $(Build.BuildId)) &gt; .buildinfo.json&#39;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">displayName</span>: <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;Emit build number&#34;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">workingDirectory</span>: <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#39;$(Build.SourcesDirectory)/src/WebBlog&#39;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">failOnStderr</span>: <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">true</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This simply passed the build id and number which are stored as variabled and saves them in a text file.</p> <p>I then have a class that reads them and constructs a link.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">using</span> Microsoft.Extensions.Hosting; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">using</span> System; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">using</span> System.IO; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">using</span> System.Linq; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">using</span> System.Reflection; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">namespace</span> WebBlog </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>{ </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">public</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">class</span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">AppVersionInfo</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">private</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">const</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span> _buildFileName = <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;.buildinfo.json&#34;</span>; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">private</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">readonly</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span> _buildFilePath; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">private</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span> _buildNumber = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span>.Empty; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">private</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span> _buildId = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span>.Empty; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">private</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span> _gitHash = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span>.Empty; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">private</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span> _gitShortHash = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span>.Empty; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">public</span> AppVersionInfo(IHostEnvironment hostEnvironment) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> _buildFilePath = Path.Combine(hostEnvironment.ContentRootPath, _buildFileName); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">public</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span> BuildNumber </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">get</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">if</span> (<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span>.IsNullOrEmpty(_buildNumber)) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">if</span> (File.Exists(_buildFilePath)) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> fileContents = File.ReadLines(_buildFilePath).ToList(); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">if</span> (fileContents.Count &gt; <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">0</span>) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> _buildNumber = fileContents[<span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">0</span>]; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">if</span> (fileContents.Count &gt; <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">1</span>) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> _buildId = fileContents[<span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">1</span>]; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">if</span> (<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span>.IsNullOrEmpty(_buildNumber)) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> _buildNumber = DateTime.UtcNow.ToString(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;yyyyMMdd&#34;</span>) + <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;.0&#34;</span>; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">if</span> (<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span>.IsNullOrEmpty(_buildId)) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> _buildId = <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;123456&#34;</span>; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">return</span> _buildNumber; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">public</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span> BuildId </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">get</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">if</span> (<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span>.IsNullOrEmpty(_buildId)) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> _ = BuildNumber; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">return</span> _buildId; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">public</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span> GitHash </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">get</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">if</span> (<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span>.IsNullOrEmpty(_gitHash)) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> version = <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;1.0.0+LOCALBUILD&#34;</span>; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> appAssembly = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">typeof</span>(AppVersionInfo).Assembly; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> infoVerAttr = (AssemblyInformationalVersionAttribute)appAssembly </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> .GetCustomAttributes(<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">typeof</span>(AssemblyInformationalVersionAttribute)).FirstOrDefault(); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">if</span> (infoVerAttr != <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">null</span> &amp;&amp; infoVerAttr.InformationalVersion.Length &gt; <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">6</span>) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> version = infoVerAttr.InformationalVersion; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> _gitHash = version[(version.IndexOf(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#39;+&#39;</span>) + <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">1</span>)..]; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">return</span> _gitHash; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">public</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span> ShortGitHash </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">get</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">if</span> (<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span>.IsNullOrEmpty(_gitShortHash)) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> _gitShortHash = GitHash.Substring(GitHash.Length - <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">6</span>, <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">6</span>); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">return</span> _gitShortHash; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>} </span></span></code></pre></div><p>The BuildId and BuildNumber properties just fetch the details saved into the text file during the build. This can then be passed to build the build link.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-html\" data-lang=\"html\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>&lt;<span style=\"color:#f92672\">a</span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">href</span><span style=\"color:#f92672\">=</span><span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;https://dev.azure.com/{OrgName}/{RepoName}/_build/results?buildId=@appInfo.BuildId&amp;view=results&#34;</span>&gt; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> @appInfo.BuildNumber </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>&lt;/<span style=\"color:#f92672\">a</span>&gt; </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Finally, the GitHash properties need to fetch the hash and shorthash of the commit which is a bit more complex. This is achieved using the following line in your build.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-yml\" data-lang=\"yml\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>- <span style=\"color:#f92672\">task</span>: <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">DotNetCoreCLI@2</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">displayName</span>: <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#39;Publish&#39;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">inputs</span>: </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">command</span>: <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#39;publish&#39;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">publishWebProjects</span>: <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">true</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">arguments</span>: <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#39;--output $(Build.ArtifactStagingDirectory) /p:SourceRevisionId=$(Build.SourceVersion)&#39;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>/p:SourceRevisionId=$(Build.SourceVersion) add the revision hash to [assembly: AssemblyInformationalVersion] during the build which can then be extracted using the gitHash property above, before being passed into the commit link.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-html\" data-lang=\"html\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>&lt;<span style=\"color:#f92672\">a</span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">href</span><span style=\"color:#f92672\">=</span><span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;https://github.com/{OrgName}/{RepoName}/commit/@appInfo.GitHash&#34;</span>&gt; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> @appInfo.ShortGitHash </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>&lt;/<span style=\"color:#f92672\">a</span>&gt; </span></span></code></pre></div>"
              - generic [ref=e3418]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e3420]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e3421]:
          - generic [ref=e3424]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e3425]:
            - generic [ref=e3426]:
              - generic [ref=e3427]: <title>
              - text: Security Headers
              - generic [ref=e3428]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e3429]:
              - generic [ref=e3430]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2020/security-headers/
              - generic [ref=e3431]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e3432]:
              - generic [ref=e3433]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e3434]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e3435]:
              - generic [ref=e3436]: <pubDate>
              - text: Sat, 26 Sep 2020 00:00:00 +0000
              - generic [ref=e3437]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e3438]:
              - generic [ref=e3439]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2020/security-headers/
              - generic [ref=e3440]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e3441]:
              - generic [ref=e3442]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3443]: term="DotNet"
                - text: ">"
              - text: DotNet
              - generic [ref=e3444]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3445]:
              - generic [ref=e3446]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3447]: term="Security"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Security
              - generic [ref=e3448]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3449]:
              - generic [ref=e3450]: <description>
              - text: "<p>Have you wondered what info you are leaking via your response headers?, do you want some kind of guide about what headers to set or remove altogether?</p> <p>Head on over to <a href=\"https://securityheaders.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">https://securityheaders.com/</a> This is a site created by security expert <a href=\"https://scotthelme.co.uk\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Scott Helme</a> that rates a URL based on what response headers it can see.</p> <p>I am pleased to say <a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com\">https://www.funkysi1701.com</a> is now getting an A.<img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"Alt Text\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2020/07rwumi94fz141hwessu.png\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"2434\" height=\"496\" /> </p> <p>So how do you add/remove headers in dotnet core?</p> <p>In my configure method in Startup.cs I have the following code block.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>app.Use( </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> next =&gt; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">return</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">async</span> context =&gt; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> context.Response.OnStarting( </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> () =&gt; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> context.Response.Headers.Add(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;Permissions-Policy&#34;</span>, <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;microphone=()&#34;</span>); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> context.Response.Headers.Remove(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;Server&#34;</span>); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> context.Response.Headers.Remove(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;X-Powered-By&#34;</span>); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> context.Response.Headers.Remove(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;X-AspNet-Version&#34;</span>); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">return</span> Task.CompletedTask; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> }); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">await</span> next(context); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> }; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> }); </span></span></code></pre></div><p>I have only included a few of the headers I am adding as the excellent <a href=\"https://securityheaders.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">https://securityheaders.com/</a> can tell you which headers you should add and what options you might want.</p>"
              - generic [ref=e3451]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e3453]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e3454]:
          - generic [ref=e3457]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e3458]:
            - generic [ref=e3459]:
              - generic [ref=e3460]: <title>
              - text: "Returning to Blogging: Why I‚Äôm Writing Again as a Developer"
              - generic [ref=e3461]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e3462]:
              - generic [ref=e3463]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2020/back-to-blogging/
              - generic [ref=e3464]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e3465]:
              - generic [ref=e3466]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e3467]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e3468]:
              - generic [ref=e3469]: <pubDate>
              - text: Fri, 25 Sep 2020 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e3470]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e3471]:
              - generic [ref=e3472]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2020/back-to-blogging/
              - generic [ref=e3473]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e3474]:
              - generic [ref=e3475]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3476]: term="Blogging"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Blogging
              - generic [ref=e3477]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3478]:
              - generic [ref=e3479]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3480]: term="Blazor"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Blazor
              - generic [ref=e3481]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3482]:
              - generic [ref=e3483]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3484]: term="DotNet"
                - text: ">"
              - text: DotNet
              - generic [ref=e3485]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3486]:
              - generic [ref=e3487]: <description>
              - text: <p>My last blog post was over six months ago.</p> <p>Covid 19 has hit the world, and I will be honest I have found it a challenging time.</p> <p>My Blog had gotten into a bit of a mess. It had become fragmented with different versions of the same thing; I will attempt to explain what has become of my blog.</p> <p>The original WordPress site can currently be found at <a href="https://www.pwnedpass.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">https://www.pwnedpass.com/</a> I would prefer it to be on a sub-domain of funkysi1701.com but for some reason I haven&rsquo;t been able to get that to work, not sure if it is a limitation of my hosting package. I like WordPress, it is very flexible, easy to get blog posts out there. But I want to write content about development and having a site I can tinker with is important to me.</p> <p>Most of my WordPress blogs have been imported into dev.to and a few extra have been written on this platform. I like dev.to it is a wonderful place to share content and it has one or two extra features I like.</p> <p>dev.to has an integration with Stackbit/Netlify and this became <a href="https://dev.funkysi1701.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">https://dev.funkysi1701.com</a> . I like having a personal site, but having the same content as dev.to. To add content to this site all I need to do is write it on dev.to and some magic will go on behind the scenes and new content will be published.</p> <p>However, as a developer I don&rsquo;t like magic, I want to understand what is going on a fiddle with all the settings and make it do what I want.</p> <p>dev.to has an API, I can build a site in .Net Core and make API calls to fetch the content I want. I understand APIs, I understand .Net and can customise my site exactly how I want it, plus play about with a .net website. This is what <a href="https://www.funkysi1701.com">https://www.funkysi1701.com</a> is now.</p> <p>So what have I built so far. I have a Server Side Blazor site running .Net 5. Why Server Side and not Client Side I hear you ask? Well only because I have more experience with Server Side and know how to quickly create a website with that technology, I may change it as time goes by, but we will see.</p> <p>I have two pages a list of my blog posts and a page that displays the content. Both of these use the dev.to API. I lied, there is a third page I hacked together to do some page redirection from the WordPress URLs. This is something I will change as time goes on.</p> <p>There are lots of improvements I want to do, there are probably also lots of broken images or links as well. Hopefully, this will result in a good platform to blog about as well as on.</p>
              - generic [ref=e3488]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e3490]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e3491]:
          - generic [ref=e3494]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e3495]:
            - generic [ref=e3496]:
              - generic [ref=e3497]: <title>
              - text: Testing for expiring SSL Certificates
              - generic [ref=e3498]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e3499]:
              - generic [ref=e3500]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2020/testing-for-expiring-ssl-certificates/
              - generic [ref=e3501]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e3502]:
              - generic [ref=e3503]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e3504]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e3505]:
              - generic [ref=e3506]: <pubDate>
              - text: Tue, 03 Mar 2020 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e3507]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e3508]:
              - generic [ref=e3509]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2020/testing-for-expiring-ssl-certificates/
              - generic [ref=e3510]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e3511]:
              - generic [ref=e3512]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3513]: term="Security"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Security
              - generic [ref=e3514]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3515]:
              - generic [ref=e3516]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3517]: term="SSL"
                - text: ">"
              - text: SSL
              - generic [ref=e3518]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3519]:
              - generic [ref=e3520]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3521]: term="Testing"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Testing
              - generic [ref=e3522]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3523]:
              - generic [ref=e3524]: <description>
              - text: "<p>Let&rsquo;s Encrypt is amazing, you can easily add SSL certificates to any website and automate the renewal process. I have talked <a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/let-s-encrypt-is-awesome-3f5j/\">before</a> about how impressive it is.</p> <p>Once you start adding SSL certificates to your production sites however you may want to check when they expire so you don&rsquo;t get caught out. You can always open your site in your favourite browser and view the certificate information and expiry date.</p> <p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"SSL Cert\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2020/jb78re4fmm1ofx81f3mu.jpg\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"671\" height=\"608\" /> However there is a way to automate this check.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">[Fact]</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">public</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">void</span> IsSSLExpiring() </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>{ </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> handler = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> HttpClientHandler </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> ServerCertificateCustomValidationCallback = CustomCallback </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> }; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> client = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> HttpClient(handler); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> HttpResponseMessage response = client.GetAsync(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;https://www.example.com&#34;</span>).GetAwaiter().GetResult(); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> Assert.True(response.IsSuccessStatusCode); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>} </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">private</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">bool</span> CustomCallback(HttpRequestMessage arg1, X509Certificate2 arg2, X509Chain arg3, SslPolicyErrors arg4) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>{ </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> now = DateTime.UtcNow; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> expire = arg2.NotAfter; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> diff = (expire - now).TotalDays; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> Assert.InRange(diff, <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">30</span>, <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">1000</span>); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">return</span> arg4 == SslPolicyErrors.None; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>} </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This code gets the SSL expiry date from <a href=\"https://www.example.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">https://www.example.com</a> and will fail the xunit test if the expiry date is less than 30 days in the future. I then schedule my tests to run regularly on all my environments with a Let&rsquo;s Encrypt Certificate and this gives me advanced warning if a SSL certificate is about to expire.</p> <p>The Assert.InRange(diff, 30, 1000) line will fail the test if the expiry date is less than 30 days or greater than 1000, but as the default expiry for Let&rsquo;s Encrypt certificates is three months it will never be greater than 1000 days even with a freshly installed certificate. These values can be tweaked to suit your use case, however 30 days is enough time for me to investigate what is happening.</p> <p>To execute my tests I use a scheduled build in Azure DevOps, but anything that regularly can run your tests will do the job.</p> <p>The code above is just a simple example to get your started for my purposes I have put all my URLs into config files and just pass these into my tests, so I don&rsquo;t need a custom test for every different URL.</p>"
              - generic [ref=e3525]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e3527]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e3528]:
          - generic [ref=e3531]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e3532]:
            - generic [ref=e3533]:
              - generic [ref=e3534]: <title>
              - text: Picard is back!
              - generic [ref=e3535]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e3536]:
              - generic [ref=e3537]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2019/picard-is-back/
              - generic [ref=e3538]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e3539]:
              - generic [ref=e3540]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e3541]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e3542]:
              - generic [ref=e3543]: <pubDate>
              - text: Thu, 08 Aug 2019 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e3544]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e3545]:
              - generic [ref=e3546]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2019/picard-is-back/
              - generic [ref=e3547]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e3548]:
              - generic [ref=e3549]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3550]: term="StarTrek"
                - text: ">"
              - text: StarTrek
              - generic [ref=e3551]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3552]:
              - generic [ref=e3553]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3554]: term="Picard"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Picard
              - generic [ref=e3555]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3556]:
              - generic [ref=e3557]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3558]: term="PatrickStewart"
                - text: ">"
              - text: PatrickStewart
              - generic [ref=e3559]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3560]:
              - generic [ref=e3561]: <description>
              - text: "<p>It has just been announced at the annual Star Trek Las Vegas (<a href=\"https://twitter.com/hashtag/STLV\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">#STLV</a> ) convention that Patrick Stewart is going to return to his role as Jean-Luc Picard in a new TV Show.</p> <iframe type=\"text/html\" width=\"662\" height=\"373\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/aCKQp1sGVRQ?version=3&amp;rel=1&amp;fs=1&amp;autohide=2&amp;showsearch=0&amp;showinfo=1&amp;iv_load_policy=1&amp;wmode=transparent\" allowfullscreen=\"true\" style=\"border:0;\"></iframe> <p>Few other details have been announced other than the TV show will take place 20 years after the film Star Trek: Nemesis and will feature the character of Jean-Luc Picard.</p> <p>Lets run though a few things I would like to see from this new show.</p> <h2 id=\"low-on-action\">Low on Action<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#low-on-action\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>Star Trek: Discovery is a great show and has brought Star Trek back to our TV shows. However it is an action show, it zooms along so fast and with so much action I would appreciate a show that can takes its time a bit more.</p> <p>I want a show that can show Picard carefully considering some moral issue and making a decision. Something we were used to seeing on TNG.</p> <h2 id=\"feature-picards-excellent-speeches\">Feature Picard‚Äôs excellent speeches<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#feature-picards-excellent-speeches\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>One of the best features I can think of Jean-Luc Picard is his ability to make speeches about one issue or other.</p> <p>Lets look at a few examples:</p> <p><strong>Insurection</strong> : Picard speaks about the forced relocation of a group of people.</p> <blockquote> <p>How many people does it take, Admiral, before it becomes wrong? Hmm? A thousand, fifty thousand, a million? How many people does it take, Admiral?</p> </blockquote> <p><strong>First</strong> <strong>Contact</strong> : Picard is hell bent on revenge for what the Borg have done to him and refuses to destroy the Enterprise to save his crew.</p> <blockquote> <p>‚ÄúI will not sacrifice the Enterprise. We‚Äôve made too many compromises already. Too many retreats. They invade our space and we fall back. They assimilate entire worlds, and we fall back. Not again! The line must be drawn here, ‚Ä¶this far, no further! And I will make them pay for what they‚Äôve done.‚Äù</p> </blockquote> <p><strong>Measure of a Man</strong> : Picard argues for the rights of Data.</p> <blockquote> <p>‚ÄúYou see, he‚Äôs met two of your three criteria for sentience, so what if he meets the third. Consciousness in even the smallest degree. What is he then? I don‚Äôt know. Do you? (to Riker) Do you? (to Phillipa) Do you? Well, that‚Äôs the question you have to answer. Your Honour, the courtroom is a crucible. In it we burn away irrelevancies until we are left with a pure product, the truth for all time. Now, sooner or later, this man or others like him will succeed in replicating Commander Data. And the decision you reach here today will determine how we will regard this creation of our genius. It will reveal the kind of a people we are, what he is destined to be. It will reach far beyond this courtroom and this one android. It could significantly redefine the boundaries of personal liberty and freedom, expanding them for some, savagely curtailing them for others. Are you prepared to condemn him and all who come after him to servitude and slavery? Your Honour, Starfleet was founded to seek out new life. Well, there it sits. Waiting. You wanted a chance to make law. Well, here it is. Make a good one.‚Äù</p> </blockquote> <h2 id=\"ask-important-questions\">Ask important questions<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#ask-important-questions\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>We live in uncertain times. There are lots of pressures on today‚Äôs world and we need to acknowledge these. Picard is an excellent character to use to ask important questions of the day.</p> <p>What does it mean to be human?<br> How should we treat people that are different to us?<br> How should we react to extremism?</p> <h2 id=\"deal-with-his-age\">Deal with his age<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#deal-with-his-age\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>In the last episode of TNG a future version of Picard is shown 25 years into the future. This is a similar time period so it will be interesting to compare the two. Have Picard look back on his life and ask questions about his life choices.</p> <p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"Picard\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2018/08/all-good-things.jpg\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"320\" height=\"320\" /> </p> <h2 id=\"be-consistent-with-his-past\">Be consistent with his past<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#be-consistent-with-his-past\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>Picard is a well known character. So writers please don‚Äôt change him. I want a character we know, not a character that looks like Picard but acts in a way contrary to what we would expect.</p> <p>Picard has a history we know, he served on the stargazer and of course the Enterprise, he has an artificial heart, he was assimiliated by the Borg. All</p> <h2 id=\"reference-50-years-of-star-trek\">Reference 50 years of Star Trek<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#reference-50-years-of-star-trek\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>Discovery and Enterprise are TV shows which have a problem. There is Trek going on after them which imposes a few rules on what can and can‚Äôt be done.</p> <p>This is a TV Show that will take place after every other Trek TV and Film and can do whatever the creators want. This gives freedom, but it also gives the responsibility to reference what has gone before.</p> <p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"Picard\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2018/08/download.jpg\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"275\" height=\"183\" /> </p> <p>The 2009 Star Trek film features the destruction of Romulus and Spock travelling back in time. How about Picard dealing with surviving Romulans helping rebuild their society, continuing the work that Spock started in the TNG episode Unification.</p> <p>I look forward to finding out what the Star Trek production team has in store for us. If they have Patrick Stewart convinced I am sure it is going to be good.</p>"
              - generic [ref=e3562]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e3564]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e3565]:
          - generic [ref=e3568]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e3569]:
            - generic [ref=e3570]:
              - generic [ref=e3571]: <title>
              - text: Infrastructure as Code - Creating Azure Resources with Terraform
              - generic [ref=e3572]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e3573]:
              - generic [ref=e3574]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2019/infrastructure-as-code-creating-azure-resources-with-terraform/
              - generic [ref=e3575]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e3576]:
              - generic [ref=e3577]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e3578]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e3579]:
              - generic [ref=e3580]: <pubDate>
              - text: Sat, 11 May 2019 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e3581]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e3582]:
              - generic [ref=e3583]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2019/infrastructure-as-code-creating-azure-resources-with-terraform/
              - generic [ref=e3584]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e3585]:
              - generic [ref=e3586]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3587]: term="Azure"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Azure
              - generic [ref=e3588]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3589]:
              - generic [ref=e3590]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3591]: term="Infrastructure"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Infrastructure
              - generic [ref=e3592]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3593]:
              - generic [ref=e3594]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3595]: term="Terrafrom"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Terrafrom
              - generic [ref=e3596]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3597]:
              - generic [ref=e3598]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3599]: term="DevOps"
                - text: ">"
              - text: DevOps
              - generic [ref=e3600]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3601]:
              - generic [ref=e3602]: <description>
              - text: "<p>Terraform is a way to script the creation of Azure Resources. By scripting the creation of your resources you can run them again and again and be certain that everything is configured exactly the same as the script has specified. No more forgetting to tick the tick box, if it‚Äôs in your script then it will be deployed with exactly the same configuration.</p> <p>The process of executing a terraform script follows this basic process.</p> <p><strong>terraform init</strong> ‚Äì Initialises the terraform directory <strong>terraform plan</strong> ‚Äì generates and displays what will be executed <strong>terraform apply</strong> ‚Äì applies the terraform script to your Azure subscription <strong>terraform destroy</strong> ‚Äì deletes your Azure resource that were created in the previous step</p> <p>Lets look at how you might execute a terraform script from your build or release pipeline.</p> <p>I am executing my terraform scripts from my release pipeline and as I don‚Äôt want to check binaries into my source code I am going to add a bit of plumbing to get things in the right places. The terraform binary can be obtained from <a href=\"https://www.terraform.io/downloads.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">https://www.terraform.io/downloads.html</a> .</p> <p>To start with I am executing a Powershell script to download the terraform binary, this is in the form of a zip file, so i need to download and unzip it.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-powershell\" data-lang=\"powershell\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\">#Download</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>$url = <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;https://releases.hashicorp.com/terraform/0.11.13/terraform_0.11.13_windows_amd64.zip&#34;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>$output = <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;terraform.zip&#34;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>(New-Object System.Net.WebClient).DownloadFile($url, $output) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\">#Unzip</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>Add-Type -AssemblyName System.IO.Compression.FileSystem </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>[<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">System.IO.Compression.ZipFile</span>]::ExtractToDirectory($output, Get-Location) </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now that I have the terraform binaries I can just run Azure Cli and execute the terraform commands above.</p> <p>Now it is time to look at the the terraform script. This particular script creates a resource group, an app service plan and a webapp.</p> <pre tabindex=\"0\"><code># Configure the Microsoft Azure Provider provider &#34;azurerm&#34; { subscription_id = &#34;&#34; client_id = &#34;&#34; client_secret = &#34;&#34; tenant_id = &#34;&#34; } resource &#34;azurerm_resource_group&#34; &#34;rg&#34; { name = &#34;resource-group&#34; location = &#34;northeurope&#34; } resource &#34;azurerm_app_service_plan&#34; &#34;plan&#34; { name = &#34;planname&#34; location = &#34;${azurerm_resource_group.rg.location}&#34; resource_group_name = &#34;${azurerm_resource_group.rg.name}&#34; sku { tier = &#34;Standard&#34; size = &#34;S1&#34; } } resource &#34;azurerm_app_service&#34; &#34;webapp&#34; { name = &#34;example-app-service&#34; location = &#34;${azurerm_resource_group.rg.location}&#34; resource_group_name = &#34;${azurerm_resource_group.rg.name}&#34; app_service_plan_id = &#34;${azurerm_app_service_plan.plan.id}&#34; } </code></pre><p>There are four guids that you need to fill in from your azure subscription and to find these you need to run a few commands from Azure Cli. Check out <a href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/linux/terraform-install-configure\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/linux/terraform-install-configure</a> for more detail on these commands.</p> <p>Run these either from Azure Cloud Shell or from Powershell command prompt after Azure Cli has been installed.</p> <p>az login ‚Äì to login to azure a browser window will open up.</p> <p>az account show ‚Äìquery &ldquo;{subscriptionId:id, tenantId:tenantId}&rdquo; This will show you your subscription id.</p> <p>az account set ‚Äìsubscription=&quot;${SUBSCRIPTION_ID}&quot; Where ${SUBSCRIPTION_ID} is the subscription id you found in the last step.</p> <p>az ad sp create-for-rbac ‚Äìrole=&ldquo;Contributor&rdquo; ‚Äìscopes=&quot;/subscriptions/${SUBSCRIPTION_ID}&quot; Where ${SUBSCRIPTION_ID} is the subscription id you found in the last step and assumes you have permission to the subscription.</p> <p>This last command will about a series of Guids which you need to fill in at the top of your terraform file appId = client_id, password = client_secret, tenant = tenant_id and subscription_id you already have.</p> <p>This just gives you a taste of what you can do with terraform. Looking at the <a href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/terraform/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Azure Terraform docs</a> there are loads of different resources you can create and even a <a href=\"https://github.com/terraform-providers/terraform-provider-azurerm\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">github repo</a> with some samples.</p>"
              - generic [ref=e3603]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e3605]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e3606]:
          - generic [ref=e3609]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e3610]:
            - generic [ref=e3611]:
              - generic [ref=e3612]: <title>
              - text: Gated Release
              - generic [ref=e3613]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e3614]:
              - generic [ref=e3615]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2019/gated-release/
              - generic [ref=e3616]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e3617]:
              - generic [ref=e3618]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e3619]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e3620]:
              - generic [ref=e3621]: <pubDate>
              - text: Fri, 05 Apr 2019 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e3622]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e3623]:
              - generic [ref=e3624]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2019/gated-release/
              - generic [ref=e3625]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e3626]:
              - generic [ref=e3627]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3628]: term="Azure"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Azure
              - generic [ref=e3629]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3630]:
              - generic [ref=e3631]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3632]: term="API"
                - text: ">"
              - text: API
              - generic [ref=e3633]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3634]:
              - generic [ref=e3635]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3636]: term="ApplicationInsights"
                - text: ">"
              - text: ApplicationInsights
              - generic [ref=e3637]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3638]:
              - generic [ref=e3639]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3640]: term="DevOps"
                - text: ">"
              - text: DevOps
              - generic [ref=e3641]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3642]:
              - generic [ref=e3643]: <description>
              - text: <p>Automated releases of software are great but how can we add an element of feedback so only good releases go live.</p> <p>I have been using Azure DevOps to release my PwnedPass android app to the Google Play Store for a while now. There are options to deploy to the alpha, Beta or Production tracks and even to set % of users to target. For the full range of options check out the Google Play <a href="https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=ms-vsclient.google-play" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">extension</a> for Azure DevOps.</p> <p>My release starts by publishing to 10% of users on the production track, my next step makes use of the increase rollout option to increase this %, you can have as many of these additional steps as you want until you reach 100% of your users.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="Image" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2019/04/image.png" loading="lazy" width="1540" height="271" /> </p> <p>Now if you run this release now it will just run through each of the steps one after the other. Now of course you can add a pre or post approval to your pipeline but this just adds a manual dependency to your release. Whoever does the approving needs to check things are working before approving or worse just approves regardless.</p> <p>Azure DevOps has the concept of <a href="https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/pipelines/release/deploy-using-approvals?view=azure-devops" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">gated releases</a> which allows you to add automated checks before or after a release happens. These automated checks can be any of the following:</p> <ul> <li>An Azure Function</li> <li>A Rest API call</li> <li>Azure Monitor Alert</li> <li>Query Work Items</li> <li>Security and Compliance Assessment</li> </ul> <p>We are going to make use of the Azure Monitor Alert, to create an alert from your Application Insights data and only continue the rollout if no failures are detected.</p> <p>Open up your application insights resource in the Azure portal and look in alerts. Click add new alert rule.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="Image" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2019/04/image-1.png" loading="lazy" width="1616" height="1347" /> </p> <p>Select your application insights resource in Resource, In Condition choose a condition to check, I chose Failed Requests, so every time a failure is registered in my API I can stop the deployment. The exact criteria you want to use is entirely up to you.</p> <p>Create an action group, I just set my alert to send an email to myself but there are other alert actions you may want to try. Give your alert a name and description and click save.</p> <p>Now all we need to do is make Azure DevOps make use of this alert. In your release pipeline select the pre-deployment conditions of your second step and open up the Gates section.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="Image" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2019/04/image-2.png" loading="lazy" width="1107" height="833" /> </p> <p>Choose a suitable time to evaluate, I have been using something long like 12 or 24 hours so if there are problems there is time for it to be noticed. Choose Version 1 of the task (I was not able to get it to work with Version 0)</p> <p>Now select your Azure subscription and Resource Group and leave the rest of the settings as they are. Now your Deployment will stop and analyse application insights for any Failed requests and will halt if it finds any.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="Image" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2019/04/image-3.png" loading="lazy" width="1748" height="232" /> </p> <p>I am still testing this out but it will take a few days to figure out if this what I want due to the large time scales involved. I feel this is going to be an improvement of manually approving release steps.</p>
              - generic [ref=e3644]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e3646]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e3647]:
          - generic [ref=e3650]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e3651]:
            - generic [ref=e3652]:
              - generic [ref=e3653]: <title>
              - text: Documenting your API
              - generic [ref=e3654]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e3655]:
              - generic [ref=e3656]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2019/documenting-your-api/
              - generic [ref=e3657]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e3658]:
              - generic [ref=e3659]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e3660]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e3661]:
              - generic [ref=e3662]: <pubDate>
              - text: Wed, 27 Mar 2019 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e3663]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e3664]:
              - generic [ref=e3665]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2019/documenting-your-api/
              - generic [ref=e3666]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e3667]:
              - generic [ref=e3668]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3669]: term="Swagger"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Swagger
              - generic [ref=e3670]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3671]:
              - generic [ref=e3672]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3673]: term="API"
                - text: ">"
              - text: API
              - generic [ref=e3674]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3675]:
              - generic [ref=e3676]: <description>
              - text: "<p>So you have created a super API that does something amazing. How do you document it so people will use it?</p> <p>One way of easily documenting your API is to install the Swashbuckle package.</p> <pre tabindex=\"0\"><code>Install-Package Swashbuckle.AspNetCore Install-Package Swashbuckle.AspNetCore.Swagger </code></pre><p>Then in you startup.cs add the following lines</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\">//In ConfigureServices</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>services.AddSwaggerGen(c =&gt; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>{ </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> c.SwaggerDoc(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;v1&#34;</span>, <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> Info { Title = <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;API&#34;</span>, Version = <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;v1&#34;</span>, Description = <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;An API Description&#34;</span> }); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> c.IncludeXmlComments(<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span>.Format(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">@&#34;{0}\\API.xml&#34;</span>, System.AppDomain.CurrentDomain.BaseDirectory)); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>}); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\">//In Configure</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>app.UseSwagger(); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>app.UseSwaggerUI(c =&gt; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>{ </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> c.SwaggerEndpoint(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;/swagger/v1/swagger.json&#34;</span>, <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;API V1&#34;</span>); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> c.RoutePrefix = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span>.Empty; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>}); </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now when you browse to your API you will see the swagger documentation system.</p> <p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"Image\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2019/03/image-3.png\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"883\" height=\"602\" /> </p> <p>The RoutePrefix setting controls the path in which swagger will display. I have my docs at the root, but you might want them under the /docs or similar path.</p> <p>The IncludeXmlComments setting from the ConfigureServices method allows you to load in any XML comments you have added to methods. For this to work you need to enable a setting to your build.</p> <p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"Image\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2019/03/image-4.png\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"997\" height=\"822\" /> </p> <p>The XML documentation file must be ticked and contain a path. Everytime you do a build, a XML file will be generated which contains all the comment blocks you have added to your code.</p> <p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"Image\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2019/03/image-5.png\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"610\" height=\"184\" /> </p> <p>Swagger will then use this XML documentation file to produce lovely looking documentation without you having to do anything extra.</p> <p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"Image\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2019/03/image-6.png\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"1796\" height=\"705\" /> </p>"
              - generic [ref=e3677]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e3679]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e3680]:
          - generic [ref=e3683]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e3684]:
            - generic [ref=e3685]:
              - generic [ref=e3686]: <title>
              - text: Azure Key Vault
              - generic [ref=e3687]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e3688]:
              - generic [ref=e3689]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2019/azure-key-vault/
              - generic [ref=e3690]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e3691]:
              - generic [ref=e3692]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e3693]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e3694]:
              - generic [ref=e3695]: <pubDate>
              - text: Tue, 19 Mar 2019 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e3696]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e3697]:
              - generic [ref=e3698]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2019/azure-key-vault/
              - generic [ref=e3699]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e3700]:
              - generic [ref=e3701]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3702]: term="Website"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Website
              - generic [ref=e3703]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3704]:
              - generic [ref=e3705]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3706]: term="Security"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Security
              - generic [ref=e3707]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3708]:
              - generic [ref=e3709]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3710]: term="Azure"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Azure
              - generic [ref=e3711]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3712]:
              - generic [ref=e3713]: <description>
              - text: "<p><a href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/en-gb/azure/key-vault/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Azure Key Vault</a> is a secure way of storing your keys, certificates and secrets so your application can access everything it needs to but you don‚Äôt have them being stored insecurely anywhere such as in source control.</p> <p>I have been wanting to give Azure Key Vault a try for a while now as it can make use of Azure Active Directory to give your web app an identity so it can authenticate itself into the key vault to access secrets. Pretty clever but with a lot of moving parts a bit complex.</p> <p>For my example I am just going to connect to my Key Vault and get a secret and display it somewhere on a web page. This is of course not what you want to do as secrets are secret and shouldn‚Äôt be displayed just used to authenticate into whatever, however it is an easy way to prove I am connecting to the Key Vault and everything is working.</p> <p>Lets look at some code. I have a .net core application and to start with lets install three nuget packages.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-txt\" data-lang=\"txt\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>Microsoft.Azure.KeyVault </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>Microsoft.Azure.Services.AppAuthentication </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.AzureKeyVault </span></span></code></pre></div><p>I‚Äôve not include version numbers as these will no doubt get updated over time but hopefully it will still work.</p> <p>Now in your Program.cs add the following code, replacing [KeyVaultName] with the name of your Key Vault.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">public</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">class</span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">Program</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">public</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">static</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">void</span> Main(<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span>[] args) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> CreateWebHostBuilder(args).Build().Run(); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">public</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">static</span> IWebHostBuilder CreateWebHostBuilder(<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span>[] args) =&gt; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> WebHost.CreateDefaultBuilder(args) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> .ConfigureAppConfiguration((context, config) =&gt; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> builtConfig = config.Build(); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> azureServiceTokenProvider = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> AzureServiceTokenProvider(); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> keyVaultClient = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> KeyVaultClient( </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> KeyVaultClient.AuthenticationCallback( </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> azureServiceTokenProvider.KeyVaultTokenCallback)); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> config.AddAzureKeyVault( </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">$&#34;https://[KeyVaultName].vault.azure.net/&#34;</span>, </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> keyVaultClient, </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> DefaultKeyVaultSecretManager()); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> }) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> .UseApplicationInsights() </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> .UseStartup&lt;Startup&gt;(); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now all you need to do is look at your configuration to pull out secrets from your Azure Key Vault. If you have a secret called AppSecret then you can use the following code snippet to retrieve its value, assuming _configuration is an implementation of Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.IConfiguration.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-txt\" data-lang=\"txt\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>_configuration[&#34;AppSecret&#34;]; </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now if you do all of this and run from an Azure Web App or run locally it will fail to pull anything from the Key Vault.
