You need to give your web app an identity and configure your key vault to allow access from that identity.</p> <p>Once my code has been deployed to an Azure Web App I get the following error.</p> <p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"Image\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2019/image.png\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"1102\" height=\"486\" /> </p> <p>Lets look at fixing that, first lets give my web app an Identity. Open up the Azure portal and find the identity section of your web app and turn the setting on.</p> <p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"Image\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2019/image-1.png\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"1218\" height=\"728\" /> </p> <p>Now you need to grant that identity permission to your key vault. In the portal open up Access Policies in your key vault and click add Policy, select the identity of your web app in the principal box and select the following settings to grant access to your secret.</p> <p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"Image\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2019/image-2.png\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"411\" height=\"855\" /> </p> <p>Now you have a website that can pull secrets out of Key Vault but only that unique identity. Anyone who has access to your source code will not have access to your secrets, even if they push your code to a different Azure Web App.</p>"
              - generic [ref=e3714]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e3716]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e3717]:
          - generic [ref=e3720]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e3721]:
            - generic [ref=e3722]:
              - generic [ref=e3723]: <title>
              - text: Technology I want to learn more about
              - generic [ref=e3724]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e3725]:
              - generic [ref=e3726]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2019/technology-i-want-to-learn-more-about/
              - generic [ref=e3727]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e3728]:
              - generic [ref=e3729]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e3730]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e3731]:
              - generic [ref=e3732]: <pubDate>
              - text: Tue, 05 Mar 2019 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e3733]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e3734]:
              - generic [ref=e3735]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2019/technology-i-want-to-learn-more-about/
              - generic [ref=e3736]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e3737]:
              - generic [ref=e3738]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3739]: term="C-Sharp"
                - text: ">"
              - text: C-Sharp
              - generic [ref=e3740]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3741]:
              - generic [ref=e3742]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3743]: term="Azure"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Azure
              - generic [ref=e3744]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3745]:
              - generic [ref=e3746]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3747]: term="Security"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Security
              - generic [ref=e3748]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3749]:
              - generic [ref=e3750]: <description>
              - text: <p>While at <a href="https://www.funkysi1701.com/2019/02/26/microsoft-ignite-the-tour-london">Microsoft Ignite</a> I heard about a lot of cool tech that I want to know more about. The best way to learn something is use it to solve a problem.</p> <p>So what can I build that is both useful and will let me play with some new tech?</p> <p>I have a Xamarin Forms app Pwned Pass that has over 500 downloads on <a href="https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=pwnedpasswords.pwnedpasswords" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Google play</a> and over 80 downloads on the <a href="https://www.microsoft.com/en-gb/p/pwned-pass/9nm2whnztnlt?rtc=1" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Microsoft Store</a> . This has given me a small user base that I can use to make use of whatever I build.</p> <p>My app makes use of the <a href="https://haveibeenpwned.com/API/v3" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">HIBP API</a> created by Troy Hunt. I am going to build my own API, initially it will just make calls to the HIBP API. Building this will give me experience of building something with .net Core from design to deployment. I have made a start already on doing this, I have an empty .net core API project which deploys to an Azure web app using the build and release pipelines from Azure DevOps.</p> <p>You may be wondering why I am not making use of Azure Functions to build this API. Azure functions is certainly a great technology that is worth learning about. However I have done a little bit with them in the past and I don‚Äôt believe I would be able to learn all the things I want to if I used Azure Functions. My primary goal is learning and sharing that learning via this blog. It may well be I move to using Azure Functions later on.</p> <p>Another tech I am keen to learn more about is <a href="https://docs.microsoft.com/en-gb/azure/key-vault/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Azure Key Vault</a> . This is a technology that allows the securing of keys, connection strings and certificates. I want my app to securely get keys and security information without any of it having to be committed to source code or shared insecurely.</p> <p>Monitoring my app is also a key learning from me. I use application insights already, but I would like to extend my understanding of this so telemetry can be fed back into the build and bad deployments stopped.</p> <p>Below is my complete list of learning and tech I want to touch on. It is a long list and I imagine it will get longer as I work through it. I want to regularly blog and share what I have been working on. I currently have a working build and release pipeline but nothing of note to build or release. I know Key Vault needs looking at early as the identity of the website in Azure is key to getting that tech working correctly.</p> <ol> <li>Build API with .net core</li> <li>Add build and release pipeline</li> <li>Make use of Azure KeyVault for secrets, connection strings etc</li> <li>Plugin My Xamarin app to make use of it</li> <li>Monitor my API with Application Insights</li> <li>Secure it with CSPs and log this into <a href="https://report-uri.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Report URI</a> </li> <li>Consider building a web frontend to my API using a javascript library or framework. Maybe react but this can be decided later.</li> <li>Dockerize the API and add the creation of docker images to the build/release pipeline</li> </ol>
              - generic [ref=e3751]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e3753]: </item>

              - generic [ref=e3761]: </title>

              - text: Azure
              - generic [ref=e3781]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3782]:
              - generic [ref=e3783]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3784]: term="Microsoft"

              - text: Microsoft
              - generic [ref=e3785]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3786]:

                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3788]: term="DevOps"
                - text: ">"
              - text: DevOps
              - generic [ref=e3789]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3790]:
              - generic [ref=e3791]: <description>
              - text: "<p>I have just spent the first day at the conference Microsoft Ignite | The Tour. <img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"Alt Text\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2019/02/D0UTj08XgAEo1YJ.jpg\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"1534\" height=\"1018\" /> The conference was free I just needed to arrange travel and accommodation. Microsoft have really looked after me and all the other guests, breakfast and lunch has been provided, I got a free t-shirt, coffee (or tea) all day plus a beer or glass of wine to end the day. And that‚Äôs before you collect any free stuff the vendors are giving away.</p> <p>The first session was Designing resilient cloud applications with <a href=\"https://twitter.com/CodeMillMatt\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Matt Soucoup</a> and talked about some cloud technologies like Azure key vault and serving static files from blob storage. Unfortunately this had a few technical issues with the demos. I think it was just connectivity with the MongoDB backend but this slightly spoiled the session. As this was the only technical problem I noticed all day I can let it pass.</p> <p>Next was a session on Azure DevOps mainly build and release pipelines called Deploying your application faster and safer with <a href=\"https://twitter.com/bbenz\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Brian Benz</a> . A lot of this I knew but good to reinforce I am doing things correctly.</p> <p>Next was a session on Application Insights called Detecting application anomalies with Telemetry with Matt Soucoup.</p> <p>Probably the most useful session was on Docker and Kubernetes called Integrate containers and Kubernetes into your Azure DevOps build and release model with <a href=\"https://twitter.com/crad77\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Marco De Sanctis</a> . Going to spend some time looking through the examples from this session.</p> <p>A session on Serverless covered Azure Functions, Azure Logic apps and the other Azure Serverless offerings. Investing in Serverless: less servers, more code with <a href=\"https://twitter.com/simona_cotin\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Simona Cotin</a> .</p> <p>Lastly was a panel discussion on the changes facing IT Pros and SysAdmins. What is the future of the IT Pro in a DevOps &amp; Cloudy world? with <a href=\"https://twitter.com/jenstirrup\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Jennifer Stirrup</a> , <a href=\"https://twitter.com/bakionur\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Baki Onur Okutucu</a> , <a href=\"https://twitter.com/AmyKateNicho\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Amy Boyd</a> and <a href=\"https://twitter.com/TheOpsMgr\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Stephen Thair</a> . Should they learn to code, how should they make sure they keep up.</p> <p>Tomorrow I have a loads more sessions, including ones about mental health, Azure pipelines, more Kubernetes stuff and dealing with failure.</p>"
              - generic [ref=e3792]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e3794]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e3795]:
          - generic [ref=e3798]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e3799]:
            - generic [ref=e3800]:
              - generic [ref=e3801]: <title>
              - text: Yaml Builds on Azure DevOps
              - generic [ref=e3802]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e3803]:
              - generic [ref=e3804]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2019/yaml-builds-on-azure-devops/
              - generic [ref=e3805]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e3806]:
              - generic [ref=e3807]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e3808]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e3809]:
              - generic [ref=e3810]: <pubDate>
              - text: Thu, 31 Jan 2019 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e3811]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e3812]:
              - generic [ref=e3813]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2019/yaml-builds-on-azure-devops/
              - generic [ref=e3814]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e3815]:
              - generic [ref=e3816]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3817]: term="CI"
                - text: ">"
              - text: CI
              - generic [ref=e3818]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3819]:
              - generic [ref=e3820]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3821]: term="Build"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Build
              - generic [ref=e3822]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3823]:
              - generic [ref=e3824]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3825]: term="Azure"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Azure
              - generic [ref=e3826]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3827]:
              - generic [ref=e3828]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3829]: term="DevOps"
                - text: ">"
              - text: DevOps
              - generic [ref=e3830]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3831]:
              - generic [ref=e3832]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3833]: term="AzureDevOps"
                - text: ">"
              - text: AzureDevOps
              - generic [ref=e3834]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3835]:
              - generic [ref=e3836]: <description>
              - text: <p>I have been using Azure DevOps (Or VSTS or VSO etc) for a while now and one of the great features is doing automatic builds with every check-in. This is more commonly known as a CI (continuous integration) build.</p> <p>More recently I have started playing about with creating my build using YAML files instead of using the web user interface to create my build.</p> <h2 id="why">Why?<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#why"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p>You may wonder why go to the effort of learning the YAML syntax when you can just create the build in Azure DevOps and then forget about it.</p> <p>Mostly it is because the build changes over time and you shouldn‚Äôt just forget about it. If something changes over time then you might want to version control it, or look at a previous version.</p> <p>Lets say you create a pull request that replaces a .net 4.7 web service with a .net core web service. If you have a CI build this PR will fail because it won‚Äôt build. If you change the build first any other builds going on will fail. What you want in this case is the build to be associated with that branch or PR. Any builds before you merge this change in will continue to work and any after this change will also work.</p> <h2 id="how">How?<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#how"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p>How do you get started with YAML builds? Well the first thing is to make sure that YAML builds are turned on, as I write this I believe they are still a feature you can turn on or off. Have a look in Preview features and make sure they are turned on.</p> <p>Next look at any of your existing builds and click the View YAML link. This will show you an example YAML file of your existing build. You could just save this as azure-pipelines.yml and checkin to the root of your project. You can also click the add new build pipeline option, this will give you some templates to start you off.</p> <p>The YAML file consists of a series of build steps usually called tasks, with a few settings before to configure things like parameters or build agents. Detailed docs about the syntax of the file can be found <a href="https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/pipelines/yaml-schema?view=azure-devops&amp;tabs=schema" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">here</a> .</p> <p>For my mobile app my YAML files consist of downloading nuget packages, building the solution, building specific projects with desired settings, running powershell or other scripts to set things up and finally publishing the results of the build as artifacts so that they can be used in any releases.</p> <h2 id="secure-it">Secure It!<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#secure-it"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p>Avoid committing passwords and secure keys into source control. I have found you can upload secure files via Azure DevOps and then add a download secure files step at the start of your build. This allows the secure file to be used during the build but the contents of the file can‚Äôt be viewed by anyone with access to the source code.</p> <p>I find it often takes a bit of thinking about how to achieve this, but it is usually possible to keep keys and secrets secure.</p>
              - generic [ref=e3837]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e3839]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e3840]:
          - generic [ref=e3843]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e3844]:
            - generic [ref=e3845]:
              - generic [ref=e3846]: <title>
              - text: Pwned Pass Update
              - generic [ref=e3847]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e3848]:
              - generic [ref=e3849]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2019/pwned-pass-update/
              - generic [ref=e3850]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e3851]:
              - generic [ref=e3852]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e3853]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e3854]:
              - generic [ref=e3855]: <pubDate>
              - text: Wed, 23 Jan 2019 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e3856]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e3857]:
              - generic [ref=e3858]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2019/pwned-pass-update/
              - generic [ref=e3859]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e3860]:
              - generic [ref=e3861]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3862]: term="Xamarin"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Xamarin
              - generic [ref=e3863]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3864]:
              - generic [ref=e3865]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3866]: term="Android"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Android
              - generic [ref=e3867]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3868]:
              - generic [ref=e3869]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3870]: term="PwnedPass"
                - text: ">"
              - text: PwnedPass
              - generic [ref=e3871]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3872]:
              - generic [ref=e3873]: <description>
              - text: <p>Its been a while since I first released Pwned Pass so lets have a look at where we are now.</p> <p>We are very close to 500 Downloads from <a href="https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=pwnedpasswords.pwnedpasswords" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Google Play</a> and we have recently smashed past 100 active installs, peaking at 116 and even now we are still over 100. I have had 9 reviews (6 x 5*, 2 x 1 * and a 4 *) which averages out at 4 * <img class="img-fluid" alt="Alt Text" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2019/01/image.png" loading="lazy" width="906" height="832" /> Over Christmas I released a UWP version that can be found in the <a href="https://www.microsoft.com/store/apps/9NM2WHNZTNLT" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Microsoft Store</a> . This has currently had 9 downloads and even had a download to windows mobile (someone out there still likes the platform!) <img class="img-fluid" alt="Alt Text" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2019/01/image-1.png" loading="lazy" width="876" height="845" /> I have a fairly smooth deployment process using Azure DevOps. After every check in of code a build runs which compiles the UWP and Android versions. The build also increments the version numbers that is required to deploy to either of the app stores.</p> <p>Every successful build of the master branch will kick off a release to the Beta track of Google Play. If I am happy I then release to 10% of the Production track, which can then be increased to 100% (or halted). The release to Microsoft Store happens after the Beta track of Google Play. Only reason for this order is that there isn‚Äôt a beta area for UWP apps so I want to quickly test change on android before rolling out for windows.</p> <p>All these steps require confirmation by me before proceeding and often don‚Äôt get further than the beta track.</p> <p>A further development is that I have open sourced the source code to <a href="">github</a> do take a look if you are curious or want to contribute. With the purchase by Microsoft there are easy ways to connect github repositories to Azure DevOps. Once I create a Pull Request in github it creates a build in Azure DevOps and all the build and release steps can happen.</p> <p>I am still not 100% sure if I want to keep my bug and issue tracking in github or Azure DevOps as both have features for doing so.</p> <p>One future improvement I want to make is to automate the creation of screenshots. When I create a new feature and it gets checked in. I would like to automatically created screenshots of the key pages and submit them to the different app stores. Currently I am not sure if this is possible or how to go about it. I have some ideas to experiment with so we will see what I can do.</p>
              - generic [ref=e3874]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e3876]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e3877]:

          - generic [ref=e3881]:
            - generic [ref=e3882]:
              - generic [ref=e3883]: <title>
              - text: "My 2019 Tech Goals: What I Plan to Achieve"
              - generic [ref=e3884]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e3885]:
              - generic [ref=e3886]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2019/lets-see-what-2019-can-do/
              - generic [ref=e3887]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e3888]:
              - generic [ref=e3889]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e3890]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e3891]:
              - generic [ref=e3892]: <pubDate>
              - text: Tue, 01 Jan 2019 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e3893]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e3894]:
              - generic [ref=e3895]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2019/lets-see-what-2019-can-do/
              - generic [ref=e3896]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e3897]:
              - generic [ref=e3898]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3899]: term="Goals"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Goals
              - generic [ref=e3900]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3902]:
              - text: <category
              - generic [ref=e3903]:
                - text: term="
                - text: "\""
              - text: />
            - generic [ref=e3904]:
              - generic [ref=e3905]: <description>
              - text: <p>This is my annual lets make some goals for the new year blog post. So in no particular order.</p> <h2 id="improve-house">Improve House<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#improve-house"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p>I can‚Äôt outdo last years goal of buying a house but I can continue to make efforts to improve it. I was going to put something about decorating or doing something to our bedrooms, however today I spotted a hole in the roof so this may well absorb most of my home improvement budget.</p> <h2 id="connect-with-local-area">Connect with local area<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#connect-with-local-area"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p>Since we moved in October we haven‚Äôt really connected with our local area yet. My only interaction with my neighbours was when my car blocked his drive!</p> <p>I am going to make efforts to change this in 2019. I don‚Äôt exactly know how yet, but I have some ideas. My son starts nursery and later school this year so could be one way to meet other parents and teachers. I want to connect with a local church, so far this hasn‚Äôt happened so need to make more effort with this. There are other local groups that put on child friendly events which would be good to attend.</p> <h2 id="lightning-talk">Lightning Talk<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#lightning-talk"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p>I failed last year to do this so it is back on my list. I know I must have stuff of value to share so going to try again on this.</p> <p>A lightning talk is a very short talk or presentation given at a conference or user group. I am not a natural public speaker so this is a step out of my comfort zone, however I am going to start small and see what happens.</p> <p>##Family Holiday As always we Fosters are going to have a holiday in the summer and have some quality family time. I also want to take the boys to London for a weekend.</p> <h2 id="blogging">Blogging<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#blogging"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p>This blog has taken a bit of a backseat in 2018 so I want to try and refocus it for 2019. My commitment is for 12 blog posts in 2019, that is one a month. It doesn‚Äôt sound like much but I know how easily life can get in the way.</p> <p>Having said that my log has had record views this year. 7159 views. However I believe this number to be incorrect and has been inflated by my app development and some of the automated processes taking place.</p> <h2 id="routine">Routine<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#routine"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p>Last goal is to try a get more of a routine going. With two small boys, one of which is starting school in September a routine is going to be essential and will allow all of us all a chance to get more things done.</p>
              - generic [ref=e3906]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e3908]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e3909]:
          - generic [ref=e3912]: <item>

              - text: Looking back at 2018

            - generic [ref=e3917]:
              - generic [ref=e3918]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2018/looking-back-at-2018/
              - generic [ref=e3919]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e3920]:
              - generic [ref=e3921]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e3922]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e3923]:
              - generic [ref=e3924]: <pubDate>
              - text: Thu, 27 Dec 2018 00:00:00 +0000
              - generic [ref=e3925]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e3926]:
              - generic [ref=e3927]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2018/looking-back-at-2018/
              - generic [ref=e3928]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e3929]:
              - generic [ref=e3930]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3931]: term="C-Sharp"
                - text: ">"
              - text: C-Sharp
              - generic [ref=e3932]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3933]:
              - generic [ref=e3934]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3935]: term="Home"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Home
              - generic [ref=e3936]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3937]:
              - generic [ref=e3938]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3939]: term="Family"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Family
              - generic [ref=e3940]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3941]:
              - generic [ref=e3942]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3943]: term="Goals"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Goals
              - generic [ref=e3944]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3945]:
              - generic [ref=e3946]: <description>
              - text: <p>As 2018 starts to draw to a close let‚Äôs look at some of the highlights from the past year.</p> <ol> <li>New Home - I started 2018 with the goal of buying my own home and I managed it. At the end of October I actually moved in but it was months of looking at houses, speaking to estate agents, saving, packing and unpacking. There is more I want to do to my home in 2019 so this is only really the beginning.</li> <li>New Job - Another goal was to kick my career up a notch and this happened in June. It has been great working as part of a large team and I have learnt loads, there is much more I want to learn and contribute to so 2019 should be great on that front.</li> <li>New Car - Not a goal that I achieved as unfortunately in October I was involved in a car accident, no one was seriously hurt but this was a horrible experience to go through. My car was written off which gave me an excuse to buy a new car.</li> <li>See more of family was a goal, I am not sure if I really achieved this. However family have been around loads for us during our move and we do live closer so hopefully I can work on this some more.</li> <li>Celebrate 5 years of marriage. It hasn&rsquo;t been an easy year for me and the wife due to moving house and all the stress that involved plus with two children she was diagnosed with Postnatal Depression which as a family we are still dealing with. All that said we had a fab weekend away and we so need to do something similar again soon.</li> <li>Family. 2018 has included many great times with my two boys. It&rsquo;s been amazing seeing them grow, in September we had a thanksgiving service for them and in July we had our annual holiday.</li> <li>Lightning Talk. This is the only thing I mentioned as a goal that didn&rsquo;t happen, it&rsquo;s on my 2019 list so hopefully I can kick myself into action but with everything else I achieved something had to slip. </li> </ol>
              - generic [ref=e3947]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e3949]: </item>

          - generic [ref=e3953]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e3954]:
            - generic [ref=e3955]:
              - generic [ref=e3956]: <title>
              - text: Running SQL Server on a Linux Container using Docker for Windows
              - generic [ref=e3957]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e3958]:
              - generic [ref=e3959]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2018/running-sql-server-on-a-linux-container-using-docker-for-windows/
              - generic [ref=e3960]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e3961]:
              - generic [ref=e3962]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e3963]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e3964]:
              - generic [ref=e3965]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 05 Nov 2018 00:00:00 +0000
              - generic [ref=e3966]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e3967]:
              - generic [ref=e3968]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2018/running-sql-server-on-a-linux-container-using-docker-for-windows/
              - generic [ref=e3969]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e3970]:
              - generic [ref=e3971]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3972]: term="Windows"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Windows
              - generic [ref=e3973]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3974]:
              - generic [ref=e3975]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3976]: term="Docker"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Docker
              - generic [ref=e3977]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3978]:
              - generic [ref=e3979]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3980]: term="SQL"
                - text: ">"
              - text: SQL
              - generic [ref=e3981]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3982]:
              - generic [ref=e3983]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e3984]: term="Linux"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Linux
              - generic [ref=e3985]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e3986]:
              - generic [ref=e3987]: <description>
              - text: <p>Recently I have been investigating what all the fuss is about Docker and it has been well worth my time as Docker is pretty awesome for automating stuff.</p> <p>My development environment has typically required installing SQL Server. SQL is a bit of a beast with lots of options and takes time to setup how you want.</p> <p>However since Microsoft have now created a version of SQL Server that runs on Linux you can run SQL Server in a Linux container with only a few commands.</p> <p>I am going to assume you already have Docker for windows installed on your development machine. If not head over to <a href="https://docs.docker.com/docker-for-windows/install/#where-to-go-next" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Docker</a> and find out how.</p> <p>The Microsoft guide to setting up SQL Server in a Linux container can be found <a href="https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/linux/quickstart-install-connect-docker?view=sql-server-2017" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">here</a> .</p> <p>First you need to download the image. In a powershell window run:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>docker pull mcr.microsoft.com/mssql/server:2017-latest </code></pre><p>This downloads the latest sql server image.</p> <p>To run this image run the following:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>docker run -e &#34;ACCEPT_EULA=Y&#34; -e &#34;SA_PASSWORD=password&#34; -p 1433:1433 --name sql -d mcr.microsoft.com/mssql/server:2017-latest </code></pre><p>To run a SQL Server image you are required to accept the terms and conditions and set a default sa password. These are added as environment variables with the -e flag.</p> <p>You also need to set the ports that your container will run on (1433 is the default SQL port) and give your container a name, in this case &ldquo;sql&rdquo;.</p> <p>If you have already installed SQL Server you will not be able to run the container on the same port as your local install. To solve this you can select a different port.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>docker run -e &#34;ACCEPT_EULA=Y&#34; -e &#34;SA_PASSWORD=password&#34; -p 1434:1433 --name sql -d mcr.microsoft.com/mssql/server:2017-latest </code></pre><p>-p 1434:1433 maps the 1433 port on the container to port 1434 of your local environment.</p> <p>Once you have run this command you can connect SQL Server Management Studio (SSMS) to (local) or (local),1434 if you are using a different port using the credentials you provided and execute any SQL you like.</p> <p>If your development environment requires windows authentication this of course is not for you, if it doesn‚Äôt you are good to go.</p> <p>The development environment I have been using has various powershell scripts for setting things up. These assume windows auth. However I have adapted them to take custom credentials.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>$credential = Get-Credential $server.ConnectionContext.LoginSecure=$false $server.ConnectionContext.set_Login($credential.UserName) $server.ConnectionContext.set_SecurePassword($credential.Password) </code></pre><p>The Get-Credential command creates a dialog where you can enter SQL credentials, this is then stored in a variable and used in the rest of the script.</p> <p><strong>How do I restore a backup file to my container?</strong></p> <p>Run:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>docker exec -it sql mkdir /var/opt/mssql/backup docker cp database.bak sql:/var/opt/mssql/backup </code></pre><p>This creates a backup folder and copies a backup file from your local environment to the container. You can then use management studio to restore the backup file (or you could write a sql script to do it). One thing to note when restoring databases, make sure the files are restored to Linux locations not windows locations.</p> <p>The only issues I have encountered so far are the lack of support for SSIS packages and no windows auth. There are sql server windows images available which I haven‚Äôt tried yet which may work better with some of these options.</p>
              - generic [ref=e3988]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e3990]: </item>

              - text: 2018 The Story So far
              - generic [ref=e3998]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e3999]:
              - generic [ref=e4000]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2018/2018-the-story-so-far/

            - generic [ref=e4002]:

              - text: Career

            - generic [ref=e4015]:

            - generic [ref=e4023]:
              - generic [ref=e4024]:

              - text: Job
              - generic [ref=e4026]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4027]:

                - text: ">"
              - text: Goals
              - generic [ref=e4030]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4031]:
              - generic [ref=e4032]: <description>
              - text: <p>Remember me? I used to write blog posts but somehow life got in the way. So much has happened this year, lets have a look at my <a href="https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2018/lets-see-2018-can">goals</a> for 2018 and see how far we have got with them.</p> <h3 id="buy-a-house">Buy a house<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#buy-a-house"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h3> <p>My first goal for 2018 was to buy a house. Well so much progress has been made with this goal.</p> <p>We looked at a few houses, and have made an offer, had it accepted and are waiting for the last few things to get arranged before we start arranging to move in.</p> <p>The location we decided upon was <a href="https://www.google.co.uk/maps/place/Thorne,&#43;Doncaster/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Thorne</a> . This is about an hour from York where most of our friends are and my wife has lived all her life, and also an hour from where my family live. I have tried my best to balance location and size of property and we think our new home is going to be a good balance but only time will tell.</p> <p>I have a bit of a mammoth time ahead of me getting everything we own packed up and moved to our new home so wish me luck, but we will get there it is just going to be hard work.</p> <h3 id="new-job">New Job<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#new-job"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h3> <p>In June 2018 I started a new job. This was slightly later than I had hoped but I believe it has been worth the wait.</p> <p>My new job has lots of perks. Finish early on a Friday (1pm), On site canteen, Cool air-conditioned office, Flexible working hours, Part of a big development team.</p> <p>The main benefit is that I am part of a big development team. I have a huge list of things to learn both in terms of technology and how large development teams function. The team is about to finish the first sprint that I have contributed to. My contributions have been very small. A bug fix here, a tweak of an API there. But the important thing is that I am making a contribution and learning along the way.</p> <p>I have also started asking questions about deployment and how this could be automated. Something that interests me, especially with the sysadmin and devops background. I have been tasked with learning <a href="https://docs.docker.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">docker</a> , so expect some blog posts on this topic in the near future.</p> <h3 id="see-more-of-family">See more of family<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#see-more-of-family"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h3> <p>This one I am going to count as a miss. I have seen family a few times this year, but my efforts have been more on the first two items in this list. Hopefully this will change as things settle down.</p> <h3 id="celebrate-5-years-of-marriage">Celebrate 5 years of Marriage<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#celebrate-5-years-of-marriage"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h3> <p>Me and the wife had a great weekend away to celebrate our wedding anniversary.</p> <h3 id="celebrate-my-two-children">Celebrate my two children<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#celebrate-my-two-children"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h3> <p>Not happened yet but it is booked and we just need to arrange a few more details.</p> <h3 id="lightning-talk">Lightning Talk<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#lightning-talk"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h3> <p>I have made no effort to do a talk and this is going to be a goal for 2019 I think. Most of the reason is concentrating on the other areas above, but also because I am not a natural speaker and I don‚Äôt like stepping out of my comfort zone. But I will do it, I just need to wait for other things to calm down a bit first.</p> <h3 id="family-holiday">Family Holiday<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#family-holiday"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h3> <p>We had a great week away at the start of July. The weather was really great (and still is) and we had lots of time doing things as a family.</p>

          - generic [ref=e4040]:
            - generic [ref=e4041]:
              - generic [ref=e4042]: <title>
              - text: Casting and Converting between types
              - generic [ref=e4043]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e4044]:
              - generic [ref=e4045]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2018/casting-and-converting-between-types/
              - generic [ref=e4046]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e4047]:
              - generic [ref=e4048]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e4049]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e4050]:
              - generic [ref=e4051]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 07 May 2018 00:00:00 +0000
              - generic [ref=e4052]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e4053]:
              - generic [ref=e4054]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2018/casting-and-converting-between-types/
              - generic [ref=e4055]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e4056]:
              - generic [ref=e4057]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4058]: term="C-Sharp"
                - text: ">"
              - text: C-Sharp
              - generic [ref=e4059]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4060]:
              - generic [ref=e4061]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4062]: term="Casting"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Casting
              - generic [ref=e4063]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4064]:
              - generic [ref=e4065]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4066]: term="Convert"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Convert
              - generic [ref=e4067]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4068]:
              - generic [ref=e4069]: <description>
              - text: <p>Recently I was asked how to convert a number to a string. Let&rsquo;s look at a few ways of approaching this problem.</p> <p>Most objects in c# have a method called ToString() which displays the string representation of that object. This is because of inheritance, all objects inherit from System.Object which defines ToString().</p> <p>Int32 is a struct so it inherits from System.ValueType which also inherits from System.Object</p> <p>so in code</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" style="color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;"><code class="language-csharp" data-lang="csharp"><span style="display:flex;"><span><span style="color:#66d9ef">int</span> a = <span style="color:#ae81ff">9</span>; </span></span><span style="display:flex;"><span><span style="color:#66d9ef">string</span> b = a.ToString(); </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now let&rsquo;s look at the reverse. However the reverse runs the risk of throwing an error, let&rsquo;s look at why.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" style="color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;"><code class="language-csharp" data-lang="csharp"><span style="display:flex;"><span><span style="color:#66d9ef">string</span> b = <span style="color:#e6db74">&#34;9&#34;</span>; </span></span><span style="display:flex;"><span><span style="color:#66d9ef">string</span> c = <span style="color:#e6db74">&#34;a&#34;</span>; </span></span><span style="display:flex;"><span><span style="color:#66d9ef">string</span> d = <span style="color:#e6db74">&#34;two&#34;</span>; </span></span></code></pre></div><p>All are valid strings but only one can be converted to a number. Use the TryParse method to convert to a number.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" style="color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;"><code class="language-csharp" data-lang="csharp"><span style="display:flex;"><span><span style="color:#66d9ef">int</span>.TryParse(<span style="color:#e6db74">&#34;9&#34;</span>, <span style="color:#66d9ef">out</span> <span style="color:#66d9ef">int</span> e); </span></span></code></pre></div><p>TryParse will not throw an exception if the conversion fails, if it succeeds variable e will contain the result. Note an earlier version of c# required you to define the out parameter before using it with TryParse.</p> <p>int.Parse exists to do the same thing however it will throw exceptions if a conversion is not possible. The same is true if you use Convert.ToInt32(&ldquo;two&rdquo;);</p> <h2 id="casting">Casting<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#casting"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p>Casting is a way to explicitly telling the compiler that a type is actually another type and you are aware data loss will occur.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" style="color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;"><code class="language-csharp" data-lang="csharp"><span style="display:flex;"><span><span style="color:#66d9ef">double</span> x = <span style="color:#ae81ff">4.5</span>; </span></span><span style="display:flex;"><span><span style="color:#66d9ef">int</span> y = (<span style="color:#66d9ef">int</span>)x; </span></span></code></pre></div><p>However it is not possible to cast a string to a number format as a string can contain any character not just number characters.</p>
              - generic [ref=e4070]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e4072]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e4073]:
          - generic [ref=e4076]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e4077]:
            - generic [ref=e4078]:
              - generic [ref=e4079]: <title>
              - text: Let‚Äôs Encrypt is awesome
              - generic [ref=e4080]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e4081]:
              - generic [ref=e4082]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2018/lets-encrypt-is-awesome/
              - generic [ref=e4083]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e4084]:
              - generic [ref=e4085]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e4086]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e4087]:
              - generic [ref=e4088]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 30 Apr 2018 00:00:00 +0000
              - generic [ref=e4089]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e4090]:
              - generic [ref=e4091]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2018/lets-encrypt-is-awesome/
              - generic [ref=e4092]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e4093]:
              - generic [ref=e4094]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4095]: term="DevOps"
                - text: ">"
              - text: DevOps
              - generic [ref=e4096]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4097]:
              - generic [ref=e4098]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4099]: term="SSL"
                - text: ">"
              - text: SSL
              - generic [ref=e4100]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4101]:
              - generic [ref=e4102]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4103]: term="Security"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Security
              - generic [ref=e4104]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4105]:
              - generic [ref=e4106]: <description>
              - text: <p>Let‚Äôs Encrypt is a free way to get a SSL certificate onto your website and until recently I had never tried it. It is very easy and I think it is awesome.</p> <p>IIS is the web server software the Microsoft include with Windows 10 and Windows Server. I have it installed on my laptop and it displays the default IIS page.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2018/iis.jpg" loading="lazy" width="2170" height="1311" /> </p> <p>It is not really a good idea to host websites on your laptop, use a dedicated web server, or host with a hosting company, however the techniques are the same and it gives me something to write about!</p> <p>In order to point a domain name at what IIS on my machine was serving up I did the following:</p> <ul> <li>Do a google search for ‚Äúwhats my IP‚Äù, this will return your public IP. Most residential ISPs use dynamic IPs so it may change over time, (which is another reason not to host a website on your laptop!)</li> <li>Add an A record on a domain with the IP address you have just got</li> <li>Your public IP most likely points at your router not your laptop so enable port forwarding of port 80 and port 443 to the internal IP of your laptop (something like 192.168.0.11 etc)</li> </ul> <p>Now comes the fun Let‚Äôs Encrypt stuff!</p> <p>First you need a Let‚Äôs Encrypt client, there are a lot of them out there mostly for linux flavours, however a bit of googling found a windows one. Go to <a href="https://github.com/PKISharp/win-acme/releases" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">https://github.com/PKISharp/win-acme/releases</a> and download the zip file and unzip it.</p> <p>Run the executable from the zip file and follow the onscreen prompts.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2018/letsencrypt.jpg" loading="lazy" width="1174" height="733" /> </p> <p>Press N to create a new certificate.</p> <p>Then press 1 to bind to single website found in your IIS setup</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2018/letsencrypt2.jpg" loading="lazy" width="1147" height="1024" /> </p> <p>And now magically Let‚Äôs Encrypt knows what you have setup in IIS.</p> <p>Now all you need to do is enter an email address incase a renewal fails and agree to the let‚Äôs encrypt terms and you are all setup.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2018/letsencrypt3.jpg" loading="lazy" width="957" height="1147" /> </p> <p>How awesome and easy is that for getting your websites working with a SSL certificate. If you have IIS configured on a server, give it a try and you can SSL all your things.</p>
              - generic [ref=e4107]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e4109]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e4110]:

              - text: DNS for Developers
              - generic [ref=e4117]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e4118]:
              - generic [ref=e4119]: <link>

            - generic [ref=e4127]:

              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2018/dns-for-developers/

            - generic [ref=e4134]:

                - text: <category

              - text: DevOps
              - generic [ref=e4137]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4138]:
              - generic [ref=e4139]: <description>
              - text: <p>DNS is the backbone of the internet and as such I believe every developer should know something about the basics and not just leave it for the sysadmin to sort.</p> <h3 id="what-is-dns">What is DNS?<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#what-is-dns"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h3> <p>DNS or Domain Name System is what translates Domain names to IP addresses and vice versa.</p> <h3 id="wait-what-is-an-ip-address-and-what-are-domain-names">Wait what is an IP address and what are domain names?<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#wait-what-is-an-ip-address-and-what-are-domain-names"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h3> <p>You do realise this is a developer blog? An IP address is a unique address on the internet and a domain name is a user friendly label for one or more of these.</p> <p>An example might be google.com which for me resolves to 216.58.204.14</p> <h3 id="how-it-works">How it works<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#how-it-works"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h3> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2018/dns-rev-1.gif" loading="lazy" width="360" height="320" /> When your browser makes a request to google.com it makes a request to your ISPs DNS Servers. This resolves google.com to 216.58.204.14</p> <p>In more detail your ISPs DNS server will forward the DNS query to another DNS server and will cache the results for a set amount of time. This is the TTL or Time To Live. Next time the ISP DNS Server will be able to reply directly without needing to forward requests.</p> <p>This forwarding and caching is what makes making a DNS change not instantaneous. The TTL needs to be reached so that no results are still being fetched from the cache of DNS servers across the globe.</p> <h3 id="dns-records">DNS Records<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#dns-records"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h3> <p>Now we know roughly how DNS works let‚Äôs look at the most common type of records</p> <h4 id="a">A<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#a"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h4> <p>A (Host) records are the most simple records which translate domain names to IPs</p> <p>eg <a href="https://www.google.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">www.google.com</a> to 216.58.204.14</p> <h4 id="cname">CNAME<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#cname"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h4> <p>A CNAME (Canonical Name) record is different to an A record in that it maps a domain name to another domain name when no A record exists.</p> <p>eg <a href="https://www.google.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">www.google.com</a> to somethingelse.google.com</p> <p>Typically Azure makes use of CNAMEs for many of its services especially adding a custom domain name</p> <h4 id="mx">MX<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#mx"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h4> <p>MX stands for Mail Exchange and is used for configuring email</p> <h4 id="name-server">Name Server<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#name-server"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h4> <p>Every domain has a number of Name Servers which tells you what servers control the DNS settings for that domain. If you change your Name Servers then the new Name servers will be where you can change your DNS settings.</p> <p>If you want to use a service like <a href="https://dnsimple.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">DNSimple</a> instead of <a href="https://www.123-reg.co.uk/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">123reg</a> or where ever you registered your domain then all you need to do is change your Name servers.</p> <h4 id="aaaa">AAAA<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#aaaa"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h4> <p>Like A record but for ipv6</p> <h3 id="what-next">What next?<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#what-next"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h3> <p>Want to put some different DNS records into practise? Buy a domain name and publish some content to it. Check out my previous post about <a href="https://www.funkysi1701.com/creating-dns-records-programmatically">programmatically adding records</a> . Want an SSL certificate? Get a wildcard one and then you can apply it to any subdomain you add to your domain.</p> <p>If you have a new website you want to publish consider which of the following is better:</p> <p><code>https://www.example.com/newsite</code></p> <p><code>https://newsite.example.com</code></p> <p>I much prefer the second option, it looks cleaner, there is no potential conflict with the parent site, no subfolder issues between production and development.</p>
              - generic [ref=e4140]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e4142]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e4143]:
          - generic [ref=e4146]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e4147]:
            - generic [ref=e4148]:
              - generic [ref=e4149]: <title>
              - text: Code Reviews
              - generic [ref=e4150]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e4151]:
              - generic [ref=e4152]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2018/codereviews/
              - generic [ref=e4153]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e4154]:
              - generic [ref=e4155]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e4156]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e4157]:
              - generic [ref=e4158]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 02 Apr 2018 00:00:00 +0000
              - generic [ref=e4159]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e4160]:
              - generic [ref=e4161]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2018/codereviews/
              - generic [ref=e4162]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e4163]:
              - generic [ref=e4164]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4165]: term="Git"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Git
              - generic [ref=e4166]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4167]:
              - generic [ref=e4168]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4169]: term="VisualStudio"
                - text: ">"
              - text: VisualStudio
              - generic [ref=e4170]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4171]:
              - generic [ref=e4172]: <description>
              - text: <p>Reviewing code is a great habit to get into. Code reviews help share knowledge between your team members and help catch bugs before they get into production. But how do you get into the habit of reviewing and avoid the we don‚Äôt have time to do this mentality?</p> <p>Visual Studio Team Services (VSTS) has some great options that can help make code reviews second nature.</p> <h4 id="pull-requests">Pull Requests<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#pull-requests"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h4> <p>A lot of source control systems have the concept of pull requests. This is where you request others to review your code usually in a branch and if they approve it, merge it into a main branch.</p> <p>To create a pull request in VSTS go to the Code section and select Pull Requests. Often VSTS will make a suggestion of what branch to make a pull request for, if you don‚Äôt see this just click the New Pull request button.</p> <p>Select a branch you want to merge from and a branch that should be merged into (usually you merge into master from a feature branch). Give your pull request a title and description and select who should review your code, this can either be an individual or a group of people. You can also review all the changes that will be reviewed so you can make any last minute changes before it is reviewed.</p> <p>Now if you are anything like me you want your code merged in as soon as you have created your pull request and there is nothing stopping you reviewing your own code and clicking approve and merge on your own pull request. However <a href="https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/vsts/git/branch-policies?view=vsts" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">branch policies</a> is a way around this problem.</p> <h4 id="branch-policies">Branch Policies<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#branch-policies"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h4> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="Branch Policy" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2018/save-policy-changes.png" loading="lazy" width="599" height="901" /> </p> <p>Branch policies allow you to specify how your code gets merged in.</p> <p>Go to the list of branches in VSTS and select branch policy and you will see a whole host of options to customise the merge process. If you do this on the master branch you will not be able to commit any changes to master without it going through a pull request.</p> <p>The first option enables you to select how many reviewers are needed on your code. If no one else works on your project best not setting this, but for everyone else setting at least one person to review your code is a great practice.</p> <p>Next you can ensure that your pull request is linked to a work item, this helps keep ensure you are actually fixing issues and not just making change for the sake of it.</p> <p>Check for comment resolution is a good setting to enable. This ensures that if your reviewer has commented about you needing to change this line here, it ensures that you do.</p> <p>Enforce merge strategy allows you to choose between fast forward merge or squash merge.</p> <p>Build validation enables the code to be built using a build definition you have configured. This is a great way to check code builds or tests pass before it gets merged in.</p> <p>The last two options allow you to specify code reviewers and third party external services.</p>
              - generic [ref=e4173]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e4175]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e4176]:
          - generic [ref=e4179]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e4180]:
            - generic [ref=e4181]:
              - generic [ref=e4182]: <title>
              - text: Android Development Options
              - generic [ref=e4183]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e4184]:
              - generic [ref=e4185]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2018/android-development-options/
              - generic [ref=e4186]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e4187]:
              - generic [ref=e4188]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e4189]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e4190]:
              - generic [ref=e4191]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 26 Mar 2018 00:00:00 +0000
              - generic [ref=e4192]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e4193]:
              - generic [ref=e4194]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2018/android-development-options/
              - generic [ref=e4195]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e4196]:
              - generic [ref=e4197]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4198]: term="Cordova"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Cordova
              - generic [ref=e4199]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4200]:
              - generic [ref=e4201]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4202]: term="Android"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Android
              - generic [ref=e4203]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4204]:
              - generic [ref=e4205]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4206]: term="CrossPlatform"
                - text: ">"
              - text: CrossPlatform
              - generic [ref=e4207]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4208]:
              - generic [ref=e4209]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4210]: term="Manifest"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Manifest
              - generic [ref=e4211]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4212]:
              - generic [ref=e4213]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4214]: term="Xamarin"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Xamarin
              - generic [ref=e4215]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4216]:
              - generic [ref=e4217]: <description>
              - text: <p>A friend asked me how to get started in Android Development and I thought I might have a go at answering that question here.</p> <p>I am by no means an expert in Android development, I do have an app in the play store so I know something.</p> <h4 id="manifest-file">Manifest File<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#manifest-file"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h4> <p>This is probably the easiest option and also doesn‚Äôt actually create an android app so I am not sure if it should be included in this list of not.</p> <p>If you have a website and you want to create an app for that you could just create a manifest file and add this to your website.</p> <p>Once your website has a manifest file, if you visit your website using a mobile phone or tablet you will get the option to add a shortcut to the home screen. You then have an app like experience in that you can click an icon to launch your website.</p> <p>A manifest file is a simple text file which specifies a few settings like the icon size, filename, what page loads when clicked and name of your ‚Äúapp‚Äù</p> <p><a href="https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/web-app-manifest/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">More information</a> </p> <h4 id="visual-studio">Visual Studio<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#visual-studio"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h4> <p>This is the option I know most about as is what I have used.</p> <p>If you are familiar with Visual Studio you can use the Xamarin Forms software to create your app in C#. Xamarin Forms allows you to easily create cross platform apps that run on Android, IOS and windows phone. So far I have only experimented with Android but it should be relatively easy to extend my code to run on other platforms.</p> <p>Xamarin Forms allows you to write one a single codebase that can be compiled to run on the different platforms. Xamarin requires the use of XAML a XML like markup language for designing UI elements.</p> <p>More Information on <a href="https://www.visualstudio.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Visual Studio</a> , <a href="https://www.xamarin.com/forms" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Xamarin Forms</a> </p> <h4 id="android-studio">Android Studio<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#android-studio"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h4> <p>I don‚Äôt know much about this option so do correct me if I don‚Äôt get the details correct.</p> <p>Android Studio can be downloaded from Google this allows you to create java code to run directly on an android device. From what I know this is fairly similar experience to Visual Studio but instead of writing your code in C# you use Android Studio and write it directly in java.</p> <p><a href="https://developer.android.com/studio/index.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">More information</a> </p> <h4 id="cordova">Cordova<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#cordova"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h4> <p>Cordova allows you to use HTML, CSS and javascript to create cross platform apps. I have no idea why I haven‚Äôt heard of this technology until today as it sounds very flexible especially if you know a little bit of javascript.</p> <p><a href="https://cordova.apache.org/docs/en/latest/guide/overview/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">More information</a> </p> <p>To summarize there are lots of different options available to create an android app. What you choose depends on what you want to build, what language and experience you have and if your app needs to be cross platform.</p>
              - generic [ref=e4218]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e4220]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e4221]:
          - generic [ref=e4224]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e4225]:
            - generic [ref=e4226]:
              - generic [ref=e4227]: <title>
              - text: Tips for Developing Yourself
              - generic [ref=e4228]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e4229]:
              - generic [ref=e4230]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2018/tips-for-developing-yourself/
              - generic [ref=e4231]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e4232]:
              - generic [ref=e4233]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e4234]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e4235]:
              - generic [ref=e4236]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 19 Mar 2018 00:00:00 +0000
              - generic [ref=e4237]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e4238]:
              - generic [ref=e4239]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2018/tips-for-developing-yourself/
              - generic [ref=e4240]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e4241]:
              - generic [ref=e4242]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4243]: term="Blogging"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Blogging
              - generic [ref=e4244]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4245]:
              - generic [ref=e4246]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4247]: term="Goals"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Goals
              - generic [ref=e4248]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4249]:
              - generic [ref=e4250]: <description>
              - text: "<p>For a while I have been mentoring a friend and I thought I might share some top tips I have implemented in my career so far.</p> <h5 id=\"hard-work\">Hard Work<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#hard-work\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h5> <p>At school I was told: ‚Äú<em>Only in the dictionary does Success come before Work</em>‚Äú. Yes it is a bit of a corny saying however it has stuck in my head and it‚Äôs true. If you want to get anywhere you need to work at it. For many years I just drifted along, but as soon as I knuckled down and worked hard my career started going somewhere.</p> <h5 id=\"write-a-blog\">Write a Blog<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#write-a-blog\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h5> <p>Writing is an important skill that you need to work at to improve. If you commit to writing one blog post a week this will help to improve this skill. Even after 150+ blog posts I still feel I need to improve. Not only that it will also help others learn something from you and shows a willingness to contribute to the community. If a Hiring Manager reads your blog he can see some of the stuff you know or care about and may help give you the edge over more experienced candidates.</p> <h5 id=\"soft-skills\">Soft Skills<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#soft-skills\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h5> <p>This is one I need to work on but you should concentrate on the so called ‚Äú<em>Soft Skills</em>‚Äú. Soft Skills are the skills you have for dealing with others. Are you good at talking to people? Or good at getting requirements out of business owners? If so you have some soft skills, don‚Äôt underestimate the value that these bring to a team and keep developing them.</p> <h5 id=\"build-a-side-project\">Build a Side Project<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#build-a-side-project\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h5> <p>Start building a side project, it doesn‚Äôt matter what it is but start building something. I started building a Xamarin app but I have learnt loads of other connected things while doing this, ViewModels, APIs, Build and Deployment processes, Azure Functions. It also gives you ammunition for things to blog about. If you are short of ideas try solving a problem or rebuild something you use.</p> <h5 id=\"use-your-spare-time\">Use your spare time<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#use-your-spare-time\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h5> <p>During the day there are moments you can reclaim for learning stuff. There are lots of <a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/podcasts\">podcast</a> which discuss useful development topics, listen to these while driving to work. Subscribe to <a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/pluralsight\">pluralsight</a> and listen to this while washing up. Don‚Äôt get too concerned with learning everything, however think how much more you are learning than not listening at all.</p> <h5 id=\"im-not-ready\">I‚Äôm not ready!<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#im-not-ready\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h5> <p>We are never ready to take that next step, it is so easy to make excuses like I need to learn x, or know y. The only way to know if you are ready is to try and to keep trying. Iterate as you go so you keep improving yourself. If you wait before you start trying you will end up waiting forever. If you start trying now you will make some small progress and have a better idea of what you need to do to achieve your goals.</p>"
              - generic [ref=e4251]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e4253]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e4254]:
          - generic [ref=e4257]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e4258]:
            - generic [ref=e4259]:
              - generic [ref=e4260]: <title>
              - text: Heroes
              - generic [ref=e4261]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e4262]:
              - generic [ref=e4263]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2018/heroes/
              - generic [ref=e4264]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e4265]:
              - generic [ref=e4266]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e4267]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e4268]:
              - generic [ref=e4269]: <pubDate>
              - text: Fri, 16 Mar 2018 00:00:00 +0000
              - generic [ref=e4270]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e4271]:
              - generic [ref=e4272]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2018/heroes/
              - generic [ref=e4273]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e4274]:
              - generic [ref=e4275]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4276]: term="StephenHawking"
                - text: ">"
              - text: StephenHawking
              - generic [ref=e4277]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4278]:
              - generic [ref=e4279]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4280]: term="Hero"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Hero
              - generic [ref=e4281]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4282]:
              - generic [ref=e4283]: <description>
              - text: <p><strong>Who was your hero growing up?</strong> Mine was Stephen Hawking.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="Stephen Hawking" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2018/Hawking-ZeroG_web-1.jpg" loading="lazy" width="1024" height="415" /> </p> <p><strong>What is a hero?</strong> A lot is said in the media about ‚ÄúHeroes‚Äù. Often the sportsperson of the hour is described as a hero. I don‚Äôt like this definition and I think there is far more to being a hero than that. One definition I saw describes a hero as <em>A person who is admired for their courage, outstanding achievements, or noble qualities.</em></p> <p><strong>Why Hawking?</strong> As a kid I thought I was pretty smart (Not really just above average), I liked Star Trek and science so Hawking was a pretty obvious choice. I remember reading all about Hawking and his life fascinated me. A brilliant man was struck down by motor neurone disease in his early twenties, however this did not stop him and he completed his doctorate and became the famous physicist we all know and love.</p> <p>My physics career was fairly short lived ending with an undergraduate course at University of York, however I really enjoyed learning the concepts that he described about space and time and was definitely a driving factor for me to learn as much as I did about Physics.</p> <p>How heroic is it to be given 2 years to live and then not only survive but to expand our understanding of the universe without being able to speak or move without the aid of technology?</p> <p>I can not imagine what it must be like to not be able to communicate without the use of a computer, but this has been Stephen Hawkings world for over 30 years. His computer system has undergone various upgrades over the years however his synthetic computer voice has continued as he identified with it and prefered it.</p> <p>Stephen Hawking had an immense intellect, I would probably describe him as one of the cleverest people on the planet.</p> <p><strong>Who are your heroes?</strong> What kind of person is your hero, is it a scientist or engineer? The world contains some very clever people who will inspire and excite young people to strive towards something. I am hopeful that my sons can be inspired even if it‚Äôs only a small way by someone like Stephen Hawking.</p>
              - generic [ref=e4284]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e4286]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e4287]:
          - generic [ref=e4290]: <item>
