              - generic [ref=e4667]: <title>
              - text: Looking back at 2017
              - generic [ref=e4668]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e4669]:
              - generic [ref=e4670]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/looking-back-at-2017/
              - generic [ref=e4671]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e4672]:
              - generic [ref=e4673]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e4674]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e4675]:
              - generic [ref=e4676]: <pubDate>
              - text: Thu, 28 Dec 2017 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e4677]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e4678]:
              - generic [ref=e4679]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/looking-back-at-2017/
              - generic [ref=e4680]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e4681]:
              - generic [ref=e4682]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4683]: term="StarTrek"
                - text: ">"
              - text: StarTrek
              - generic [ref=e4684]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4685]:
              - generic [ref=e4686]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4687]: term="Goals"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Goals
              - generic [ref=e4688]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4689]:
              - generic [ref=e4690]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4691]: term="Azure"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Azure
              - generic [ref=e4692]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4693]:
              - generic [ref=e4694]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4695]: term="Baby"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Baby
              - generic [ref=e4696]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4697]:
              - generic [ref=e4698]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4699]: term="C-Sharp"
                - text: ">"
              - text: C-Sharp
              - generic [ref=e4700]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4701]:
              - generic [ref=e4702]: <description>
              - text: <p>As 2017 starts to draw to a close let‚Äôs look at some of the highlights from the past year.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="Edward" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2017/DSC_0376-e1510563039193-225x300.jpg" loading="lazy" width="225" height="300" /> </p> <ol> <li>Edward</li> </ol> <p>In November I became a father again and celebrated the arrival of Edward into the world. Before the birth I was worried how well my first son James would adapt to the new arrival but I am happy to say I didn‚Äôt need to, he mostly ignores the new arrival.</p> <ol start="2"> <li>Star Trek</li> </ol> <p>In September the latest Star Trek TV series Discovery arrived on Netflix. I have been very positive so far about the show, I am still positive however there are things that annoy me about the new show, however I am keen to see the next episode each week so they are definitely doing something right.</p> <ol start="3"> <li>Office move</li> </ol> <p>In May I helped my employer move to brand new <a href="https://funkysi1701.com/office-move" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">offices</a> . This was a lot of hard work, but everything went as planned and our new home is great.</p> <ol start="4"> <li>Side projects <img class="img-fluid" alt="Google Play" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2017/googleplay.jpg" loading="lazy" width="512" height="512" /> </li> </ol> <p>I blogged in February about having a side project but it wasn‚Äôt until later in the year that this solidified into what I am working on now. It started as a way to understand <a href="https://funkysi1701.com/interfaces" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">interfaces</a> this then led to learning Xamarin and creating an android app to help promote this blog. Troy Hunt expanded his HIBP API to include passwords that have been in data breaches, I then started working on pwned passwords which is a simple android frontend for this.</p> <ol start="5"> <li>Learning R</li> </ol> <p>In Feb I also experimented with a new programming language <a href="https://funkysi1701.com/learning-r" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">R</a> . It started with a problem about converting exchange rates and ended with a SQL stored procedure that executed some R code, I still want to learn lots more but it was a good example of the sorts of thing you can build with R.</p> <ol start="6"> <li>DNS programmatically</li> </ol> <p>One of my most successful blogs was about how you can create <a href="https://dev.to/funkysi1701/creating-dns-records-programmatically-26lp" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">dns</a> records within your application eg sites that have yourname.domain in the url. It was a great chance to look at how dns works and learn more about what azure can do to manage this. I want to expand on this and build something.</p> <p>So that was 2017, for some ideas about what 2018 might have in store for me look out for my next blog post.</p>
              - generic [ref=e4703]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e4705]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e4706]:
          - generic [ref=e4709]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e4710]:
            - generic [ref=e4711]:
              - generic [ref=e4712]: <title>
              - text: Getting started with Azure Table Storage
              - generic [ref=e4713]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e4714]:
              - generic [ref=e4715]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/azure-table-storage/
              - generic [ref=e4716]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e4717]:
              - generic [ref=e4718]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e4719]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e4720]:
              - generic [ref=e4721]: <pubDate>
              - text: Sun, 17 Dec 2017 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e4722]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e4723]:
              - generic [ref=e4724]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/azure-table-storage/
              - generic [ref=e4725]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e4726]:
              - generic [ref=e4727]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4728]: term="Azure"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Azure
              - generic [ref=e4729]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4730]:
              - generic [ref=e4731]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4732]: term="SQL"
                - text: ">"
              - text: SQL
              - generic [ref=e4733]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4734]:
              - generic [ref=e4735]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4736]: term="TableStorage"
                - text: ">"
              - text: TableStorage
              - generic [ref=e4737]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4738]:
              - generic [ref=e4739]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4740]: term="Database"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Database
              - generic [ref=e4741]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4742]:
              - generic [ref=e4743]: <description>
              - text: "<p>Azure Table storage is cheap way to store data, however it has some drawbacks that you should be aware of.</p> <p>Azure Table storage is a simple way to store NoSQL data with key/attribute pairs. I am very familiar with storing data in SQL databases and would still choose SQL over Table storage, however Table storage is significantly cheaper so could be worth investigating depending on your project.</p> <p><a href=\"https://www.troyhunt.com/working-with-154-million-records-on/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Troy Hunt</a> makes use of Table storage for his Have I been pwned? website so there are projects out there that make use of it to great affect.</p> <p>To work with Table storage you need to use a nuget package <strong>WindowsAzure.Storage</strong></p> <p><strong>Install-Package WindowsAzure.Storage</strong></p> <p>To load data from a Table in Azure Table storage I use the following code</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>CloudStorageAccount storageAccount = CloudStorageAccount.Parse(connectionString); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>CloudTableClient tableClient = storageAccount.CreateCloudTableClient(); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>CloudTable table = tableClient.GetTableReference(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;tablename&#34;</span>); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>TableOperation retrieveOperation = TableOperation.Retrieve&lt;Entity&gt;(PartitionKey, Rowkey); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>table.CreateIfNotExists(); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>TableResult retrievedResult = table.Execute(retrieveOperation); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>Example eg = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> Example(); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">if</span> (retrievedResult.Result != <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">null</span>) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>{ </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> eg.ID = ((Entity)retrievedResult.Result).Id; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> eg.Date = ((Entity)retrievedResult.Result).Date; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>} </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">return</span> eg; </span></span></code></pre></div><p>You need to create a class (called Entity in the example above) derived from TableEntity which defines the Partitionkey and Rowkey, plus and other columns you want to store in table storage. The row key and partition key uniquely identify the data in the table, think of this as the primary key of the table if you are used to SQL. This class must also contain a parameterless constructor.</p> <p>This is the only way to retrieve data, using the partitionkey and rowkey. If you want to retrieve a specific piece of data you would need to retrieve all rows and then search them for what you need. For me this is not a big problem as I only have 150 rows but if you have millions of rows you may need to think carefully how to use this.</p> <p>To save data I use a very similar piece of code</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>CloudStorageAccount storageAccount = CloudStorageAccount.Parse(path); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>CloudTableClient tableClient = storageAccount.CreateCloudTableClient(); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>CloudTable table = tableClient.GetTableReference(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;tablename&#34;</span>); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>Entity post = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> Entity(ID, DateTime.Now); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>TableOperation insertOperation = TableOperation.InsertOrReplace(post); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>table.CreateIfNotExists(); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>table.Execute(insertOperation); </span></span></code></pre></div><p>I create a Entity object and then pass this as a parameter into the InsertOrReplace method.</p> <p>To delete data it is also very similar, you create an entity object and pass this as a parameter to the Delete method.</p> <p>When debugging my table storage code I found the <a href=\"https://azure.microsoft.com/en-gb/features/storage-explorer/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Azure Storage Explorer</a> very useful for seeing what data actually existed in the table and what might be throwing an error, usually something wrong with my Entity.</p> <p>I mentioned earlier that Table Storage was cheaper than SQL Azure. Well for my simple playing about with things I have found my monthly charge of ¬£10+ has been reduced to ¬£1+ If I were to build anything that is more than just me learning about how it works I would probably continue to use SQL but for the cost of learning new tech it is well worth giving table storage a try.</p>"
              - generic [ref=e4744]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e4746]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e4747]:
          - generic [ref=e4750]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e4751]:
            - generic [ref=e4752]:
              - generic [ref=e4753]: <title>
              - text: How to get Zero Code Changes outside of Source Control
              - generic [ref=e4754]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e4755]:
              - generic [ref=e4756]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/get-zero-code-changes-outside-source-control/
              - generic [ref=e4757]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e4758]:
              - generic [ref=e4759]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e4760]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e4761]:
              - generic [ref=e4762]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 13 Nov 2017 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e4763]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e4764]:
              - generic [ref=e4765]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/get-zero-code-changes-outside-source-control/
              - generic [ref=e4766]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e4767]:
              - generic [ref=e4768]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4769]: term="Git"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Git
              - generic [ref=e4770]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4771]:
              - generic [ref=e4772]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4773]: term="SQL"
                - text: ">"
              - text: SQL
              - generic [ref=e4774]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4775]:
              - generic [ref=e4776]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4777]: term="VisualStudio"
                - text: ">"
              - text: VisualStudio
              - generic [ref=e4778]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4779]:
              - generic [ref=e4780]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4781]: term="SourceCode"
                - text: ">"
              - text: SourceCode
              - generic [ref=e4782]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4783]:
              - generic [ref=e4784]: <description>
              - text: <p>Source control is bread and butter for web developers, however not so much for SQL developers and other business people. One of my goals for the coming year is to get the whole of my team using source control processes.</p> <p>One of the arguments against using source control is there will always be a few exceptions where it won‚Äôt be used. Lets look at a few scenarios to help make the case for source control.</p> <p><strong>Scenario One</strong></p> <p>Web Dev 1 makes a change in production to fix an issue and doesn‚Äôt use source control. Web Dev 2 is working on a new feature and makes use of source control. He is given the sign-off to deploy his new feature and in the process undoes Web Dev 1‚Äôs fix.</p> <p>Management blames Web Dev 2 as they ‚Äúbroke‚Äù stuff during the deployment. Web Dev 2 doesn‚Äôt understand what happened and Web Dev 1 is oblivious to the entire scenario despite in reality being part of the problem.</p> <p><strong>Scenario Two</strong></p> <p>A SQL Dev works all night to fix a problem. He deploy to production and doesn‚Äôt notice a missed where clause due to lack of sleep.</p> <p>‚Äî</p> <p>Let‚Äôs look at these two scenarios done with the whole team buying into source control.</p> <p><strong>Scenario One</strong></p> <p>Web Dev 1 makes a change in production to fix an issue and also commits to source control. This takes him an extra 5 minutes (if that!) Web Dev 2 is working on a new feature and makes use of source control. He is given the sign-off to deploy his new feature and in the process merges Web Dev 1‚Äôs fix before he deploys to production.</p> <p>Management is happy with Web Dev 1, nothing is broken and new functionality has made the website better not worse.</p> <p><strong>Scenario Two</strong></p> <p>A SQL Dev works all night to fix a problem. He deploy to production and doesn‚Äôt notice a missed where clause due to lack of sleep, he also commits to source control this takes him an extra 5 minutes (if that!).</p> <p>In the morning a colleague looks through the commits made during the night and queries the missing where clause. A fix is made in source control and deployed, management and the client are unaware that a problem was created and fixed.</p> <p>‚Äî</p> <p>These are simple scenarios but I cannot think of any situation where the outcome would be better to not use source control. These examples assume no continuous deployment, adding this to the system before every team has bought into source control would cause bugs and issues all over the place.</p> <p>However with a team that is 100% behind source control continuous deployment can achieve an amazing productivity boost. After every commit code could be automatically tested, reviewed by other members of the team and deployed to test environments for further analysis. Only tested code that has been reviewed can get anywhere near production environments.</p> <p>Having said all this there are ways especially on the SQL side to mitigate loosing changes while you work on training individuals and convincing management. Before any code is deployed to production do a schema compare. If you only see changes you have made you can proceed, if you don‚Äôt shout at your team.</p> <p><strong>Advantages</strong></p> <p>Code Reviews<br> Team awareness of what is being changed<br> History of changes<br> Smoother Deployments<br> Automation<br> Better Teamwork<br> Diff changes between different versions<br> Many more</p> <p><strong>Disadvantages</strong></p> <p>Time to learn tools<br> Remember to commit changes<br> Technologies that use binary files harder to version control</p>
              - generic [ref=e4785]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e4787]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e4788]:
          - generic [ref=e4791]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e4792]:
            - generic [ref=e4793]:
              - generic [ref=e4794]: <title>
              - text: SQL with Visual Studio Code
              - generic [ref=e4795]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e4796]:
              - generic [ref=e4797]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/sql-with-visual-studio-code/
              - generic [ref=e4798]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e4799]:
              - generic [ref=e4800]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e4801]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e4802]:
              - generic [ref=e4803]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 06 Nov 2017 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e4804]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e4805]:
              - generic [ref=e4806]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/sql-with-visual-studio-code/
              - generic [ref=e4807]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e4808]:
              - generic [ref=e4809]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4810]: term="Database"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Database
              - generic [ref=e4811]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4812]:
              - generic [ref=e4813]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4814]: term="SQL"
                - text: ">"
              - text: SQL
              - generic [ref=e4815]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4816]:
              - generic [ref=e4817]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4818]: term="VisualStudio"
                - text: ">"
              - text: VisualStudio
              - generic [ref=e4819]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4820]:
              - generic [ref=e4821]: <description>
              - text: <p>Writing SQL queries is typically done with SQL Management Studio (SSMS). However this tool is a bit of a beast so let‚Äôs look at how you could use Visual Studio Code instead.</p> <p>Visual Studio Code is a free text editor but it is so much more than just a text editor. VS Code can be downloaded from <a href="https://code.visualstudio.com/Download" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">https://code.visualstudio.com/Download</a> </p> <p>To work with SQL Server download the mssql extension. Press <strong>CTRL+SHIFT+P</strong> and then Select <strong>Install Extension</strong> and type <strong>mssql</strong>.</p> <p>Intellisense in Visual Studio Code is brilliant, better than SSMS. Lets look at how to get it all set up.</p> <p>Create a new file and set the language type to SQL (Press <strong>CTRL+K,M</strong> )</p> <p>Open the command palette, <strong>CTRL+SHIFT+P</strong> and type SQL to show the mssql commands. Select the Connect command.</p> <p>Then select <strong>Create Connection Profile</strong> , this creates a profile to connect with your SQL Server. Follow the prompts to get it all setup.</p> <p>Look in the bottom right corner of the status bar and you should see you are connected.</p> <p>Now if you type sql you will see a long list of SQL code snippets that you could use.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="SQL Code snippets" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2017/vscode-sql-snippets.png" loading="lazy" width="1016" height="534" /> </p> <p>Choose a snippet to create, and edit it as required. When you are happy press **CTRL+SHIFT+E ** to execute.</p> <p>This is basically all there is to it. However this is an incredibly powerful way of working, the intellisense instantly tells you what database objects you can use in your query and there is a wealth of different snippets you can use.</p> <p>When returning data you get a similar view to SSMS but you can save as Excel, CSV or JSON.</p> <p>SSMS is a very graphical way of doing things, you can double click a table and see its columns or indexes. VS Code relies on TSQL commands but you have access to exactly the same information.</p> <p>For more information about VS Code and the mssql extension check out <a href="https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/linux/sql-server-linux-develop-use-vscode" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/linux/sql-server-linux-develop-use-vscode</a> </p>
              - generic [ref=e4822]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e4824]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e4825]:
          - generic [ref=e4828]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e4829]:
            - generic [ref=e4830]:
              - generic [ref=e4831]: <title>
              - text: Interfaces are cool!
              - generic [ref=e4832]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e4833]:
              - generic [ref=e4834]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/interfaces-are-cool/
              - generic [ref=e4835]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e4836]:
              - generic [ref=e4837]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e4838]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e4839]:
              - generic [ref=e4840]: <pubDate>
              - text: Tue, 31 Oct 2017 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e4841]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e4842]:
              - generic [ref=e4843]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/interfaces-are-cool/
              - generic [ref=e4844]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e4845]:
              - generic [ref=e4846]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4847]: term="BadDesign"
                - text: ">"
              - text: BadDesign
              - generic [ref=e4848]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4849]:
              - generic [ref=e4850]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4851]: term="Interface"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Interface
              - generic [ref=e4852]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4853]:
              - generic [ref=e4854]: <description>
              - text: <p>A while back I <a href="https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/interfaces/">blogged</a> about learning about interfaces as I didn‚Äôt really understand the value of them. I do now.</p> <p>I created an application that used interfaces so I could learn how it worked. I created a Logger Interface and created multiple classes that implemented that interface so I could swap out the different implementations easily. I created a SQL Logger and a File Logger and my code could be written and be completely unaware of which implementation it was using.</p> <p>This application uses SQL Azure and so I have a monthly bill to pay. Wouldn‚Äôt it be cool if I could reduce this bill? How about using the cheaper table storage instead?</p> <p><strong>Easy!</strong></p> <p>Create a new class that implements my interface and all I need to do is write the three methods defined in my interface and I can swap from SQL Azure to table storage.</p> <p>Another benefit to interfaces is testing. Say I have an interface called inotification for sending notifications, I can have several implementations of this email, twitter, slack etc</p> <p>None of these implementations should be used in unit tests, as you don‚Äôt want a tweet being sent every time you run your tests. Why not create an implementation that simply returns something for each method call and doesn‚Äôt actually do anything. I can then run my tests with my fake implementation which tests my code logic but not the implementation I have chosen (this can be tested later on with integration tests or user testing if required).</p> <p>This is pretty much all I have to say about interfaces. I just like how I can swap different implementations.</p> <p>It does take a bit of work to get the interface setup. I found that when writing the second implementation the interface would need to change slightly, mostly as it was badly designed to begin with. I think for beginners there may be some value to writing multiple implementations of an interface so you can be sure your interface is good, however I am sure with experience this will not be required.</p>
              - generic [ref=e4855]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e4857]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e4858]:
          - generic [ref=e4861]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e4862]:
            - generic [ref=e4863]:
              - generic [ref=e4864]: <title>
              - text: Creating DNS records programmatically
              - generic [ref=e4865]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e4866]:
              - generic [ref=e4867]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/creating-dns-records-programmatically/
              - generic [ref=e4868]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e4869]:
              - generic [ref=e4870]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e4871]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e4872]:
              - generic [ref=e4873]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 16 Oct 2017 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e4874]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e4875]:
              - generic [ref=e4876]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/creating-dns-records-programmatically/
              - generic [ref=e4877]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e4878]:
              - generic [ref=e4879]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4880]: term="Azure"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Azure
              - generic [ref=e4881]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4882]:
              - generic [ref=e4883]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4884]: term="DNS"
                - text: ">"
              - text: DNS
              - generic [ref=e4885]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4886]:
              - generic [ref=e4887]: <description>
              - text: "<p>DNS is the backbone of the internet. It converts domain names into IP addresses. But how can we do clever things with it?</p> <p>Making DNS changes has always been a pain. You have to remember what company you registered your domain name with, then locate the login details for their website, login and fill in some web form and wait for the changes to replicate across the internet.</p> <p>There are various websites that assign you a custom subdomain name like name.domain.com, obviously they must do this programmatically, they don‚Äôt have a guy following the above process.</p> <p>Lets see how we could do this.</p> <p>My first thought was to make use of the DNSimple API. <a href=\"https://developer.dnsimple.com/v2/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">https://developer.dnsimple.com/v2/</a> The API allows all sort of DNS changes to be made, however this is a paid service so let‚Äôs look at other options.</p> <p>Azure now has a DNS section. You can go to the portal, add a DNS zone, and then add as many A, CNAME and MX records as you need. This is of course no better than doing it manually.</p> <p>Azure offers a <a href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/dns/dns-sdk\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">SDK</a> and an example Visual Studio project. Lets look at how it works.</p> <p>First you need to setup some credentials to use your Azure subscription. The easiest way to do this is with powershell.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-powershell\" data-lang=\"powershell\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>Login<span style=\"color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010\">‚Äì</span>AzureRmAccount </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>$sp = New-AzureRmADServicePrincipal <span style=\"color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010\">‚Äì</span>DisplayName exampleapp <span style=\"color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010\">‚Äì</span>Password <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;{provide-password}&#34;</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>Sleep <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">20</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>New-AzureRmRoleAssignment <span style=\"color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010\">‚Äì</span>RoleDefinitionName Contributor <span style=\"color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010\">‚Äì</span>ServicePrincipalName $sp.ApplicationId </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This will create a AD Service Principal which has access to your Azure subscription.</p> <p>You need to get the following IDs from the Azure portal.</p> <p>subscriptionId for your subscription<br> tenantId or the Azure AD Directory ID<br> applicationId of the service principal created above<br> password you entered into the powershell script above</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> serviceCreds = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">await</span> ApplicationTokenProvider.LoginSilentAsync(tenantId, clientId, secret); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> dnsClient = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> DnsManagementClient(serviceCreds); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>dnsClient.SubscriptionId = subscriptionId; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> recordSetParams = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> RecordSet(); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>recordSetParams.TTL = <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">3600</span>; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>recordSetParams.ARecords = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> List&lt;ARecord&gt;(); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>recordSetParams.ARecords.Add(<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> ARecord(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;1.2.3.4&#34;</span>)); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> recordSet = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">await</span> dnsClient.RecordSets.CreateOrUpdateAsync(resourceGroupName, <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;funkysi1701.com&#34;</span>, <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;test&#34;</span>, RecordType.A, recordSetParams); </span></span></code></pre></div><p>The above code connects to Azure and creates an A record for test.funkysi1701.com that points at the ip address 1.2.3.4.</p> <p>Other DNS records can be created in a similar way.</p> <p>The above example creates a new RecordSet but you can use the following to delete or get existing records.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> recordSet = dnsClient.RecordSets.Get(resourceGroupName, <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;funkysi1701.com&#34;</span>, <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;test&#34;</span>, RecordType.A); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>dnsClient.RecordSets.Delete(resourceGroupName, <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;funkysi1701.com&#34;</span>, <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;test&#34;</span>, RecordType.A); </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now I have found out that I can write a console app to edit my DNS records I need to change the nameservers for all my domains so I can take advantage of this new feature.</p>"
              - generic [ref=e4888]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e4890]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e4891]:
          - generic [ref=e4894]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e4895]:
            - generic [ref=e4896]:
              - generic [ref=e4897]: <title>
              - text: Discovery ‚Äì My thoughts so far
              - generic [ref=e4898]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e4899]:
              - generic [ref=e4900]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/discovery-my-thoughts-so-far/
              - generic [ref=e4901]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e4902]:
              - generic [ref=e4903]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e4904]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e4905]:
              - generic [ref=e4906]: <pubDate>
              - text: Tue, 10 Oct 2017 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e4907]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e4908]:
              - generic [ref=e4909]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/discovery-my-thoughts-so-far/
              - generic [ref=e4910]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e4911]:
              - generic [ref=e4912]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4913]: term="StarTrek"
                - text: ">"
              - text: StarTrek
              - generic [ref=e4914]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4915]:
              - generic [ref=e4916]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4917]: term="Discovery"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Discovery
              - generic [ref=e4918]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4919]:
              - generic [ref=e4920]: <description>
              - text: <p>I tried to resist but I am going to have to write about the new Star Trek series Discovery. Warning this post is going to include SPOILERS. If you read on you have been warned.</p> <p>I watched the first two episodes of the brand new Star Trek TV show. As I am an international viewer I used Netflix, if you are from the US you need to use CBS All Access. <img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2017/DAD0hTKUAAAUkTP.jpg" loading="lazy" width="1199" height="663" /> </p> <p>I have heard a lot of complaining that the show is not free to watch. CBS is making Star Trek Discovery to make money, if they don‚Äôt make money they will stop making it. Its as simple as that.</p> <p><a href="https://www.netflix.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Netflix</a> costs ¬£5.99 per month and <a href="https://www.cbs.com/all-access/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">CBS All Access</a> costs $5.99 per month. I don‚Äôt believe this is a lot of money. The 5.99 above allows you to watch any of the 726 Star Trek episodes at any time of day whenever you want as many times as you want, plus you have access to all the other movies or TV shows available. I don‚Äôt think this is too much to ask.</p> <p>Back to Discovery. I loved it! It felt like Star Trek. I had feared it might only share the name and would be an action filled TV show that had little in common with what he had seen before. I was wrong this is definitely a show that can proudly call itself Star Trek.</p> <p><strong>The Klingons</strong></p> <p>When it was first announced that the Klingons would feature in the new show I was a bit ‚Äúmeh‚Äù. We had done lots with the Klingons before and they had never been my favourite alien race. <img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2017/star-trek-discovery-klingons-1002567-1280x0.jpg" loading="lazy" width="1280" height="704" /> </p> <p>The look of the Klingons was also going to be changed, I have to admit this didn‚Äôt bother me. Klingons have had their look updated before. In 1966 Klingons had dark faces and smooth foreheads, in 1979 the forehead ridges were added as the first Star Trek movie was made, and now Discovery has removed all hair from Klingons. I can explain it away as productional changes, I don‚Äôt need an on screen explanation like we had on Enterprise (or even DS9).</p> <p>What I have seen so far is a menacing alien race that fits with what we have seen before with lots of references to honor, Kahless and speaking Klingon. I must admit reading all the subtitles is getting a bit tiresome, but that is a minor issue.</p> <p><strong>Conflict</strong></p> <p>Historically Star Trek has not featured conflict between the main starfleet characters due to the idea that humanity has evolved beyond this. DS9 got round this by having Odo and Kira who are not starfleet characters so can have a little bit of conflict. Discovery has completely abandoned this idea.</p> <p>In the pilot episode, the Michael Burnham commits mutiny on her captain, even attacking her with a vulcan nerve pinch. In the third episode we finally meet the discovery crew. Gone are the TNG days where the ships crew are like a family, I am not sure I can think of a single character that would call another character ‚Äúfriend‚Äù. We are in a time of war so this would be expected, however I do hope we see deepening friendships form between characters.</p> <p>I am OK with the change to feature more conflict. I must admit the darkness of the third episode, did stop to make me think a bit, however by the fourth episode I was won over.</p> <p><strong>Cast</strong></p> <p>The story is concentrated around Michael Burnham, so I do worry that other characters won‚Äôt get a look in. However from what I have seen Michael Burnham is a great character. She is a strong female character, with a intriguing back story relating to Sarek and possibly also Spock.</p> <p>Saru the alien character on the show, played by the very tall Doug Jones is great. From the trailers he was all about sensing death, but there is far more to him than that. I am looking forward to learn more about him and his threat ganglia.</p> <p>As the show has gone on we have started to learn about the other characters like Captain Lorca, Tilly and Paul Stamets.</p> <p><strong>Title Sequence</strong></p> <p>I don‚Äôt like the opening title sequence, it feels very cheap like a draft version which hasn‚Äôt been finished yet. I was looking forward to a title sequence that would show off the USS Discovery, maybe like TNG where it warps around our own solar system. What we see is some of the tech that features in Star Trek which is nice but I want more. The theme tune while great that it features parts from the classic theme doesn‚Äôt stand on its own. I can hum all the other TV shows themes, and now after 4 episodes would struggle to do that.</p> <p>However I expect that after a while I will grow to like this more.</p> <p><strong>Overall</strong></p> <p>I like Discovery and I will keep watching it. I want to find out what happens to the characters. There are no annoying characters like other shows have had. There is character development, none of the characters are going to finish where they started. I want more friendship between characters, but I expect that will come, I want more exploring and doing Star Trek stuff, but most of all I want more episodes, roll on next weeks show.</p> <p>Other things I noticed</p> <ul> <li>Sound effects on the bridge are awesome, it makes me feel at home</li> <li>The USS Discovery doesn‚Äôt feature in the first two episodes despite being the title of the show.</li> <li>Others have noted that Captain Georgiou has books on her shelf which feature classic episode titles</li> </ul>
              - generic [ref=e4921]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e4923]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e4924]:
          - generic [ref=e4927]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e4928]:

              - generic [ref=e4930]: <title>
              - text: Star Trek is back with Discovery
              - generic [ref=e4931]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e4932]:

              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/star-trek-is-back-with-discovery/

              - generic [ref=e4937]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e4938]:
              - generic [ref=e4939]: <pubDate>

              - generic [ref=e4940]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e4941]:
              - generic [ref=e4942]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/star-trek-is-back-with-discovery/
              - generic [ref=e4943]: </guid>
