              - generic [ref=e4945]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4946]: term="StarTrek"
                - text: ">"
              - text: StarTrek
              - generic [ref=e4947]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4948]:
              - generic [ref=e4949]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4950]: term="Discovery"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Discovery
              - generic [ref=e4951]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4952]:
              - generic [ref=e4953]: <description>
              - text: "<p>In <a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/star-trek-is-back-in-2017\">November 2015</a> it was announced that a new Star Trek series was going to be launched. It has been a long wait with multiple delays but Star Trek Discovery is finally here.</p> <p>Star Trek Discovery launches in the US on 24th September and in the UK on 25th September.</p> <iframe src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/UoV3kc05Nwc?rel=0\" width=\"560\" height=\"315\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"allowfullscreen\"></iframe> <p>Lets have a look back how we got here.</p> <p>Star Trek was created by Gene Roddenberry in the 1960s. He imagined a show where we would explore the galaxy while also exploring the human condition. He described it as a wagon train to the stars. However it was cancelled after 79 episodes and three seasons due to budget cuts and low viewers.</p> <p>After cancellation its popularity boomed in reruns. In the mid 1970s an animated series was created. But demand for Star Trek continued until a new Star Trek show was commissioned called Phase Two.</p> <p>In 1977 Star Wars came out, and the phase two idea was cancelled and turned into a movie. In 1979 we got Star Trek The Motion Picture. It went massively over budget and failed to really capture the Star Trek spirit.</p> <p>A much cheaper sequel was created in 1982 Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan with Roddenberry taking more of a back seat. A film widely considered to be one of the best trek films. Four more feature films starring the original cast were made.</p> <p>However in 1987 Gene Roddenberry teamed up with Rick Berman and The Next Generation was created with a brand new cast. The series ran for seven seasons set roughly a century after the adventures of Kirk and Spock.</p> <p>Popularity of Star Trek soured and this led Rick Berman to help create the spin off series Deep Space 9, Voyager and lastly Enterprise along with four feature films continuing the adventures of the TNG cast. When Enterprise was cancelled in 2005, Star Trek appeared to be dead after 18 years on TV.</p> <p>However in 2009 movie creator JJ Abrams recast the classic crew for the big screen. The film was big on action, but took place in an alternative timeline allowing for familiar characters to have new adventures without interfering with events depicted in the TV shows.</p> <p>Two sequels to this film have been produced and are bringing Star Trek back into popularity. This has given rise to Discovery. Star Trek is returning to the TV screen and it is going to be great.</p> <p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"Discovery\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2017/gqojtfz1dhmxoiri7g8p.png\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" /> </p>"
              - generic [ref=e4954]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e4956]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e4957]:
          - generic [ref=e4960]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e4961]:
            - generic [ref=e4962]:
              - generic [ref=e4963]: <title>
              - text: Azure Friday
              - generic [ref=e4964]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e4965]:
              - generic [ref=e4966]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/azure-friday/
              - generic [ref=e4967]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e4968]:
              - generic [ref=e4969]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e4970]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e4971]:
              - generic [ref=e4972]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 18 Sep 2017 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e4973]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e4974]:
              - generic [ref=e4975]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/azure-friday/
              - generic [ref=e4976]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e4977]:
              - generic [ref=e4978]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4979]: term="Azure"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Azure
              - generic [ref=e4980]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4981]:
              - generic [ref=e4982]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e4983]: term="ApplicationInsights"
                - text: ">"
              - text: ApplicationInsights
              - generic [ref=e4984]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e4985]:
              - generic [ref=e4986]: <description>
              - text: <p>I think Azure is great, but there is loads to it so I can never know about all of its features. There is a video series hosted by Scott Hanselman called <a href="https://channel9.msdn.com/Shows/Azure-Friday" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Azure Fridays</a> which I have started to watch in an effort to keep more up to date about some of its cool features.</p> <iframe src="https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/shows/azure-friday/debug-net-apps-in-production-snapshot-debugger-in-application-insights/player" width="960" height="540" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe> <p>I watched this video recently and it is all about application insights and new ways you can debug your web applications by creating snapshots. I am a big fan of application insights so adding extra ways to debug my apps is a big win for me. Once I get this feature working in my code I will no doubt blog about it.</p>
              - generic [ref=e4987]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e4989]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e4990]:
          - generic [ref=e4993]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e4994]:
            - generic [ref=e4995]:
              - generic [ref=e4996]: <title>
              - text: Azure Functions
              - generic [ref=e4997]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e4998]:
              - generic [ref=e4999]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/azure-functions/
              - generic [ref=e5000]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e5001]:
              - generic [ref=e5002]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e5003]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e5004]:
              - generic [ref=e5005]: <pubDate>
              - text: Tue, 12 Sep 2017 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e5006]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e5007]:
              - generic [ref=e5008]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/azure-functions/
              - generic [ref=e5009]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e5010]:
              - generic [ref=e5011]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5012]: term="Azure"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Azure
              - generic [ref=e5013]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5014]:
              - generic [ref=e5015]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5016]: term="DevOps"
                - text: ">"
              - text: DevOps
              - generic [ref=e5017]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5018]:
              - generic [ref=e5019]: <description>
              - text: "<p>I recently blogged about using <a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/using-azure-webjobs-to-automate-stuff\">Azure Web Jobs</a> , Azure Function is another way of doing the same thing, lets look at how they work.</p> <p>(Sorry its been a while since I blogged but I suspect an erratic schedule will continue for the next few months.)</p> <p>To create an Azure Function go to the Azure portal and click add new and search for &ldquo;Function App&rdquo;</p> <p>Give your app a name and select the usual resource group and location settings.</p> <p>Now when you open Function Apps you should see your new app.</p> <p>I want my Function App to run on a schedule so I clicked the + next to functions and selected TimerTrigger. I am a c# programmer so I selected this option as well.</p> <p>Give your function a name and specify using the usual cron notation how often it should run. I want mine to run at 9.30pm each night so use 0 30 21 * * *</p> <p>Now comes the code bit. By default you get a window with the following code in it</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">using</span> System; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">public</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">static</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">void</span> Run(TimerInfo myTimer, TraceWriter log) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>{ </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> log.Info(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">$&#34;C# Timer trigger function executed at: {DateTime.Now}&#34;</span>); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>} </span></span></code></pre></div><p>It is entirely up to you what you get your function to do. In my case I just wanted to call a URL on a schedule so I created some code that used httpclient.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">using</span> System; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">using</span> System.Net.Http; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">public</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">static</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">async</span> Task Run(TimerInfo myTimer, TraceWriter log) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>{ </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> log.Info(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">$&#34;Buffer 0 function executed at: {DateTime.Now}&#34;</span>); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> HttpClient client = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> HttpClient(); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> result = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">await</span> client.GetAsync(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;URL&#34;</span>); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span> resultContent = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">await</span> result.Content.ReadAsStringAsync(); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> log.Info(resultContent); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>} </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Once you have created your app and it has run you can use the monitor section to view success and failures.</p> <p>There is loads more you can do with Azure Function but this is a good place to start.</p>"
              - generic [ref=e5020]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e5022]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e5023]:
          - generic [ref=e5026]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e5027]:
            - generic [ref=e5028]:
              - generic [ref=e5029]: <title>
              - text: Pwned Pass ‚Äì Available from the Play Store
              - generic [ref=e5030]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e5031]:
              - generic [ref=e5032]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/pwned-pass-available-from-the-play-store/
              - generic [ref=e5033]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e5034]:
              - generic [ref=e5035]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e5036]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e5037]:
              - generic [ref=e5038]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 14 Aug 2017 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e5039]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e5040]:
              - generic [ref=e5041]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/pwned-pass-available-from-the-play-store/
              - generic [ref=e5042]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e5043]:
              - generic [ref=e5044]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5045]: term="Android"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Android
              - generic [ref=e5046]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5047]:
              - generic [ref=e5048]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5049]: term="Mobile"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Mobile
              - generic [ref=e5050]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5051]:
              - generic [ref=e5052]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5053]: term="App"
                - text: ">"
              - text: App
              - generic [ref=e5054]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5055]:
              - generic [ref=e5056]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5057]: term="PwnedPass"
                - text: ">"
              - text: PwnedPass
              - generic [ref=e5058]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5059]:
              - generic [ref=e5060]: <description>
              - text: "<p>Pwned Pass is now available from the <a href=\"https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=pwnedpasswords.pwnedpasswords\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Google Play Store</a> .</p> <p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"Pwned Pass\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2017/Screenshot_20170813-205152.png\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"1080\" height=\"1920\" /> </p> <p>Pwned Pass is a simple android app that allows you to type in a password and tells you if it has been used in a data breach.</p> <p>Troy Hunt of <a href=\"https://haveibeenpwned.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Have I Been Pwned?</a> recently added a new API to his website which allows you to search his extensive database of pwned passwords, 306 million of them. I have simply created a Android frontend to this API.</p> <p>The API itself takes a SHA1 hash of the password and either returns a HTTP 200 if the password is found or a HTTP 404 if the password does not exist in the HIBP database. For more details of how Troy Hunt created this check out his <a href=\"https://www.troyhunt.com/introducing-306-million-freely-downloadable-pwned-passwords/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">blog post</a> .</p> <p>My app simply generates a SHA1 hash of anything that is typed in and then passes this to Troy Hunt‚Äôs API. I then get the HTTP return code so I know if the password exists or not.</p> <p>It should be noted that: <strong>Do not send any password you actively use to a third-party service ‚Äì even this one!</strong> I don‚Äôt log anything that you type into my app and all I am then doing is passing a SHA1 hash over SSL to HIBP. However you shouldn‚Äôt trust my word alone.</p> <p>The app itself is written in Visual Studio with Xamarin Forms in a similar fashion to the app I talked about <a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/android-app-development-and-the-visual-studio-mobile-centre\">last week</a> .</p> <p>As I am using Xamarin Forms there is the potential that I may develop iPhone or UWP versions of this code in the future. With that in mind I have made use of interfaces for the android specific parts of the code.</p> <p>I also make use of the <a href=\"https://www.nuget.org/packages/modernhttpclient/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">modernhttpclient</a> nuget package due to problems I encountered with httpclient and SSL. This is due to limitations of what libraries are available in mono and what has been implemented, I suspect there are better ways to solve this but that is all part of the fun.</p> <p>Please do have a look at Pwned Pass and let me know what you think. Especially if it doesn‚Äôt work or throws errors. I would like to spend time making this app as good as I can make it.</p>"
              - generic [ref=e5061]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e5063]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e5064]:
          - generic [ref=e5067]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e5068]:
            - generic [ref=e5069]:
              - generic [ref=e5070]: <title>
              - text: Android App Development and the Visual Studio Mobile Centre
              - generic [ref=e5071]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e5072]:
              - generic [ref=e5073]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/android-app-development-and-the-visual-studio-mobile-centre/
              - generic [ref=e5074]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e5075]:
              - generic [ref=e5076]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e5077]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e5078]:
              - generic [ref=e5079]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 07 Aug 2017 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e5080]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e5081]:
              - generic [ref=e5082]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/android-app-development-and-the-visual-studio-mobile-centre/
              - generic [ref=e5083]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e5084]:
              - generic [ref=e5085]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5086]: term="App"
                - text: ">"
              - text: App
              - generic [ref=e5087]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5088]:
              - generic [ref=e5089]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5090]: term="Azure"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Azure
              - generic [ref=e5091]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5092]:
              - generic [ref=e5093]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5094]: term="Android"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Android
              - generic [ref=e5095]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5096]:
              - generic [ref=e5097]: <description>
              - text: <p>For the past week or so I have been playing around with Xamarin and creating an android app.</p> <p>Well I now have an app in the Google Play Store. Check out <a href="https://play.google.com/store/apps/dev?id=6148298088834956775" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">https://play.google.com/store/apps/dev?id=6148298088834956775</a> . <img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2017/Screenshot_20170806-190053.png" loading="lazy" width="1080" height="1920" /> </p> <p>Before you rush and download the app I must warn you that it doesn‚Äôt do much yet. It displays some content that is on my website and there are a few links to allow sharing of content. I have some ideas to display content from my blog and allow sharing. I also have some other ideas for apps that might actually be useful to people that are not me. If you have ideas or feature requests do let me know.</p> <p>Ok how did I go about creating this app and getting it in the app store?</p> <p>Xamarin is now part of Visual Studio so step one is install all the Xamarin features to Visual Studio and build an app.</p> <p>Next I wanted to monitor my app. Now I know Application Insights doesn‚Äôt support apps so what tools are out there? HockeyApp is something I had heard of but they are in the process of being replaced with <a href="https://appcenter.ms/apps" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Visual Studio Mobile Centre</a> .</p> <p>It was relatively easy to hook up my app to Visual Studio Mobile Centre. First install the required nuget packages. Then add using statements and the following line to your MainActivity.cs file (these instructions are available on the Mobile Centre)</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" style="color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;"><code class="language-csharp" data-lang="csharp"><span style="display:flex;"><span><span style="color:#66d9ef">using</span> Microsoft.Azure.Mobile; </span></span><span style="display:flex;"><span><span style="color:#66d9ef">using</span> Microsoft.Azure.Mobile.Analytics; </span></span><span style="display:flex;"><span><span style="color:#66d9ef">using</span> Microsoft.Azure.Mobile.Crashes; </span></span><span style="display:flex;"><span><span style="color:#66d9ef">using</span> Microsoft.Azure.Mobile.Distribute; </span></span><span style="display:flex;"><span><span style="color:#66d9ef">using</span> Microsoft.Azure.Mobile.Push; </span></span></code></pre></div><div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" style="color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;"><code class="language-csharp" data-lang="csharp"><span style="display:flex;"><span>MobileCenter.Start(<span style="color:#e6db74">&#34;[Unique ID]&#34;</span>,<span style="color:#66d9ef">typeof</span>(Analytics), <span style="color:#66d9ef">typeof</span>(Crashes), <span style="color:#66d9ef">typeof</span>(Distribute), <span style="color:#66d9ef">typeof</span>(Push)); </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now you can connect the Mobile Centre to your source code (VSTS in my case) and get it to run a build for every commit.</p> <p>One complexity of the build is that you need to supply a keystore file (basically a certificate to digitally sign your app). I found the best way to do this was to use Visual Studio to create the file.</p> <p>In VS2017 there is a option called Archive Manager under the tools menu. In here click the distribute button and select Ad-hoc. In the signing identity section you can create a keystore file. Enter a few details and a keystore file will be created in AppData\Local\Xamarin\Mono for Android\Keystore[keystore name][keystore name.keystore]</p> <p>Once you have added the keystore file to your build you can enable the distribute option. Now you will get an email after every build with a link to install your app.</p> <p>Every time your app crashes the details will be logged in the crashes section for you to explore and fix the issues.</p> <p>The Analytics section allows you to explore how your app is being used. You can also add Analytics.TrackEvent(&ldquo;Feature X&rdquo;) to measure the usage of different features.</p> <p>There are more things you can do which I will explore more at another time along with how to get your app into the Google Play Store.</p>
              - generic [ref=e5098]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e5100]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e5101]:
          - generic [ref=e5104]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e5105]:
            - generic [ref=e5106]:
              - generic [ref=e5107]: <title>
              - text: Creating your own nuget packages with VSTS
              - generic [ref=e5108]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e5109]:
              - generic [ref=e5110]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/creating-nuget-packages/
              - generic [ref=e5111]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e5112]:
              - generic [ref=e5113]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e5114]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e5115]:
              - generic [ref=e5116]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 31 Jul 2017 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e5117]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e5118]:
              - generic [ref=e5119]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/creating-nuget-packages/
              - generic [ref=e5120]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e5121]:
              - generic [ref=e5122]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5123]: term="Nuget"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Nuget
              - generic [ref=e5124]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5125]:
              - generic [ref=e5126]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5127]: term="C-Sharp"
                - text: ">"
              - text: C-Sharp
              - generic [ref=e5128]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5129]:
              - generic [ref=e5130]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5131]: term="VisualStudio"
                - text: ">"
              - text: VisualStudio
              - generic [ref=e5132]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5133]:
              - generic [ref=e5134]: <description>
              - text: <p>For a while I have found myself writing the same bits of code for different web projects. This annoys me as it goes against the DRY principle (don‚Äôt repeat yourself).</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="Nuget" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2017/nuget.png" loading="lazy" width="444" height="135" /> One possible solution is to write your own nuget packages. You can then add this piece of code to any project you work on.</p> <p><a href="https://www.nuget.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">nuget.org</a> is the public nuget feed where any developer can download nuget packages. You could publish your nuget package here, but your might want to restrict access so better to create a private nuget feed.</p> <p>Lets look at how we create a nuget feed in Visual Studio. First thing you need to do is install the <a href="https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=ms.feed" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Package Management</a> extension to Visual Studio Team Services (its free for less than 5 users), this will add a packages section under the build menu.</p> <p>Before you can start using this new feature you need to add a Package Management License in the users hub.</p> <p>Once that is done you can create a feed. You need to give your feed a name, decide if only members of the current project or everyone in your account should have access to read and contribute to.</p> <p>Now you have a feed you could use the nuget package command to create a nupkg file and then nuget push command to add it to your feed. A better way is to get Visual Studio Team Services to do all the hard work.</p> <p>Create a new project in Visual Studio Team Service to house your nuget package. In the build section add an empty build definition. Choose a build agent, I am using the Hosted VS2017. Then add the following steps nuget restore, Visual Studio Build, nuget pack and nuget push.</p> <ul> <li>nuget restore ‚Äì this step is only needed if your code depends on other packages. If it depends on other packages that are only in your feed you must specify your feed in the feeds and authentication section.</li> <li>Visual Studio Build ‚Äì this builds your code like you would in Visual Studio. The only config I made to this step was to specify Release in configuration.</li> <li>nuget pack ‚Äì this creates the nupkg file from your built project. In configuration to package specify the same as you specified in the previous step (in my case Release)</li> <li>nuget push ‚Äì this publishes to your feed, so of course you need to specify your feed.</li> </ul> <p>One last thing to configure is to enable the continuous integration option in triggers. This means whenever you push code all these steps will run and you have a new version of your nuget package.</p> <p>In Visual Studio you need to create a *.nuspec file, this contains all the meta data about your nuget package. Let look at an example.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" style="color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;"><code class="language-xml" data-lang="xml"><span style="display:flex;"><span><span style="color:#75715e">&lt;?xml version=&#34;1.0&#34;?&gt;</span> </span></span><span style="display:flex;"><span><span style="color:#f92672">&lt;package</span> <span style="color:#f92672">&gt;</span> </span></span><span style="display:flex;"><span> <span style="color:#f92672">&lt;metadata&gt;</span> </span></span><span style="display:flex;"><span> <span style="color:#f92672">&lt;id&gt;</span>$id$<span style="color:#f92672">&lt;/id&gt;</span> </span></span><span style="display:flex;"><span> <span style="color:#f92672">&lt;version&gt;</span>1.0.2<span style="color:#f92672">&lt;/version&gt;</span> </span></span><span style="display:flex;"><span> <span style="color:#f92672">&lt;title&gt;</span>Nuget<span style="color:#f92672">&lt;/title&gt;</span> </span></span><span style="display:flex;"><span> <span style="color:#f92672">&lt;authors&gt;</span>Simon Foster<span style="color:#f92672">&lt;/authors&gt;</span> </span></span><span style="display:flex;"><span> <span style="color:#f92672">&lt;owners&gt;</span>Simon Foster<span style="color:#f92672">&lt;/owners&gt;</span> </span></span><span style="display:flex;"><span> <span style="color:#f92672">&lt;requireLicenseAcceptance&gt;</span>false<span style="color:#f92672">&lt;/requireLicenseAcceptance&gt;</span> </span></span><span style="display:flex;"><span> <span style="color:#f92672">&lt;description&gt;</span>An example of a nuget package.<span style="color:#f92672">&lt;/description&gt;</span> </span></span><span style="display:flex;"><span> <span style="color:#f92672">&lt;releaseNotes&gt;</span>Release Notes<span style="color:#f92672">&lt;/releaseNotes&gt;</span> </span></span><span style="display:flex;"><span> <span style="color:#f92672">&lt;copyright&gt;</span>Copyright 2017<span style="color:#f92672">&lt;/copyright&gt;</span> </span></span><span style="display:flex;"><span> <span style="color:#f92672">&lt;projectUrl&gt;</span>https://[yourVSaccount].visualstudio.com/nuget/<span style="color:#f92672">&lt;/projectUrl&gt;</span> </span></span><span style="display:flex;"><span> <span style="color:#f92672">&lt;/metadata&gt;</span> </span></span><span style="display:flex;"><span><span style="color:#f92672">&lt;/package&gt;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>One last thing to mention is version numbers. You can either change the version number in your *.nuspec file everytime you push changes. This will create stable packages like 1.0, 1.1, 1.2 etc</p> <p>However you can use the automatic version number setting in the nuget pack build step. However I have found this only ever creates pre-release packages and I haven‚Äôt found a way to upgrade a package from pre-release to stable.</p> <p>This is a really neat way to reuse your code in multiple projects. I have only been looking at this for a few days and I have already extracted code to do with emails, creating excel downloads and database related methods. I suspect that doing this will also have a side benefit of forcing me to create code with fewer dependencies so more code can be turned into a nuget package.</p>
              - generic [ref=e5135]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e5137]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e5138]:
          - generic [ref=e5141]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e5142]:
            - generic [ref=e5143]:
              - generic [ref=e5144]: <title>
              - text: Async and Await
              - generic [ref=e5145]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e5146]:
              - generic [ref=e5147]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/async-and-await/
              - generic [ref=e5148]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e5149]:
              - generic [ref=e5150]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e5151]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e5152]:
              - generic [ref=e5153]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 24 Jul 2017 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e5154]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e5155]:
              - generic [ref=e5156]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/async-and-await/
              - generic [ref=e5157]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e5158]:
              - generic [ref=e5159]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5160]: term="Async"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Async
              - generic [ref=e5161]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5162]:
              - generic [ref=e5163]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5164]: term="Await"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Await
              - generic [ref=e5165]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5166]:
              - generic [ref=e5167]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5168]: term="C-Sharp"
                - text: ">"
              - text: C-Sharp
              - generic [ref=e5169]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5170]:
              - generic [ref=e5171]: <description>
              - text: "<p>For a while the Async and Await commands in c# have confused me.</p> <p>Like most things the best way to learn about something is to use it in a real world example. I am currently adding an email alert feature to a website. This is an ideal example of something that would benefit from Asynchronous programming. There is no need for the webpage to wait to send 1000s of emails, lets just send a call to get started and allow the browser to carry on as normal.</p> <p>This is my first try at using async and await so feel free to suggest best practises in the comments.</p> <p>Lets start with a Send method in my EmailController.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">public</span> ActionResult Send(<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">int</span> id, <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">int</span> pageId, <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">int</span> userID) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>{ </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">if</span> (!Authorize.checkPageIsAuthorised(userID, (Authorize.PageIds)pageId)) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">return</span> Redirect(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;/login&#34;</span>); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">else</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> Task&lt;<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span>&gt; t = SendNotifications(id,userID); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">return</span> Redirect(Request.UrlReferrer.ToString()); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>} </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This simply checks to see if you have permission to the page. If not redirects to the login page otherwise it makes a method call and redirects back to the page it came from.</p> <p>Lets have a look at that method call in more detail.</p> <p>Task<string> t = SendNotification(id, userid);</p> <p>SendNotification doesn‚Äôt return a normal string it returns a Task<string>, so lets look at how we are creating this.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">public</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">async</span> Task&lt;<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span>&gt; SendNotifications(<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">int</span> id,<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span> type,<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">int</span> userid) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>{ </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#75715e\">//logic ommitted</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">await</span> ef.SendEmail(model, emailHtmlBody); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">return</span> <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;OK&#34;</span>; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>} </span></span></code></pre></div><p>The return type is set to Task but it has the aysnc keyword appended to it. It also makes a call with the await keyword.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">public</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">async</span> Task SendEmail(EmailModel model,<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span> emailHtmlBody) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>{ </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#75715e\">//logic removed</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">await</span> smtp.SendMailAsync(message); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>} </span></span></code></pre></div><p>So that is it. My first bit of code that uses Async and Await. My controller calls a method asynchronously which then calls another method asynchronously which sends emails asynchronously.</p> <p>Async ‚Äì This enables the Await keyword to be used in the method</p> <p>Await ‚Äì This is where things get asynchronous. The await keyword allows the code to wait asynchronously for the long running code to complete.</p>"
              - generic [ref=e5172]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e5174]: </item>

          - generic [ref=e5178]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e5179]:
            - generic [ref=e5180]:
              - generic [ref=e5181]: <title>
              - text: How good is your SSL?
              - generic [ref=e5182]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e5183]:
              - generic [ref=e5184]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/how-good-is-your-ssl/
              - generic [ref=e5185]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e5186]:
              - generic [ref=e5187]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e5188]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e5189]:
              - generic [ref=e5190]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 17 Jul 2017 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e5191]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e5192]:
              - generic [ref=e5193]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/how-good-is-your-ssl/
              - generic [ref=e5194]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e5195]:
              - generic [ref=e5196]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5197]: term="SSL"
                - text: ">"
              - text: SSL
              - generic [ref=e5198]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5199]:
              - generic [ref=e5200]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5201]: term="Security"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Security
              - generic [ref=e5202]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5203]:
              - generic [ref=e5204]: <description>
              - text: <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="Troy Hunt SSL expert" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2017/Troy-Hunt-Profile-Photo.jpg" loading="lazy" width="800" height="800" /> </p> <p>I recently watched Troy Hunt‚Äôs <a href="https://www.pluralsight.com/courses/https-every-developer-must-know" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">What Every Developer Must Know about HTTPS</a> course on Pluralsight. Its very good and really make you think about SSL certificates and how to correctly implement them.</p> <p>One thing in particular Troy mentions is the website <a href="https://www.ssllabs.com/ssltest/index.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">SSL Labs</a> . This website allows you to test a websites implementation of SSL. A grade of A to F is assigned with A being the best and F being the worst.</p> <p>Troy Hunt has a <a href="https://www.troyhunt.com/do-you-really-want-bank-grade-security/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">blog</a> post where he discusses how Australian Banks score. Lets look at a few UK banks.</p> <table> <thead> <tr> <th><strong>Bank</strong></th> <th><strong>SSL Certificate</strong></th> <th><strong>Grade</strong></th> <th><strong>Home Page Under SSL</strong></th> </tr> </thead> <tbody> <tr> <td>HSBC</td> <td><a href="https://www.hsbc.co.uk" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">www.hsbc.co.uk</a> </td> <td>B</td> <td>Y</td> </tr> <tr> <td>Nationwide</td> <td>onlinebanking.nationwide.co.uk</td> <td>C</td> <td>N</td> </tr> <tr> <td>NatWest</td> <td><a href="https://www.nwolb.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">www.nwolb.com</a> </td> <td>C</td> <td>N</td> </tr> <tr> <td>Barclaycard</td> <td><a href="https://www.barclaycard.co.uk" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">www.barclaycard.co.uk</a> </td> <td>A-</td> <td>Y</td> </tr> <tr> <td>Barclays</td> <td>bank.barclays.co.uk</td> <td>A-</td> <td>N</td> </tr> <tr> <td>Lloyds Bank</td> <td><a href="https://www.lloydsbank.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">www.lloydsbank.com</a> </td> <td>A</td> <td>N</td> </tr> <tr> <td>Royal Bank of Scotland</td> <td><a href="https://www.rbsdigital.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">www.rbsdigital.com</a> </td> <td>C</td> <td>N</td> </tr> <tr> <td>Standard Chartered</td> <td><a href="https://www.sc.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">www.sc.com</a> </td> <td>C</td> <td>Y</td> </tr> <tr> <td>Virgin Money</td> <td>uk.virginmoney.com</td> <td>A+</td> <td>Y</td> </tr> <tr> <td>Santander</td> <td>retail.santander.co.uk</td> <td>A-</td> <td>N</td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <p>On the whole the ratings are all quite good with all being in the range A-C. However I have also indicated if they have SSL on the home page. Only 4 out 10 website listed above have the home page load under SSL.</p> <p>Why does this matter as long as the login is under SSL? Any page that loads over http is potentially at risk from a man in the middle attack. A fake malicious home page could contain links to any page and trick users into entering personal information.</p> <p>If you want to test a bank or other website not listed here. Go to <a href="https://www.ssllabs.com/ssltest/index.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">https://www.ssllabs.com/ssltest/index.html</a> and type the address that is on the SSL certificate in to the search. The good news is that this site scores a A.</p> <p>Troy mentions that there is rapid growth in the adoption of SSL, there is also rapid growth in improving ratings. One of these banks went from a C to an A during the course of writing this blog.</p>
              - generic [ref=e5205]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e5207]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e5208]:
          - generic [ref=e5211]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e5212]:
            - generic [ref=e5213]:
              - generic [ref=e5214]: <title>
              - text: Writing your first test
              - generic [ref=e5215]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e5216]:
              - generic [ref=e5217]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/writing-your-first-test/
              - generic [ref=e5218]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e5219]:
              - generic [ref=e5220]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e5221]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e5222]:
              - generic [ref=e5223]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 10 Jul 2017 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e5224]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e5225]:
              - generic [ref=e5226]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/writing-your-first-test/
              - generic [ref=e5227]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e5228]:
              - generic [ref=e5229]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5230]: term="Act"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Act
              - generic [ref=e5231]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5232]:
              - generic [ref=e5233]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5234]: term="Arrange"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Arrange
              - generic [ref=e5235]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5236]:
              - generic [ref=e5237]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5238]: term="Assert"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Assert
              - generic [ref=e5239]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5240]:
              - generic [ref=e5241]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5242]: term="Testing"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Testing
              - generic [ref=e5243]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5244]:
              - generic [ref=e5245]: <description>
              - text: <p>Whenever I write a new test I have to think how best to do it. Hopefully I can summarise a few tips here to help get started.</p> <h3 id="arrange-act-assert">Arrange Act Assert<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#arrange-act-assert"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h3> <p>The first thing I think about when writing a test is Arrange, Act, Assert. Arrange, Act, Assert is a pattern for writing the tests.</p> <p><strong>Arrange</strong> ‚Äì This gets things in order ready to execute the test.</p> <p><strong>Act</strong> ‚Äì This executes the method you want to test.</p> <p><strong>Assert</strong> ‚Äì This compares the value produced in the Act step with a known value typically with a method similar to the following</p> <p>Assert.AreEqual(expected value, actual value)</p> <p>Say for example you wanted to test a method called ReturnsTrue() which does nothing but returns a value of true. This method is in a class called ReturnsTrueClass</p> <p>The Arrange step in this example would be.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" style="color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;"><code class="language-csharp" data-lang="csharp"><span style="display:flex;"><span>ReturnsTrueClass t = <span style="color:#66d9ef">new</span> ReturnsTrueClass(); </span></span></code></pre></div><p>The Act step in this example would be.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" style="color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;"><code class="language-csharp" data-lang="csharp"><span style="display:flex;"><span><span style="color:#66d9ef">var</span> result = t.ReturnTrue(); </span></span></code></pre></div><p>The Assert step in this example would be.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" style="color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;"><code class="language-csharp" data-lang="csharp"><span style="display:flex;"><span>Assert.AreEqual(<span style="color:#66d9ef">true</span>, result); </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This is a stupidly simple example but hopefully you get the idea of how you can build all your tests with these three steps.</p> <p>Recently I saw a tweet complaining that someone has mixed up expected and actual in the Assert statement.</p> <blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p lang="en" dir="ltr">There is a minor but special hell reserved for those who mix up the expected and actual parameters in Assert.Equals</p>&mdash; Keith Williams (@zogface) <a href="https://twitter.com/zogface/status/882737770095149056?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">July 5, 2017</a></blockquote> <script async src="https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script> <p>At first glance this probably isn‚Äôt the worst mistake to make as if your tests are all passing actual and expected are the same.</p> <p>However tests will fail, that is the whole point of them, you can then fix bits of code. If you have mixed up actual and expected it adds extra time to debugging and figuring out what values are produced from your code and what you are expecting it to produce. It may be your test uses a mocking framework and somewhere in there, there is an issue, with mixed up expected/actual you may assume a problem in your code rather than the test.</p> <p>Also, how do you make such an error? When I type Assert.AreEquals() in Visual Studio, Visual Studio tells me what each parameter does, it takes a matter of seconds to do this, just by hovering over the code.</p> <p>One last tip to say about tests. Write your tests to test the behaviour of your application.</p>
              - generic [ref=e5246]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e5248]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e5249]:
          - generic [ref=e5252]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e5253]:
            - generic [ref=e5254]:
              - generic [ref=e5255]: <title>
              - text: Uploading Files to AWS
              - generic [ref=e5256]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e5257]:
              - generic [ref=e5258]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/uploading-files-to-aws/
              - generic [ref=e5259]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e5260]:
              - generic [ref=e5261]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e5262]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e5263]:
              - generic [ref=e5264]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 03 Jul 2017 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e5265]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e5266]:
              - generic [ref=e5267]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/uploading-files-to-aws/
              - generic [ref=e5268]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e5269]:
              - generic [ref=e5270]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5271]: term="AWS"
                - text: ">"
              - text: AWS
              - generic [ref=e5272]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5273]:
              - generic [ref=e5274]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5275]: term="C-Sharp"
                - text: ">"
              - text: C-Sharp
              - generic [ref=e5276]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5277]:
              - generic [ref=e5278]: <description>
              - text: "<p>I am a fan of Azure but today I have been looking at AWS. Specifically how to upload and download files.</p> <p>AWS S3 stores files in Buckets. I already had an AWS S3 account setup with a Bucket. I am going to assume you have got a bucket setup and concentrate on the code to get files in and out.</p> <p>First step is to use nuget to install the AWS packages. In nuget the packages you want are called AWSSDK.Core and AWSSDK.S3.</p> <p>The using statements you want to use are called Amazon.S3 and Amazon.S3.Transfer, not sure why this doesn‚Äôt match nuget, this difference caught me out a couple of times.</p> <p>Now to the code that uploads files</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-c#\" data-lang=\"c#\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>AmazonS3Client AWSclient = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> AmazonS3Client(accessKeyID, secretAccessKeyID, Amazon.RegionEndpoint.EUWest1); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>TransferUtility fileTransferUtility = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> TransferUtility(AWSclient); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">using</span> (FileStream streamWriter = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> FileStream(path, FileMode.Open)) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>{ </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> TransferUtilityUploadRequest fileTransferUtilityRequest = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> TransferUtilityUploadRequest </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> BucketName = <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;flawlessimages&#34;</span>, </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> InputStream = streamWriter, </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> Key = fileName </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> }; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> fileTransferUtility.Upload(fileTransferUtilityRequest); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>} </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Lets break it down and look at what it does.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-c#\" data-lang=\"c#\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>AmazonS3Client AWSclient = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> AmazonS3Client(accessKeyID, secretAccessKeyID, Amazon.RegionEndpoint.EUWest1); </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This creates an instance of AmazonS3Client, we are passing the Access Key and Secret Access Key both of which can be found from your Amazon S3 account My Security Credentials section. Amazon.RegionEndpoint.EUWest1 specifies the amazon data centres that your bucket is located in.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-c#\" data-lang=\"c#\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>TransferUtility fileTransferUtility = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> TransferUtility(AWSclient); </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This creates an instance of TransfterUtility using the AmazonS3Client instance we created in the previous step.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-c#\" data-lang=\"c#\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">using</span> (FileStream streamWriter = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> FileStream(path, FileMode.Open)) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>{ </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This opens up a filestream from a files path and specifies that the file should be opened.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-c#\" data-lang=\"c#\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>TransferUtilityUploadRequest fileTransferUtilityRequest = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> TransferUtilityUploadRequest </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>{ </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> BucketName = <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;flawlessimages&#34;</span>, </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> InputStream = streamWriter, </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> Key = fileName </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>}; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>fileTransferUtility.Upload(fileTransferUtilityRequest); </span></span></code></pre></div><p>This last step specifies which bucket to upload to, what input stream to upload and the Key to use. Key is just AWS way of referring to files, more commonly referred to as the filename.</p> <p>This is all you need to do to upload a file to your Bucket. The file will be located at <a href=\"https://s3-eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/[bucketname]/[filename]\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">https://s3-eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/[bucketname]/[filename]</a> , however by default it will not be downloadable until you set Read permission to everyone, once you do that anyone who has the link will be able to download your file.</p> <p>This is the same permission level as any file you have on your webserver, however AWS has a better way.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-c#\" data-lang=\"c#\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">using</span> (s3Client = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> AmazonS3Client(accessKeyID, secretAccessKeyID, Amazon.RegionEndpoint.USEast1)) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>{ </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> GetPreSignedUrlRequest request1 = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> GetPreSignedUrlRequest </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> BucketName = bucketName, </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> Key = filename, </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> Expires = DateTime.Now.AddMinutes(<span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">5</span>) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> }; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> urlString = s3Client.GetPreSignedURL(request1); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>} </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Here we are generating a url to download the file, but we are specifying that it is only valid for 5 minutes. This means that if you share the url it will only work for 5 minutes, after that AWS will give an access denied message.</p> <p>This is much better security than you have on a typical web server, and easy to implement, every time a user clicks on a download link you generate a new presigned url and send the download to the browser, as long as this process doesn‚Äôt take longer than 5 minutes the user will never know.</p>"
              - generic [ref=e5279]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e5281]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e5282]:
          - generic [ref=e5285]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e5286]:
            - generic [ref=e5287]:
              - generic [ref=e5288]: <title>
              - text: Using Azure WebJobs to Automate Stuff
              - generic [ref=e5289]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e5290]:
              - generic [ref=e5291]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/using-azure-webjobs-to-automate-stuff/
              - generic [ref=e5292]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e5293]:
              - generic [ref=e5294]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e5295]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e5296]:
              - generic [ref=e5297]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 26 Jun 2017 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e5298]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e5299]:
              - generic [ref=e5300]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/using-azure-webjobs-to-automate-stuff/
              - generic [ref=e5301]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e5302]:
              - generic [ref=e5303]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5304]: term="Automate"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Automate
              - generic [ref=e5305]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5306]:
              - generic [ref=e5307]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5308]: term="Azure"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Azure
              - generic [ref=e5309]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5310]:
              - generic [ref=e5311]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5312]: term="Cron"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Cron
              - generic [ref=e5313]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5314]:
              - generic [ref=e5315]: <description>
              - text: "<p>I keep hearing about Azure WebJobs but I have never used them. Time to change this.</p> <p>WebJobs are a feature of Azure App Service that can run a script at a specific time. In my case I would like to hit a specific url of my website at the same time every day.</p> <p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"WebJobs\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2017/addkeepalivewebjob.png\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"313\" height=\"615\" /> To the right you can see an example of the WebJobs form on the Azure portal that you need to fill in.</p> <p>You need to supply a name for your webjob.</p> <p>You need to upload the script that will run in my case I used a powershell script. My script consisted of which basically just loads the url specified.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-powershell\" data-lang=\"powershell\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>$progressPreference = <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;silentlyContinue&#34;</span>; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>$result = Invoke-WebRequest -Uri (<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;https://www.google.com&#34;</span>) -Method Get -UseBasicParsing; </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Type refers to if your job will be triggered or run continuously, I want it to be triggered.</p> <p>Triggers refers to if you want it to be scheduled or manual, something that you can run on an ad hoc basis. I of course want scheduled.</p> <p>If you are familiar with the linux CRON then the next box will make sense to you for everyone else I will try and make sense of it. The box consists of 6 numbers which can either have a value or a *. The numbers correspond to the following {second} {minute} {hour} {day} {month} {day of the week}.</p> <p>A hourly job would be expressed as 0 0 * * * *, ie every day of week, every month, every day, every hour and only when minute and second equals zero. For more help with this check out the <a href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/app-service-web/web-sites-create-web-jobs#CreateScheduledCRON\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">MSDN docs</a> about it. I want to use 0 30 21 * * * to run daily at 9.30pm.</p> <p>That‚Äôs it everything setup, now time to wait and see if it works.</p> <p><strong>Oh no!</strong></p> <p>It failed to run at the specified time.</p> <p>The reason for this is the scheduler requires the feature Always On to be turned on which is not available in the free App Service. Before you reach for your wallets, I found a solution on this <a href=\"https://tomssl.com/2016/12/20/how-to-get-azure-webjobs-to-run-indefinitely-for-free/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">blog post</a> that allows them to run on the free tier.</p> <p>The thinking behind this solution is you need to keep the website alive throughout the day so Tom has created a script that does this. His script can be found on his blog or on his <a href=\"https://github.com/TomChantler/Self-KeepAlive\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">github page</a> .</p> <p>Set this script up to run every 5 minutes (0 */5 * * * *) like the example above.</p> <p>The nextthing you need to do is create a Custom connection string in the Application Settings blade called SecretThing. Tom‚Äôs script references this to access the website and keep it alive. The password you need to put in SecretThing can be found in you publish profile (downloaded from the Overview blade in the Azure portal). For more details and a better explanation check out <a href=\"https://tomssl.com/2016/12/20/how-to-get-azure-webjobs-to-run-indefinitely-for-free/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Tom‚Äôs blog</a> .</p> <p>One last thing to mention about WebJobs is that you can see details about when they have run at https://[YourWebAppName].scm.azurewebsites.net/azurejobs/#/jobs and this can be a great place to help debug your scripts.</p>"
              - generic [ref=e5316]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e5318]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e5319]:
          - generic [ref=e5322]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e5323]:
            - generic [ref=e5324]:
              - generic [ref=e5325]: <title>
              - text: Fiddler and APIs
              - generic [ref=e5326]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e5327]:
              - generic [ref=e5328]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/fiddler-and-apis/
              - generic [ref=e5329]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e5330]:
              - generic [ref=e5331]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e5332]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e5333]:
              - generic [ref=e5334]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 19 Jun 2017 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e5335]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e5336]:
              - generic [ref=e5337]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/fiddler-and-apis/
              - generic [ref=e5338]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e5340]:
              - text: <category
              - generic [ref=e5341]:
                - text: term="
                - text: "\""
              - text: />
            - generic [ref=e5343]:
              - text: <category
              - generic [ref=e5344]:
                - text: term="
                - text: "\""
              - text: />
            - generic [ref=e5345]:
              - generic [ref=e5346]: <description>
              - text: <p>A while ago I blogged about <a href="https://www.funkysi1701.com/2017/04/17/automation-promotion/">promoting</a> my blog with Buffer. At the time I made use of the nuget package <a href="https://www.nuget.org/packages/BufferAPI/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">BufferAPI</a> but lets look at some improvements I can make.</p> <p>The BufferAPI package worked great from my console app, but when I tried to use it from a Controller in an MVC app I never got it to work. Lets look at the API docs and see if I can rewrite it.</p> <p>There are two main types of API calls GET which gets data from the server and POST which posts data to the server. These come from the types of HTTP requests.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="Alt Text" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2017/6wozrfdoqvtjaoxs7j1v.jpg" loading="lazy" width="638" height="359" /> </p> <p>I quickly figured out how to use the GET API call to authenticate using <a href="https://api.bufferapp.com/1/profiles.json?access_token=XXXX" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">https://api.bufferapp.com/1/profiles.json?access_token=XXXX</a> </p> <p>However POST was defeating me. That was until I remembered <a href="http://www.telerik.com/fiddler" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Fiddler</a> .</p> <p>I had heard Troy Hunt (and others) talk of using Fiddler to examine what data is being passed among websites. Troy uses it to do a man in the middle test to see what information can be stolen.</p> <p>It is really easy to setup, install Fiddler, click yes to a few security warnings and you can see what information is being passed from your code to remote APIs.</p> <p>Once I had Fiddler installed I could compare what information is being passed between a successful API call using the BufferAPI nuget package and an unsuccessful API call using my code.</p> <p>Fiddler also showed that passing my authentication token in a POST request is much better. Despite both GET and POST being encrypted when using HTTPS, anything at either end that logs URLs will have a log of your username and password.</p> <p>If you have not tried Fiddler, give it a try especially if you are doing things with API calls.</p>
              - generic [ref=e5347]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e5349]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e5350]:
          - generic [ref=e5353]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e5354]:
            - generic [ref=e5355]:
              - generic [ref=e5356]: <title>
              - text: How do I add Power BI data to a webpage?
              - generic [ref=e5357]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e5358]:
              - generic [ref=e5359]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/how-do-i-add-power-bi-data-to-a-webpage/
              - generic [ref=e5360]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e5361]:
              - generic [ref=e5362]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e5363]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e5364]:
              - generic [ref=e5365]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 12 Jun 2017 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e5366]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e5367]:
              - generic [ref=e5368]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/how-do-i-add-power-bi-data-to-a-webpage/
              - generic [ref=e5369]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e5370]:
              - generic [ref=e5371]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5372]: term="PowerBI"
                - text: ">"
              - text: PowerBI
              - generic [ref=e5373]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5375]:
              - text: <category
              - generic [ref=e5376]:
                - text: term="
                - text: "\""
              - text: />
            - generic [ref=e5377]:
              - generic [ref=e5378]: <description>
              - text: <p>Last week I talked about <a href="https://www.funkysi1701.com/2017/06/05/businessintelligence/">Power BI</a> , what it is and some of the different services you can use with it. This week lets add some of that data to a simple web page.</p> <p>For this example I am going to add the google analytics data from this website to this page.</p> <p>First login to your Power BI <a href="https://app.powerbi.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">https://app.powerbi.com/</a> </p> <p>Click the get data link at the bottom left.</p> <p>Click My Organisation to bring up the app search box.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="Alt Text" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2017/46c1lyxy053xcq66fowf.jpg" loading="lazy" width="768" height="406" /> </p> <p>Click the Apps tab and search for ‚Äúgoogle‚Äù in the search box, you should then see Google Analytics, click into this and then click the get it now button.</p> <p>Log into your google account. If you have multiple google accounts I found it worked best to sign out of all of them or run this in an incognito window.</p> <p>Once you are signed in you should see a list of the different google analytics data you have, select the one you want to use and click import.</p> <p>Power BI will then go away and start loading the data.</p> <p>Once loaded go to Reports and select the Google Analytics that has been loaded. If you have more than one, it is a good idea to rename each one eg Corporate Site Google Analytics, Blog Google Analytics so you won‚Äôt get mixed up.</p> <p>In the file menu select Publish to web and agree that you are OK for this to be made public.</p> <p>You will then be given a piece of HTML code that starts with &lt;iframe copy this onto your web page. Reload your webpage and you should see something similar to mine below.</p> <p>It should be noted that while you can but the webpage containing the iframe behind a login page, the data could still be accessed if you knew the url contained within the iframe, this is why the link can be emailed and continue to work.</p>
              - generic [ref=e5379]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e5381]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e5382]:
          - generic [ref=e5385]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e5386]:
            - generic [ref=e5387]:
              - generic [ref=e5388]: <title>
              - text: What the heck is Business Intelligence?
              - generic [ref=e5389]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e5390]:
              - generic [ref=e5391]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/businessintelligence/
              - generic [ref=e5392]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e5393]:
              - generic [ref=e5394]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e5395]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e5396]:
              - generic [ref=e5397]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 05 Jun 2017 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e5398]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e5399]:
              - generic [ref=e5400]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/businessintelligence/
              - generic [ref=e5401]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e5402]:
              - generic [ref=e5403]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5404]: term="ApplicationInsights"
                - text: ">"
              - text: ApplicationInsights
              - generic [ref=e5405]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5406]:
              - generic [ref=e5407]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5408]: term="BusinessIntelligence"
                - text: ">"
              - text: BusinessIntelligence
              - generic [ref=e5409]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5410]:
              - generic [ref=e5411]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5412]: term="SQL"
                - text: ">"
              - text: SQL
              - generic [ref=e5413]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5414]:
              - generic [ref=e5415]: <description>
              - text: "<p>The term <strong>Business Intelligence (BI)</strong> refers to technologies, applications and practices for the collection, integration, analysis, and presentation of business information. The purpose of Business Intelligence is to support better business decision making. Essentially, Business Intelligence systems are data-driven Decision Support Systems (DSS). Business Intelligence is sometimes used interchangeably with briefing books, report and query tools and executive information systems.</p> <h3 id=\"what-is-power-bi\">What is Power BI?<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#what-is-power-bi\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p><strong>Power BI</strong> is a business analytics service provided by Microsoft. It provides interactive visualisations with self-service business intelligence capabilities, where end users can create reports and dashboards by themselves, without having to depend on any information technology staff or database administrator.</p> <p>Microsoft describe it as follows: <strong>Power BI</strong> is a suite of business analytics tools that deliver insights throughout your organisation. Connect to hundreds of data sources, simplify data prep, and drive ad hoc analysis. Produce beautiful reports, then publish them for your organisation to consume on the web and across mobile devices. Everyone can create personalised dashboards with a unique, 360-degree view of their business. And scale across the enterprise, with governance and security built-in.</p> <h3 id=\"what-can-you-do-with-it\">What can you do with it?<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#what-can-you-do-with-it\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>One of the first thing you can do with Power Bi is connect some of the apps that you use.</p> <p>To sign up to use Power BI go to <a href=\"https://powerbi.microsoft.com/en-us/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">https://powerbi.microsoft.com/en-us/</a> </p> <p>Once you are signed in click the get data link in the bottom left corner and browse through the apps you can use.</p> <p>If your website uses google analytics you can connect it up to Power BI and see some cool analytics. The below map was generated from some google analytics data, you can see that this website has had users across the globe, with UK and USA getting a lot of hits. <img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"Business Intelligence from Google Analytics\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2017/Capture.jpg\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"1189\" height=\"627\" /> </p> <p>Another thing you can do is connect Azure Application Insights. This provides some similar data to google analytics about who is visiting your site.</p> <p>If your code is hosted in Visual Studio Team Services you can get some cool analytics from your commit history. <img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"Business Intelligence from VSTS\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2017/Capture-1.jpg\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"1299\" height=\"348\" /> </p> <p>There is a huge long list of apps you can connect to power BI so you can start getting all sorts of analysis very easily. I am hopefully going to talk another time about getting custom data into Power BI.</p>"
              - generic [ref=e5416]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e5418]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e5419]:
          - generic [ref=e5422]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e5423]:
            - generic [ref=e5424]:
              - generic [ref=e5425]: <title>
              - text: Have I Been Pwned?
              - generic [ref=e5426]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e5427]:
              - generic [ref=e5428]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/have-i-been-pwned/
              - generic [ref=e5429]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e5430]:
              - generic [ref=e5431]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e5432]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e5433]:
              - generic [ref=e5434]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 29 May 2017 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e5435]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e5436]:
              - generic [ref=e5437]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/have-i-been-pwned/
              - generic [ref=e5438]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e5439]:
              - generic [ref=e5440]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5441]: term="Pwned"

              - text: Pwned
              - generic [ref=e5442]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5443]:
              - generic [ref=e5444]:
                - text: <category
