          - generic [ref=e5574]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e5575]:
            - generic [ref=e5576]:
              - generic [ref=e5577]: <title>
              - text: Office Move
              - generic [ref=e5578]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e5579]:
              - generic [ref=e5580]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/office-move/
              - generic [ref=e5581]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e5582]:
              - generic [ref=e5583]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e5584]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e5585]:
              - generic [ref=e5586]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 01 May 2017 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e5587]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e5588]:
              - generic [ref=e5589]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/office-move/
              - generic [ref=e5590]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e5591]:
              - generic [ref=e5592]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5593]: term="ITAdmin"
                - text: ">"
              - text: ITAdmin
              - generic [ref=e5594]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5595]:
              - generic [ref=e5596]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5597]: term="Routers"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Routers
              - generic [ref=e5598]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5599]:
              - generic [ref=e5600]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5601]: term="Servers"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Servers
              - generic [ref=e5602]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5603]:
              - generic [ref=e5604]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5605]: term="OfficeMove"
                - text: ">"
              - text: OfficeMove
              - generic [ref=e5606]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5607]:
              - generic [ref=e5608]: <description>
              - text: "<p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"New Rack\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2017/20170422_191127-e1493403982560-169x300.jpg\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"169\" height=\"300\" /> For the past few weeks my software developing has been taking a back seat as I planned and coordinated the IT requirements of an office move.</p> <p>The company I work for has been working out of a converted barn, but as the company has grown we have outgrown the building and for quite a while it has been a real squeeze to get everyone in. We now have a shiny new offices with plenty of room for growth.</p> <p>It was at the start of the year when I first started getting involved with the new office. At that time building work was about to begin. The office had concrete floors so in order to get network and power points in the floor, channels would have to be cut into the concrete for the floor boxes and cable runs.</p> <p>At the old office our servers were in a cabinet in the corner of the room which meant they could be quite loud especially when the fans were going full pelt. Our American owners were supplying brand new IT equipment and we would have a dedicated server room.</p> <p>Soon a weekly conference call was setup so we could coordinate with the IT people in America and the various different contractors that would help deliver our new office.</p> <p>One thing I was particularly proud of was YDS. York Data Services (YDS) is an ISP I have worked with in the past at a previous job and I was able to continue my relationship with them and they were contacted and became our primary internet supplier.</p> <p>Unfortunately most ISPs have to deal with BTOpenreach who have a bit of a monopoly on getting phone lines or leased lines installed. The initial estimate we were given was two weeks after we were due to move in. It was looking like we would move in and two weeks later we would get an internet connection. We were in the process of getting quotes for a temporary internet connection when BT contacted us and could get us connected up. <img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"New Office\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2017/18121045_1302238519862436_8711390769620542649_o.jpg\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"2048\" height=\"1536\" /> </p> <p>Soon afterwards a huge cabinet and two pallets full of equipment was delivered. Two days later a team was dispatched to rack everything up. On the rack we had the following equipment: 4 x UPS, 4 x Network Switches, 2 x Routers (for 2 x Leased Lines from different providers, the secondary connection has not been installed yet), 2 x Palo Alto Firewall devices, 2 x New Servers.</p> <p>Just prior to our move we had a rack full of equipment but no patch cables, nothing connected up and I was beginning to get concerned that we would not be ready in time.</p> <p>Thankfully a team was dispatched to help out over the weekend of the move, with the patch cables being delivered only hours beforehand. I worked closely with them and we worked late into the night. By the end of the Friday night our domain controller had been moved and its IP address updated. DHCP scopes had been setup for the new network. Once that was done we could get the WiFi points connected up (These had already been fitted to the ceiling).</p> <p>The following day we moved our existing servers and updated their IP addresses and got everything patched up. Furniture started arriving so desks could start being setup and phones connected up. Everything was slotting into place, and for the first time our new office was starting to look like an office.</p> <p>By the time it got to Monday the only problem was the phone number had not transferred as requested (something else to blame on BT) All staff could either connect via an Ethernet cable or connect to our brand new WiFi network and had access to all the IT services they had at the old office. Another minor issue was the NAS we used for backups had to be reset as it couldn‚Äôt communicate with the domain so no one could login, luckily this didn‚Äôt affect the data on it.</p> <p>From my perspective the move was a massive success considering how complex and how many different people had been involved.</p>"
              - generic [ref=e5609]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e5611]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e5612]:
          - generic [ref=e5615]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e5616]:
            - generic [ref=e5617]:
              - generic [ref=e5618]: <title>
              - text: GitHub history
              - generic [ref=e5619]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e5620]:
              - generic [ref=e5621]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/github-history/
              - generic [ref=e5622]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e5623]:
              - generic [ref=e5624]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e5625]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e5626]:
              - generic [ref=e5627]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 24 Apr 2017 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e5628]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e5629]:
              - generic [ref=e5630]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/github-history/
              - generic [ref=e5631]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e5632]:
              - generic [ref=e5633]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5634]: term="Git"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Git
              - generic [ref=e5635]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5636]:
              - generic [ref=e5637]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5638]: term="Github"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Github
              - generic [ref=e5639]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5640]:
              - generic [ref=e5641]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5642]: term="Code"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Code
              - generic [ref=e5643]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5644]:
              - generic [ref=e5645]: <description>
              - text: <p>I created my GitHub account in August 2010, lets look at what I have done with it.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2017/git10.jpg" loading="lazy" width="1471" height="331" /> </p> <p>In 2010 I started by committing the code for an old php website I had created. Then in December I committed some other php sites.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2017/git11.jpg" loading="lazy" width="1484" height="331" /> </p> <p>Between 12 December 2010 and 29 September 2011 I must have created some automated process which is why there is a commit every day. Looking at the diff it appears to be related to tracking visitors to a site. I assume back then I hadn‚Äôt heard of the .gitignore file!</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2017/git14.jpg" loading="lazy" width="1479" height="336" /> </p> <p>Nothing for a few years until 2014, when I started compiling a code samples collection, this is bits of code that I want to show off, I have added to this since 2015 so I really should go back to this as my skills have developed a bit since then.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2017/git15.jpg" loading="lazy" width="1471" height="331" /> </p> <p>In 2015 I really started to think of myself as a developer, I added repositories for Raspberry Pi, and a few C# ideas I had. I ended the year taking part in Advent of Code</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2017/git16.jpg" loading="lazy" width="1470" height="332" /> </p> <p>What did I do last year? Well I started going to York Code Dojo and this meant lots of forks from their code examples and also my first pull request. I also did a fair bit of looking at other repositories trying to find a good open source project to contribute to, still not found one for me yet. Lastly I ended 2016 with a bit of Advent of Code.</p> <p>Not sure how enthralling a blog post this is, but fascinating to see the different commit histories.</p>
              - generic [ref=e5646]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e5648]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e5649]:
          - generic [ref=e5652]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e5653]:
            - generic [ref=e5654]:
              - generic [ref=e5655]: <title>
              - text: Automation of the Promotion of my Blog
              - generic [ref=e5656]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e5657]:
              - generic [ref=e5658]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/automation-promotion/
              - generic [ref=e5659]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e5660]:
              - generic [ref=e5661]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e5662]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e5663]:
              - generic [ref=e5664]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 17 Apr 2017 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e5665]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e5666]:
              - generic [ref=e5667]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/automation-promotion/
              - generic [ref=e5668]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e5669]:
              - generic [ref=e5670]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5671]: term="Buffer"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Buffer
              - generic [ref=e5672]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5673]:
              - generic [ref=e5674]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5675]: term="Blogging"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Blogging
              - generic [ref=e5676]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5677]:
              - generic [ref=e5678]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5679]: term="XML"
                - text: ">"
              - text: XML
              - generic [ref=e5680]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5681]:
              - generic [ref=e5682]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5683]: term="RSS"
                - text: ">"
              - text: RSS
              - generic [ref=e5684]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5685]:
              - generic [ref=e5686]: <description>
              - text: <p>I would like to automate the promotion of this blog. Currently to promote this blog on social media I use a few different services. <img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2017/img-buffer-illustration-hub-960@2x.png" loading="lazy" width="1780" height="794" /> </p> <p>Buffer (<a href="https://buffer.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">buffer.com</a> ) is a service that allows you to schedule updates to the main social media channels (Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn and Google+)</p> <p>IFTTT or If This Then That (<a href="https://ifttt.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">ifttt.com</a> ) is a service that allows you to connect different online services. You can send an email when a specific event occurs in your calendar for example.</p> <p>I have been using a combination of these services to share to social media some of my past blog posts. I then add to my calendar details of my blog posts. Then I use IFTTT to add the event to Buffer, and then buffer tweets on a schedule.</p> <p>This works great however it is a manual process to add my posts to my calendar. I have been using a spreadsheet to help me generate an ics calendar file which I import into my google calendar. There must be a better way of doing this.</p> <p>I have written some code that reads the RSS feed of my blog and then shares that to Buffer using the Buffer API. The code I am creating is far from finished however I am trying to use the concepts of clean code to make it as flexible as possible.</p> <p>I have an interface called ISocial which my buffer code implements, but it would be easy to add a class that implements the same interface but uses the twitter or facebook APIs. My code reads from a specific WordPress RSS feed, but it should be easy enough to adapt to read from a SQL database or any other data source.</p> <p>I am currently unsure what kind of interface to use for this application. I could create a web page that controls the functionality, or maybe just a windows application, or maybe both of these are complicating things and all I need is just a console application that could be added as a scheduled task.</p>
              - generic [ref=e5687]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e5689]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e5690]:
          - generic [ref=e5693]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e5694]:
            - generic [ref=e5695]:
              - generic [ref=e5696]: <title>
              - text: Blame
              - generic [ref=e5697]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e5698]:
              - generic [ref=e5699]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/blame/
              - generic [ref=e5700]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e5701]:
              - generic [ref=e5702]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e5703]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e5704]:
              - generic [ref=e5705]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 10 Apr 2017 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e5706]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e5707]:
              - generic [ref=e5708]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/blame/
              - generic [ref=e5709]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e5710]:
              - generic [ref=e5711]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5712]: term="Blame"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Blame
              - generic [ref=e5713]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5714]:
              - generic [ref=e5715]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5716]: term="Culture"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Culture
              - generic [ref=e5717]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5718]:
              - generic [ref=e5719]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5720]: term="DevOps"
                - text: ">"
              - text: DevOps
              - generic [ref=e5721]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5722]:
              - generic [ref=e5723]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5724]: term="SoftSkills"
                - text: ">"
              - text: SoftSkills
              - generic [ref=e5725]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5726]:
              - generic [ref=e5727]: <description>
              - text: <p>I recently came home from a busy day of work to my wife blaming me for allowing our 18 month old son to reach some paint and get it all over the carpet. She was concentrating on the fact that he could reach the paint not on the fact that she had brilliantly got the paint out of the carpet.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2017/blame-shifting.jpg" loading="lazy" width="347" height="346" /> </p> <p>My instinct on being blamed is to deny it, or start throwing blame back at her. It is possible I put the paint in his reach, it is also possible it was someone else.</p> <p>It is very easy to blame someone else. For example, looking through the git history to find out who changed a specific file is only a few clicks.</p> <p>But is it ever productive to blame someone? Is it not better to focus our energy on fixing the issue at hand?</p> <p>In the world of business it is easy to go from blaming other people until you have a blame culture. When you have a blame culture everyone starts looking out for themselves so it‚Äôs not them that gets the blame and productivity will suffer.</p> <p>I think it is more important to put in place processes to minimise issues happening again. If a deployment causes downtime, don‚Äôt ask who‚Äôs fault is it and sack them. Instead what can we do to reduce the chance of it happening again?</p> <p>As someone who has an interest in DevOps, I often break things and don‚Äôt want to get blamed for that, I do want to improve my processes so I am not always breaking the same things.</p> <p>What do you think about Blame? Is what can we do differently always better than who did this?</p>
              - generic [ref=e5728]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e5730]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e5731]:
          - generic [ref=e5734]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e5735]:
            - generic [ref=e5736]:
              - generic [ref=e5737]: <title>
              - text: Interfaces
              - generic [ref=e5738]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e5739]:
              - generic [ref=e5740]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/interfaces/
              - generic [ref=e5741]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e5742]:
              - generic [ref=e5743]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e5744]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e5745]:
              - generic [ref=e5746]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 27 Mar 2017 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e5747]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e5748]:
              - generic [ref=e5749]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/interfaces/
              - generic [ref=e5750]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e5751]:
              - generic [ref=e5752]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5753]: term="C-Sharp"
                - text: ">"
              - text: C-Sharp
              - generic [ref=e5754]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5755]:
              - generic [ref=e5756]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5757]: term="Interface"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Interface
              - generic [ref=e5758]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5759]:
              - generic [ref=e5760]: <description>
              - text: "<p>I am trying to understand interfaces and when to use them in my code.</p> <p>An interface defines a contract and any class that implements that interface agrees to fulfil that contract.</p> <p>Lets look at an example as this tends to be how I learn best.</p> <p>Most applications require some sort of data to work from so lets start by defining IData which can load data.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">public</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">interface</span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">IData</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>{ </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> Blog LoadData(<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span> Connectionstring); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>} </span></span></code></pre></div><p>My interface defines one method LoadData and outputs an object called Blog (I will explain why in a minute)</p> <p>A common data source is a SQL database so we could define a SQL class that implements IData.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">public</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">class</span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">SQL</span> : IData </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>{ </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">public</span> Blog LoadData(<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span> Connectionstring) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> Blog blog = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> Blog(); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">using</span> (SqlConnection con = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> SqlConnection(Connectionstring)) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> con.Open(); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#75715e\">//etc</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>We could also get data from an RSS feed of a blog (hence why I called the object Blog earlier)</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">public</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">class</span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">XML</span> : IData </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>{ </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">public</span> Blog LoadData(<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span> Connectionstring) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> XmlDocument myXmlDocument = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> XmlDocument(); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> myXmlDocument.Load(Connectionstring); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> Blog blog = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> Blog(); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">foreach</span> (XmlNode RootNode <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">in</span> myXmlDocument.ChildNodes) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#75715e\">//etc</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Both classes implement IData and have a method called LoadData which has a string parameter and outputs a blog object. The string parameter is either a connection string to a SQL database or the URL of the rss feed. Not sure if there is a better way of doing this bit, maybe the name of the string needs making more generic.</p> <p>Now we have some classes that implement an interface what can we do with them. Lets write a class called GetData which gets data but doesn‚Äôt care if it comes form the rss feed or a SQL database.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">public</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">class</span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">GetData</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>{ </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">private</span> IData _repo; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">public</span> GetData(IData repo) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> _repo = repo; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">public</span> Blog LoadData(<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">string</span> Connectionstring) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> original = _repo.LoadData(Connectionstring); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">return</span> original; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>} </span></span></code></pre></div><p>When we call GetData we can either pass in XML or SQL as the class is not tied to either implementation. We could even write other classes that implement IData for testing purposes.</p> <p>My full code can be found on <a href=\"https://github.com/funkysi1701/InterfaceExample\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">github</a> .</p> <p>The advantages of writing code in this way include code that is easier to extend, easier to test and easier to maintain. This is only the start of my understanding and I am sure this is going to be a topic I come back to in the next few weeks.</p>"
              - generic [ref=e5761]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e5763]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e5764]:
          - generic [ref=e5767]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e5768]:
            - generic [ref=e5769]:
              - generic [ref=e5770]: <title>
              - text: SOLID and other programming terms
              - generic [ref=e5771]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e5772]:
              - generic [ref=e5773]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/solid-programming-terms/
              - generic [ref=e5774]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e5775]:
              - generic [ref=e5776]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e5777]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e5778]:
              - generic [ref=e5779]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 20 Mar 2017 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e5780]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e5781]:
              - generic [ref=e5782]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/solid-programming-terms/
              - generic [ref=e5783]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e5784]:
              - generic [ref=e5785]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5786]: term="DesignPatterns"
                - text: ">"
              - text: DesignPatterns
              - generic [ref=e5787]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5788]:
              - generic [ref=e5789]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5790]: term="DRY"
                - text: ">"
              - text: DRY
              - generic [ref=e5791]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5792]:
              - generic [ref=e5793]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5794]: term="MVC"
                - text: ">"
              - text: MVC
              - generic [ref=e5795]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5796]:
              - generic [ref=e5797]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5798]: term="SOLID"
                - text: ">"
              - text: SOLID
              - generic [ref=e5799]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5800]:
              - generic [ref=e5801]: <description>
              - text: <p>This week I have been looking at improving my understanding of a few programming terms, like SOLID and I will try and define them so I can look back here when I get confused.</p> <h3 id="mvc">MVC<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#mvc"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h3> <p>I have previously blogged about <a href="https://www.funkysi1701.com/2016/03/17/model-view-controller-mvc/">MVC</a> , but my understanding was not 100% correct so I will refine this here.</p> <p><strong>Model</strong> ‚Äì Now this is where my understanding was not quite correct. I thought the model was the actual source data, eg an XML file, SQL database etc. The model is the business logic so this is a processed version of the source data. MVC does not care where data is stored it can be flat files, SQL, XML or anything really.</p> <p><strong>View</strong> ‚Äì This displays data to the user and typically is the HTML/CSS markup. Only display related logic would get included in the view.</p> <p><strong>Controller</strong> ‚Äì This is another place I had got a bit confused. I had thought all the logic lived here. This is incorrect controllers are only concerned with getting data between Model and View.</p> <h3 id="solid">SOLID<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#solid"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h3> <p>SOLID are five principles of object oriented programming and design.</p> <p><strong>S</strong> is for Single Responsibility Principle. A class or piece of code should be responsible for doing one thing.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2017/SingleResponsibilityPrinciple2_71060858.jpg" loading="lazy" width="750" height="600" /> </p> <p><strong>O</strong> is for Open/Closed Principle. Code should be open for extensions but closed for modifications. Often this refers to the way you can implement an interface and add extra functionality.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2017/ocp.jpg" loading="lazy" width="640" height="513" /> </p> <p><strong>L</strong> is for Liskov Substitution Principle. Objects in a program can be replaced with subtypes of that object with out changing functionality.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2017/LiskovSubtitutionPrinciple_52BB5162.jpg" loading="lazy" width="750" height="600" /> </p> <p><strong>I</strong> is for Interface Segregation Principle. Large interfaces should be split down into small interfaces so that clients only know about methods that are of interest.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2017/isp.jpg" loading="lazy" width="640" height="513" /> </p> <p><strong>D</strong> is for Dependency Inversion Principle. High and Low level modules should depend on abstractions.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2017/dip.jpg" loading="lazy" width="640" height="513" /> </p> <p>I need to look into SOLID some more but here are some <a href="https://www.codeproject.com/Articles/703634/SOLID-architecture-principles-using-simple-Csharp" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">examples</a> .</p> <h3 id="dry">DRY<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#dry"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h3> <p>DRY is simply Don‚Äôt Repeat Yourself. It is often easy to spot when a function call will help you not have to use the same bit of code in different places. I am often spotting places where I can put this into action.</p>
              - generic [ref=e5802]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e5804]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e5805]:
          - generic [ref=e5808]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e5809]:
            - generic [ref=e5810]:
              - generic [ref=e5811]: <title>
              - text: Test Driven Development or TDD
              - generic [ref=e5812]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e5813]:
              - generic [ref=e5814]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/test-driven-development-tdd/
              - generic [ref=e5815]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e5816]:
              - generic [ref=e5817]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e5818]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e5819]:
              - generic [ref=e5820]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 13 Mar 2017 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e5821]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e5822]:
              - generic [ref=e5823]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/test-driven-development-tdd/
              - generic [ref=e5824]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e5825]:
              - generic [ref=e5826]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5827]: term="TestDrivenDevelopment"
                - text: ">"
              - text: TestDrivenDevelopment
              - generic [ref=e5828]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5829]:
              - generic [ref=e5830]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5831]: term="Testing"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Testing
              - generic [ref=e5832]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5833]:
              - generic [ref=e5834]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5835]: term="VisualStudio"
                - text: ">"
              - text: VisualStudio
              - generic [ref=e5836]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5837]:
              - generic [ref=e5838]: <description>
              - text: <p>A few weeks back I attended a talk at <a href="http://www.agileyorkshire.org/event-announcements/tuesfebruary21st-drolivershawtestdrivendevelopmentthemostmisusedterminsoftwaredevelopmentandkeithwilliamsdependenciesinjectionandabstractionforfunandprofit" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Agile Yorkshire</a> about Test Driven Development or TDD by Dr Oliver Shaw. I was impressed at how easy Oliver made it look, so as I have never tried it I thought I should give it a try.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2017/tdd_flow.gif" loading="lazy" width="489" height="511" /> </p> <p>Test Driven Development or TDD is a way of development which starts with writing a Unit Test. First you write a failing test, then you write the code to make it pass, then you refactor your code. This can be remembered by thinking of <strong>Red, Green, Refactor</strong>. Red being the failing test, Green being getting the test to pass, and Refactor being the refactoring.</p> <p>During the demonstration Oliver used a language called scala and a system that automatically reran all the tests after every change. I code with Visual Studio in C# is there a way I can get my tests to run automatically as well?</p> <p>A bit of googling and configuring I can answer this as Yes.</p> <p>The nuget package called <a href="https://github.com/codereflection/Giles" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Giles</a> is a watcher which will rerun your tests similar to how Oliver did it with his scalar environment. Fans of Buffy the Vampire Slayer will get the joke of why a watcher is called Giles. I couldn‚Äôt get this to work with MSTest but works fine with NUnit. There is a powershell script giles.ps1 which you need to run and will update every so often with how many tests have passed or failed. However you may not see this if you are coding in Visual Studio but there is a way to get a notification.</p> <p>If you install the application Growl you can get notifications from Giles which pop up and then disappear. So whatever you have on screen you can find out almost instantly if you have broken tests.</p> <p>Another thing that I wanted to configure is a way of viewing code coverage and which methods are tested and which aren‚Äôt. If you are familiar with VSTS after a build it gives you a percentage score for test coverage. I don‚Äôt find this overly useful as it doesn‚Äôt tell you what is covered and what isn‚Äôt. Also what if you want to use Github, how do you calculate the code coverage then?</p> <p>The nuget packages <a href="https://www.nuget.org/packages/OpenCover/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">OpenCover</a> and <a href="https://www.nuget.org/packages/ReportGenerator/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">ReportGenerator</a> allow a html report of code coverage to be produced. I created a batch script that can be run whenever you require this information.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>[path]\OpenCover.Console.exe -target:&#34;[path]\nunit3-console.exe&#34; -targetargs:&#34;[path]\Test.dll&#34; -output:&#34;[path]\coverage.xml&#34; -register:user [path]\ReportGenerator.exe &#34;-reports:[path]\coverage.xml&#34; &#34;-targetdir:[path]&#34; </code></pre><p>The commands are fairly straightforward, the only tricky bit is sorting out all the filepaths to the different programs.</p> <p>Now that I have all this plumbing setup time to give TDD a try and see what I can build.</p>
              - generic [ref=e5839]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e5841]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e5842]:
          - generic [ref=e5845]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e5846]:
            - generic [ref=e5847]:
              - generic [ref=e5848]: <title>
              - text: Github Vs Bitbucket Vs Visual Studio Team Services
              - generic [ref=e5849]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e5850]:
              - generic [ref=e5851]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/github-vs-bitbucket-vs-vsts/
              - generic [ref=e5852]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e5853]:
              - generic [ref=e5854]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e5855]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e5856]:
              - generic [ref=e5857]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 06 Mar 2017 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e5858]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e5859]:
              - generic [ref=e5860]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/github-vs-bitbucket-vs-vsts/
              - generic [ref=e5861]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e5862]:
              - generic [ref=e5863]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5864]: term="Git"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Git
              - generic [ref=e5865]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5866]:
              - generic [ref=e5867]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5868]: term="Bitbucket"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Bitbucket
              - generic [ref=e5869]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5870]:
              - generic [ref=e5871]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5872]: term="DevOps"
                - text: ">"
              - text: DevOps
              - generic [ref=e5873]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5874]:
              - generic [ref=e5875]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5876]: term="AzureDevOps"
                - text: ">"
              - text: AzureDevOps
              - generic [ref=e5877]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5878]:
              - generic [ref=e5879]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5880]: term="SourceControl"
                - text: ">"
              - text: SourceControl
              - generic [ref=e5881]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5882]:
              - generic [ref=e5883]: <description>
              - text: "<p>As a developer using source control and git is bread and butter of what we do. Github is probably the most popular and widely known hosting service for source control but I have also used Bitbucket and Visual Studio Team Services. Lets have a look at each one and what they offer. Note while I have included prices I have only tried out the free versions.</p> <h3 id=\"github\">Github<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#github\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2017/github-octocat.png\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"1200\" height=\"630\" /> </p> <ul> <li>URL: <a href=\"https://github.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">https://github.com/</a> </li> <li>Private Repositories: Not Available for free</li> <li>Public Repositories: Unlimited</li> <li>Team Size: Unlimited</li> <li>Prices: $7 per month for unlimited private repositories, $25 per month for 5 users then $9 per month per user</li> </ul> <p>This is probably the most widely used service for hosting code. Over 13 million repositories of code. This is an ideal solution if you want your code to be publicly viewable, but take care not to publish passwords, private keys or your companies trade secrets. Every developer should have a Github account for displaying bits of code they are proud of.</p> <p>There are a number of externally built APIs that link into Github for doing extra features, like building, code coverage etc</p> <h3 id=\"bitbucket\">Bitbucket<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#bitbucket\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2017/d8TRzzL.png\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"277\" height=\"277\" /> </p> <ul> <li>URL: <a href=\"https://bitbucket.org/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">https://bitbucket.org/</a> </li> <li>Private Repositories: Unlimited</li> <li>Public Repositories: Unlimited</li> <li>Team Size: Less than 5</li> <li>Prices: $10 per month for 10 Users, $100 per month for 100 Users, $200 per month for Unlimited Users</li> </ul> <p>At my last job we used Bitbucket extensively for all our projects. All the code was private so only the team could access it, however before I left we were approaching the 5 user limit (but looking at these prices cost seems very reasonable)</p> <h3 id=\"visual-studio-team-services\">Visual Studio Team Services<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#visual-studio-team-services\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2017/Visual-Studio-Team-Services.png\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"960\" height=\"434\" /> </p> <ul> <li>URL: <a href=\"https://www.visualstudio.com/team-services/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">https://www.visualstudio.com/team-services/</a> </li> <li>Private Repositories: Unlimited</li> <li>Public Repositories: Not Available</li> <li>Team Size: Less than 5</li> <li>Prices: $30 per month for 10 users, and other features paid for via Azure Invoices</li> </ul> <p>Visual Studio Team Services or VSTS is Microsoft‚Äôs version control solution and I have only just started using it, however what I have seen I like. There are lots of options for building your code so VSTS is more than just hosting your code it is verging on a Continuous Integration/Delivery solution. Being a Microsoft product there are numerous links to Azure and it is easy to deploy stuff to that platform.</p> <p>All three have options for tracking issues but VSTS have options to add Stakeholder users which would allow none developers to add and keep track of issues and progress with them.</p> <p>If I want to run tests, look at code coverage VSTS is probably the solution I would go for, if I want something that is public I would go for Github. What do you think which of these is your favourite?</p>"
              - generic [ref=e5884]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e5886]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e5887]:
          - generic [ref=e5890]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e5891]:
            - generic [ref=e5892]:
              - generic [ref=e5893]: <title>
              - text: Learning R
              - generic [ref=e5894]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e5895]:
              - generic [ref=e5896]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/learning-r/
              - generic [ref=e5897]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e5898]:
              - generic [ref=e5899]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e5900]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e5901]:
              - generic [ref=e5902]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 27 Feb 2017 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e5903]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e5904]:
              - generic [ref=e5905]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/learning-r/
              - generic [ref=e5906]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e5907]:
              - generic [ref=e5908]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5909]: term="ExchangeRates"
                - text: ">"
              - text: ExchangeRates
              - generic [ref=e5910]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5911]:
              - generic [ref=e5912]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5913]: term="R"
                - text: ">"
              - text: R
              - generic [ref=e5914]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5915]:
              - generic [ref=e5916]: <description>
              - text: "<p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"R\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2017/Exchange-Rate-Calculator.jpg\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"1024\" height=\"689\" /> Today I spent some time learning the R language.</p> <p>The problem I was trying to solve was to convert local prices of some items into Euros. I had been using a fixed exchange rate for all data, but as exchange rates fluctuate so much this is incorrect.</p> <p>My first though was to find a free API that I could query to get the values I wanted. The first API I found didn‚Äôt cover all the currencies, the next one I found I burnt through the free allowance in one pass.</p> <p>A colleague of mine mentioned using R to solve this, he sent me some links and I set out to write my first piece of R code.</p> <p>My finished code can be found on <a href=\"https://github.com/funkysi1701/ExchangeRate/blob/master/script.R\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">github</a> and I will attempt to explain some of it.</p> <p>R defines functions fairly simply</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-r\" data-lang=\"r\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>nameoffunction <span style=\"color:#f92672\">&lt;-</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">function</span>(arg1, arg2) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>{ </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> arg1 <span style=\"color:#f92672\">*</span> arg2 </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>} </span></span></code></pre></div><p>I have created a function that takes 2 parameters date and currency. I know I have about 10 different currencies that I want to get currencies for and I want to loop through each day so I will need to pass in a date.</p> <p>The source of my exchange rate information is the <a href=\"https://www.xe.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">www.xe.com</a> website, its historical exchange rate page passes currency and date into the query string so I should be able to build up a string containing all the different elements.</p> <p>All programming language can concatenate strings and R is no different. R uses paste()</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-r\" data-lang=\"r\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>var <span style=\"color:#f92672\">&lt;-</span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">paste</span>(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;Hello&#34;</span>, <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;World&#34;</span>) </span></span></code></pre></div><p>However R has an annoying feature in this function. I would expect that var in the above example would contain &ldquo;HelloWorld&rdquo;, it doesn‚Äôt it contains &ldquo;Hello World&rdquo;. Why it automatically adds a space I don‚Äôt know?</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-r\" data-lang=\"r\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>var <span style=\"color:#f92672\">&lt;-</span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">paste</span>(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;Hello&#34;</span>, <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;World&#34;</span>, sep<span style=\"color:#f92672\">=</span><span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;&#34;</span>) </span></span></code></pre></div><p>I am not entirely sure what all of the code does but I can take a good guess.</p> <p>read_html() I would guess loads a html page, html_nodes() finds all the html tags of a certain type on the page, in my case &lt;table&gt;, html_table() reads the first table it finds.</p> <p>table1[2] selects the second column, and head() selects a specific number of rows. I want the first row and second column so I combine these two as head(table1[2],1)</p> <p>Now that I have found my exchange rate what do I do with it? R can read and write to SQL Server so why not store this info in a SQL lookup table. I can then use this data in a stored procedure when I process my data.</p> <p>To query sql you can use sqlQuery(), it has two parameters, a sql connection and a TSQL command (eg a SELECT, INSERT, UPDATE statement)</p> <p>I use a while loop to loop through every day between 1st October 2016 and today and look up the exchange rate for each currency.</p> <p>For now I am manually running this R script, however there are ways to run R directly from SQL Server which I may well investigate. I could then have a SQL job to run this on a schedule, maybe once a day to get the latest exchange rates. I also would like to do something a bit cleverer like only getting exchange rates for the days that I need them by querying existing database tables.</p>"
              - generic [ref=e5917]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e5919]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e5920]:
          - generic [ref=e5923]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e5924]:
            - generic [ref=e5925]:
              - generic [ref=e5926]: <title>
              - text: Side Project ‚Äì Connect 4
              - generic [ref=e5927]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e5928]:
              - generic [ref=e5929]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/side-project-connect-4/
              - generic [ref=e5930]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e5931]:
              - generic [ref=e5932]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e5933]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e5934]:
              - generic [ref=e5935]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 06 Feb 2017 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e5936]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e5937]:
              - generic [ref=e5938]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2017/side-project-connect-4/
              - generic [ref=e5939]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e5940]:
              - generic [ref=e5941]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5942]: term="Connect4"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Connect4
              - generic [ref=e5943]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5944]:
              - generic [ref=e5945]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5946]: term="PWA"
                - text: ">"
              - text: PWA
              - generic [ref=e5947]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5948]:
              - generic [ref=e5949]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5950]: term="Website"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Website
              - generic [ref=e5951]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5952]:
              - generic [ref=e5953]: <description>
              - text: <p>Hello?</p> <p>You have probably like me almost forgotten about this blog. Life has got in the way over the last few months, but lets see if I can restart my blogging habit.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2017/Connect4.png" loading="lazy" width="639" height="553" /> </p> <p>In 2017 I want to start a side project for a few reasons. I want to improve my coding skills and look at things I wouldn‚Äôt normally during my day job.</p> <p>I have been trying to decide what to build. The actual project doesn‚Äôt matter too much, it is the techniques I use during build that matters the most. I would like something that I can start off as a windows app and then extend onto the web or mobile apps.</p> <p>I started off thinking about a Rubik‚Äôs cube app, however my initial coding has lead me to believe it is probably too complex for my first app.</p> <p>Last year I spent an evening looking at Connect 4 during a <a href="https://yorkcodedojo.github.io/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">York Code Dojo</a> session. I think this should be complex enough that I can code some logic to efficiently solve the game, however not too complex I get defeated before building too much.</p> <p>So far I have built a console app that displays via Console.Write() commands, a grid to represent the game, with 0 meaning empty, 1 red and 2 yellow etc. I am currently working on the logic to solve the game, once I have that in a good state I can extend into a winforms app, into a web (MVC most likely) app and finally a mobile app (I have no knowledge about how to do this yet, but something I would like to try one day).</p> <p>Over the last few days I listened to .NetRocks where they discussed <a href="https://www.dotnetrocks.com/?show=1396" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Progressive Web Apps</a> . This sounds like a great challenge for me to aim for. A progressive Web App is a website that automatically detects various properties to give you an app that runs well whatever the state of your internet connection and whatever browser you are in.</p> <p>I have lots to learn but I can split it down into small sections and I can build something that demonstrates some of my skills.</p>
              - generic [ref=e5954]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e5956]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e5957]:
          - generic [ref=e5960]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e5961]:
            - generic [ref=e5962]:
              - generic [ref=e5963]: <title>
              - text: What should be in Source Control?
              - generic [ref=e5964]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e5965]:
              - generic [ref=e5966]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2016/what-should-be-in-source-control/
              - generic [ref=e5967]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e5968]:
              - generic [ref=e5969]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e5970]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e5971]:
              - generic [ref=e5972]: <pubDate>
              - text: Thu, 24 Nov 2016 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e5973]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e5974]:
              - generic [ref=e5975]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2016/what-should-be-in-source-control/
              - generic [ref=e5976]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e5977]:
              - generic [ref=e5978]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5979]: term="Git"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Git
              - generic [ref=e5980]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5981]:
              - generic [ref=e5982]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5983]: term="SourceCode"
                - text: ">"
              - text: SourceCode
              - generic [ref=e5984]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5985]:
              - generic [ref=e5986]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5987]: term="SourceControl"
                - text: ">"
              - text: SourceControl
              - generic [ref=e5988]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5989]:
              - generic [ref=e5990]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e5991]: term="C-Sharp"
                - text: ">"
              - text: C-Sharp
              - generic [ref=e5992]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e5993]:
              - generic [ref=e5994]: <description>
              - text: <p>I am currently working on source code that is over 5Gb in size. This is mostly due to a poorly thought out folder structure, there are code files, images and Excel files all jumbled together. I think a clear distinction should be made between source code and data.</p> <h3 id="source-code">Source Code<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#source-code"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h3> <p>I will define source code as anything that is written in order to compile and run the project. If it is a webpage it will be all the HTML, CSS and Javascript or any file used to produce these. I would also include any configuration files and files used to build/deploy the website or project. Anything that is compiled from your source files can safely be ignored.</p> <h3 id="data">Data<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#data"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h3> <p>I would define data as anything that is added to the project during its life. So if you have an upload option, anything that is uploaded I would describe as data. The site should still function without (or very little) data.</p> <h3 id="images">Images<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#images"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h3> <p>Images can fit into both groups. Any icons or images attached to the functionality of the project I would class as source code. However anything that is uploaded should be classed as Data.</p> <h3 id="databases">Databases<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#databases"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h3> <p>The database should also be classed as both. The data, anything that is inside a database table should normally be classed as data. Stored Procedures, Functions and Views are all Source Code and would benefit from version control.</p> <h3 id="source-control--backup">Source Control != Backup<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#source-control--backup"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h3> <p>Source control is not an excuse not to backup things. Don‚Äôt just commit files to source control so you know you can restore them if you need to. Files in general in source control are there so you can see how they changed over time as the code base changed. Files in you backup are a snapshot of what the application was at a point in time and will include ALL the data.</p> <p>One last point before I end. If you are hosting on a Cloud Computing platform like Azure it gives you an easy way to distinguish between Data and Code.</p> <p>Anything in your</p> <ul> <li>Web App = Code</li> <li>Blob Storage = Data</li> <li>SQL = Data/Code</li> </ul> <p>Each project is unique and there will always be exceptions to these suggestions but I think this is a good goal to have. What do you think?</p>
              - generic [ref=e5995]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e5997]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e5998]:
          - generic [ref=e6001]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e6002]:
            - generic [ref=e6003]:
              - generic [ref=e6004]: <title>
              - text: Getting control of a codebase
              - generic [ref=e6005]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e6006]:
              - generic [ref=e6007]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2016/getting-control-of-a-codebase/
              - generic [ref=e6008]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e6009]:
              - generic [ref=e6010]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e6011]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e6012]:
              - generic [ref=e6013]: <pubDate>
              - text: Thu, 17 Nov 2016 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e6014]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e6015]:
              - generic [ref=e6016]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2016/getting-control-of-a-codebase/
              - generic [ref=e6017]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e6018]:
              - generic [ref=e6019]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e6020]: term="Javascript"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Javascript
              - generic [ref=e6021]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e6022]:
              - generic [ref=e6023]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e6024]: term="AzureDevOps"
                - text: ">"
              - text: AzureDevOps
              - generic [ref=e6025]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e6026]:
              - generic [ref=e6027]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e6028]: term="SQL"
                - text: ">"
              - text: SQL
              - generic [ref=e6029]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e6030]:
              - generic [ref=e6031]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e6032]: term="VisualStudio"
                - text: ">"
              - text: VisualStudio
              - generic [ref=e6033]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e6034]:
              - generic [ref=e6035]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e6036]: term="C-Sharp"
                - text: ">"
              - text: C-Sharp
              - generic [ref=e6037]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e6038]:
              - generic [ref=e6039]: <description>
              - text: <p>So recently I started working on a new codebase. I will be honest when I first saw it, it was a mess. Here are a few of the things I did to try and regain control.</p> <p>I was given access to the source code on Visual Studio Team Services. However this consisted of a single commit 3 months ago. When I looked at what was running on the production server it was clear that changes were being made live with no regard for source control.</p> <p>The first thing I did was commit everything that was running live into source control.</p> <p>Next I created a SQL Server Data Tools (SSDT) project to keep track of all the database objects. Previously there was a folder with some stored procedures in it, but these did not match with what was currently running.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="SQL Server 2012 Management Studio Splash Screen" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2016/sql-server-2012-management-studio-splash-screen.png" loading="lazy" width="529" height="360" /> </p> <p>I now had in source control the current state of the website and the database, so I knew I could get things back to this state if I made some bad changes.</p> <p>Lets start by looking at the website code I had. There was no solution file, the only way to look at the website was to setup my local IIS to run what was in the website folder. I could then use Visual Studio to &ldquo;open&rdquo; my local IIS website and attach to process to debug it.</p> <p>Next I Looked at Default.aspx to see how the website worked. The majority of the website code was stored in the database stored procedures. After the tag there was a &lt;% %&gt; which contained a Response.Write(RunSP.RunStoredProcedure(Parameter1, Parameter2, &hellip;) command, which executed a stored procedure and the results of the stored procedure was the html code including any javascript that the webpage needed to display. I will be honest I have never seen any code like it. My guess is that the developer was secretly a DBA and wanted to make any web page changes by just changing how the stored procedures work.</p> <p>This meant that the website is not going to do anything without a backup of the database running, and meant my SSDT project was going to be vital. However the database was in a bad state, it consisted of a fair few broken objects and SSDT would not build.</p> <p>Using find I went through each of the broken database objects to find where in the code they were being used. Luckily most were referenced in commented out code, so I just removed all the broken database objects. The database could now be built. However there was a dependency on the users table of another database. (This was the developers solution to sharing logins between websites) As I was using SSDT I added a database dependency, problem solved for now.</p> <p>Next I tried publishing my database. SQL CMD encountered a parsing error. The reason for this was my SPs contained javascript eg $(document), SQL CMD uses $(DatabaseName) as variables for different database so it was getting itself confused.</p> <p>My solution was to use Find and Replace to replace all the $ with &rsquo; + CHAR(36) + '</p> <p>So I now have a SSDT project that builds and publishes but still no website project.</p> <p>To get the website running from Visual Studio I started off creating a .Net 4 website project and added Entity Framework 5 and MVC 3 via nuget. I then copied all the website code into the new project, and with a bit of work I got it to build. Most of the work was relating to namespaces and referencing the correct one and moving the EF model from AppCode to a custom named folder. A bit of trial and error later I had a version of the website that could be run from Visual Studio.</p> <p>I have not deployed my new version of the website as it needs further testing. No automated testing or even a smoke test checklist currently exist.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2016/Visual-Studio-Team-Services.png" loading="lazy" width="960" height="434" /> </p> <p>As my source code is hosted on Visual Studio Team Services (VSTS), I can get VSTS to build each commit and check I haven‚Äôt broken the build. This is not that helpful at the moment, hopefully one day I will have automated tests that can be run here as well.</p> <p>Wow, I feel like I have done loads with this code so far but there is loads more still to do. I need to understand more about the business processes behind the code with a hope to understand why some architectural decisions have been made. I want to refactor the code as much as is possible, I would like to remove much of the html/javascript from the stored procedures as I can‚Äôt see that there is any advantage to running a website like this. Please correct my if I am wrong.</p>
              - generic [ref=e6040]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e6042]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e6043]:
          - generic [ref=e6046]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e6047]:
            - generic [ref=e6048]:
              - generic [ref=e6049]: <title>
              - text: LINQ
              - generic [ref=e6050]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e6051]:
              - generic [ref=e6052]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2016/linq/
              - generic [ref=e6053]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e6054]:
              - generic [ref=e6055]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e6056]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e6057]:
              - generic [ref=e6058]: <pubDate>
              - text: Thu, 06 Oct 2016 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e6059]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e6060]:
              - generic [ref=e6061]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2016/linq/
              - generic [ref=e6062]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e6063]:
              - generic [ref=e6064]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e6065]: term="LINQ"
                - text: ">"
              - text: LINQ
              - generic [ref=e6066]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e6067]:
              - generic [ref=e6068]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e6069]: term="SQL"
                - text: ">"
              - text: SQL
              - generic [ref=e6070]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e6071]:
              - generic [ref=e6072]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e6073]: term="C-Sharp"
                - text: ">"
              - text: C-Sharp
              - generic [ref=e6074]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e6075]:
              - generic [ref=e6076]: <description>
              - text: "<p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2016/step30.jpg\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"515\" height=\"355\" /> </p> <h3 id=\"what-is-linq\">What is LINQ?<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#what-is-linq\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p><strong>LINQ</strong> is an acronym for Language Integrated Query, which describes where it‚Äôs used and what it does. The Language Integrated part means that LINQ is part of programming language syntax. In particular, both C# and VB are languages that ship with .NET and have LINQ capabilities.</p> <h3 id=\"how-do-i-use-linq-in-my-c-code\">How do I use LINQ in my C# code?<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#how-do-i-use-linq-in-my-c-code\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>To use LINQ the first thing you need to do is add the LINQ using statement.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">using</span> System.Linq; </span></span></code></pre></div><p>In your code you need a datasource, for this example I am going to use a simple array, but it can be anything eg SQL, XML etc</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">int</span>[] data = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">int</span>[<span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">10</span>] { <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">0</span>, <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">1</span>, <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">2</span>, <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">3</span>, <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">4</span>, <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">5</span>, <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">6</span>, <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">7</span>, <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">8</span>, <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">9</span> }; </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Next you need a LINQ query. (Note I know the Q in LINQ means query, so I have just written query query, if you are one of those people who hates seeing PIN number you might not like this blog post.) A LINQ query is very similar to a T-SQL query, so if like me you are good with databases this should make sense to you.</p> <p>In T-SQL you can have:</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-sql\" data-lang=\"sql\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">SELECT</span> num </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">FROM</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">data</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">WHERE</span> num <span style=\"color:#f92672\">=</span> <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">1</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>In LINQ this becomes:</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> query = </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">from</span> num <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">in</span> data </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">where</span> num == <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">1</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">select</span> num; </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Finally you need to do something with the query you have written. I am just going to print the results of my query to console.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">foreach</span> (<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> num <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">in</span> query) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>{ </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> Console.Write(num); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>} </span></span></code></pre></div><h3 id=\"what-other-sql-like-syntax-can-i-use\">What other SQL like syntax can I use?<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#what-other-sql-like-syntax-can-i-use\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>In T-SQL you can control ordering using ORDER BY, LINQ has a similar syntax orderby</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">orderby</span> num <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">descending</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>In T-SQL you can use GROUP BY, to do something similar with LINQ</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">group</span> num <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">by</span> num.Type <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">into</span> type </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">select</span> type </span></span></code></pre></div><div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">foreach</span> (<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> type <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">in</span> query) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>{ </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> Console.Write(type.Key); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">foreach</span> (<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> num <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">in</span> type) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> Console.Write(num); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>} </span></span></code></pre></div><h3 id=\"joins\">JOINS<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#joins\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>So you thought joining tables was a SQL Server only thing. Think again you can do this in LINQ</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> joinquery = </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">from</span> cust <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">in</span> customers </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">join</span> prod <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">in</span> products <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">on</span> prod.CustomerId <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">equals</span> cust.Id </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">select</span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> { ProductName = prod.Name, CustomerName = cust.CompanyName }; </span></span></code></pre></div><h3 id=\"conclusion\">Conclusion<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#conclusion\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>There are loads more LINQ functionality that you can use. While writing this blog I found <a href=\"https://code.msdn.microsoft.com/101-LINQ-Samples-3fb9811b\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">https://code.msdn.microsoft.com/101-LINQ-Samples-3fb9811b</a> which has loads of examples of different queries that you can write with LINQ.</p> <p>This has inspired me to use LINQ more in my code and learn more about the different queries that could be written.</p>"
              - generic [ref=e6077]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e6079]: </item>

              - text: Nagios
              - generic [ref=e6115]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e6116]:
              - generic [ref=e6117]:
                - text: <category
