          - generic [ref=e6567]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e6568]:
            - generic [ref=e6569]:
              - generic [ref=e6570]: <title>
              - text: Exchange Web Services
              - generic [ref=e6571]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e6572]:
              - generic [ref=e6573]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2016/exchange-web-services/
              - generic [ref=e6574]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e6575]:
              - generic [ref=e6576]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e6577]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e6578]:
              - generic [ref=e6579]: <pubDate>
              - text: Thu, 21 Apr 2016 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e6580]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e6581]:
              - generic [ref=e6582]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2016/exchange-web-services/
              - generic [ref=e6583]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e6584]:
              - generic [ref=e6585]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e6586]: term="EWS"
                - text: ">"
              - text: EWS
              - generic [ref=e6587]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e6588]:
              - generic [ref=e6589]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e6590]: term="MVC"
                - text: ">"
              - text: MVC
              - generic [ref=e6591]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e6592]:
              - generic [ref=e6593]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e6594]: term="Exchange"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Exchange
              - generic [ref=e6595]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e6596]:
              - generic [ref=e6597]: <description>
              - text: "<p>Where I work we use a really old fashioned way of recording where in the country employees are: Excel!</p> <p>For years I have been trying to persuade staff to use calendars in Exchange. Outlook is great for looking at one or two people‚Äôs calendars at once but quickly gets unmanageable for looking at ten or more peoples availability.</p> <p>Recently I have started looking into how easy it is to query this information to give a custom view.</p> <p>Microsoft provide an API to query exchange information called Exchange Web Services or EWS. I have only used EWS with my Exchange 2010 setup, but the documentation mentions working with Exchange 2007 and older or Exchange online.</p> <p>Here are the basics of what I have tried. Fire up Visual Studio and from nuget install EWS.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-powershell\" data-lang=\"powershell\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>Install-Package Microsoft.Exchange.WebServices </span></span></code></pre></div><p>I started off with a simple Console App to see how it all worked, and then extended it to a MVC website. I found querying exchange directly was slow, but it is easy enough to cache information in a database.</p> <p>To start you need to create an Exchange Service object, by specifying the version of Exchange you are using.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>ExchangeService service = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> ExchangeService(ExchangeVersion.Exchange2010); </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Next you need to pass the URL you are using to access Exchange.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>service.Url = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> Uri(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;mail.example.com&#34;</span>); </span></span></code></pre></div><p>To access information from exchange you need to pass some Exchange credentials, ideally a username and password that has access to view all the calendars you want to look at.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>service.Credentials = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> WebCredentials(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;username&#34;</span>,<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;password&#34;</span>); </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Next pass the email address of the user who owns the calendar you want to look at.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>service.ImpersonatedUserId = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> ImpersonatedUserId(ConnectingIdType.SmtpAddress, <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;me@example.com&#34;</span>); </span></span></code></pre></div><p>My particular exchange server has a self signed SSL certificate which is not going to be trusted by remote clients. The following line ignores this validation check and makes my program connect.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>System.Net.ServicePointManager.ServerCertificateValidationCallback = (sender, certificate, chain, sslPolicyErrors) =&gt; <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">true</span>; </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now that we have connected to exchange we just need a few lines to look for events in the calendars.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\">// Initialize the calendar folder object with only the folder ID.</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>CalendarFolder calendar = CalendarFolder.Bind(service, WellKnownFolderName.Calendar, <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> PropertySet()); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\">// Set the start and end time and number of appointments to retrieve.</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>CalendarView cView = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> CalendarView(startDate, endDate); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\">// Limit the properties returned to the appointment&#39;s subject, start time, and end time.</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>cView.PropertySet = <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">new</span> PropertySet(AppointmentSchema.Subject, AppointmentSchema.Start, AppointmentSchema.End); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\">// Retrieve a collection of appointments by using the calendar view.</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>FindItemsResults&lt;Appointment&gt; appointments = calendar.FindAppointments(cView); </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now that you have an appointments object you can loop through each element with a foreach loop. In my case I assign each elements Subject to a variable, which I can then do what I like with (display in a console window, save to a database, display in an MVC website.)</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-csharp\" data-lang=\"csharp\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">foreach</span> (Appointment a <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">in</span> appointments) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>{ </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">if</span> (a.Subject != <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">null</span>) </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> subject += a.Subject.ToString(); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> } </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>} </span></span></code></pre></div><p>My website queries a SQL database which I can easily populate with a console app that runs at regular intervals throughout the day.</p> <p>There is a lot more I want to do with this project as this is only the basics of what you can do with Exchange Web Services. So expect more blog posts on this subject as I expand its functionality and learn new ways of doing things.</p>"
              - generic [ref=e6598]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e6600]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e6601]:
          - generic [ref=e6604]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e6605]:
            - generic [ref=e6606]:
              - generic [ref=e6607]: <title>
              - text: Revisiting Team City
              - generic [ref=e6608]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e6609]:
              - generic [ref=e6610]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2016/revisiting-teamcity/
              - generic [ref=e6611]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e6612]:
              - generic [ref=e6613]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e6614]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e6615]:
              - generic [ref=e6616]: <pubDate>
              - text: Thu, 24 Mar 2016 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e6617]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e6618]:
              - generic [ref=e6619]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2016/revisiting-teamcity/
              - generic [ref=e6620]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e6621]:
              - generic [ref=e6622]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e6623]: term="CI"
                - text: ">"
              - text: CI
              - generic [ref=e6624]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e6625]:
              - generic [ref=e6626]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e6627]: term="DevOps"
                - text: ">"
              - text: DevOps
              - generic [ref=e6628]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e6629]:
              - generic [ref=e6630]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e6631]: term="SourceControl"
                - text: ">"
              - text: SourceControl
              - generic [ref=e6632]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e6633]:
              - generic [ref=e6634]: <description>
              - text: "<p>Last year I blogged about <a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/2015/04/01/teamcity/\">Team City</a> , well I have been looking at it again recently. In that time they have even changed their logo!</p> <p>Lets start with thinking about what I want my Continuous Integration server to do.</p> <ol> <li>Check out my code from source control (usually master but all feature branches would be even better)</li> <li>Configure specific setting for build</li> <li>Build my code</li> <li>Build my databases</li> <li>Run any unit tests</li> <li>(Optional) Run deployment to Azure Test/Live site</li> </ol> <p>There are probably other things I want to achieve but I will start with these six.</p> <ol> <li>Checking out code from source control is something Team City does out of the box, so I can safely say I have done this now. It even monitors a branch for changes and initiates a new check out.</li> <li>Team City allows you to create specific build steps so in theory you can have multiple builds for every variation of settings that you want for your code. I have not tried this yet apart from building with the default config, but I don‚Äôt expect it will be too difficult.</li> <li>I have managed to get my code to build with Team City, it took a bit of tweaking the different build steps but wasn‚Äôt too difficult. Team City has a visual studio build agent which takes you solution file and does what it needs to. The one problem I have found with this step is that I get errors with my tests if I select a Debug config instead of Release.</li> <li>Databases are always the problem part of the deployment. So far I have manually deployed my databases but I intend on revisit this step. A <a href=\"https://stackoverflow.com/questions/21555038/how-can-i-execute-sql-scripts-using-teamcity\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">stackoverflow</a> post suggests that I can run SQL code via Team City in the following way by creating a command line executable:</li> </ol> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>Command executable: c:<span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">\\P</span>rogram Files<span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">\\M</span>icrosoft SQL Server<span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">\\1</span>00<span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">\\T</span>ools<span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">\\B</span>inn<span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">\\s</span>qlcmd.exe </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>Command parameters: -S <span style=\"color:#f92672\">[</span>ServerName<span style=\"color:#f92672\">]</span> -i <span style=\"color:#f92672\">[</span>PathToSQLScript<span style=\"color:#f92672\">]</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>I have yet to try this but I am hopefully that it will just work. Dropping a database and restoring a back and then running different SQL scripts is all possible from TSQL, so I should be OK. Watch this space for more details.</p> <ol start=\"5\"> <li>Running the unit tests got me stuck for a while. I tried setting it up using VSTest or MSTest neither worked mainly because a config file wasn‚Äôt being copied with the test binaries. When I tried using NUnit it just worked. The tests that failed gave me a few config settings to change.</li> <li>I have powershell scripts that deploy to Azure websites, I think that these could form the basis of a deployment to Azure. Again the difficult step here may end up being deploying all the different databases to Azure. This is also the riskiest step as I need to connect to live servers which is why I will leave this to last, at the very least I could generate scripts that do a full deployment.</li> </ol> <p>That‚Äôs it for now. Once I have this all working I will revisit again with details of the database steps as I am expecting a few challenges to overcome. What have you used a CI Server for? Are there other things I want to achieve from a project like this? Why not contact me or leave a comment below</p>"
              - generic [ref=e6635]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e6637]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e6638]:
          - generic [ref=e6641]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e6642]:
            - generic [ref=e6643]:
              - generic [ref=e6644]: <title>
              - text: Model View Controller (MVC)
              - generic [ref=e6645]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e6646]:
              - generic [ref=e6647]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2016/model-view-controller-mvc/
              - generic [ref=e6648]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e6649]:
              - generic [ref=e6650]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e6651]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e6652]:
              - generic [ref=e6653]: <pubDate>
              - text: Thu, 17 Mar 2016 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e6654]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e6655]:
              - generic [ref=e6656]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2016/model-view-controller-mvc/
              - generic [ref=e6657]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e6658]:
              - generic [ref=e6659]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e6660]: term="MVC"
                - text: ">"
              - text: MVC
              - generic [ref=e6661]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e6662]:
              - generic [ref=e6663]: <description>
              - text: <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2016/27.jpg" loading="lazy" width="327" height="314" /> </p> <p>Model View Controller or MVC is a software architectural pattern for implementing user interfaces on computers. It divides a given software application into three interconnected parts, so as to separate internal representations of information from the ways that information is presented to or accepted from the user.</p> <p>I have been trying to get my head around the concept of MVC for a while, hopefully writing this article will help solidify my understanding of it.</p> <p>One of the core concepts of MVC is the ability to separate concerns so you can concentrate your energies on one aspect of the application.</p> <p><strong>Model</strong> This is the data. If your application uses a database the model often mirrors what you have in the database and concerns itself retrieving information from the database.</p> <p><strong>View</strong> This concerns itself with displaying the data to the user. Typically this is the html pages of your application.</p> <p><strong>Controller</strong> This concerns itself with actually doing things and deals with user interaction. Typically it will get data from the view and send data to the model.</p> <p>The three concerns can be developed in isolation as they do not depend on each other, for larger development teams you can even divide up development much easier that a traditional app.</p> <p>The basic concept of MVC I get and understand, however I find myself getting bogged down in the details.</p> <p>The database doesn‚Äôt matter. I need to remember this and not get sidetracked in writing custom methods to connect to the database which end up unmanageable. I know SQL, so can easily write SQL commands to copy data into the format I need for my app. The app I am currently working on involves a large amount of existing data, and I need to concentrate on the MVC parts and worry about the database later.</p> <p>In previous attempts I have tried to build my model against many tables, but instead I can write a query against many tables and insert that into one table which the Model can then use.</p> <p>Changing the model often results in an error informing you that the context has changed since the database was created. The easy solution to this in my case is to drop the database and allow entity framework to recreate the database each time. As long as my database contains no new data, I won‚Äôt loose anything.</p> <p>One of the core advantages of MVC is the ability to test it or even use test driven development (TDD). I haven‚Äôt really dabbled with testing yet as I am still trying to get my head around the fundamentals, but once I have made some progress with my app I want to test, so next time I get asked to add a new feature I have no fear about breaking stuff.</p> <p>For the first time I have got an app with a working Authentication system from the start. And it is remarkably easy to implement with one keyword. Adding <strong>[Authorize]</strong> to the top of your controller is all that is needed. Building the actual Authentication system is relatively easy from Visual Studio, as it has templates for Azure AD, Forms Based, Open Auth like google/twitter etc.</p> <p>It is still very early days for my MVC app and my understanding of it, but I feel I have turned the corner and can actually build something with it now, rather than be stuck in a downward spiral of confusion.</p> <p>What do you think about MVC why not leave a comment below? For more info about MVC I have been looking at <a href="http://www.asp.net/mvc" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.asp.net/mvc</a> which has more information and tutorials.</p>
              - generic [ref=e6664]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e6666]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e6667]:
          - generic [ref=e6670]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e6671]:
            - generic [ref=e6672]:
              - generic [ref=e6673]: <title>
              - text: Surface Book Review
              - generic [ref=e6674]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e6675]:
              - generic [ref=e6676]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2016/surface-book-review/
              - generic [ref=e6677]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e6678]:
              - generic [ref=e6679]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e6680]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e6681]:
              - generic [ref=e6682]: <pubDate>
              - text: Thu, 10 Mar 2016 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e6683]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e6684]:
              - generic [ref=e6685]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2016/surface-book-review/
              - generic [ref=e6686]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e6687]:
              - generic [ref=e6688]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e6689]: term="Laptop"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Laptop
              - generic [ref=e6690]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e6691]:
              - generic [ref=e6692]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e6693]: term="Hardware"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Hardware
              - generic [ref=e6694]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e6695]:
              - generic [ref=e6696]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e6697]: term="Technology"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Technology
              - generic [ref=e6698]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e6699]:
              - generic [ref=e6700]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e6701]: term="Microsoft"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Microsoft
              - generic [ref=e6702]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e6703]:
              - generic [ref=e6704]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e6705]: term="Windows"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Windows
              - generic [ref=e6706]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e6707]:
              - generic [ref=e6708]: <description>
              - text: <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2016/en-INTL-PDP0-Surface-Book-CR9-00001-P2.jpg" loading="lazy" width="780" height="400" /> I have just bought myself a new laptop, but it is not just any laptop it is a <a href="https://www.microsoftstore.com/store/msuk/en_GB/pdp/productID.332604800" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Microsoft Surface Book</a> .</p> <p>I think this is probably the first time I have bought myself a top of the range laptop and after a few days of use I am loving it.</p> <p>The Surface Book is the latest in Microsoft‚Äôs Surface line of tablets but the first to feature a keyboard and be more like a traditional laptop. The keyboard is detachable from the keyboard so you can use the Surface Book like a tablet.</p> <p>As it is a top of the range laptop, it was not cheap, so if price is a significant factor in your laptop choice this is not the machine for you. Microsoft are trying to compete with Apple‚Äôs Macbook range.</p> <p>So what did I get for my money:</p> <ul> <li>Windows 10 Pro</li> <li>16Gb RAM</li> <li>512Gb SSD (Formatted Size nearer 474Gb)</li> <li>6th Generation Intel Core i7 Processor</li> <li>Surface Pen</li> <li>13.5-inch touch screen</li> </ul> <p>I have only had the device for a few days but these are my thoughts so far. My primary reason for buying this is for doing development work with Visual Studio and SQL Server.</p> <p>I really like the Surface Pen. This is a feature that I didn‚Äôt think I would use much. The Pen connects via bluetooth and allows interaction with the touch screen. The pressure sensitive screen allows all sort of touch actions to be performed.</p> <p>I especially like the choice of keyboards that are offered when the physical keyboard is detached. You can have either a on screen keyboard which you can type with pen or fingers, an on screen keyboard that splits in half or you can write with the pen. This is an amazing feature. My handwriting is not good but most of the time it understands my scrawl. With this option you can hand write a tweet or fill in a form on a webpage. For speed I would not recommend this form of input for large amounts of text, but for browsing the web of when you are just clicking on links it is great.</p> <p>Windows Hello ‚Äì I can unlock windows just by looking at my screen. How cool is that! It was really easy to setup, it just takes a photo of your face and next time you login all you need to do it look at the screen. Note if you are working in tablet mode, make sure the tablet is the correct way up.</p> <p>It‚Äôs not all brilliant though. Detaching the screen is fiddly and sometimes takes a few moments to do. A few times I have felt I needed another hand but I am sure the more I do this the easier I will find it to do.</p> <p>Battery life isn‚Äôt great especially when running off the tablet only. This is due to the machine having two batteries, one in the base and one in the screen so with keyboard attached you have much longer use times. Actually I am finding the battery is lasting longer now that I have used it for a few days.</p> <p>The screen has a very high resolution 3000 x 2000 but using clever zooming technology everything is still readable and not tiny. However I use Remote Desktop a lot and this caused me a problem. When RDPing the remote session used the host screen resolution which made everything tiny on my servers. The solution to this can be found on <a href="https://superuser.com/questions/891413/remote-connection-desktop-manager-2-7-does-not-support-dpi-scaling-anymore" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">SuperUser</a> and involved using Microsoft‚Äôs Remote Desktop Connection Manager, a cool bit of software for managing multiple RDP sessions. This is actually an improvement on the way I usually work, but until I found the answer this was annoying.</p> <p>Another minor annoyance with the keyboard is that you can‚Äôt press Ctrl-Alt-Del with one hand. Normally this isn‚Äôt a requirement but if the screen locks while I have my son on my lap I am stuck, but I won‚Äôt blame the surface book for this.</p> <p>When I got my Surface Book I was also given a Microsoft Wireless Display Adapter. I am not a fan of this bit of tech as I can‚Äôt get it to work. I briefly got my old laptop to connect but my Surface Book keeps telling me NO!</p> <p>Overall I like the Surface Book. It is certainly the nicest laptop I have ever used. Now that I have the docking station I can connect two monitors, have a wired internet connection and it becomes a proper work horse. What does everyone else think? Better than Apple‚Äôs range of laptops?</p>
              - generic [ref=e6709]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e6711]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e6712]:
          - generic [ref=e6715]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e6716]:
            - generic [ref=e6717]:
              - generic [ref=e6718]: <title>
              - text: Trying Out Azure Active Directory
              - generic [ref=e6719]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e6720]:
              - generic [ref=e6721]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2016/trying-out-azure-active-directory/
              - generic [ref=e6722]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e6723]:
              - generic [ref=e6724]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e6725]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e6726]:
              - generic [ref=e6727]: <pubDate>
              - text: Thu, 03 Mar 2016 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e6728]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e6729]:
              - generic [ref=e6730]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2016/trying-out-azure-active-directory/
              - generic [ref=e6731]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e6732]:
              - generic [ref=e6733]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e6734]: term="ActiveDirectory"
                - text: ">"
              - text: ActiveDirectory
              - generic [ref=e6735]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e6736]:
              - generic [ref=e6737]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e6738]: term="Azure"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Azure
              - generic [ref=e6739]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e6740]:
              - generic [ref=e6741]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e6742]: term="Authentication"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Authentication
              - generic [ref=e6743]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e6744]:
              - generic [ref=e6745]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e6746]: term="AzureActiveDirectory"
                - text: ">"
              - text: AzureActiveDirectory
              - generic [ref=e6747]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e6748]:
              - generic [ref=e6749]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e6750]: term="DevOps"
                - text: ">"
              - text: DevOps
              - generic [ref=e6751]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e6752]:
              - generic [ref=e6753]: <description>
              - text: <p>One of my plans is to create new MVC Webapps for my companies databases. Once I publish these I will need to secure them so only staff have access.</p> <p>The traditional way to do this would be insert membership tables into my database. The user then has to remember another username and password and I have to secure the storage of these credentials. Lots of work for everyone.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2016/arch.png" loading="lazy" width="600" height="430" /> </p> <p>There is a better way by using Azure Active Directory. You have probably heard of Active Directory, if you are a SysAdmin you probably use it all the time to manage your corporate users and computers. Azure Active Directory is an extension of this into the Cloud.</p> <p>I have blogged in the past about using Azure but this is the first time I have tried connecting my internal domain to Azure. There is a <a href="https://vlabs.holsystems.com/vlabs/technet?eng=VLabs&amp;auth=external&amp;src=vlabs&amp;altadd=true&amp;labid=13535" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Virtual Lab</a> which helped me try out some of these ideas.</p> <p>The first thing I did was to create a new Directory in Azure. I did this via the old portal (<a href="https://manage.windowsazure.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">manage.windowsazure.com</a> ) it might be possible via the new portal but I don‚Äôt know how yet.</p> <p>Click New, select App Services &gt; Active Directory &gt; Directory and select Custom Create. Select Create new directory, give it a name and a domain name and select a region from the drop down. Then add a Global Admin for this directory.</p> <p>There is a tool called <a href="https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=47594" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Azure Active Directory Connect</a> . Download and Install this with express settings on one of your domain controllers. You need to specify a domain admin account to access your domain and the Azure Global Admin account you just created.</p> <p>At this point I went to bed so I am not sure how long it tool to sync all the domain information but by morning it was all showing in the users list on Azure.</p> <p>All my user accounts are showing with a @contoso.onmicrosoft.com, it is possible to use custom domains but I haven‚Äôt figured out that step yet. I made a change in my Active Directory and a while later that change was showing in Azure AD.</p> <p>So now what? Open up Visual Studio and see if I can use Azure to Authenticate.</p> <p>I selected to create a new MVC web project and clicked the change authenticate option. One of the options was Work and School Accounts, I then selected Cloud Single Organization and entered contoso.onmicrosoft.com. I then ran this app and it authenticated using Azure using my domain password. Really impressed at how easy that was.</p> <p>The app then shows up on Azure in the old portal. In Applications you can see a list of which users have access to your app and configure few other app related settings.</p> <p>This is a long way off being useful in my actual app, but it shows that the basics of what I am trying to do does work. Anyone done anything similar with Azure AD? How did you get on?</p>
              - generic [ref=e6754]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e6756]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e6757]:
          - generic [ref=e6760]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e6761]:
            - generic [ref=e6762]:
              - generic [ref=e6763]: <title>
              - text: Coding myself into a corner
              - generic [ref=e6764]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e6765]:
              - generic [ref=e6766]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2016/coding-myself-into-a-corner/
              - generic [ref=e6767]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e6768]:
              - generic [ref=e6769]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e6770]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e6771]:
              - generic [ref=e6772]: <pubDate>
              - text: Thu, 25 Feb 2016 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e6773]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e6774]:
              - generic [ref=e6775]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2016/coding-myself-into-a-corner/
              - generic [ref=e6776]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e6777]:
              - generic [ref=e6778]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e6779]: term="Databse"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Databse
              - generic [ref=e6780]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e6781]:
              - generic [ref=e6782]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e6783]: term="Access"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Access
              - generic [ref=e6784]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e6785]:
              - generic [ref=e6786]: <description>
              - text: <p>I spend an awful lot of my working life adding new features and improvements to a legacy database system.</p> <p>A <strong>legacy</strong> system is an old method, technology, computer system, or application program, ‚Äúof, relating to, or being a previous or outdated computer system.‚Äù Often a pejorative term, referencing a system as &ldquo;<strong>legacy</strong>&rdquo; often implies that the system is out of date or in need of replacement.</p> <p>My particular legacy system is Microsoft Access. We use Microsoft Access to provide the front end for all our internal databases. The particular technology we use is ADP files which are only supported in Access 2000, 2003 or 2010.</p> <p>Microsoft has already dropped support for Access 2000 and 2003, and support for 2010 is due to be dropped in 2020.</p> <p>So why am I coding myself into a corner? Its simple for every feature or improvement I create in Access, I increase the amount of features I need to create or port to a new front end.</p> <p>This is a very depressing thought, everything I create will need creating again. I am not saving myself work but increasing the amount of work I need to do again.</p> <p>The bad news is that my employers like almost all businesses demand results and like a good employee I have been delivering them. I have been promised the mythical ‚Äúwhen we are quiet‚Äù you can work on rebuilding the database front end. I know this will likely never happen so what are my options.</p> <p><strong>Do nothing</strong> I have warned my managers that this work needs doing and it is up to them to give me the resources I need. This is not an acceptable option. Firstly I am not future proofing the business, 2020 will be here before we know it. Also I am not developing myself as a developer, as the only experience I am getting is with Legacy technology that has expired or will do very soon. No one wants to employ someone who only has legacy experience.</p> <p><strong>Do something</strong> I need to keep delivering results and doing what is asked of me. Like any good engineer I should be multiplying my estimates by four, meaning that I have some time that can be used for looking at the bigger picture. This is a win-win option really. Employer gets a solution that is future proof, Employee gets valuable experience in up to date technology.</p> <p>What do you think? Have you been tied to legacy technology? Why not leave a comment below.</p>
              - generic [ref=e6787]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e6789]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e6790]:
          - generic [ref=e6793]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e6794]:
            - generic [ref=e6795]:
              - generic [ref=e6796]: <title>
              - text: Star Trek Episode Review The Best of Both Worlds
              - generic [ref=e6797]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e6798]:
              - generic [ref=e6799]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2016/star-trek-episode-review-the-best-of-both-worlds/
              - generic [ref=e6800]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e6801]:
              - generic [ref=e6802]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e6803]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e6804]:
              - generic [ref=e6805]: <pubDate>
              - text: Thu, 18 Feb 2016 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e6806]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e6807]:
              - generic [ref=e6808]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2016/star-trek-episode-review-the-best-of-both-worlds/
              - generic [ref=e6809]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e6810]:
              - generic [ref=e6811]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e6812]: term="StarTrek"
                - text: ">"
              - text: StarTrek
              - generic [ref=e6813]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e6814]:
              - generic [ref=e6815]: <description>
              - text: "<p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2016/Picard_kidnapped_by_the_Borg.jpg\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"1000\" height=\"865\" /> </p> <ul> <li>Episode Title: <strong>The Best of Both Worlds</strong></li> <li>Star Trek Type: TNG</li> <li>Original Air Date: 18 June 1990 &amp; 24 September 1990</li> <li>Written By: Michael Piller</li> <li>Directed By: Cliff Bole</li> </ul> <p>The Borg threaten the Federation, when they kidnap Captain Picard and destroy a fleet of 39 Starships. Luckily some original thinking from Commander Riker and Lieutenant Commander Shelby saves the Federation from assimilation.</p> <p>Thoughts: I love this episode! It is probably my favourite episode in the whole of trek. I can‚Äôt think of a single scene which I don‚Äôt like.</p> <p>It is a two parter that actually works best as a two parter. The moment that Riker orders the Enterprise to fire on the Borg is great. At the time some thought that Patrick Stewart might leave the show and be replaced by Riker/Shelby. I am very glad that didn‚Äôt happen but it is interesting to ponder what that might be like.</p> <p>The Borg soundtrack in this episode is great. Ron Jones really captures the spooky threat that the Borg are. I was always disappointed that some of that didn‚Äôt continue in First Contact and when the Borg return in Voyager.</p> <p>The episode has a cracking pace. From the moment the Borg first attack the Enterprise to the moment the Borg ship explodes the show doesn‚Äôt slow down.</p> <pre tabindex=\"0\"><code>I am Locutus‚Ä¶ of Borg. Resistance‚Ä¶ is futile. Your life, as it has been‚Ä¶ is over. From this time forward‚Ä¶ you will service‚Ä¶ us. </code></pre><p>Commander Shelby is a great character that enhances the episode and introduces conflict between characters, particularly Riker.</p> <p>I have heard that Riker‚Äôs thoughts about his career was a mirror to writer Michael Piller‚Äôs thoughts about leaving the show. Luckily for us he stayed.</p> <p>In a future episode of DS9 Worf comments that he felt there was nothing that they couldn‚Äôt do during this time. I have to agree the tag team of him and Data is a great one. If I want rescuing it would be Data and Worf that I would want.</p> <p>My good friends at <a href=\"http://www.trekmate.org.uk/the-best-of-both-worlds-tng-s3-e26-review-the-battle-bridge/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Trekmate</a> have just reviewed part one, why not have a listen?</p>"
              - generic [ref=e6816]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e6818]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e6819]:
          - generic [ref=e6822]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e6823]:
            - generic [ref=e6824]:
              - generic [ref=e6825]: <title>
              - text: My git repository is too large!
              - generic [ref=e6826]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e6827]:
              - generic [ref=e6828]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2016/my-git-repository-is-too-large/
              - generic [ref=e6829]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e6830]:
              - generic [ref=e6831]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e6832]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e6833]:
              - generic [ref=e6834]: <pubDate>
              - text: Thu, 11 Feb 2016 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e6835]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e6836]:
              - generic [ref=e6837]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2016/my-git-repository-is-too-large/
              - generic [ref=e6838]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e6839]:
              - generic [ref=e6840]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e6841]: term="Git"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Git
              - generic [ref=e6842]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e6843]:
              - generic [ref=e6844]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e6845]: term="SourceControl"
                - text: ">"
              - text: SourceControl
              - generic [ref=e6846]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e6847]:
              - generic [ref=e6848]: <description>
              - text: "<p>Today I did a clone of one of my git repositories and it took ages to download. Looking into what got downloaded it was easy to see why. The .git folder was over 500Mb in size.</p> <p>I know how this has happened. This repository was created in 2013 and has been used by me as a dumping ground for lots of things related to the code which never should have been committed.</p> <p>Since 2013 I have learnt a lot more about coding and git so the current version of the files in git isn‚Äôt too bad. But git keeps the history of changes for every file so bad practices like this are kept.</p> <p>What can I do about this? Well what does google suggest? I found this <code>http://stevelorek.com/how-to-shrink-a-git-repository.html</code> (link no longer exists).</p> <p>It suggests ways of listing all the large files that are stored in git and a way to remove them. As I am the only person that regularly commits to this repository I see no problem with giving it a go.</p> <p>I will summarise the steps here.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-txt\" data-lang=\"txt\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>git clone url </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now you need all the remote branches so there is a bash script to run</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\">#!/bin/bash </span></span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">for</span> branch in <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">`</span>git branch -a | grep remotes | grep -v HEAD | grep -v master<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">`</span>; <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">do</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>git branch ‚Äìtrack <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">${</span>branch##*/<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">}</span> $branch </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">done</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Another bash script then lists the top 10 large files</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-bash\" data-lang=\"bash\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\">#!/bin/bash </span></span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\">#set -x</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\"># Shows you the largest objects in your repo‚Äôs pack file.</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\"># Written for osx.</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\">#</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\"># @see http://stubbisms.wordpress.com/2009/07/10/git-script-to-show-largest-pack-objects-and-trim-your-waist-line/</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\"># @author Antony Stubbs</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\"># set the internal field spereator to line break, so that we can iterate easily over the verify-pack output</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>IFS<span style=\"color:#f92672\">=</span>$‚Äô<span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">\\n</span>‚Äô; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\"># list all objects including their size, sort by size, take top 10</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>objects<span style=\"color:#f92672\">=</span><span style=\"color:#e6db74\">`</span>git verify-pack -v .git/objects/pack/pack-*.idx | grep -v chain | sort -k3nr | head<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">`</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>echo ‚ÄúAll sizes are in kB. The pack column is the size of the object, compressed, inside the pack file.‚Äù </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>output<span style=\"color:#f92672\">=</span>‚Äúsize,pack,SHA,location‚Äù </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">for</span> y in $objects <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">do</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\"># extract the size in bytes</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>size<span style=\"color:#f92672\">=</span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">$((</span><span style=\"color:#e6db74\">`</span>echo $y | cut -f <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">5</span> -d ‚Äò ‚Äò<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">`</span><span style=\"color:#f92672\">/</span><span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">1024</span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">))</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\"># extract the compressed size in bytes</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>compressedSize<span style=\"color:#f92672\">=</span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">$((</span><span style=\"color:#e6db74\">`</span>echo $y | cut -f <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">6</span> -d ‚Äò ‚Äò<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">`</span><span style=\"color:#f92672\">/</span><span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">1024</span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">))</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\"># extract the SHA</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>sha<span style=\"color:#f92672\">=</span><span style=\"color:#e6db74\">`</span>echo $y | cut -f <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">1</span> -d ‚Äò ‚Äò<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">`</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\"># find the objects location in the repository tree</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>other<span style=\"color:#f92672\">=</span><span style=\"color:#e6db74\">`</span>git rev-list ‚Äìall ‚Äìobjects | grep $sha<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">`</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#75715e\">#lineBreak=`echo -e ‚Äú\\n‚Äù`</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>output<span style=\"color:#f92672\">=</span>‚Äú<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">${</span>output<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">}</span><span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">\\n</span><span style=\"color:#e6db74\">${</span>size<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">}</span>,<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">${</span>compressedSize<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">}</span>,<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">${</span>other<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">}</span>‚Äù </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">done</span> </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>echo -e $output </span></span></code></pre></div><p>After running the script you will see details of your largest files. I had *.msi and *.exe files in the mix. To remove them run the following, where filename is the path to the file that needs removing.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-txt\" data-lang=\"txt\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>git filter-branch ‚Äìtag-name-filter cat ‚Äìindex-filter ‚Äògit rm -r ‚Äìcached ‚Äìignore-unmatch filename‚Äô ‚Äìprune-empty -f ‚Äî ‚Äìall </span></span></code></pre></div><p>To reclaim the disk space run the following commands</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-txt\" data-lang=\"txt\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>rm -rf .git/refs/original/ </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>git reflog expire ‚Äìexpire=now ‚Äìall </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>git gc ‚Äìprune=now </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>git gc ‚Äìaggressive ‚Äìprune=now </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now push your changes back to the remote server.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-txt\" data-lang=\"txt\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>git push origin ‚Äìforce ‚Äìall </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>git push origin ‚Äìforce ‚Äìtags </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now if you do a clone it will be much smaller than before and you can get back to coding much quicker, without having to wait.</p>"
              - generic [ref=e6849]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e6851]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e6852]:
          - generic [ref=e6855]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e6856]:
            - generic [ref=e6857]:
              - generic [ref=e6858]: <title>
              - text: SQL Transaction Log Backups
              - generic [ref=e6859]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e6860]:
              - generic [ref=e6861]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2016/transaction-log-backups/
              - generic [ref=e6862]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e6863]:
              - generic [ref=e6864]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e6865]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e6866]:
              - generic [ref=e6867]: <pubDate>
              - text: Thu, 04 Feb 2016 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e6868]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e6869]:
              - generic [ref=e6870]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2016/transaction-log-backups/
              - generic [ref=e6871]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e6872]:
              - generic [ref=e6873]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e6874]: term="Database"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Database
              - generic [ref=e6875]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e6876]:
              - generic [ref=e6877]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e6878]: term="SQL"
                - text: ">"
              - text: SQL
              - generic [ref=e6879]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e6880]:
              - generic [ref=e6881]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e6882]: term="Backups"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Backups
              - generic [ref=e6883]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e6884]:
              - generic [ref=e6885]: <description>
              - text: <p>Like many DBAs I spend a lot of time maintaining my SQL Server backups.</p> <p>From SQL Server I maintain both full backups and transaction log backups. I have often restored my full backups but until recently I have never restored a transaction log backup. All backup strategy‚Äôs are only as good as the last time you tested the restore process.</p> <h2 id="so-what-is-a-transaction-log-backup">So what is a transaction log backup?<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#so-what-is-a-transaction-log-backup"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p>A transaction log backup contains all the transaction log records generated since the last full backup and is used to allow the database to be recovered to a specific point in time (usually the time right before a disaster strikes). Since these are incremental, if you want to restore the database to a particular point in time, you need to have all the transaction log records necessary to replay database changes up to that point in time.</p> <h2 id="how-to-do-the-restore">How to do the restore.<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#how-to-do-the-restore"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p>First right click on Databases in SQL Management Studio and select restore database. You should then get a screen similar to this.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2016/restore1.jpg" loading="lazy" width="878" height="732" /> </p> <p>In source click the &hellip; to allow you to select your backup files.</p> <p>Now normally I have only ever selected one file here, the *.bak file. Instead select the *.bak and all the *.trn files as well. After SQL Server has chugged for a few minutes (time will depend on number of transaction files and server/disk speed etc) the restore plan section should fill up with files.</p> <p>In the destination database box, type in the name of the database you want to restore. I recommend using a different name to avoid overwriting the original database, appending Test or a datetime to the name is what I usually do.</p> <p>On my test server I need to untick the take tail-log backups option off the options screen before I can execute the restore.</p> <p>Now you can either check the tick boxes in the restore plan section or (more fun) click the timeline button to select at what point in time you want to restore to.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2016/restore2.jpg" loading="lazy" width="797" height="474" /> </p> <p>You can either select the point in time with your mouse or specify the exact point in the time textbox. Alternatively you can just select the most recent point, probably the most likely option when disaster strikes.</p> <p>Now that I have tried doing this on my test server I feel much more confident that when disaster does strike I can get things restored quickly and painlessly.</p> <h2 id="how-often-should-you-run-transaction-backups">How often should you run transaction backups?<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#how-often-should-you-run-transaction-backups"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p>The answer to this question depends on how critical your data is. Until very recently I ran mine ever 15 minutes, I have increased this to every 5 minutes, but I have seen recommendations of running it <a href="https://www.brentozar.com/archive/2014/02/back-transaction-logs-every-minute-yes-really/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">every minute</a> . The more critical your data the more often you should run them.</p>
              - generic [ref=e6886]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e6888]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e6889]:
          - generic [ref=e6892]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e6893]:
            - generic [ref=e6894]:
              - generic [ref=e6895]: <title>
              - text: Development Annoyance
              - generic [ref=e6896]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e6897]:
              - generic [ref=e6898]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2016/development-annoyance/
              - generic [ref=e6899]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e6900]:
              - generic [ref=e6901]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e6902]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e6903]:
              - generic [ref=e6904]: <pubDate>
              - text: Fri, 29 Jan 2016 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e6905]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e6906]:
              - generic [ref=e6907]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2016/development-annoyance/
              - generic [ref=e6908]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e6909]:
              - generic [ref=e6910]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e6911]: term="Agile"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Agile
              - generic [ref=e6912]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e6913]:
              - generic [ref=e6914]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e6915]: term="SQL"
                - text: ">"
              - text: SQL
              - generic [ref=e6916]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e6917]:
              - generic [ref=e6918]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e6919]: term="Project"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Project
              - generic [ref=e6920]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e6921]:
              - generic [ref=e6922]: <description>
              - text: <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2016/How-you-can-stop-annoyance-or-frustrations-quickly.jpg" loading="lazy" width="425" height="282" /> </p> <p>I spend a lot of my time creating new features that simplify my companies business processes.</p> <p>A good example of this is an invoicing system I created. Instead of users working off different spreadsheets and copying and pasting data between various different programs the user can click a couple of buttons and everything is done and they can move on to the next task.</p> <p>I am currently expanding this system so more of the companies work can be invoiced quickly and simply.</p> <h2 id="i-like-working-on-this-kind-of-problem">I like working on this kind of problem<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#i-like-working-on-this-kind-of-problem"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p>I get to discuss with the different departments involved, finding out how they work and what could make their lives better.</p> <p>I then get to look at what structures already exist in the database and get to rip out anything that makes no sense (Today I had a Customer table which has a primary key called ClientId ‚Äì its now a Client table with PK ClientId) and add new structures to store new information.</p> <p>I then can build a user interface so the users can interact with the data.</p> <p>But the most important part of the process comes next. This is when I show the users what I have built and how it will make their lives better, they can then feed back to me questions and comments. How do I do x?, what about y?, have you thought about z?</p> <p>After this very valuable feedback I can go back and tweak what I have done making it better and better until the users think it is suitable for what they need.</p> <h2 id="now-why-did-i-call-this-post-development-annoyance">Now why did I call this post development annoyance?<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#now-why-did-i-call-this-post-development-annoyance"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p>I find it intensely annoying that after spending weeks of my time working on creating something to be used. Users either make do with my solution and never tell me the one thing that really annoys them or worse they go back to the time consuming process and never feedback the one or two changes I need to make to complete the project.</p> <p>Now I am not perfect, like many IT people my people skills are somewhat lacking but apart from asking people what can you do to get the feedback you need to complete the project?</p> <p>I do not have the knowledge that other departments have so I consider development a team effort that requires everyone to contribute otherwise it will not finish.</p> <p>The second outcome where users return to their old ways is the most annoying. It could well be months or even years before I find out that what I created is not being used any more. By that time my memory of what I did and more importantly why I did what I did has been lost and forgotten.</p> <p>So users please, please tell me what works and what doesn‚Äôt and what things I can do to improve things. I want my solutions to constantly improve and get better and I can only do that with your help.</p>
              - generic [ref=e6923]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e6925]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e6926]:
          - generic [ref=e6929]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e6930]:
            - generic [ref=e6931]:
              - generic [ref=e6932]: <title>
              - text: Star Trek Episode Review Arena
              - generic [ref=e6933]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e6934]:
              - generic [ref=e6935]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2016/star-trek-episode-review-arena/
              - generic [ref=e6936]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e6937]:
              - generic [ref=e6938]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e6939]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e6940]:
              - generic [ref=e6941]: <pubDate>
              - text: Thu, 21 Jan 2016 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e6942]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e6943]:
              - generic [ref=e6944]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2016/star-trek-episode-review-arena/
              - generic [ref=e6945]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e6946]:
              - generic [ref=e6947]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e6948]: term="StarTrek"
                - text: ">"
              - text: StarTrek
              - generic [ref=e6949]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e6950]:
              - generic [ref=e6951]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e6952]: term="Gorn"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Gorn
              - generic [ref=e6953]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e6954]:
              - generic [ref=e6955]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e6956]: term="Arena"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Arena
              - generic [ref=e6957]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e6958]:
              - generic [ref=e6959]: <description>
              - text: "<p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2016/Gorn.jpg\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"662\" height=\"977\" /> </p> <ul> <li>Episode Title: <strong>Arena</strong></li> <li>Star Trek Type: TOS</li> <li>Original Air Date: 19 January 1967</li> <li>Teleplay: Gene L Coon</li> <li>Story By: Frederic Brown</li> <li>Directed By: Joseph Pevney</li> </ul> <p>The episode begins with the Enterprise in orbit of Cestus III. Commodore Travers requests a tactical team join the away team. When the away team beam down Cestus III has been destroyed.</p> <p>Spock detects non-human life signs, obviously the aliens that destroyed the outpost. They attack the Enterprise, stranding the away team who are under heavy fire. Sulu is instructed to do whatever he can to protect the Enterprise and leaves orbit.</p> <p>Kirk finds the armoury and a grenade launcher, after firing the enemy withdraws.</p> <p>After beaming back aboard the Enterprise they pursue the unknown enemy into uncharted space. One of the survivors of Cestus III explains that the enemy attacked without warning.</p> <p>Kirk is determined to destroy the enemy ship before it reaches home and the Enterprise prepares for battle.</p> <p>An unknown solar system scans the Enterprise as they continue their pursuit of the enemy ship. The enemy ship comes to a complete stop. The Enterprise prepares to attack but before they can they also come to a complete stop. The Metrons have stopped both ships because both ships were on a mission of violence. The captains of both ships will be placed on a planet where the winner can destroy the other.</p> <p>Captain Kirk and the enemy captain appear on a desert planet. The enemy is a reptilian like species called the Gorn. The Gorn has superior strength to humans but Kirk manages to escape his first encounter.</p> <pre tabindex=\"0\"><code>&#34;This is Captain James Kirk of the Starship Enterprise. Whoever finds this, please get it to Starfleet Command. I‚Äôm engaged in personal combat with a creature apparently called a Gorn. He‚Äôs immensely strong. Already, he has withstood attacks from me that would have killed a Human being. Fortunately, though strong, he is not agile. The agility and I hope the cleverness, is mine.&#34; </code></pre><p>The Metrons said that the planet contained materials to allow the building of a weapon, however at first glance Kirk sees nothing that could help him defeat the much strong Gorn captain. He does find some diamonds, too small to be used as a weapon.</p> <p>Kirk pushes a huge boulder over a cliff onto the Gorn captain, which appears to knock him out, however he survives and Kirk barely escapes. Kirk then finds Sulphur, which triggers a memory.</p> <p>The Metrons allow the Enterprise to watch the last stages of Kirks struggle. They see Kirk discover Potassium Nitrate. The Gorn accuses the Federation of trespassing into their space.</p> <p>Kirk starts constructing a weapon using the diamonds, sulphur and potassium nitrate to make a gunpowder explosion to fire the diamonds at the Gorn captain. Just in time he applies a spark to his weapon and his opponent lies defeated.</p> <p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2016/Gorn_Kirk_cannon.jpg\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"600\" height=\"450\" /> </p> <p>Kirk refused to kill the Gorn captain as they may have been just defending themselves. The Metron announces that Kirk has displayed the advanced trait of mercy and there may be hope for humanity after all.</p> <p>Thoughts: I like this episode very much. It has some classic Star Trek ideas in it.</p> <p>We have a super powerful alien race (the Metrons) that think there is hope for humanity.</p> <p>We have Kirk using raw materials to construct a weapon using simple chemistry.</p> <p>We have an enemy race that appears destructive but may have just been defending themselves.</p> <p>We have the classic location of Vasquez Rocks, somewhere that if I ever visit the US I have to visit.</p> <p>We have the very cheesy Gorn mask, yes its not realistic but the story is strong enough that it doesn‚Äôt really matter. Enterprise brought back the Gorn but as a CGI character and I think I may prefer the rubber mask.</p> <p>Interestingly the weapon Kirk builds would likely not work. The US show MythBusters proved that the bamboo wasn‚Äôt strong enough to hold the explosion and the weapon would likely wound Kirk as much as it would wound the Gorn.</p> <p>Score: 10/10 Redshirt Count: Cestus III Outpost, 1 Red Shirt and 1 yellow shirt from away team.</p>"
              - generic [ref=e6960]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e6962]: </item>

              - generic [ref=e6970]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e6971]:

              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2016/disaster-planning/
              - generic [ref=e6973]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e6974]:
              - generic [ref=e6975]: <author>

              - generic [ref=e6976]: </author>

              - generic [ref=e6979]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e6980]:
              - generic [ref=e6981]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2016/disaster-planning/
              - generic [ref=e6982]: </guid>

              - text: BT
              - generic [ref=e6990]: </category>

                - text: ">"
              - text: Outage

            - generic [ref=e6995]:
              - generic [ref=e6996]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e6997]: term="Flood"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Flood
              - generic [ref=e6998]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e6999]:
              - generic [ref=e7000]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e7001]: term="Phone"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Phone
              - generic [ref=e7002]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e7003]:
              - generic [ref=e7004]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e7005]: term="Internet"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Internet
              - generic [ref=e7006]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e7007]:
              - generic [ref=e7008]: <description>
              - text: <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2016/flood.jpg" loading="lazy" width="2325" height="2325" /> </p> <p>Over the Christmas break the city of York experienced the worst flooding disaster it has seen in recent years. If you want to help donations are being taken at <a href="https://mydonate.bt.com/events/yorkfloodappeal/272657" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">York Flood Appeal</a> .</p> <p>Luckily I wasn‚Äôt affected but it was really sad seeing many of my favourite streets full of water. Thousands of people had to be evacuated from their homes when the water was at its highest.</p> <p>York has its phone exchange located in the centre of the city and as the flood waters rose, this building flooded. BT who run the exchange worked flat out trying to restore phone and broadband services to York and the surrounding area, but this lead to at least 24 hours or more of downtime for users.</p> <p>During this time most of the city wasn‚Äôt able to take card payments from customers (due to an internet connection being required), cash machines were not working for the same reasons and the most worrying thing access to emergency services was not available.</p> <blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p lang="en" dir="ltr">Anyone would think the city phones were down <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/yorkfloods?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">#yorkfloods</a> <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/bthardatwork?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">#bthardatwork</a> <a href="https://t.co/ZavLMsG2Js">pic.twitter.com/ZavLMsG2Js</a></p>&mdash; Simon Foster (@funkysi1701) <a href="https://twitter.com/funkysi1701/status/681439632886738944?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">December 28, 2015</a></blockquote> <script async src="https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script> <p>I am in no way critical of the hard working engineers that worked on the BT exchange to restore services to the city. However I have to ask what was contained in the BT disaster recovery plan.</p> <p>As an IT Manager myself backups and disaster planning is something I need to think about and plan for. Recent investment in our internet connection meant that we are now on a leased line so BTs downtime would not have affected us in terms of network connectivity, I am uncertain about phone but I believe as a business we could have continued running during this time if we needed to.</p> <p>Planning for a disaster is not something I ever make enough time, however I definitely want to spend more time on it and I do have the basics of a plan in my head which is probably more than BT has.</p> <p>BT is a huge company they run almost the entire country‚Äôs phone lines and according to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BT_Group" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">wikipedia</a> have operations in 170 countries. I think that they can afford to have someone plan for disaster recovery.</p> <p>The York Exchange is located next to a river that often floods. What could the company have done to avoid this problem?</p> <ol> <li>Relocate some or all of its services to a location away from the river.</li> <li>Add the ability to reroute services through an alternative exchange.</li> <li>Many towns and villages surrounding York use the BT exchange surely some of these could have been configured to use other exchanges.</li> </ol> <p>In these days of terror alerts and bomb scares. Imagine if York was London and all it took to take down communication ability of the capital was one Exchange to be offline?</p> <p>I am sure BT are looking at what they did right and what they did wrong and if you are reading this have a look at your own disaster recovery policy. Don‚Äôt get caught out like BT did.</p>
              - generic [ref=e7009]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e7011]: </item>

          - generic [ref=e7016]:

              - generic [ref=e7019]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e7020]:

              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2016/top-50-star-trek-episodes/
              - generic [ref=e7022]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e7023]:
              - generic [ref=e7024]: <author>

              - generic [ref=e7025]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e7026]:

              - generic [ref=e7028]: </pubDate>

              - text: Voyager

              - text: DeepSpaceNine

              - text: Kirk
              - generic [ref=e7051]: </category>

                - text: <category
