          - generic [ref=e7512]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e7513]:
            - generic [ref=e7514]:
              - generic [ref=e7515]: <title>
              - text: Copying settings to an Azure Website
              - generic [ref=e7516]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e7517]:
              - generic [ref=e7518]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/copying-settings-to-an-azure-website/
              - generic [ref=e7519]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e7520]:
              - generic [ref=e7521]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e7522]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e7523]:
              - generic [ref=e7524]: <pubDate>
              - text: Thu, 01 Oct 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e7525]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e7526]:
              - generic [ref=e7527]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/copying-settings-to-an-azure-website/
              - generic [ref=e7528]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e7529]:
              - generic [ref=e7530]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e7531]: term="Clouds"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Clouds
              - generic [ref=e7532]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e7533]:
              - generic [ref=e7534]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e7535]: term="Azure"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Azure
              - generic [ref=e7536]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e7537]:
              - generic [ref=e7538]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e7539]: term="DevOps"
                - text: ">"
              - text: DevOps
              - generic [ref=e7540]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e7541]:
              - generic [ref=e7542]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e7543]: term="Powershell"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Powershell
              - generic [ref=e7544]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e7545]:
              - generic [ref=e7546]: <description>
              - text: "<p>The Software as a Service (SaaS) website that I work on has been sold to lots of clients now. Which is great news.</p> <p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/09/2275.app-1.png\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"550\" height=\"240\" /> </p> <p>However the more Azure websites we have, the more websites we have to administer, especially if like us you take advantage of Traffic Manager which requires multiple website in different regions. Azure has some great options for making this administration easier. One job is adding all the settings onto the Azure portal, so far I have been manually adding these, but a quicker way is to use powershell.</p> <h2 id=\"powershell\">PowerShell<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#powershell\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>PowerShell is everywhere these days. You can use it to control Servers, Active Directory and Exchange. So it is no surprise that you can use it to control Azure.</p> <p>Open a powershell window and run the following command.</p> <pre tabindex=\"0\"><code>Get-AzurePublishSettingsFile </code></pre><p>This command opens an IE window which you can login to Azure and download a file which contains settings that Azure can use. Save the *.publishsettings file and run the following command.</p> <pre tabindex=\"0\"><code>Import-AzurePublishSettingsFile &#34;C:\\MyPublishSettings\\mysubscriptions.publishsettings&#34; </code></pre><p>This imports your Azure settings so that PowerShell can do clever things.</p> <pre tabindex=\"0\"><code>Select-AzureSubscription -Default &#34;mysubscription&#34; </code></pre><p>This selects which of your Azure subscriptions to use. Now run the following to import settings into PowerShell.</p> <pre tabindex=\"0\"><code>$s = @{&#34;DebugEmailAccount&#34;=&#34;test@example.com&#34;;&#34;SiteWarningBannerText&#34;=&#34;&#34;} </code></pre><p>And finally run the following to import this settings into the Azure website you specified.</p> <pre tabindex=\"0\"><code>Set-AzureWebsite azure-websitename -AppSettings $s </code></pre><p>Sounds easy doesn‚Äôt it. Well it is. The hardest part is getting the settings in the correct format to be imported but this is only string manipulation.</p> <p>For my project I already have a build script which populates a settings.config file with all these settings, so I have just duplicated this to create a settings.config.importtoAzure file. Next time I have a website to create, I can create it on Azure and run the above script, pasting in the settings file that my build has already produced for me.</p> <p>This only scratches the surface of what you can do with Azure and PowerShell, hopefully I will do far more in the future.</p>"
              - generic [ref=e7547]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e7549]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e7550]:
          - generic [ref=e7553]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e7554]:
            - generic [ref=e7555]:
              - generic [ref=e7556]: <title>
              - text: Adding Internet Connection Resiliency
              - generic [ref=e7557]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e7558]:
              - generic [ref=e7559]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/adding-internet-connection-resiliency/
              - generic [ref=e7560]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e7561]:
              - generic [ref=e7562]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e7563]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e7564]:
              - generic [ref=e7565]: <pubDate>
              - text: Thu, 24 Sep 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e7566]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e7567]:
              - generic [ref=e7568]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/adding-internet-connection-resiliency/
              - generic [ref=e7569]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e7570]:
              - generic [ref=e7571]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e7572]: term="Fibre"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Fibre
              - generic [ref=e7573]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e7574]:
              - generic [ref=e7575]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e7576]: term="VPN"
                - text: ">"
              - text: VPN
              - generic [ref=e7577]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e7578]:
              - generic [ref=e7579]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e7580]: term="Internet"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Internet
              - generic [ref=e7581]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e7582]:
              - generic [ref=e7583]: <description>
              - text: <p>I have been asked to investigate adding a fail over internet connection to one of our offices.</p> <p>Currently this office is connected via a wireless link with our head office. Unfortunately we have recently experienced some poor performance with this connection, this has now been corrected but like all technology there is the chance of it failing in some way in the future and causing loss of business because of it.</p> <h2 id="internet-connection">Internet Connection<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#internet-connection"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p>This is one of my first considerations. I need a reliable internet connection and there are a lot of options to consider, lets look at a few.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="Internet Connection" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/internet-connection-drops-every-couple-minutes-cable-sxchu-internet1.jpg" loading="lazy" width="2193" height="837" /> </p> <p><strong>ADSL Connection</strong> This is your standard internet connection that most homes have, you get around 20Mb/s download but only 2Mb/s upload for a fairly low price per month. Speeds are dependent on area and the quality and distance from your exchange, some rural areas have speeds much lower than this. As this connection is for an office I want the best connection I can afford so would rather not go down this option if I can avoid it.</p> <p><strong>FTTC (Fibre to the Cabinet)</strong> This is what ISPs typically mean when they say superfast broadband. The cables that have been laid to your exchange cabinet have been upgraded to fibre optic cables which are capable of much faster transfer speeds (eg 40Mb/s download and 10Mb/s upload). This is my ideal choice, however BT Openreach are responsible for upgrading the country to these cables and they are not very quick about it. A few years back when investigating this FTTC had almost reached our office, but when I investigated today nothing seems to have progressed. Both FTTC and ADSL require a phone line into the office to run on.</p> <p><strong>Leased Line</strong> This is where your ISP connects a dedicated line to your office which provides you a much faster connection (upload and download speeds are the same) but this is very expensive. We have this for our head office as this is where our servers are located and the faster speed benefits the entire company. We do not want to do this for every branch office as it will be too expensive.</p> <p><strong>Spur from a Leased Line</strong> It could be possible to branch or spur off the leased line to our second office. This would be one leased line that terminates in two locations instead of one. However due to the distances involved I do not think this will be possible in my case and may end up costing as much as a second leased line.</p> <p><strong>ISP</strong> As well as the type of connection I need to decide who will provide it. There are hundreds of ISPs out there but I like to use ISPs that have a good reputation or I have used in the past and have been happy with. I do not stick with one ISP for all my connections as I like to have some connections that continue to work should that ISP be experiencing problems. ISPs that I would recommend are YDS, Eclipse and PlusNet</p> <p><strong>Money Off</strong> While I am talking about internet connections the government has been offering a scheme offering businesses money off upgrading their connections to a superfast connection (either FTTC or Leased Line) More information can be found on your councils website, If you have an office in York have a look here for more details. We got ¬£3000 off installation so worth investigating if you qualify.</p> <h2 id="vpn-connection">VPN Connection<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#vpn-connection"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p>Offices require access to far more resources than just the internet. This particular office requires access to our email and database servers as a bare minimum. One way to access a remote offices network resources is through a VPN (Virtual Private Network) connection. So my next consideration is how to establish a VPN link between our offices.</p> <p><strong>Software</strong> Windows Server includes RRAS (Routing and Remote Access Service) which you can use to configure a VPN connection. One important thing to note is that the server needs at least two network connections, one on the internet with a public IP and one on the internal network.</p> <p><strong>Hardware</strong> The more expensive routers often have settings that allow the configuration of a VPN connection.</p> <p>I have used both of these methods in the past. RRAS is a pain to work with but has evolved with the newer versions of windows server, so may not be as bad as I remember. Using a router to do VPN introduces its own set of problems and there is no guarantee of avoiding RRAS, you may still need it to authenticate the VPN provided by your router.</p> <h2 id="multiple-connection-handling">Multiple Connection Handling<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#multiple-connection-handling"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p>Internet connectivity is being provided in two ways, the primary way is via a Wireless link and the second way is via one of the options above.</p> <p>There are lots of options to deal with multiple connections, do I want to load balance both connections and use them all the time, do I want to fail over onto the second connection only if the first one fails, or do I want it to be a manual process or switching over to the backup network if problems occur.</p> <p>As you can see there are lots of different technologies to consider before I can add resiliency to this office and I haven‚Äôt even started to think about if an additional server will be required.</p>
              - generic [ref=e7584]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e7586]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e7587]:
          - generic [ref=e7590]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e7591]:
            - generic [ref=e7592]:
              - generic [ref=e7593]: <title>
              - text: Unmanaged Database Deployment
              - generic [ref=e7594]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e7595]:
              - generic [ref=e7596]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/unmanaged-database-deployment/
              - generic [ref=e7597]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e7598]:
              - generic [ref=e7599]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e7600]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e7601]:
              - generic [ref=e7602]: <pubDate>
              - text: Thu, 10 Sep 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e7603]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e7604]:
              - generic [ref=e7605]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/unmanaged-database-deployment/
              - generic [ref=e7606]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e7607]:
              - generic [ref=e7608]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e7609]: term="SQL"
                - text: ">"
              - text: SQL
              - generic [ref=e7610]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e7611]:
              - generic [ref=e7612]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e7613]: term="Backups"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Backups
              - generic [ref=e7614]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e7615]:
              - generic [ref=e7616]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e7617]: term="Deployment"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Deployment
              - generic [ref=e7618]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e7619]:
              - generic [ref=e7620]: <description>
              - text: <p>For the past few months I have been deploying changes to my companies database every couple of weeks or so. Over a weekend when the database was not being used I would make a backup of the database, load up visual studio, deploy the database changes and copy a couple of front-end files.</p> <p>My weekends and evenings have recently become a bit more precious to me since the arrival of my son James. At suitable times to run the database upgrade I am either, asleep, about to fall asleep or be spending time with James.</p> <p>This entire deployment can be set to run at a time of my choosing using SQL Server Jobs, (not sure why I never thought of doing this before). I still need to check everything is working after it has run. The job can send me an email if it encounters any problems so I can still ensure the company has the minimum of problems but has more frequent changes.</p> <h2 id="unmanaged-database-deployment">Unmanaged Database Deployment<a class="anchor ms-1" href="#unmanaged-database-deployment"><i class="fas fa-link"></i></a></h2> <p>OK so what do I need to do to set this up.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/09/deploy.jpg" loading="lazy" width="711" height="811" /> </p> <ol> <li>Test all your code changes are working correctly on a backup of the database and everything is committed to source control.</li> <li>Backup everything that is going to be changed so it can be rolled back in case of a problem. I don‚Äôt rely on the daily backup jobs for this, I do my own. Maybe I am a bit paranoid, or maybe I am just being cautious.</li> </ol> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" style="color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;"><code class="language-sql" data-lang="sql"><span style="display:flex;"><span>BACKUP <span style="color:#66d9ef">DATABASE</span> DBName <span style="color:#66d9ef">TO</span> DISK<span style="color:#f92672">=</span><span style="color:#e6db74">&#39;E:\SQL Backups\Filename.bak&#39;</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>I would include in the backup file name the date and time of the deployment for easy reference later on. For the front-end files these are backed up daily and only ever change during a deployment so I am going to rely on the day to day backups, plus they are in source control so in a worse case scenario I can look there.</p> <ol start="3"> <li>From Visual Studio create a deployment script using the publish option and save as a file on your database server.</li> <li>Create a SQL Server Job and give it a descriptive name.</li> <li>In steps create a step called backup and enter the T-SQL code above. Set this to stop on failure and continue on success.</li> <li>Create a second step called upgrade of type operating system with the following code.</li> </ol> <pre tabindex="0"><code>sqlcmd -S (local) -i &#34;E:\SQL Backups\deploy_test.sql&#34; </code></pre><p>The -S parameter is the name of your SQL Server instance and the -i parameter is the path to the sql script you generated from Visual Studio above. Set this job to quit reporting success or failure.</p> <ol start="7"> <li>In schedule create a date time you want the job to run, make sure this is a one time job as you don‚Äôt want it to try and run again possibly causing problems.</li> <li>In notifications I have set to email on completion, you can set it to email on failure only. I would prefer to know the outcome of the job regardless.</li> <li>Using SQL Server jobs to copy files over the network is possible but is not trivial to setup so I am going to use windows task scheduler for this.</li> <li>Create a job in task scheduler to copy all the ADPs or ADEs that have been changed. If the SQL job fails you will need to copy the old versions of these back but that is simple enough to do.</li> </ol> <p>This process can be expanded to check code out of source control and do even more automated deployments but for now this is good enough for my purposes.</p>
              - generic [ref=e7621]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e7623]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e7624]:
          - generic [ref=e7627]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e7628]:
            - generic [ref=e7629]:
              - generic [ref=e7630]: <title>
              - text: Baby Magic and Becoming a Father
              - generic [ref=e7631]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e7632]:
              - generic [ref=e7633]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/baby-magic-and-becoming-a-father/
              - generic [ref=e7634]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e7635]:
              - generic [ref=e7636]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e7637]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e7638]:
              - generic [ref=e7639]: <pubDate>
              - text: Thu, 03 Sep 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e7640]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e7641]:
              - generic [ref=e7642]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/baby-magic-and-becoming-a-father/
              - generic [ref=e7643]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e7644]:
              - generic [ref=e7645]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e7646]: term="Father"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Father
              - generic [ref=e7647]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e7648]:
              - generic [ref=e7649]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e7650]: term="Baby"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Baby
              - generic [ref=e7651]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e7652]:
              - generic [ref=e7653]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e7654]: term="Family"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Family
              - generic [ref=e7655]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e7656]:
              - generic [ref=e7657]: <description>
              - text: <p>I am pleased to announce the birth of James David Martin Foster weighing 9 lb 12 on 19th August 2015.</p> <p>Mother and Baby (and Father) are doing well.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/07/james5.jpg" loading="lazy" width="1080" height="810" /> </p> <p>I am not a baby person, I hate children and I run a mile from other people‚Äôs babies.</p> <p>But James performed some magic on me and now I will do anything for him. If you have had children you probably know what I am talking about and if you haven‚Äôt you are probably like me 24 hours before James arrived.</p> <p>During the pregnancy I had been living in denial that I would become a father, despite the wife speaking about nothing else and our home filing with baby equipment. It was only minutes before I first saw my son that I changed.</p> <p>Due to James‚Äôs large size, the birth wasn‚Äôt easy. After about an hour of pushing the midwife called in a team of doctors and nurses to help and I think it was at this point that it started to hit me. I am not an emotional man, if anything I tend to repress my feelings but I completely and utterly failed to do that on this occasion. By the time the baby had been placed on my wife‚Äôs chest tears of joy were streaming down my face and this continued for some time. Moments after birth James had a tight grip on my finger. His tiny hands were like miniature versions of my own hands.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="Baby James holding finger" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/08/jameshand.jpg" loading="lazy" width="562" height="1000" /> </p> <p>I have been asked what it felt like holding James in my arms for the first time, this happened on the following day. I am not sure if I can put it into words, but a few adjectives come to mind, amazing, great, fantastic, humbling. James depends on me (and his mother) for everything and his existence has put a new spin on everything I do. I want to be there for him, help him learn stuff, provide for him and love him.</p> <p>I have been working very hard recently, spending my free time writing this blog, learning stuff and doing other work. The reasons for this hard work are now clear, I work so I can provide for James and so I can spend my free time with him.</p> <p>Before James arrived I had it in my head that his mother would do the majority of the caring for him. This is not going to happen now that I have met James. I want to cuddle him, change his nappies, dress him, hold his hand, take him to school, watch TV with him, stroke his head when he is ill, tell him about my life experiences, introduce him to wine, tell him about girls, help him move home, etc.</p> <p>I am not saying being a parent is going to be easy. I am pretty clueless about what is in store for us, but already I am worrying if he is OK, trying to calm him down when he is upset and being woken in the early hours.</p> <p>Anyway only time will tell if I continue being this positive about fatherhood, but so far I am loving it. Normal blog posts will hopefully resume over the next few weeks (or when I have time).</p>
              - generic [ref=e7658]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e7660]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e7661]:
          - generic [ref=e7664]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e7665]:
            - generic [ref=e7666]:
              - generic [ref=e7667]: <title>
              - text: Due Dates
              - generic [ref=e7668]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e7669]:
              - generic [ref=e7670]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/due-dates/
              - generic [ref=e7671]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e7672]:
              - generic [ref=e7673]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e7674]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e7675]:
              - generic [ref=e7676]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 17 Aug 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e7677]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e7678]:
              - generic [ref=e7679]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/due-dates/
              - generic [ref=e7680]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e7681]:
              - generic [ref=e7682]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e7683]: term="DueDate"
                - text: ">"
              - text: DueDate
              - generic [ref=e7684]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e7685]:
              - generic [ref=e7686]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e7687]: term="Baby"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Baby
              - generic [ref=e7688]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e7689]:
              - generic [ref=e7690]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e7691]: term="Estimate"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Estimate
              - generic [ref=e7692]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e7693]:
              - generic [ref=e7694]: <description>
              - text: <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/08/928f90bcd221f78a30f18541a5ca2e7f.jpg" loading="lazy" width="404" height="337" /> As I write this I have less than 2 days until the due date for the birth of my first child.</p> <p>Its a very exciting time, but it is also infuriating waiting for it to arrive. Even in the 21st century science can not predict with any accuracy when a baby is going to arrive and we just have to wait for mother nature to do its thing.</p> <p>I feel like I am stuck in limbo at the moment I have lots of work to do, lots of development changes to do on the databases, but I also know that at a moments notice I need to drop what I am doing and try and be a father.</p> <p>Due dates for babies is based on average pregnancies lasting 40 weeks, but there is no such thing as an average pregnancy. But to keep this blog post on topic I somehow need to compare due dates for pregnancy with software development.</p> <p>In software development we often get asked for estimates on when a particular development task will be finished. Estimates in software development are very difficult to make accurate as there are so many variables that you do not know the answer to until you start getting stuck into doing the work. One technique is to try and split the work down into small steps and estimate how long each small step will take and then add them all together. But even this technique still has a large margin of error.</p> <p>What would it be like if when management asked we gave an estimate similar to what pregnant women receive? Instead of a deadline when all work has to be finished by, you have a date when there is a 50% chance of the work being finished.</p> <p>I think management would have a difficult time dealing with this amount of uncertainty, I certainly am waiting for this baby to arrive.</p>
              - generic [ref=e7695]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e7697]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e7698]:
          - generic [ref=e7701]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e7702]:
            - generic [ref=e7703]:
              - generic [ref=e7704]: <title>
              - text: How complex are my stored procedures?
              - generic [ref=e7705]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e7706]:
              - generic [ref=e7707]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/how-complex-are-my-stored-procedures/
              - generic [ref=e7708]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e7709]:
              - generic [ref=e7710]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e7711]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e7712]:
              - generic [ref=e7713]: <pubDate>
              - text: Thu, 13 Aug 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e7714]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e7715]:
              - generic [ref=e7716]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/how-complex-are-my-stored-procedures/
              - generic [ref=e7717]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e7718]:
              - generic [ref=e7719]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e7720]: term="Complexity"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Complexity
              - generic [ref=e7721]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e7722]:
              - generic [ref=e7723]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e7724]: term="SQL"
                - text: ">"
              - text: SQL
              - generic [ref=e7725]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e7726]:
              - generic [ref=e7727]: <description>
              - text: <p>Recently me and my development team have been looking at performance and how to improve it.</p> <p>One area of improvement we have identified is with our stored procedures, which we plan to rewrite. But how do we identify which are the easiest to rewrite and which are the hardest?</p> <p>My first thought was maybe to count the number of times each keyword is used and rank them somehow. eg each JOIN gets 5, OUTER APPLY gets 20, each term in WHERE gets 1, and then combine that with the length of the query and how many parameters.</p> <p>However doing a bit of googling I came across the following <a href="https://aalamrangi.wordpress.com/2012/12/24/calculate-tsql-stored-procedure-complexity" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">blog</a> and <a href="https://gallery.technet.microsoft.com/Calculate-TSQL-Stored-831b683a" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">sql script</a> . This script analyses the stored procedures in terms of number of lines of code, number of parameters and number of dependencies.</p> <p>The complexity is divided into SIMPLE, MEDIUM and COMPLEX.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>WHEN NumberOfLines * NumberOfDependencies * NumberOfParameters &lt; 5000 THEN ‚ÄòSimple‚Äô WHEN NumberOfLines * NumberOfDependencies * NumberOfParameters &lt; 10000 THEN ‚ÄòMedium‚Äô ELSE ‚ÄòComplex‚Äô </code></pre><p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/08/reportscreenshot1.png" loading="lazy" width="674" height="235" /> </p> <p>This gives a fairly good estimate of which stored procedures are the most complex and which would probably take the longest time to rewrite.</p>
              - generic [ref=e7728]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e7730]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e7731]:
          - generic [ref=e7734]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e7735]:
            - generic [ref=e7736]:
              - generic [ref=e7737]: <title>
              - text: ICYMI What does it mean?
              - generic [ref=e7738]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e7739]:
              - generic [ref=e7740]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/icymi-what-does-it-mean/
              - generic [ref=e7741]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e7742]:
              - generic [ref=e7743]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e7744]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e7745]:
              - generic [ref=e7746]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 10 Aug 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e7747]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e7748]:
              - generic [ref=e7749]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/icymi-what-does-it-mean/
              - generic [ref=e7750]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e7751]:
              - generic [ref=e7752]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e7753]: term="ICYMI"
                - text: ">"
              - text: ICYMI
              - generic [ref=e7754]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e7755]:
              - generic [ref=e7756]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e7757]: term="Learning"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Learning
              - generic [ref=e7758]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e7759]:
              - generic [ref=e7760]: <description>
              - text: <p>For a while now I have seen ICYMI splattered around the internet. I had no idea what it meant so just ignored it but I have finally had enough and I googled for a definition and I now know what it means.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>ICYMI ‚Äì In Case You Missed It </code></pre><p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/08/in-case-you-missed-it-small.jpg" loading="lazy" width="400" height="400" /> ICYMI is often used on social media sites to indicate articles that you might have missed.</p> <p>Software Development is littered with acronyms and technical terms that I don‚Äôt always know the meaning of.</p> <p>When reading it is easy to ignore them and try and understand the rest of the article. However there are loads of resources out there that can explain technical terms in a wide variety of different ways.</p> <p>I have tried to explain a few different terms and concepts on this <a href="https://www.funkysi1701.com/">blog</a> . In the process of writing them I often do a bit of research and read a variety of different definitions, some confuse the heck out of me, while others make me go ahh that makes sense now.</p> <p>When reading to learn, don‚Äôt be afraid to dig deeper and understand it all, don‚Äôt read the same terms again and again not understanding them like I did with ICYMI.</p>
              - generic [ref=e7761]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e7763]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e7764]:
          - generic [ref=e7767]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e7768]:
            - generic [ref=e7769]:
              - generic [ref=e7770]: <title>
              - text: Common git commands
              - generic [ref=e7771]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e7772]:
              - generic [ref=e7773]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/common-git-commands/
              - generic [ref=e7774]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e7775]:
              - generic [ref=e7776]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e7777]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e7778]:
              - generic [ref=e7779]: <pubDate>
              - text: Thu, 06 Aug 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e7780]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e7781]:
              - generic [ref=e7782]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/common-git-commands/
              - generic [ref=e7783]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e7784]:
              - generic [ref=e7785]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e7786]: term="Git"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Git
              - generic [ref=e7787]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e7788]:
              - generic [ref=e7789]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e7790]: term="SourceControl"
                - text: ">"
              - text: SourceControl
              - generic [ref=e7791]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e7792]:
              - generic [ref=e7793]: <description>
              - text: <p>I use git as my source control system. Here are some of the most common git commands in no particular order.</p> <ul> <li>Check Out a git Repository <strong>git clone /path/to/repository</strong></li> <li>Add files to commit <strong>git add <filename></strong></li> <li>Commit files to <strong>git git commit -m ‚ÄúCommit message‚Äù</strong></li> <li>Push changes to server <strong>git push origin master</strong></li> <li>Show status <strong>git status</strong></li> <li>Create new branch <strong>git checkout -b <branchname></strong></li> <li>Switch to a branch <strong>git checkout <branchname></strong></li> <li>Get remote changes <strong>git pull</strong></li> <li>Merge a different branch into the current one <strong>git merge <branchname></strong></li> <li>View merge conflicts <strong>git diff</strong></li> <li>Temporarily stash uncommitted changes <strong>git stash</strong></li> <li>Undo a commit <strong>git reset ‚Äìhard <commit></strong></li> <li>Show details about a commit <strong>git show <commit></strong></li> <li>Show version history of current branch <strong>git log</strong></li> <li>Gets all remote branches <strong>git fetch origin</strong></li> </ul> <p>Most of the time I use the <a href="https://sourceforge.net/projects/gitextensions/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">git extensions</a> tools to do my git work, but there are times when only the command line will do.</p>
              - generic [ref=e7794]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e7796]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e7797]:
          - generic [ref=e7800]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e7801]:
            - generic [ref=e7802]:
              - generic [ref=e7803]: <title>
              - text: Volunteering for a Technical Team
              - generic [ref=e7804]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e7805]:
              - generic [ref=e7806]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/volunteering-for-a-technical-team/
              - generic [ref=e7807]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e7808]:
              - generic [ref=e7809]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e7810]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e7811]:
              - generic [ref=e7812]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 03 Aug 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e7813]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e7814]:
              - generic [ref=e7815]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/volunteering-for-a-technical-team/
              - generic [ref=e7816]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e7817]:
              - generic [ref=e7818]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e7819]: term="EasyWorship"
                - text: ">"
              - text: EasyWorship
              - generic [ref=e7820]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e7821]:
              - generic [ref=e7822]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e7823]: term="Church"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Church
              - generic [ref=e7824]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e7825]:
              - generic [ref=e7826]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e7827]: term="Volunteers"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Volunteers
              - generic [ref=e7828]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e7829]:
              - generic [ref=e7830]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e7831]: term="Projection"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Projection
              - generic [ref=e7832]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e7833]:
              - generic [ref=e7834]: <description>
              - text: <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/20150802_113719.jpg" loading="lazy" width="5312" height="2988" /> For the past few years I have volunteered on the technical team at my local church <a href="http://www.belfrey.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">St Michael le Belfrey</a> .</p> <p>For the church to function well it requires volunteers in all sorts of roles, people to welcome visitors, people to pray, people to play music, people to look after children and many other roles.</p> <p>My natural ability lies more with technology than with people so when I decided that I wanted to get more involved it was the technical team that I volunteered for. The technical team is split into two main parts, the PA team which concerns itself with ensuring everyone can hear everything OK and the Projection team which concerns itself with everything that gets projected. I have no knowledge about what sounds good and what doesn‚Äôt so it was the projection team that I joined and have been involved with.</p> <p>The church has three projectors, one big one and two slightly smaller ones for the side aisles, and a PC located at the back of church which is what the projectionist uses to control what gets projected. There are many things that get projected, lyrics to songs, PowerPoint presentations and the occasional video and to make things easy one piece of software is used to control all of this <a href="https://www.easyworship.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">EasyWorship</a> .</p> <p>EasyWorship contains a huge database of song lyrics, so you can quickly select what ever is being sung and project the lyrics on screen. It also allows the addition of PowerPoint files, image or video files and even a web page and they can be projected. EasyWorship allows different things to be queued up in order and that order can be saved as a schedule.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/CFMwY_UUgAAc2k2.jpg" loading="lazy" width="600" height="450" /> </p> <p>The projectionist‚Äôs job is to follow along with the order of service and project things onto screen at the right time. Simple! No not really. The worship leader will skip songs, play songs in a different order, add new songs, videos will fail to play, easy worship will freeze up or crash or the liturgy that the vicar wants isn‚Äôt in the EasyWorship database.</p> <p>You need to be on your toes as a projectionist but over the years I have become a good projectionist and have really enjoyed my time doing this. You can see me having a laugh with the Head of Music and Worship on the right.</p> <p>More recently I have taken on a bigger role for the projection team. I have been coordinating the rota for the volunteers on the projection team. This has given me new challenges, but it has been great to work closely with the Technical Manager and more recently the Head of Music and Worship and get to know the whole team better. The biggest problem that the team has is insufficient volunteers, it had this problem when I joined the team and it has this problem today. If you are reading this consider if this is something you could get involved with? The team has some really hard working people who do an excellent job each week, just wish we had a few more to ease everyone‚Äôs work load.</p> <p>I am taking a break from the projection team as my wife is due to give birth to my first child in the next few days. I have had a great time, I have worked with some great people and for the most part I will miss volunteering. There are of course things that have not been great, volunteers that have left the team, changes at the church, and many early mornings when I would rather still be in bed but I am glad that I have been involved.</p>
              - generic [ref=e7835]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e7837]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e7838]:
          - generic [ref=e7841]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e7842]:

            - generic [ref=e7846]:

              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/upper-pylon-2-1-x-09-the-passenger/

              - generic [ref=e7851]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e7852]:
              - generic [ref=e7853]: <pubDate>

              - generic [ref=e7854]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e7855]:
              - generic [ref=e7856]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/upper-pylon-2-1-x-09-the-passenger/

            - generic [ref=e7858]:
              - generic [ref=e7859]:
                - text: <category

                - text: ">"
              - text: StarTrek
              - generic [ref=e7861]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e7862]:
              - generic [ref=e7863]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e7864]: term="podcast"
                - text: ">"
              - text: podcast
              - generic [ref=e7865]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e7866]:
              - generic [ref=e7867]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e7868]: term="trekmate"
                - text: ">"
              - text: trekmate
              - generic [ref=e7869]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e7870]:
              - generic [ref=e7871]: <description>
              - text: <p>I recorded another podcast the other week it can be found <a href="http://www.trekmate.org.uk/upper-pylon-2-1-x-09-the-passenger/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.trekmate.org.uk/upper-pylon-2-1-x-09-the-passenger/</a> and feedback about it can be left on the trekmate forums <a href="http://forum.trekmatefamily.com/2015/07/thoughts-on-up2s-the-passenger-or-vantika-x-33/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://forum.trekmatefamily.com/2015/07/thoughts-on-up2s-the-passenger-or-vantika-x-33/</a> </p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/07/Bashir-Choked.jpg" loading="lazy" width="638" height="480" /> </p> <p>This week on Upper Pylon 2, we are joined by our first UK guest, Simon (aka <a href="https://twitter.com/funkysi1701" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">funkysi1701</a> ) as we take a look at the Bashir-centric ‚Äúmystery‚Äù episode, ‚ÄúThe Passenger.‚Äù</p> <p>When a former prisioner, Rao Vantika (a name you‚Äôll hear COUNTLESS times throughout the episode) is killed, his pursuer believes that the late murderer is not really dead, and continues her investigation at DS9 while an important shipment is scheduled to arrive. Will Vantika reappear, and if so, who will he appear as? Well, if you‚Äôve seen the opening of the episode, it really isn‚Äôt all that hard to deduce. But join the UP2 crew as we dissect this little caper.</p> <p>As always, be sure to leave us your feedback about the episode!</p>
              - generic [ref=e7872]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e7874]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e7875]:
          - generic [ref=e7878]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e7879]:
            - generic [ref=e7880]:
              - generic [ref=e7881]: <title>
              - text: 10 facts about Windows 10
              - generic [ref=e7882]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e7883]:
              - generic [ref=e7884]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/10-facts-about-windows-10/
              - generic [ref=e7885]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e7886]:
              - generic [ref=e7887]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e7888]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e7889]:
              - generic [ref=e7890]: <pubDate>
              - text: Wed, 29 Jul 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e7891]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e7892]:
              - generic [ref=e7893]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/10-facts-about-windows-10/
              - generic [ref=e7894]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e7895]:
              - generic [ref=e7896]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e7897]: term="Microsoft"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Microsoft
              - generic [ref=e7898]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e7899]:
              - generic [ref=e7900]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e7901]: term="Windows10"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Windows10
              - generic [ref=e7902]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e7903]:
              - generic [ref=e7904]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e7905]: term="OperatingSystem"
                - text: ">"
              - text: OperatingSystem
              - generic [ref=e7906]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e7907]:
              - generic [ref=e7908]: <description>
              - text: <p>Today Microsoft release Windows 10 so what else can I talk about? I like many technology people are very excited today. This version of window is the first that Microsoft have release for free.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/07/Windows-10_Product-Family.jpg" loading="lazy" width="1920" height="1080" /> </p> <p>10 You heard that correct Windows 10 is <strong>free</strong>. If you upgrade your device to windows 10 before 29th July 2016 it is free and will continue working on that device forever.</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>Upgrade to Windows 10 within the first year and it is yours free, forever. No subscriptions, no additional costs. </code></pre><p>9 As with any upgrade always backup your computer and any important files before you do anything. Microsoft and any IT expert will tell you this. For a great guide to upgrading see Scott Hansleman‚Äôs <a href="http://www.hanselman.com/blog/GettingStartedWithWindows10.aspx" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">blog</a> . I have upgraded my laptop without any problems but there will always be exceptions so take extra care.</p> <p>8 Windows 10 is the <strong>LAST</strong> version of windows. I don‚Äôt know what this means but I can take a guess.</p> <p>Typically Microsoft has created a new version of windows every few years. With every new version there has come headaches and problems as people try to make software and hardware work with the next version. Microsoft is instead going to try and release updates and patches to the operating system to keep things up to date.</p> <p>However I can see that only working for so long. Eventually Microsoft will make something new but it is unlikely to be called Windows. Maybe it will be something hosted in the Cloud, as they have a really strong presence with Azure which is only going to grow as time goes on.</p> <p>7 Windows 10 is available in 7 different flavours.</p> <ul> <li>Windows 10 Home ‚Äì equivalent to the Home editions we have had since XP. This version is designed for your typical consumer.</li> <li>Windows 10 Mobile ‚Äì this version is designed to run on phones and tablets. Unlike previous Phone versions, everything you can find on the desktop OS should be available on the phone (but optimised for the smaller screens)</li> <li>Windows 10 Pro ‚Äì this is the version I will be testing with my work PCs. It is designed for small businesses and allows domain joining.</li> <li>Windows 10 Enterprise ‚Äì this version is only available via Volume Licensing so not easily available to the typical user but is aimed at larger businesses.</li> <li>Windows 10 Education ‚Äì another version that is only available via Volume Licensing but targeted at schools and universities.</li> <li>Windows 10 Mobile Enterprise ‚Äì this version is for mobile and tablets in the business world. Standard policies can be applied to all your employees mobile devices.</li> <li>Windows 10 IoT Core ‚Äì this is an interesting version designed to run on hardware and Internet of Things (IoT) devices. I would quite like to play with this version on my Raspberry Pi</li> </ul> <p>6 Windows 10 introduces a brand new web browser called Edge. For years web developers have hated Internet Explorer, for its lack of support for the latest web standards. Internet Explorer 6 caused many users to migrate away to browsers like firefox and later Chrome and despite Microsoft‚Äôs best effort with the later versions people have not moved back. Edge is an attempt at a fresh start.</p> <p>5 In 2011 Apple introduced the personal assistant Siri, well now Microsoft are bringing us <strong>Cortana</strong> the windows equivalent. With Cortana you can ask your computer to do anything, set reminders, search the internet, answer questions, anything. With advanced voice recognition you can speak as well as type your questions. Cortana is now part of Windows 10.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/05/win10.jpg" loading="lazy" width="888" height="537" /> </p> <p>4 Windows 10 brings back the start menu. The start menu you have always used to access programs works the same but features of the windows 8 start screen have been incorporated into it.</p> <p>3 Windows 10 is more <strong>secure</strong>. Security patches are frequently released for all operating systems, but windows 10 has been designed with security in mind. For businesses there are options to completely lock down your users environment only allowing ‚Äòwhite listed‚Äô programs to run.</p> <p>2 <strong>Continuum</strong> is one of the most revolutionary things about Windows 10. Continuum is the notion that one computing experience is continued regardless of the device used or the location. Continuum will automatically adjust your screen to make the best use of its size. Tablets and phones have the tiled view and start screen, if you connect a keyboard and monitor it will behave like a full blown PC. This is mind bending, that a phone running windows 10 can do as much as your laptop.</p> <p>1 Today I am off to a Windows 10 launch event where I expect many of these features will be discussed and most likely many more.</p>
              - generic [ref=e7909]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e7911]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e7912]:
          - generic [ref=e7915]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e7916]:
            - generic [ref=e7917]:
              - generic [ref=e7918]: <title>
              - text: Writing better Git commit messages
              - generic [ref=e7919]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e7920]:
              - generic [ref=e7921]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/writing-better-git-commit-messages/
              - generic [ref=e7922]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e7923]:
              - generic [ref=e7924]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e7925]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e7926]:
              - generic [ref=e7927]: <pubDate>
              - text: Sat, 25 Jul 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e7928]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e7929]:
              - generic [ref=e7930]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/writing-better-git-commit-messages/
              - generic [ref=e7931]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e7932]:
              - generic [ref=e7933]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e7934]: term="Git"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Git
              - generic [ref=e7935]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e7936]:
              - generic [ref=e7937]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e7938]: term="SourceControl"
                - text: ">"
              - text: SourceControl
              - generic [ref=e7939]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e7940]:
              - generic [ref=e7941]: <description>
              - text: <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/07/git_commit.png" loading="lazy" width="439" height="250" /> </p> <p>I always use source control for my coding changes, however some of my commit messages leave something to be desired.</p> <p>I always try to write a commit message but I often think that the change themselves should be enough to indicate what I did. I also don‚Äôt need to include who made the change or the time and date and that gets included automatically.</p> <p>Here are some tips I have found that may help me in the future.</p> <ol> <li> <p>Ask yourself why you are making this change. The Who, When and What are already being covered so it is only the why that needs including in the commit message.</p> </li> <li> <p>If your commit breaks something or causes side affects or a new dependency this should be included in the commit message. If your commit breaks functionality, consider if you really need to commit it yet, maybe only commit once fixed?</p> </li> <li> <p>If your commit includes a long list of changes consider if the commit needs splitting into several commits. It is easy to only commit one or two files write a specific commit message and then commit the rest of the changes separately.</p> </li> <li> <p>Consider including a subject for larger commits. The following comes from the git manual.</p> </li> </ol> <pre tabindex="0"><code>Though not required, it‚Äôs a good idea to begin the commit message with a single short (less than 50 character) line summarizing the change, followed by a blank line and then a more thorough description. The text up to the first blank line in a commit message is treated as the commit title, and that title is used throughout Git. </code></pre><ol start="5"> <li>If you use a subject follow the following conventions:</li> </ol> <ul> <li>Limit of 50 characters</li> <li>Start with a capital letter</li> <li>Do not end with a full stop</li> <li>Use the imperative mood i.e. write as if issuing a command</li> </ul>
              - generic [ref=e7942]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e7944]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e7945]:
          - generic [ref=e7948]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e7949]:
            - generic [ref=e7950]:
              - generic [ref=e7951]: <title>
              - text: My Love/Hate Relationship with Microsoft Access
              - generic [ref=e7952]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e7953]:
              - generic [ref=e7954]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/microsoft-access/
              - generic [ref=e7955]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e7956]:
              - generic [ref=e7957]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e7958]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e7959]:
              - generic [ref=e7960]: <pubDate>
              - text: Fri, 24 Jul 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e7961]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e7962]:
              - generic [ref=e7963]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/microsoft-access/
              - generic [ref=e7964]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e7965]:
              - generic [ref=e7966]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e7967]: term="Database"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Database
              - generic [ref=e7968]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e7969]:
              - generic [ref=e7970]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e7971]: term="Access"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Access
              - generic [ref=e7972]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e7973]:
              - generic [ref=e7974]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e7975]: term="SQL"
                - text: ">"
              - text: SQL
              - generic [ref=e7976]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e7977]:
              - generic [ref=e7978]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e7979]: term="VBA"
                - text: ">"
              - text: VBA
              - generic [ref=e7980]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e7981]:
              - generic [ref=e7982]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e7983]: term="MicrosoftOffice"
                - text: ">"
              - text: MicrosoftOffice
              - generic [ref=e7984]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e7985]:
              - generic [ref=e7986]: <description>
              - text: <p>For historical reasons I use Microsoft Access as the front-end for all my line of business databases.</p> <p>Access allows you to create an ADP file that can connect to your SQL Server database. However Office has dropped support for this, so the last version of office that I can use is Office 2010.</p> <p>Before I start hating on Access there are some good things about the platform. Users with very little knowledge can create a database fairly quickly. Development time is also fairly low as it doesn‚Äôt take long to create a new form, and add a few buttons which open different reports.</p> <p>For the last 5 years or so I have built a range of different forms in Access, (and even if I do say so myself), I have got quite good at creating forms that users can be more productive with. Access has the concept of a subform which is a form embedded in a form, each form can be connected to a different query and can be connected to each other so it is relatively easy to create something quite powerful.</p> <p>Access report are an easy way to create professional looking reports that can be sent out to clients, or used by management and they also have the concept of subreports, (same as subforms but embedded in a report), this means you don‚Äôt have to write one query to pull back every piece of data that shows up in a report.</p> <p>VBA or Visual Basic for Access allows you easily do things programmatically, like run something if something is selected or a button is clicked. This is not the easiest programming language to work with, however once you have used it for a while you get used to its quirks. My favourite function is IIF, the syntax is fairly simple IIF(expr, truepart, falsepart), if expr evaluates to true the truepart is executed (executed can be as simple as displaying certain text in certain conditions), if it is false the falsepart is executed, and you can also chain them together which I have done to produce something very complex looking.</p> <p>Now for the negative side of things. Access creates a binary ADP file, binary files can not be version controlled in git or subversion. This is a big problem as I want to keep track of every change I make. It also means that branching or working with others on big projects is also difficult.</p> <p>One work around I have found to this problem is <a href="https://accesssvn.codeplex.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">AccessSVN</a> . This program takes an ADP and creates text files of every form and report. It also can create an ADP from these files as well, however I have had varying success with this feature so I prefer to just create the text files if possible. What I do after I have made a change to the ADP is to run AccessSVN, create text files and commit these to source control. You can then see what controls have been changed or added. It also helps with bugs as I have found that sometimes while testing access will apply a filter to a form, which will break things if deployed, which is very annoying.</p> <p>Access can only do what access was designed to do. There are some advanced features that we would like to add to our databases. Things like sending emails or uploading reports to a website. This is not Access fault as it was never designed to be able to do such things but I am often asked about what is possible.</p> <p>End of support for Office 2010 is approaching and I have plans to stop using Access but until then I need to keep supporting our existing front ends.</p>
              - generic [ref=e7987]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e7989]: </item>
