          - generic [ref=e7993]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e7994]:
            - generic [ref=e7995]:
              - generic [ref=e7996]: <title>
              - text: 7 Warning Signs that you are a Bad Programmer
              - generic [ref=e7997]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e7998]:
              - generic [ref=e7999]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/7-warning-signs-that-you-are-a-bad-programmer/
              - generic [ref=e8000]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e8001]:
              - generic [ref=e8002]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e8003]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e8004]:
              - generic [ref=e8005]: <pubDate>
              - text: Thu, 23 Jul 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e8006]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e8007]:
              - generic [ref=e8008]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/7-warning-signs-that-you-are-a-bad-programmer/
              - generic [ref=e8009]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e8010]:
              - generic [ref=e8011]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8012]: term="BadProgrammer"
                - text: ">"
              - text: BadProgrammer
              - generic [ref=e8013]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8014]:
              - generic [ref=e8015]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8016]: term="Plan"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Plan
              - generic [ref=e8017]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8018]:
              - generic [ref=e8019]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8020]: term="BadProgrammer"
                - text: ">"
              - text: BadProgrammer
              - generic [ref=e8021]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8022]:
              - generic [ref=e8023]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8024]: term="SourceControl"
                - text: ">"
              - text: SourceControl
              - generic [ref=e8025]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8026]:
              - generic [ref=e8027]: <description>
              - text: "<p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"You are coding it wrong\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/07/you_are_coding_it_wrong.png\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"359\" height=\"232\" /> </p> <p>Am I a good programmer or a bad programmer?</p> <p>Here are 7 signs that might mean you are more towards the bad end of the scale.</p> <ul> <li>1: You fail to plan before you start coding</li> </ul> <p>I am very guilty of this, I love to jump into the code before thinking. But I am slowly starting to see the advantages of sketching a few things out before I write any code.</p> <p>Most of my coding recently has been SQL based and I am starting to like sketching out table designs. I have also started to sketch out the UI before I start coding. I am not saying that you need to plan every single line of code, but a little bit of planning can go a long way.</p> <ul> <li>2: You fail to use version control</li> </ul> <p>I have blogged about using version control in the past but it really is a very useful technology. It not only keeps track of every file in your solution and stores its entire history, but you can separate different versions into branches and see who changed what and when (and if the commit message is detailed enough why).</p> <ul> <li>3: You use bad variable names</li> </ul> <p>Whats wrong with variable1 and variable2 as variable names? Variables should be named after what they do or what they contain, but it is very easy to start copy and pasting them and before you know it you have a variable1 and variable2 situation. Remember that Visual Studio has some powerful refactoring tools so relatively easy to get them back in order.</p> <ul> <li>4: You repeat your code</li> </ul> <p>I‚Äôve been reading Pragmatic Programmer and one of their first tips was DRY ‚Äì Don‚Äôt Repeat Yourself. They go to extremes with nothing being repeated anywhere in your code, but I don‚Äôt think you need to go too far, you can be reasonable. If you have the same code repeated four times, then creating a function for this code will dramatically improve your code.</p> <ul> <li>5: You struggle to understand your own code</li> </ul> <p>Why did I do it this way? I feel like I am always trying to remember the reasons I chose to code the way I did previously. Part of the reason for this is that I am constantly learning at the moment, but there is more that I can do to help myself understand in the future.</p> <ul> <li>6: You are selfish and don‚Äôt share</li> </ul> <p>I am not selfish, if I learn something really cool I have to tell someone. I like writing stuff on here to share with the world. I am thinking of news ways to train my staff.</p> <ul> <li>7: You work on multiple projects</li> </ul> <p>Yes Guilty as charged with this one. I have multiple projects that I am working on at work, I also have a fair few personal projects that I would like to work on. Not sure I completely agree that multiple projects equals bad programmer.</p>"
              - generic [ref=e8028]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e8030]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e8031]:
          - generic [ref=e8034]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e8035]:
            - generic [ref=e8036]:
              - generic [ref=e8037]: <title>
              - text: Things to know before working on your database
              - generic [ref=e8038]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e8039]:
              - generic [ref=e8040]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/things-to-know-before-working-on-your-databasethings-to-know-before-working-on-your-database/
              - generic [ref=e8041]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e8042]:
              - generic [ref=e8043]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e8044]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e8045]:
              - generic [ref=e8046]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 20 Jul 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e8047]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e8048]:
              - generic [ref=e8049]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/things-to-know-before-working-on-your-databasethings-to-know-before-working-on-your-database/
              - generic [ref=e8050]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e8051]:
              - generic [ref=e8052]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8053]: term="Backups"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Backups
              - generic [ref=e8054]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8055]:
              - generic [ref=e8056]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8057]: term="SQL"
                - text: ">"
              - text: SQL
              - generic [ref=e8058]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8059]:
              - generic [ref=e8060]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8061]: term="DisasterRecovery"
                - text: ">"
              - text: DisasterRecovery
              - generic [ref=e8062]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8063]:
              - generic [ref=e8064]: <description>
              - text: <p>I recently saw this blog <a href="http://www.brentozar.com/archive/2015/07/questions-to-ask-before-you-touch-a-database-server/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">post</a> by <a href="http://www.brentozar.com/team/brent-ozar/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Brent Ozar</a> that I thought I might discuss.</p> <p>Brent listed 13 questions to ask about a database before you start working with it. I am going to go through these 13 questions and expand on them based on my experiences.</p> <ol> <li><strong>Is this database in production now?</strong></li> </ol> <p>I think it should go without saying that the first thing you should find out is if your database is in production. If its not in production you can do what you like and no one will notice. I know what databases are in production and which aren‚Äôt where I work so I can answer this one.</p> <ol start="2"> <li><strong>If this goes down, what apps go down with it?</strong></li> </ol> <p>What apps are running on what databases is a good second question. I have at least one database which has multiple front end apps. At first glance you would think that that these two apps are not connected but they are, I need to be careful with both of these apps to make sure they don‚Äôt break each other. I know what apps run off what databases.</p> <ol start="3"> <li><strong>When those apps go down, is there potential for loss of life or money?</strong></li> </ol> <p>This is a difficult question so I will split it into two. Loss of life, my databases don‚Äôt control life support machines or nuclear weapons so my first instinct would be to say no. However it is not that straightforward, what if your app allowed contractors to know the location of dangers inside a property they were working in. Once your app goes down, they could have an accident due to lack of information. Loss of money, this one is more straightforward. Time is money in the business world so any time that your app is down and your employees are not able to work is a loss of money. If your database is linked to an eCommerce site, the loss of money could be extremely high. I know what affect downtime will have on my users and business.</p> <ol start="4"> <li><strong>How sensitive are these apps to temporary slowdowns?</strong></li> </ol> <p>Similar to the previous question, a slowdown can be as serious as downtime for some applications. Luckily most of my apps are internal only so are not seriously affected by slowness.</p> <ol start="5"> <li><strong>When was the last successful backup?</strong></li> </ol> <p>I manage the backup schedule for all my databases so I know exactly when each one was last backed up. When ever I do anything to a production database I will run a backup so I can roll back in case of problems. As part of developing changes I run my changes on a backup of the data. I can script all my changes and repeatedly run them against a backup until I am sure no problems will occur.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/07/uf010206.jpg" loading="lazy" width="233" height="238" /> </p> <ol start="6"> <li><strong>When was the last successful restore test?</strong></li> </ol> <p>More important than a backup is testing restoring your databases. If you can‚Äôt restore data then your backup is useless. I try to test restoring my backups at least weekly so I know that I can rely on my backups.</p> <ol start="7"> <li><strong>Is everyone okay losing data back to the last successful backup?</strong></li> </ol> <p>If disaster strikes you could loose all data between now and the time of your last backup. But all is not lost transactional backups can be scheduled throughout the day, in my case the most data we could loose is 15 minutes. This could be configured to be more or less frequent depending on your data. But remember the previous question and make sure you test a restore of your transactional backups, if you can‚Äôt restore from them you will be forced to restore from the last successful backup.</p> <ol start="8"> <li><strong>When was the last successful clean corruption test?</strong></li> </ol> <p>Corruption can be a killer if it is not found quickly. If you need to restore to the last backup before corruption occurred this could result in a significant amount of data loss. To check for corruption you need to run DBCC regularly.</p> <ol start="9"> <li><strong>Do we have a development or staging environment where I can test my changes first?</strong></li> </ol> <p>If the answer to this is no, then your next job is to setup a development or staging area. Having a development environment makes development a lot easier and I don‚Äôt think I could manage to do all the changes I have done recently without one.</p> <ol start="10"> <li><strong>Is there any documentation for why the server was configured this way?</strong></li> </ol> <p>I really wish we had more documentation about configurations as it would make finding out why thing were setup the way they are. So unfortunately the answer to this question is No.</p> <ol start="11"> <li><strong>What changes am I not allowed to make?</strong></li> </ol> <p>Depending on what your app does, where it is hosted, how quick the changes are needed and many other factors will all restrict what changes you can make. Historical decisions on the database can also affect what changes can be made, if the database has been structured in a certain way, it may be very difficult to restructure it in a more efficient way.</p> <ol start="12"> <li><strong>Who can test that my changes fixed the problem?</strong></li> </ol> <p>This is an interesting question, from experience the best people to speak to about problems with the database are the users. If they can show you how to reproduce a problem, you should be able to fix this problem, after that you can probably get them to verify that it has been fixed.</p> <ol start="13"> <li><strong>Who can test that the apps still work as designed, and that my changes didn‚Äôt have unintended side effects?</strong></li> </ol> <p>This is an extension of the previous question. The main users of your app should be your first port of call to find out if the app works as expected. However exploring side affects and undesired features is something that I would test as part of the development process. It has taken a while but I have constructed a detailed check list that can be used for testing so I know that most bugs can be found before release.</p>
              - generic [ref=e8065]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e8067]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e8068]:
          - generic [ref=e8071]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e8072]:
            - generic [ref=e8073]:
              - generic [ref=e8074]: <title>
              - text: New Horizons Pluto Spacecraft
              - generic [ref=e8075]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e8076]:
              - generic [ref=e8077]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/new-horizons-pluto-spacecraft/
              - generic [ref=e8078]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e8079]:
              - generic [ref=e8080]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e8081]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e8082]:
              - generic [ref=e8083]: <pubDate>
              - text: Tue, 14 Jul 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e8084]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e8085]:
              - generic [ref=e8086]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/new-horizons-pluto-spacecraft/
              - generic [ref=e8087]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e8088]:
              - generic [ref=e8089]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8090]: term="Pluto"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Pluto
              - generic [ref=e8091]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8092]:
              - generic [ref=e8093]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8094]: term="Hardware"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Hardware
              - generic [ref=e8095]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8096]:
              - generic [ref=e8097]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8098]: term="Spacecraft"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Spacecraft
              - generic [ref=e8099]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8100]:
              - generic [ref=e8101]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8102]: term="Software"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Software
              - generic [ref=e8103]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8104]:
              - generic [ref=e8105]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8106]: term="Technology"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Technology
              - generic [ref=e8107]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8108]:
              - generic [ref=e8109]: <description>
              - text: "<p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/07/84270464_p_lorri_fullframe_color.png\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"976\" height=\"630\" /> </p> <p>To explore Strange New Worlds, well today the NASA spacecraft New Horizons has been doing just that. This is the most detailed photograph yet of the furthest planet we have ever explored, Pluto.</p> <p>New Horizons was launched on 19th January 2006. It has been travelling for 3463 days (9.5 years).</p> <p>In 2006 we were still using Windows XP and Office 2003. In 2006 I wasn‚Äôt even working in IT. As a software developer it is hard to imagine writing software that won‚Äôt be used for another 9.5 years.</p> <p>The spacecraft carries two computer systems: the Command and Data Handling system and the Guidance and Control processor. Each of the two systems is duplicated for redundancy, for a total of four computers. The processor used for its flight computers is the Mongoose-V, a 12 MHz radiation-hardened version of the MIPS R3000 CPU. Multiple clocks and timing routines are implemented in hardware and software to help prevent faults and downtime. To conserve heat and mass, spacecraft and instrument electronics are housed together in IEMs (integrated electronics modules). There are two redundant IEMs. Including other functions such as instrument and radio electronics, each IEM contains 9 boards. The processor distributes operating commands to each subsystem, collects and processes instrument data, and sequences information sent back to Earth. It also runs the advanced ‚Äúautonomy‚Äù algorithms that allow the spacecraft to check the status of each system and, if necessary, correct any problems, switch to backup systems or contact operators on Earth for help.</p> <p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/07/Mission-Spacecraft-structure.jpg\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"720\" height=\"523\" /> </p> <p>For data storage, New Horizons carries two low-power solid-state recorders (one backup) that can hold up to 8 gigabytes each. The main processor collects, compresses, reformats, sorts and stores science and housekeeping (telemetry) data on the recorder ‚Äì similar to a flash memory card for a digital camera ‚Äì for transmission to Earth through the telecommunications subsystem.</p> <p>Communication with the spacecraft is via X band. The craft had a communication rate of 38 kbit/s at Jupiter; at Pluto‚Äôs distance, a rate of approximately 1000 bit/s. To put this speed into context, the size of the image at the top of this page is 649kb and would take over 86 minutes to travel from Pluto to Earth, (I am sure the actual image was much larger and took even longer to reach us.) Besides the low bandwidth, Pluto‚Äôs distance also causes a latency of about 4.5 hours (one-way). The 70 m (230 ft) NASA Deep Space Network (DSN) dishes are used to relay commands once it is beyond Jupiter. It will take 16 months to send the full set of Pluto encounter science data back to Earth.</p> <p>Most software encounters a problem from time to time, but the software on board this spacecraft has to keep running for almost a decade. Due to the distances involved its not possible to upload any code tweaks. Any commands that are sent to the spacecraft will take 4.5 hours to even get there so there needs to be a huge amount of autonomy and redundancy to cope with such a massive journey.</p> <p>I can‚Äôt even imagine how you would begin to write the software to run such a craft. I don‚Äôt think I have written any code that is as old as is running on the New Horizons craft, and if I had I would guess the quality would be quite poor certainly not good enough to work non stop for a decade.</p> <p>There are some incredibly clever people out there who have been involved in this project. Congratulations team you have every right on being proud as the data starts to trickle back to earth.</p>"
              - generic [ref=e8110]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e8112]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e8113]:
          - generic [ref=e8116]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e8117]:
            - generic [ref=e8118]:
              - generic [ref=e8119]: <title>
              - text: How to upgrade to Windows 10
              - generic [ref=e8120]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e8121]:
              - generic [ref=e8122]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/how-to-upgrade-to-windows-10/
              - generic [ref=e8123]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e8124]:
              - generic [ref=e8125]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e8126]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e8127]:
              - generic [ref=e8128]: <pubDate>
              - text: Sat, 11 Jul 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e8129]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e8130]:
              - generic [ref=e8131]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/how-to-upgrade-to-windows-10/
              - generic [ref=e8132]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e8133]:
              - generic [ref=e8134]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8135]: term="ScottHansleman"
                - text: ">"
              - text: ScottHansleman
              - generic [ref=e8136]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8137]:
              - generic [ref=e8138]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8139]: term="Free"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Free
              - generic [ref=e8140]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8141]:
              - generic [ref=e8142]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8143]: term="SystemAdministration"
                - text: ">"
              - text: SystemAdministration
              - generic [ref=e8144]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8145]:
              - generic [ref=e8146]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8147]: term="WIndows10"
                - text: ">"
              - text: WIndows10
              - generic [ref=e8148]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8149]:
              - generic [ref=e8150]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8151]: term="Upgrade"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Upgrade
              - generic [ref=e8152]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8153]:
              - generic [ref=e8154]: <description>
              - text: <p>Microsoft are releasing a new operating system on July 29th called Windows 10.</p> <p>If you have questions about Windows 10 watch this video by <a href="https://www.hanselman.com/blog/Windows10IsComingheresWhatToTellNontechnicalParent.aspx" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Scott Hansleman</a> . He explains how to upgrade from Windows 7 and 8 to Windows 10 and what to expect after you upgrade.</p> <iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/nuCpdlMFvUY" title="YouTube video player" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe> <p>My advice to everyone is that you backup your devices before you upgrade, this is good practice before you install any software or updates.</p> <p>Microsoft are offering Windows 10 for free for a whole year, so don‚Äôt panic. Take your time, backup all your important files and when you are ready install Windows 10. Nothing is going to stop working after July 29th if you don‚Äôt have the latest operating system on your machine.</p> <p>I hope this helps answer some of your questions about what to do at the end of the month. If not feel free to write a comment or contact me with your questions.</p>
              - generic [ref=e8155]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e8157]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e8158]:
          - generic [ref=e8161]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e8162]:
            - generic [ref=e8163]:
              - generic [ref=e8164]: <title>
              - text: Why do we call them bugs?
              - generic [ref=e8165]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e8166]:
              - generic [ref=e8167]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/why-do-we-call-them-bugs/
              - generic [ref=e8168]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e8169]:
              - generic [ref=e8170]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e8171]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e8172]:
              - generic [ref=e8173]: <pubDate>
              - text: Tue, 07 Jul 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e8174]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e8175]:
              - generic [ref=e8176]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/why-do-we-call-them-bugs/
              - generic [ref=e8177]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e8178]:
              - generic [ref=e8179]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8180]: term="Debugging"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Debugging
              - generic [ref=e8181]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8182]:
              - generic [ref=e8183]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8184]: term="Bugs"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Bugs
              - generic [ref=e8185]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8186]:
              - generic [ref=e8187]: <description>
              - text: <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/07/11666093_10153470803062792_4914668365512645054_n.jpg" loading="lazy" width="960" height="540" /> </p> <p>On my way home from the office I spotted this little chap. In my expert opinion it is a &ldquo;bug&rdquo;.</p> <p>This particular &ldquo;bug&rdquo; is harmlessly sitting outside, but have you ever wondered why computer problems are often named after this little chap (and his friends)?</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/07/H96566k.jpg" loading="lazy" width="740" height="583" /> </p> <p>The first recorded bug report was in 1947 when Grace Hopper found a moth between the relays of a Harvard Mark II, this moth was then tapped in the log book as evidence.</p> <p>Since then the process of removing bugs has been called &ldquo;debugging&rdquo;. However bugs had existed in electrical devices before this.</p> <p>In the early days of telegraphy, there were two types of keyers. The older ‚Äúmanual‚Äù keyers which required the operator to code the dots and dashes. And the newer, semi-automatic keyers that would send a string of dots automatically. These semi-automatic keyers were called &ldquo;bugs&rdquo;. One of the most common brands of these keyers, the Vibroplex, used a graphic of a beetle.</p> <p>Luckily the bugs I deal with don‚Äôt have legs or wings and are just errors in computer code. When I debug code I need to look at the inner workings of the code, looking for problems, most often it is a typo or piece of logic that doesn‚Äôt match up. But the relationship between computer bugs and living bugs does continue, the bug tracking software bugzilla uses a cartoon bug as its logo.</p>
              - generic [ref=e8188]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e8190]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e8191]:
          - generic [ref=e8194]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e8195]:
            - generic [ref=e8196]:
              - generic [ref=e8197]: <title>
              - text: Agile Software Development
              - generic [ref=e8198]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e8199]:
              - generic [ref=e8200]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/agile-software-development/
              - generic [ref=e8201]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e8202]:
              - generic [ref=e8203]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e8204]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e8205]:
              - generic [ref=e8206]: <pubDate>
              - text: Sat, 04 Jul 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e8207]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e8208]:
              - generic [ref=e8209]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/agile-software-development/
              - generic [ref=e8210]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e8211]:
              - generic [ref=e8212]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8213]: term="Agile"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Agile
              - generic [ref=e8214]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8215]:
              - generic [ref=e8216]: <description>
              - text: <p>I have heard the term <strong>Agile Software Development</strong> quite a bit, but lets see if we can define it and see if I do any of the processes involved with it.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="Agile Software Development" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/07/Agile-Marketing-Series-What-is-Agile-Marketing.png" loading="lazy" width="579" height="290" /> </p> <p>The dictionary defines ‚ÄòAgile‚Äô as mentally quick, or nimble, or quick in movement.</p> <p>In 2001 The Manifesto for Agile Software Development first introduced the term agile. The manifesto is based on 12 principles.</p> <ul> <li>Customer satisfaction by early and continuous delivery of useful software</li> <li>Welcome changing requirements, even late in development</li> <li>Working software is delivered frequently (weeks rather than months)</li> <li>Close, daily cooperation between business people and developers</li> <li>Projects are built around motivated individuals, who should be trusted</li> <li>Face-to-face conversation is the best form of communication (co-location)</li> <li>Working software is the principal measure of progress</li> <li>Sustainable development, able to maintain a constant pace</li> <li>Continuous attention to technical excellence and good design</li> <li>Simplicity‚Äîthe art of maximizing the amount of work not done‚Äîis essential</li> <li>Self-organizing teams</li> <li>Regular adaptation to changing circumstance</li> </ul> <p>Lets go through this list one by one and examine what I understand of it and how I might have used it in the past.</p> <p><strong>Customer satisfaction by early and continuous delivery of useful software</strong></p> <p>My boss bombards me with hundreds of changes that she wants straight away, I keep her reasonably happy by giving her regular small improvements. Yesterday I released some changes, and two weeks before that I released another chunk, on Monday I will find out that I haven‚Äôt included feature Y, so in another couple of weeks feature Y will be delivered. This is my understanding of delivering continuous improvements to my software.</p> <p><strong>Welcome changing requirements, even late in development</strong></p> <p>Lets ignore the word welcome, as changing requirements are really annoying. I designed a system to track how far through a 5 step process you were, after I deployed that change it was discovered that the process was actually 18 steps. Annoying as this was, my design allowed the easy addition of these extra stages.</p> <p><strong>Working software is delivered frequently</strong></p> <p>Yes, I do this, see my comments above. If you make a single change and then deploy it, bug fixes are easy as most of it is still in your head. If you spend 6 months making 1000 changes, it will take you extra time to remind yourself what you did and why.</p> <p><strong>Close, daily cooperation between business people and developers</strong></p> <p>I don‚Äôt do this daily but I regularly demo my changes to other departments and directors so I can gather feedback and further revise my changes. Before I start work I always try to understand what is needed and how they want it to work and try and figure out what they need not what they want (different things)</p> <p><strong>Projects are built around motivated individuals, who should be trusted</strong></p> <p>Not sure I understand this one. There are people that use my projects that I always go to, to find out how it is being used. There are also people that are not interested in change, it is always far more difficult to convince them of the value of what I am working on.</p> <p><strong>Face-to-face conversation is the best form of communication</strong></p> <p>When I was an IT support guy, I used to like going up to someone‚Äôs desk and seeing them experience the problem, it could usually be fixed in a couple of clicks. However when you had a call from a remote office and had to talk through trying different things it could take hours to fix. The same can be said of deploying a new feature, if you talk to your users and explain what has been added they are far more likely to use it, than if you send them an email listing what you have done.</p> <p><strong>Working software is the principal measure of progress</strong></p> <p>If a Manager can click two buttons to find out how busy their department is, when before they only had out of date spreadsheets, this is a clear measure of progress. Any time spent on code that never gets deployed doesn‚Äôt improve anything, its only when that code starts being used has progress been made.</p> <p><strong>Sustainable development, able to maintain a constant pace</strong></p> <p>I am pretty sure I don‚Äôt do this. I work harder at some times than others. Sometimes there are other projects or other demands on my time and so development on a particular project will decrease and there are times when I eat, sleep, dream about a project.</p> <p><strong>Continuous attention to technical excellence and good design</strong></p> <p>I do strive towards good design and with each deployment aim to improve the quality of code in production. However my limited knowledge means that I don‚Äôt always produce the best code but it is improving. If I look at some work I have done in the past, I would definitely do some of that differently if working on it now.</p> <p><strong>Simplicity‚Äîthe art of maximizing the amount of work not done‚Äîis essential</strong></p> <p>When I first read this one, it made no sense to me. However I believe it can be restated as minimising the amount of work done. Recently I was writing SQL code and I had about 4 or 5 different queries to produce the report that was needed. Every time the requirements changed it was a long slog through each of these queries to update them. In the end I had to rewrite this whole process using one query, it took some time but was simpler and is now easier and quicker to maintain. The simpler the code is the easier and quicker it is to maintain, and you have less work to do.</p> <p><strong>Self-organizing teams</strong></p> <p>Not sure this applies to me as I work in a team of one. I do try and keep myself organised but not sure if that qualifies as self-organizing.</p> <p><strong>Regular adaptation to changing circumstance</strong></p> <p>Very similar to the second point about changing requirements but I think also includes changes required due to problems you encounter along the way. A simple example of this is when you encounter a problem, there are lots of different ways to solve it. If you can‚Äôt solve something in the database layer, then it might be solved with a script or in the user interface.</p> <p>So in summary I am not only a developer but very close to being an Agile developer as well, assuming these 12 points are what is needed to be ‚ÄòAgile‚Äô</p>
              - generic [ref=e8217]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e8219]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e8220]:
          - generic [ref=e8223]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e8224]:
            - generic [ref=e8225]:
              - generic [ref=e8226]: <title>
              - text: Developer Personality Test
              - generic [ref=e8227]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e8228]:
              - generic [ref=e8229]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/developer-personality-test/
              - generic [ref=e8230]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e8231]:
              - generic [ref=e8232]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e8233]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e8234]:
              - generic [ref=e8235]: <pubDate>
              - text: Thu, 02 Jul 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e8236]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e8237]:
              - generic [ref=e8238]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/developer-personality-test/
              - generic [ref=e8239]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e8240]:
              - generic [ref=e8241]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8242]: term="Developer"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Developer
              - generic [ref=e8243]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8244]:
              - generic [ref=e8245]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8246]: term="Personaility"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Personaility
              - generic [ref=e8247]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8248]:
              - generic [ref=e8249]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8250]: term="Myers-Briggs"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Myers-Briggs
              - generic [ref=e8251]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8252]:
              - generic [ref=e8253]: <description>
              - text: <p>I was sent a <a href="https://www.surveygizmo.com/s3/1883619/Developer-Personality-Test" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">link</a> to a developer personality test earlier. The test aims to give you a look at your developer personality similar to the famous Myers-Briggs personality test. A shorter version of this test can be found <a href="https://www.surveygizmo.com/s3/1900187/Short-Developer-Personality-Test" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">here</a> .</p> <p>Myers-Briggs tells you if you are <strong>Introvert (I)</strong> or <strong>Extrovert (E)</strong>, <strong>Feeling (F)</strong> or <strong>Thinking (T)</strong>, <strong>Perception (P)</strong> or <strong>Judging (J)</strong> and <strong>Sensing (S)</strong> or <strong>Intuition (N)</strong>.</p> <p>This test however tells you if you are:</p> <p><strong>Independent vs Collaborative</strong></p> <p><strong>Abstract vs Low-Level</strong></p> <p><strong>Frontier vs Conservative</strong></p> <p><strong>Generalist vs Specialist</strong></p> <p><strong>Idealist vs Pragmatist</strong></p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/07/19etmksoopu2ojpg.jpg" loading="lazy" width="1196" height="1280" /> </p> <p><strong>Independent:</strong> You prefer to spend most of your time working in an isolated environment. You rarely want to collaborate because you have a better chance of solving problems on your own. If you do have to collaborate on the direction of a project, you dislike it when you have to defend your position or when others try to muddy your plans for the project. It‚Äôs better to have one strong vision for a project from the lead programmer on that project. Having a large team or allowing others to have significant control over the project risks communication errors, a muddied code base, and inefficiencies. If one developer has a firm grasp on the entire codebase, they‚Äôll be much better at fixing and improving it quickly.</p> <p><strong>Collaborative:</strong> Good code doesn‚Äôt happen in a vacuum. You need a team to keep you energized and on your toes so that you‚Äôre constantly improving the project code using the entire team‚Äôs varied experience and strengths. You like to talk frequently with colleagues and discuss ideas so that you can learn from others and spark ideas. It doesn‚Äôt matter what their experience level is, you can always learn something by including everyone. A solo coder can‚Äôt possibly code a large software project with the speed and quality that a team can.</p> <p><strong>Abstract:</strong> You prefer to write in languages and frameworks that simplify development as much as possible and use as few characters and lines of code as possible. The trajectory of software development has always been toward making life easier and error-free. Programming has always been about adding more abstraction layers to simplify tasks, so why not trust the technology on your layer and don‚Äôt worry about handling the lower layers?</p> <p><strong>Low-Level:</strong> The more abstraction tools and high-level languages we build, the further we get from understanding and controlling the deeper components in our programs. This means lower performance and endless bug searches. Developers today need to have a stronger understanding of compilers, memory management, pointer arithmetic, and other low-level topics.</p> <p><strong>Frontiers:</strong> You like to work at the cutting edge. Using too many old languages and technologies bores you, and it severely hinders your software‚Äôs potential to keep outdated technologies in it for too long. Developers need keep their ears to the ground for new technologies and new versions of tools that they already use. Even if the community and maturity of the project isn‚Äôt at a level that most enterprises would consider ‚Äúsafe,‚Äù you‚Äôre willing to be an early adopter if you believe the community and the technology has momentum. Development technology is changing faster every day, and we need to constantly be adopting new tools and methods to keep up.</p> <p><strong>Conservative:</strong> It seems like every 10 years we forget all the problems we solved in the previous decade and start to build ‚Äònew‚Äô tools that solve the same problems, even though there is a perfectly good solution that has existed for years. Enterprises have it right when they make conservative decisions about their technology stack. Why would you hang your business on a technology with only a few years of maturity in just a handful of production use cases? Technologies like PHP, Java, and SQL have been mainstays of the development industry for years, and it takes a lot of time for new technologies to make it into that maturity tier.</p> <p><strong>Generalist:</strong> You like to be known as a ‚ÄúJack of all Trades‚Äù and a reference for others on your team. You jump at every chance to enhance your skills in a wide variety technology topics, not just the ones that apply to your day to day work. You don‚Äôt always know when it might be useful to have these extra skills, but when the time comes, you are ready. If more developers took the time to learn other skills outside of the ones relevant to their project, they‚Äôd work more seamlessly with the rest of their organization because they‚Äôd have more empathy and understanding of the challenges that their colleagues face.</p> <p><strong>Specialist:</strong> If you‚Äôre a Jack of all Trades, you‚Äôre a master of none. Mastery in one or two areas is what makes you valuable. What‚Äôs the point of learning skills for other jobs you don‚Äôt have and can‚Äôt control? When you plan for a project or do technical research, it‚Äôs always focused on something you‚Äôre working on. You don‚Äôt get side-tracked. If you learn a new skill, it‚Äôs because the project requires that you do it. Most or all of your hobby projects are also building your mastery of the skills you use at your job.</p> <p><strong>Idealist:</strong> You believe in the power of well-defined processes. It‚Äôs crucial to an organization‚Äôs success that they create and follow appropriate and effective processes for building software. Trying to improvise or play it by ear invites the possibility of workflow errors that can decrease the quality of the software or even cause major product failures. Planning is also extremely important to you. You like to research all of the things you will need to know before starting a project. It‚Äôs important to find out the best architecture for your software beforehand, and then strictly implement that architecture with objective best practices. The more planning and scaffolding you do in the beginning, the less overall work you will have to do to complete the software.</p> <p><strong>Pragmatist:</strong> Speed is your best weapon in a competitive industry, and to quickly prototype and build new products, you need to have a flexible, pragmatic process. You don‚Äôt have a few months to plan your projects, you need to just start coding and a good path for the project will reveal itself. Great products are made through frequent feedback and releases, so why shouldn‚Äôt your plan be just as adaptable? Your plan should be adapted to changes in the software, and your expertise should be adapted to the project. You shouldn‚Äôt spend your precious time studying a problem that you‚Äôre not certain to run into while coding your projects. Trying to build test coverage for every possible scenario and having long meetings throughout the process are a waste of time and distract you from doing more productive work.</p> <p>I am not going to admit where I came in this test as being a newbie developer my answers are very subjective and I don‚Äôt believe I have enough experience to really say where I lie on many of these issues.</p> <p>I only have experience of working on my own and in very small teams, while I think working in a bigger team would have benefits I have no experience of this.</p>
              - generic [ref=e8254]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e8256]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e8257]:
          - generic [ref=e8260]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e8261]:
            - generic [ref=e8262]:
              - generic [ref=e8263]: <title>
              - text: Sudoku Challenge
              - generic [ref=e8264]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e8265]:
              - generic [ref=e8266]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/sudoku-challenge/
              - generic [ref=e8267]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e8268]:
              - generic [ref=e8269]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e8270]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e8271]:
              - generic [ref=e8272]: <pubDate>
              - text: Fri, 26 Jun 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e8273]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e8274]:
              - generic [ref=e8275]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/sudoku-challenge/
              - generic [ref=e8276]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e8277]:
              - generic [ref=e8278]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8279]: term="Dojo"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Dojo
              - generic [ref=e8280]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8281]:
              - generic [ref=e8282]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8283]: term="C-Sharp"
                - text: ">"
              - text: C-Sharp
              - generic [ref=e8284]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8285]:
              - generic [ref=e8286]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8287]: term="LeedsSharp"
                - text: ">"
              - text: LeedsSharp
              - generic [ref=e8288]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8289]:
              - generic [ref=e8290]: <description>
              - text: <p>Last night I went to a Code Dojo at Leeds Sharp (the coding user group I have started going to). A Code Dojo is a programming challenge that people work on usually in pairs.</p> <p>The challenge that we worked on was to code a solution to the puzzle game Sudoku. The code we worked with can be found on github.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/06/2000px-Sudoku-by-L2G-20050714.svg_.png" loading="lazy" width="2000" height="2000" /> </p> <p>I don‚Äôt know much about Sudoku but the game goes like this. You start with a 9√ó9 grid, and the idea is to fill in all the missing numbers.</p> <p>Each Row can only use each digit 1 to 9 once, each column can only use each digit 1 to 9 once and each subgrid (3√ó3) can only use each digit once.</p> <p>I worked with Richard one of the Leeds Sharp organisers, we started by trying to loop through each empty cell and insert values in a brute force attack, but this approach didn‚Äôt get us very far (literally as the application crashed!)</p> <p>The approach that we needed to use was to loop through calculating possible values.</p> <p>It was only when I sat down at this dojo did I realise how much I still have to learn, but while talking with Richard about different approaches and different coding structures I started to learn.</p>
              - generic [ref=e8291]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e8293]: </item>

          - generic [ref=e8297]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e8298]:
            - generic [ref=e8299]:
              - generic [ref=e8300]: <title>
              - text: Fathers Day
              - generic [ref=e8301]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e8302]:
              - generic [ref=e8303]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/fathers-day/
              - generic [ref=e8304]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e8305]:
              - generic [ref=e8306]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e8307]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e8308]:
              - generic [ref=e8309]: <pubDate>
              - text: Sun, 21 Jun 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e8310]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e8311]:
              - generic [ref=e8312]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/fathers-day/
              - generic [ref=e8313]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e8314]:
              - generic [ref=e8315]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8316]: term="Father"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Father
              - generic [ref=e8317]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8318]:
              - generic [ref=e8319]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8320]: term="BASIC"
                - text: ">"
              - text: BASIC
              - generic [ref=e8321]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8322]:
              - generic [ref=e8323]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8324]: term="1980s"
                - text: ">"
              - text: 1980s
              - generic [ref=e8325]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8326]:
              - generic [ref=e8327]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8328]: term="Lynx"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Lynx
              - generic [ref=e8329]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8330]:
              - generic [ref=e8331]: <description>
              - text: <p>In the UK today is Fathers Day. Happy Fathers Day Dad!</p> <p>I thought I might talk about how he encouraged my interest in technology, especially as in about 8 weeks I will become a parent and will have someone to encourage and inspire.</p> <p>I am going to sound really old but when I was born there was no internet, no mobile phones and computers more often appeared in sci-fi than in your home.</p> <p>The first computer I remember us owning was a Lynx. A quick google reveals there were a number of different models, I have no idea what we had but here is what I found.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/06/PRODPIC-2926.jpg" loading="lazy" width="500" height="308" /> </p> <p>In March 1983 the Lynx 48K was released, in September this was upgraded to 96K. In December 1983 a new Lynx was released with 128K. To put these numbers in perspective on my desktop is an image file that is 123K! The CPU in this computer was rated at between 4 and 6Mhz. (Modern PCs have CPUs around the 1.5Ghz or 1500Mhz)</p> <p>The Lynx we had, didn‚Äôt have a disk drive or a mouse. Programs were loaded from audio tapes (Audio tape was a form of data storage that came before CDs where data was stored on magnetic tape, most often used for music) The tapes we had would often get stuck and data wouldn‚Äôt load. The answer to this was to fast-forward/rewind the tape or hit the tape on your leg. For some reason this is a memory I still have of my dad hitting a tape on his leg to get a game or something else to load on the lynx. We also had a joystick for playing some of the games. I believe we also had an early thermal printer.</p> <p>My memory of the Lynx is in black and white. The reason for this is that the Lynx was connected to an old black and white TV, it was a special treat when we connected the main colour TV to the Lynx.</p> <p>We had a wide range of games for the Lynx, I can remember Jet Set Willy, and Diggerman. But there were also programs which my father had created. The Lynx had a form of BASIC where you can write you own programs and my father spent many hours writing programs for me and my sister. (We actually never realized this at the time)</p> <p>With that as my introduction to computers is it any wonder that I do what I do now? Now what should I do for my child to encourage them in a similar way?</p> <p>As a family we never owned a games console. Not sure if this was a financial or moral choice but it is something I will have to think about. I want my child to be knowledgeable about computers and able to compete in the competitive job market, but I also want them to know about science and nature and to enjoy their childhood. Lots of technology choices to make over the next few years.</p>
              - generic [ref=e8332]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e8334]: </item>

            - generic [ref=e8363]:
              - generic [ref=e8364]: <description>
              - text: "<p>WOW! I have reached the milestone of 50 blog posts.</p> <p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"Top 50\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/06/top-50-2012.jpg\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"1500\" height=\"1125\" /> </p> <p>I have tried to blog at least every week and I have learnt a lot. I have talked about my work, technology, things I have learnt, things I want to do and many more things. It is too soon to tell if my blog is going to be a success, but I think I am starting to find my ‚Äòblog‚Äô voice and I intend to keep on blogging.</p> <p>To celebrate here are some of my highlights.</p> <ol> <li> <p><a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/2015/05/30/user-groups-and-f/\">User Groups and F#</a> By far my most popular blog post. I talk about my first visit to the Leeds Sharp group and an introduction to the F# language.</p> </li> <li> <p><a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/2015/03/25/monitoring-screens/\">Monitoring Screens</a> I talk about creating a big screen of vital monitoring information.</p> </li> <li> <p><a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/2015/02/13/ten-forward-episode-135-anti-firbob-is-back-or-simons-desert-island-trek/\">Ten Forward Episode #135</a> ‚Äì Simon‚Äôs Desert Island Trek My appearance on the Ten Forward Podcast</p> </li> <li> <p><a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/2015/04/05/building-something-with-a-raspberry-pi/\">Building something with a Raspberry Pi</a> I blog about getting a Raspberry Pi to play around with</p> </li> <li> <p><a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/02/23/improving-your-blog/\">Improving your Blog</a> John Sonmez tries to help my blog improve</p> </li> <li> <p><a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/2015/01/16/javascript-progress/\">Javascript progress</a> About learning javascript</p> </li> <li> <p><a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/2015/04/11/the-raspberry-pi-adventure-starts/\">The Raspberry Pi Adventure Starts</a> I get a Raspberry Pi and start building something with it</p> </li> <li> <p><a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/2015/04/21/weakest-database-design/\">Weakest Database Design</a> I talk about database design</p> </li> <li> <p><a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/2015/05/17/trying-windows-10/\">Trying Windows 10</a> I talk about my experience with the latest windows operating system</p> </li> <li> <p><a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/2015/02/04/laziness/\">Laziness</a> I talk about the extreme ways IT Professionals go to be more lazy</p> </li> </ol>"

          - generic [ref=e8371]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e8372]:
            - generic [ref=e8373]:
              - generic [ref=e8374]: <title>
              - text: Requirement Gathering
              - generic [ref=e8375]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e8376]:
              - generic [ref=e8377]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/requirement-gathering/
              - generic [ref=e8378]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e8379]:
              - generic [ref=e8380]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e8381]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e8382]:
              - generic [ref=e8383]: <pubDate>
              - text: Tue, 16 Jun 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e8384]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e8385]:
              - generic [ref=e8386]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/requirement-gathering/
              - generic [ref=e8387]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e8388]:
              - generic [ref=e8389]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8390]: term="Database"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Database
              - generic [ref=e8391]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8392]:
              - generic [ref=e8393]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8394]: term="Requirements"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Requirements
              - generic [ref=e8395]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8396]:
              - generic [ref=e8397]: <description>
              - text: <p><strong>Why is it so hard to find out exactly what is needed when designing changes to a system?</strong></p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/06/Requirements-Gathering-User-Experience-UX-Project-Cartoon.jpg" loading="lazy" width="728" height="543" /> </p> <p>When adding functionality to databases I always like to dive in and start adding extra columns and new tables. But at some point you need to find out what is needed.</p> <p>The process of gathering requirements that I have followed goes something like this.</p> <p>My boss tells me that we need a system to solve x problem. This is the broad overview of what is needed.</p> <p>Next I need to find out specifically how the system is being used and what things need adding. Discussing the specifics with my boss often results in a high level of confusion. I always try to speak with the users that will be using this system on a daily basis. If I create something that isn‚Äôt liked people will avoid using it and it won‚Äôt solve the original problem so I always think it is very important to speak to the day to day user.</p> <p>After I have an idea of what is needed, I build something. Once I have something that sort of works, I will try and demonstrate this to the user to gather feedback. This feedback is invaluable as it will often reveal if I am going in the right direction and reveal missing requirements that need to be incorporated in the finished solution.</p> <p>I will often repeat the last stage a few times especially if there is a big change needed, once I am happy I will demonstrate to my boss before deploying the solution.</p> <p>After deployment there is often a period of fixing issues and gathering feedback before I can consider the project finished.</p> <p>This whole process is very time consuming as there is a period of changes being tweaked back and forth following feedback. A better way is to gather a detailed specification of what is needed and work towards delivering that.</p>
              - generic [ref=e8398]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e8400]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e8401]:
          - generic [ref=e8404]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e8405]:
            - generic [ref=e8406]:
              - generic [ref=e8407]: <title>
              - text: Runaway SQL Log growth
              - generic [ref=e8408]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e8409]:
              - generic [ref=e8410]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/runaway-sql-log-growth/
              - generic [ref=e8411]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e8412]:
              - generic [ref=e8413]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e8414]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e8415]:
              - generic [ref=e8416]: <pubDate>
              - text: Fri, 12 Jun 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e8417]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e8418]:
              - generic [ref=e8419]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/runaway-sql-log-growth/
              - generic [ref=e8420]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e8421]:
              - generic [ref=e8422]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8423]: term="ITAdmin"
                - text: ">"
              - text: ITAdmin
              - generic [ref=e8424]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8425]:
              - generic [ref=e8426]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8427]: term="Backups"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Backups
              - generic [ref=e8428]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8429]:
              - generic [ref=e8430]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8431]: term="SQL"
                - text: ">"
              - text: SQL
              - generic [ref=e8432]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8433]:
              - generic [ref=e8434]: <description>
              - text: <p>Today is my day off, but I wake up and have a quick look at <a href="https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/i-love-nagios/">nagios</a> to see if there is anything I need to worry about. Yes there is, SQL Server has run out of disk space on its data disk.</p> <p>I race downstairs and VPN onto the server to find out what has happened. One of my monitoring databases has had runaway log growth and is over 80Gb is size.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" style="color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;"><code class="language-sql" data-lang="sql"><span style="display:flex;"><span>BACKUP LOG [DBName] <span style="color:#66d9ef">WITH</span> TRUNCATE_ONLY </span></span><span style="display:flex;"><span>DBCC SHRINKFILE(<span style="color:#e6db74">&#39;DBName_Log&#39;</span>) </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Free disk space is back to normal, all users will be unaware of the problem and everything is fine again. I create a daily job that runs the above code, that way it should stay a manageable size.</p> <p>Next I need to find out why it happened and to prevent it happening again in the future (Next time I have a day off I want to lie in!)</p> <p>I check the SQL logs and notice</p> <p>BACKUP LOG WITH TRUNCATE_ONLY or WITH NO_LOG is deprecated. The simple recovery model should be used to automatically truncate the transaction log.</p> <p>Then I remember what I have done to cause this issue. I have a separate disk for my backup files and earlier in the week I noticed this disk was filling up, a large amount of space was taken up by transactional backup files. I thought I don‚Äôt need to backup the transactions for this non critical database, I will just do a full backup at the start of everyday.</p> <p>However what I forgot is that a transactional backup keeps the log file under control, once this backup was stopped the log file grew uncontrollably. The answer, change the database from FULL mode to SIMPLE. <img class="img-fluid" alt="image002" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/image002-300x270.png" loading="lazy" width="300" height="270" /> </p> <p>This is my understanding of how backups work in FULL mode. A full backup is done at the start of the day which resets the log file, then changes in the database are stored in the log file, this is backed up into a transactional backup and the log file gets reset. If you have regular transactional backups throughout the day the log file doesn‚Äôt grow too much, however with no transactional backups your log file contains an entire days worth of changes and so for a monitoring database this could be quite large.</p> <p>In SIMPLE mode you can‚Äôt do transactional backups and the log doesn‚Äôt grow uncontrollably. This shouldn‚Äôt be used for production databases as if there is a problem you could loose data.</p>
              - generic [ref=e8435]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e8437]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e8438]:

            - generic [ref=e8446]:

              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/pragmatic-programmer-broken-windows/
