              - generic [ref=e8450]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e8451]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e8452]:
              - generic [ref=e8453]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 08 Jun 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e8454]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e8455]:
              - generic [ref=e8456]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/pragmatic-programmer-broken-windows/
              - generic [ref=e8457]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e8458]:
              - generic [ref=e8459]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8460]: term="Windows"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Windows
              - generic [ref=e8461]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8462]:
              - generic [ref=e8463]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8464]: term="Books"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Books
              - generic [ref=e8465]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8466]:
              - generic [ref=e8467]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8468]: term="Tips"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Tips
              - generic [ref=e8469]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8470]:
              - generic [ref=e8471]: <description>
              - text: "<p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/06/1-ucIHdOcnByPsF5eX0j_mhg.jpeg\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"2000\" height=\"1360\" /> </p> <p>Last night I started reading <a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Pragmatic-Programmer-Journeyman-Master-ebook/dp/B003GCTQAE/ref=mt_kindle?_encoding=UTF8&amp;me=\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">The Pragmatic Programmer by Andrew Hunt and David Thomas</a> .</p> <p>One practical tip that immediately jumped out at me as useful in my quest to be a better programmer: <strong>Don‚Äôt live with broken windows</strong>.</p> <p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/06/tpp.jpg\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"2200\" height=\"2800\" /> </p> <p>The theory goes like this: an abandoned building with a single broken window attracts additional broken windows, graffiti, litter, and a sense that no one cares about this building. However this can be avoided if the authorities repair the window straight away.</p> <p>You can apply this theory to other walks of life, too, like keeping your kitchen clean. After you‚Äôve spent hours cleaning your kitchen to make it spotless, you make an effort to keep it clean. But if your kitchen is piled high with dirty pans, leaving out an extra mug or dirty bowl isn‚Äôt going to feel like it makes any difference.</p> <p>The software engineering implications of this theory are that if you take care to keep your code tidy, it will stay that way. If you know something is broken but never make time to fix it, other bugs and issues will creep into it, until it‚Äôs a mess that no one dares touch.</p> <p>We have a website that is starting to get a bit buggy. It‚Äôs not broken, but it‚Äôs been a while since anyone has given it any love. Bits of its functionality are starting to get flaky.</p> <p>Being the only programmer in my place of work, I seldom have time to think about this website ‚Äî let alone sit down and maintain it.</p> <p>But the number of related support calls have been gradually increasing ‚Äî more windows are breaking ‚Äî and I‚Äôm spending more and more time patching its bugs to keep people happy.</p> <p>Know that I‚Äôm aware of the broken windows principle, I know exactly what to do: sit down with this website for a couple of days and find out what exactly is causing these issues.</p> <p>Then I‚Äôll rebuild the flaky bits, replace the proverbial cracked glass, and wash down a few walls while I‚Äôm at it.</p>"
              - generic [ref=e8472]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e8474]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e8475]:
          - generic [ref=e8478]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e8479]:
            - generic [ref=e8480]:
              - generic [ref=e8481]: <title>
              - text: I‚Äôm a developer now
              - generic [ref=e8482]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e8483]:
              - generic [ref=e8484]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/im-a-developer-now/
              - generic [ref=e8485]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e8486]:
              - generic [ref=e8487]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e8488]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e8489]:
              - generic [ref=e8490]: <pubDate>
              - text: Wed, 03 Jun 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e8491]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e8492]:
              - generic [ref=e8493]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/im-a-developer-now/
              - generic [ref=e8494]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e8495]:
              - generic [ref=e8496]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8497]: term="Self-Belief"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Self-Belief
              - generic [ref=e8498]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8499]:
              - generic [ref=e8500]: <description>
              - text: <p>For a while now I have been at the door of describing myself as a developer, but I think I have finally gone through that door.</p> <p>It is all a state of mind, its not about having x amount of knowledge, its just about saying ‚ÄúYeah, I‚Äôm a developer now.‚Äù</p> <p>One thing that pushed me through that door, was an application form for something in which I ticked the software developer box instead of the IT Manager box.</p> <p>The other thing is some of the tasks I worked on recently. One of our databases has a Web Service running that supplies a website with some figures, and we found out recently that this needed changing due to a change on this website. Our contractor quoted us to do this work, I think it was 8 hours. My boss said why don‚Äôt you have a go at doing it instead and save us money.</p> <p>So I had a go, thinking this will take me a couple of days at least, as I will have to figure out how the code works and end up not understanding it. But no I had the changes done in less time than the contractor had quoted us. Go Me! I will say that these changes have yet to be fully tested, so I still might end up spending more time on this.</p>
              - generic [ref=e8501]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e8503]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e8504]:
          - generic [ref=e8507]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e8508]:
            - generic [ref=e8509]:
              - generic [ref=e8510]: <title>
              - text: User Groups and F#
              - generic [ref=e8511]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e8512]:
              - generic [ref=e8513]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/user-groups-and-f/
              - generic [ref=e8514]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e8515]:
              - generic [ref=e8516]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e8517]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e8518]:
              - generic [ref=e8519]: <pubDate>
              - text: Sat, 30 May 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e8520]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e8521]:
              - generic [ref=e8522]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/user-groups-and-f/
              - generic [ref=e8523]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e8524]:
              - generic [ref=e8525]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8526]: term="F-Sharp"
                - text: ">"
              - text: F-Sharp
              - generic [ref=e8527]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8528]:
              - generic [ref=e8529]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8530]: term="C-Sharp"
                - text: ">"
              - text: C-Sharp
              - generic [ref=e8531]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8532]:
              - generic [ref=e8533]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8534]: term="Leeds-Sharp"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Leeds-Sharp
              - generic [ref=e8535]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8536]:
              - generic [ref=e8537]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8538]: term="UserGroups"
                - text: ">"
              - text: UserGroups
              - generic [ref=e8539]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8540]:
              - generic [ref=e8541]: <description>
              - text: "<p>For a while I have been threatening to try a user group. Well this week I went to my first meeting.</p> <p>The user group I went to is called <a href=\"https://www.meetup.com/Leeds-Sharp/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Leeds Sharp</a> who are celebrating their third birthday, happy birthday guys and thanks for the cake.</p> <p>The talk was all about F#. I know nothing about <a href=\"https://fsharp.org/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">F#</a> other than it is in visual studio. The speaker was <a href=\"https://twitter.com/ptrelford\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Phil Trelford</a> an expert in F# and former game developer who regularly speaks at conferences. Phil is an expert programmer, one of his stories was that while he had a broken arm, he wrote a copy of Excel in F#. Even with two hands I wouldn‚Äôt know where to start on something like that.</p> <p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/05/CGHJLlbWEAAbl14.jpg\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"1024\" height=\"577\" /> </p> <p>There are plenty of advantages to using F# over C#, fewer lines of code was one. In Phil‚Äôs example he had some C# code which was about 30 lines but the F# was 2, part of the reason for this is F# has no {}.</p> <p>I found myself thinking this must be too good to be true there must be some disadvantages to using F#?</p> <p>I don‚Äôt know what they are yet, I am guessing you need to play around with the language a bit to really understand them.</p> <p>One claim that was made was that F# has less bugs. I am unsure how this can be true. Code is written by humans, humans will make mistakes which ever language they choose, there will be bugs.</p> <p>After the group I came away with a few things to try out. Try the F# tutorial that can be found in Visual Studio, try a Koan, this is a piece of code that contains failing tests, in the process of fixing the tests you learn the language, come back next time to Leeds Sharp and learn something else.</p>"
              - generic [ref=e8542]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e8544]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e8545]:
          - generic [ref=e8548]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e8549]:
            - generic [ref=e8550]:
              - generic [ref=e8551]: <title>
              - text: Visual Studio
              - generic [ref=e8552]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e8553]:
              - generic [ref=e8554]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/visual-studio/
              - generic [ref=e8555]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e8556]:
              - generic [ref=e8557]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e8558]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e8559]:
              - generic [ref=e8560]: <pubDate>
              - text: Tue, 26 May 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e8561]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e8562]:
              - generic [ref=e8563]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/visual-studio/
              - generic [ref=e8564]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e8565]:
              - generic [ref=e8566]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8567]: term="CodeLens"
                - text: ">"
              - text: CodeLens
              - generic [ref=e8568]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8569]:
              - generic [ref=e8570]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8571]: term="Azure"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Azure
              - generic [ref=e8572]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8573]:
              - generic [ref=e8574]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8575]: term="VisualStudio"
                - text: ">"
              - text: VisualStudio
              - generic [ref=e8576]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8577]:
              - generic [ref=e8578]: <description>
              - text: <p>I recently replaced my installation of Visual Studio 2013 with Visual Studio 2015 RC.</p> <p>I like the new version, I am not a Visual Studio expert so it will probably take me a while to find all the good stuff but here are some initial thoughts.</p> <p>Being as my MSDN subscription is still valid I have installed the professional version to take advantage of its extra features like CodeLens.</p> <p>One of the first things I spotted was that the integration with Azure has been improved. In the last version it was difficult to sign in to Azure with the correct credentials, especially if you have more than one Azure account. Now you can add multiple Accounts and Subscriptions.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/05/i1.png" loading="lazy" width="582" height="252" /> </p> <p>CodeLens is a feature that has been around in Visual Studio since 2013, but in 2015 it is available in Professional meaning more people have access to it.</p> <p>CodeLens gives coders useful information at a glance. Above each class/method is listed how many references there are. If you click on the number of references you can see where that class or method is referenced in the rest of your code. Useful to be able to see which methods or classes are not being used.</p> <p>Next CodeLens shows who (according to git) last changed the class or method and how many days ago that was. Clicking on it shows a cool graph of when changes have happened and who did them.</p> <p>Next you can see the number of changes that have been made, basically a source control history, but without having to load up your git client.</p> <p>For code that doesn‚Äôt contain classes or methods such as T_SQL you can see at the bottom of your code window the last two CodeLens information to help you track down what changes have happened recently.</p> <p>The last new feature that I have noticed is the Light Bulbs that keep showing up all over my code. I think the Light Bulbs might be called Quick Actions, but whatever they are called they are suggestions on how to improve your code. So far they have suggested to be to get rid of using references that are not used, simplify a fully qualified name, drop unneeded this keywords. I am sure more will popup as I do more coding.</p> <p>These improvements to Visual Studio I like, and I am sure there are many more that I haven‚Äôt noticed. I expect support for the vNext .net framework is also in there somewhere which hopefully I can play around with soon.</p>
              - generic [ref=e8579]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e8581]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e8582]:
          - generic [ref=e8585]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e8586]:
            - generic [ref=e8587]:
              - generic [ref=e8588]: <title>
              - text: Overflow
              - generic [ref=e8589]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e8590]:
              - generic [ref=e8591]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/overflow/
              - generic [ref=e8592]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e8593]:
              - generic [ref=e8594]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e8595]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e8596]:
              - generic [ref=e8597]: <pubDate>
              - text: Fri, 22 May 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e8598]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e8599]:
              - generic [ref=e8600]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/overflow/
              - generic [ref=e8601]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e8602]:
              - generic [ref=e8603]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8604]: term="Database"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Database
              - generic [ref=e8605]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8606]:
              - generic [ref=e8607]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8608]: term="Access"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Access
              - generic [ref=e8609]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8610]:
              - generic [ref=e8611]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8612]: term="Integer"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Integer
              - generic [ref=e8613]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8614]:
              - generic [ref=e8615]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8616]: term="SQL"
                - text: ">"
              - text: SQL
              - generic [ref=e8617]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8618]:
              - generic [ref=e8619]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8620]: term="Overflow"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Overflow
              - generic [ref=e8621]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8622]:
              - generic [ref=e8623]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8624]: term="Variables"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Variables
              - generic [ref=e8625]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8626]:
              - generic [ref=e8627]: <description>
              - text: "<p>Today I encountered a new error.</p> <p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/05/error.jpg\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"385\" height=\"220\" /> </p> <p>Run-time error ‚Äò6‚Äô: Overflow doesn‚Äôt really tell me much. The error was occurring in the Access ADP front-end of our main database. It was only occurring for one particular Id number which was really confusing me.</p> <p>First thing I tried was to remove the most recent changes I had made, this made no difference. So time to look at the VBA code that was run just before the error.</p> <pre tabindex=\"0\"><code>Dim iPropertyId As Integer iPropertyId = DLookup(‚ÄúPropertyId‚Äù, ‚ÄúSurvey‚Äù, ‚Äú[ProjectNo]=‚Äù &amp; Me.ProjectNo) </code></pre><p>All looks good, even running the Dlookup query in SQL Management Studio threw no errors.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-sql\" data-lang=\"sql\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">SELECT</span> PropertyId <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">FROM</span> dbo.Survey <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">WHERE</span> ProjectNo <span style=\"color:#f92672\">=</span> </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Next thing I tried was explicitly setting iPropertyId to the problematic Id, still the same error.</p> <p>This made me look at the error message again. Overflow suggest something being too big, but what could it be.</p> <p>Integer has a size limit of 32,767 and the value I was trying to pass into iProperty was 32779. This was what was causing the problem, my database had grown to such a size that Integer was too small, I needed to change it to a Long Integer. Long has a size of 2,147,483,647 so my database should keep working for a while more.</p> <p>The famous programming help website <a href=\"https://stackoverflow.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Stack Overflow</a> is named after such an error. This error shows how difficult it is to decide what variable type to use, as you don‚Äôt know how quickly your database will grow.</p>"
              - generic [ref=e8628]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e8630]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e8631]:
          - generic [ref=e8634]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e8635]:
            - generic [ref=e8636]:
              - generic [ref=e8637]: <title>
              - text: Trying windows 10
              - generic [ref=e8638]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e8639]:
              - generic [ref=e8640]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/trying-windows-10/
              - generic [ref=e8641]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e8642]:
              - generic [ref=e8643]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e8644]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e8645]:
              - generic [ref=e8646]: <pubDate>
              - text: Sun, 17 May 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e8647]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e8648]:
              - generic [ref=e8649]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/trying-windows-10/
              - generic [ref=e8650]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e8651]:
              - generic [ref=e8652]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8653]: term="Windows8"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Windows8
              - generic [ref=e8654]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8655]:
              - generic [ref=e8656]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8657]: term="Windows10"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Windows10
              - generic [ref=e8658]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8659]:
              - generic [ref=e8660]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8661]: term="Format"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Format
              - generic [ref=e8662]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8663]:
              - generic [ref=e8664]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8665]: term="Reinstall"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Reinstall
              - generic [ref=e8666]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8667]:
              - generic [ref=e8668]: <description>
              - text: <p>My laptop has been getting a bit cluttered up with stuff so this weekend I gave it a reset.</p> <p>As I am using windows 8 this was much easier than doing a format reinstall which I have done many times with previous OSes. Open settings and select recovery and after about 4 hours everything was back to factory settings.</p> <p>I then installed a few updates and then installed the windows 10 preview. One of the requirements for windows 10 is Windows 8 Update (the one that came after 8.1), it took a few reboots and updates until I got that installed.</p> <p>I had purchased the pro pack which gives you the same features as windows 8 pro but I didn‚Äôt notice until after I installed 10 that this hadn‚Äôt been installed. I will need to roll back to windows 8 apply the update and then reinstall 10 again. I can‚Äôt really be bothered to do that, so I will live without HyperV for now. As it is I have done a lot of sitting around waiting for things to finish installing.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/05/win10.jpg" loading="lazy" width="888" height="537" /> </p> <p>I much prefer Windows 10 to Windows 8, an earlier preview had an issue with drivers for my second screen but that appears to have been resolved now. The start menu is back and I prefer it, to being taken to that extra screen of options that windows 8 had.</p> <p>I prefer the email client that windows 8 had to the windows 10 version as my work emails don‚Äôt work with it. I assume this is due to how my exchange server has been configured and maybe a later preview will allow my email to work or failing that I will have to get emails at work fixed properly.</p> <p>All apps now open in windows which is much nicer. Cortana is very similar to Google Home on my phone where I can talk and ask it stuff. But I never use this sort of feature apart from testing it.</p> <p>The new web browser has some nice features like the option to scribble over a web page but nothing that special that I think I will change my default browser from Chrome. It will be interesting to see how it performs in browser stats.</p> <p>I am part way through installing Visual Studio 2015 RC, but I think that will have to be a separate post.</p>
              - generic [ref=e8669]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e8671]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e8672]:

                - generic [ref=e8714]: term="SaaS"
                - text: ">"
              - text: SaaS
              - generic [ref=e8715]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8716]:
              - generic [ref=e8717]: <description>
              - text: <p>In Cloud Computing there are a lot of terms that end aas or As a Service. Most of these I hadn‚Äôt heard of until I started writing this list.</p> <p>Any service that is delivered over the internet instead of hosted locally on your network or PC could in theory be described as an As a Service.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/05/19656ee.jpg" loading="lazy" width="841" height="675" /> </p> <p><strong>PaaS Platform As a Service</strong></p> <p>This is one of the big ones. Microsoft Azure provides a Platform as a Service which I am familiar with. Platform as a Service is where a provider provides a platform where you can build apps or websites.</p> <p><strong>SaaS Software As a Service</strong></p> <p>Another popular one. Software as a Service can be as simple as a website that runs a service that a customer wants to use, I work for a company that provides a SaaS product.</p> <p><strong>IaaS Infrastructure As a Service</strong></p> <p>The last of the big ones. A good example of IaaS is a Virtual Machine which can either be hosted on a server somewhere (a private cloud) or on the internet via a company such as Azure (public cloud) The Pizza as a Service diagram illustrates the differences between Saas, PaaS and Iaas.</p> <p><strong>NaaS Network As a Service</strong></p> <p>This is just a type of IaaS that specializes in providing networking. Anything that provides network connectivity could be included in this category.</p> <p><strong>CaaS Communications As a Service</strong></p> <p>Another subtype of IaaS this time specializing in communications, this could include Voice over IP or other similar technologies.</p> <p><strong>MONaaS Monitoring As a Service</strong></p> <p>If you have a SaaS, PaaS or IaaS you will most likely want to monitor that it is working, I certainly do. This is something that is often included in your IaaS or PaaS package. Azure has various tools for monitoring and this could be included in this category.</p> <p><strong>BaaS Backup As a Service</strong></p> <p>With the growth of cloud storage and the decrease in its cost, backing up to the cloud is a very attractive option. Any service that allows you to backup and restore from the internet can be included in this category. Your provider needs to manage your backups for it to be truly BaaS rather than just another place to store your files.</p> <p><strong>DaaS Desktop As a Service</strong></p> <p>This is where your desktop is visualized and stored in the cloud. I know very little about this as I have never used it, but I would imagine you need a strong internet connection for it to work reliably.</p> <p><strong>DBaaS Database As a Service</strong></p> <p>This is a simple one if your database is stored in the cloud like Azure SQL Database then it fits into this category. If you run your own sql server install on a VM then it doesn‚Äôt fit in this category as you are still managing it yourself and is IaaS</p> <p><strong>HaaS Hardware As a Service</strong></p> <p>HaaS this is another subcategory of IaaS which concentrates on hardware.</p> <p><strong>IDaaS Identity As a Service</strong></p> <p>This is where the management of who you are is managed in the cloud. Single Sign-On could be achieved if a website redirected determining if you are who you say you are to a particular IDaaS. Azure Active Directory is an example of this.</p> <p><strong>SaaS Storage As a Service</strong></p> <p>You get the idea now, storing files on a remote cloud product is an example of Storage as a Service. DropBox or OneDrive are good examples of this.</p> <p>Writing this blog post has given me a better understanding of all the aaS that are out there. I am sure I haven‚Äôt explained some of these very well and no doubt missed some off.</p>
              - generic [ref=e8718]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e8720]: </item>

            - generic [ref=e8793]:
              - generic [ref=e8794]: <description>
              - text: "<p>I am going to take a break this week from talking about technology to talk about Star Trek.</p> <p>I have just listened to a <a href=\"http://www.trekmate.org.uk/ten-forward-episode-146-lists-are-dumb-but-this-episode-is-not/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">podcast</a> where they consider this <a href=\"https://uk.ign.com/articles/2009/05/08/top-25-star-trek-characters\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">list</a> of great Star Trek Characters. I am now going to try and come up with my own top 25 characters. Here we go.</p> <ol> <li><strong>Spock</strong>. My number one star trek character is Spock. Leonard Nimoy who recently passed away brilliantly brought this character to life. We have the inner turmoil that many of us can associate with, we have a journey to become more human, we have the pursuit of logic. We have the great interplay between him and McCoy and Kirk.</li> </ol> <p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/02/Spock_2293.jpg\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"720\" height=\"544\" /> </p> <ol start=\"2\"> <li> <p><strong>Data</strong>. My second number one star trek character, well OK, second star trek character is Data. His weekly exploration of what it meant to be human is star trek&rsquo;s best exploration of the human condition. There are so many moments which make me like Data but I think when he builds his daughter, Lal is possibly my favourite.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Picard</strong>. The Captain of the Enterprise. You want to know about leadership or diplomacy you watch Captain Picard in action. If only more of our world leaders could be like Captain Picard we would have all our Earthly problems sorted by tea-time.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Kirk</strong>. The original captain of the Enterprise, not so much a Diplomat but could talk a computer to death in minutes. A fun guy to be around as long as you didn‚Äôt work in security or want a long lasting relationship with him, (sorry ladies this guy is married to the Enterprise)</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Worf</strong>. Our favourite Klingon. The most honourable man on this list and could handle himself in a battle. Also popular with the ladies if Troi and Dax have anything to say about it.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Sisko</strong>. Our third captain, but Sisko had much more on his plate than the others. He had a Son to bring up, he lost his wife, he was in the middle of the biggest war the Federation has ever seen (at least on screen anyway), he became a religious icon and later a God.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>7 of 9</strong>. The sexy borg from Voyager what‚Äôs not to like? Also brought some much needed conflict to the Voyager crew.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Garak</strong>. The plain and simple tailor from DS9. But is he also a spy? There are so many layers to Garak you have no idea what to believe.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>McCoy</strong>. Bones to his friends. A great Doctor but even greater friend to Jim Kirk and Spock (not that either of them would admit it.)</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>EMH</strong>. Please state the nature of the medical emergency, started the show off as just another piece of technology and ended up one of the crews most important characters.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Janeway</strong> Coffee Addict and defeated the Borg our first female captain.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Dukat</strong>. DS9s regular bad guy. Started off Bad, then softened to be a good guy for a bit and then signed an alliance that started a war, in the middle of that he went crazy and ended up going to the Bajoran Hell</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Weyoun</strong>. The leader of the dominion from the Gamma Quadrant. Was a clone so he could be killed off a few times and still come back. Had some great interplay with Dukat and later Damar.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Damar</strong>. Started life as Dukat‚Äôs lieutenant and rose in rank to leader of his people, before switching sides to lead a rebellion.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Scotty</strong>. You cannae change the laws of Physics. An engineer that weekly performed miracles, more often because of large repair estimates.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Barclay</strong>. The only Starfleet officer that was unsure of himself and couldn&rsquo;t talk to people (Oh a bit like me then)</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Riker</strong> The Captain Kirk of Picard‚Äôs crew, could inspire his crew and was popular with the ladies, but looks better with a beard.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>O‚ÄôBrien</strong>. The everyman of DS9. He constantly had a station that was falling apart but he managed to keep it going, a bit like how I feel sometimes.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Quark/Rom/Nog</strong>. These three Ferengi made the Ferengi good again. Nog started off as comic relief and ended up a Starfleet officer after turning his back on the acquisition of profit. Rom like his son turned his back on profit to fix things, and Quark was the businessman always had his eye for profit.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Odo</strong>. The shape shifting outsider that maintained order. Was truly an outsider with no idea where he had come from, but eventually he came to tolerate and even love us Solids.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Martok</strong> Klingon with one eye that welcomed Worf into his house after his second dis-commendation.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Zefram Cochrane</strong> Without this guy there would be no Star Trek. Invented the warp drive and enjoyed drinking.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Uhura</strong> Just a communications officer, but in reality was so much more. One of the first black women on television and inspired a generation to better themselves, was the other half of the first inter-racial kiss</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Mirror Universe Hoshi</strong>. Our universe Hoshi Sato was timid and scared of warp drive, the mirror universe version ended up empress of an entire Empire.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Kai Winn</strong> Power corrupts and Absolute power corrupts absolutely and Kai Winn is a prime example of this, so blinded by power she couldn&rsquo;t hear what her precious Gods were telling her and ended up sleeping with her arch enemy.</p> </li> </ol> <hr> <h2 id=\"more-star-trek-content\">More Star Trek Content<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#more-star-trek-content\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>If you enjoyed this character ranking, check out these other Star Trek articles:</p> <ul> <li><a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2016/01/07/top-50-star-trek-episodes\">Top 50 Star Trek Episodes</a> - My ranking of the greatest episodes across all series</li> <li><a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2021/12/15/a-comparison-of-all-good-things-and-star-trek-picard\">A Comparison of All Good Things and Star Trek Picard</a> - Examining how Picard&rsquo;s future was predicted</li> <li><a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2016/02/18/star-trek-episode-review-the-best-of-both-worlds\">Star Trek Episode Review: The Best of Both Worlds</a> - A deep dive into the iconic Borg episode featuring Picard</li> <li><a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2023/picard-season-three\">Picard Season 3</a> - My thoughts on the final season of Star Trek Picard</li> <li><a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2024/trekranks\">TrekRanks #174</a> - My appearance on the TrekRanks podcast</li> </ul> <p><strong>Want more Trek content?</strong> Browse all my <a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/tags/trek\">Star Trek articles</a> </p>"
              - generic [ref=e8795]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e8797]: </item>

          - generic [ref=e8802]:
            - generic [ref=e8803]:
              - generic [ref=e8804]: <title>
              - text: Using your Rubber Duck
              - generic [ref=e8805]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e8806]:
              - generic [ref=e8807]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/rubber-duck/
              - generic [ref=e8808]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e8809]:
              - generic [ref=e8810]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e8811]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e8812]:
              - generic [ref=e8813]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 04 May 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e8814]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e8815]:
              - generic [ref=e8816]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/rubber-duck/
              - generic [ref=e8817]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e8818]:
              - generic [ref=e8819]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8820]: term="Lonely"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Lonely
              - generic [ref=e8821]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8822]:
              - generic [ref=e8823]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8824]: term="RubberDuck"
                - text: ">"
              - text: RubberDuck
              - generic [ref=e8825]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8826]:
              - generic [ref=e8827]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8828]: term="Troubleshooting"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Troubleshooting
              - generic [ref=e8829]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8830]:
              - generic [ref=e8831]: <description>
              - text: <p>Rubber Duck is a process in development where you talk through an issue with an inanimate object such as a Rubber Duck. It gets its name from the book The Pragmatic Programmer where it was first used.</p> <p>I am the only programmer where I work and often I find myself with a question that I can‚Äôt find the answer to. I do however have a few friends who are far more knowledgeable than I am about this sort of thing. I often find myself explaining my problem via an email to them. During the process of writing this email I have to explain my problem and this sometime reveals the problem and I don‚Äôt even need to send the email. At other times by the time they have replied to me, my brain has moved on with the problem sufficiently that I am close to a solution if I am not already there.</p> <p>Other people use different items as their ‚ÄòRubber Duck‚Äô, people on the code newbie forum have used items such as a cat, stuffed octopus, a Lego minfig, or just plain old talking to yourself.</p> <p>Being the only programmer in my office is difficult. A simple what do you think of this question that could be asked across the office has to be done inside my head and I may think a needlessly complex solution is better than a simple one just because I haven‚Äôt thought of the simpler version yet. There are of course advantages to being the only programmer, I can do what I want and learn any technology I like, but I am starting to think the advantages of programming in a group are outweighing programming alone.</p>
              - generic [ref=e8832]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e8834]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e8835]:
          - generic [ref=e8838]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e8839]:
            - generic [ref=e8840]:
              - generic [ref=e8841]: <title>
              - text: I might actually like SQL Server
              - generic [ref=e8842]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e8843]:
              - generic [ref=e8844]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/i-might-actually-like-sql-server/
              - generic [ref=e8845]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e8846]:
              - generic [ref=e8847]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e8848]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e8849]:
              - generic [ref=e8850]: <pubDate>
              - text: Thu, 23 Apr 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e8851]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e8852]:
              - generic [ref=e8853]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/i-might-actually-like-sql-server/
              - generic [ref=e8854]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e8855]:
              - generic [ref=e8856]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8857]: term="Learning"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Learning
              - generic [ref=e8858]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8859]:
              - generic [ref=e8860]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8861]: term="SQL"
                - text: ">"
              - text: SQL
              - generic [ref=e8862]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8863]:
              - generic [ref=e8864]: <description>
              - text: <p>How did this happen I think I may actually like SQL Server now?</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/download.jpg" loading="lazy" width="248" height="203" /> </p> <p>I remember a few years back when I used to grumble about writing a SQL query that included a JOIN. For some reason back then I could never get my head around JOINs.</p> <p>Today is a totally different story. I wrote a deployment script that did the following:</p> <ol> <li>dropped a database,</li> <li>restored a database from a backup file,</li> <li>Created a database table,</li> <li>copied the contents of a table into this table,</li> <li>disabled and re-enabled some triggers,</li> <li>dropped some constraints and columns from a table</li> <li>and renamed some columns.</li> </ol> <p>It‚Äôs not like I woke up this morning with SQL Server knowledge. For many years I have been adding extra features and changing functionality to our line of business database and over time my SQL confidence has grown.</p> <p>For every single one of the steps above I googled and looked up the SQL syntax (every time I write an insert or update statement I look up the syntax, one day it will stick in my brain!) I think the main reason is once you have used SQL for a while you get to see how it works and can split it down into small steps.</p> <p>As I <a href="https://www.funkysi1701.com/2015/04/21/weakest-database-design/">blogged</a> the other day I am currently working on improving a bad database and today I wanted to test the deployment process. All my changes are in a SSDT project so I took a backup of my database and tried to publish.</p> <p>Error! Your changes will result in data loss, no surprises there as I was expecting that error. The main culprit for this was a trigger I wrote but I didn‚Äôt find that out until the end of the day.</p> <p>As I was working on a backup I could do what I like including destructive changes. I tried creating a pre deployment script. I thought if that runs first, I can persuade SSDT that it matches SQL Server and therefore no data is being lost.</p> <p>This didn‚Äôt work, but I had created the start of my script mentioned above. I had steps 3 and 4. Lets try running my script first and then try running the deployment of my SSDT project. To get this to work I am going to have to rebuild my database a few times, I did this manually with SQL Management studio a couple of times until I thought, I could add this to my script ‚Äì that‚Äôs step 1 and 2 done.</p> <p>Then I got some errors about triggers so I tried disabling them and re-enabling them after it had finished. That‚Äôs step 5.</p> <p>Finally I needed to drop some columns, this resulted in an error about a constraint. A few trial and error run through‚Äôs to find out which constraints I needed to drop and then I could drop the columns.</p> <p>The last step was to rename some columns. I thought after this I can run publish from visual studio. No it still complained about data loss. I dropped another trigger and then I could run everything without any errors.</p> <p>Wohoo! Aren‚Äôt I clever. A simplified version of my code is below</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" style="color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;"><code class="language-sql" data-lang="sql"><span style="display:flex;"><span>USE master <span style="color:#f92672">-</span><span style="color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010">‚Äì</span>can<span style="color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010">‚Äô</span>t <span style="color:#66d9ef">drop</span> the <span style="color:#66d9ef">database</span> <span style="color:#66d9ef">if</span> its <span style="color:#66d9ef">open</span><span style="color:#f92672">!</span> </span></span><span style="display:flex;"><span><span style="color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010">‚Äì</span><span style="color:#f92672">-</span>Step <span style="color:#ae81ff">1</span> </span></span><span style="display:flex;"><span><span style="color:#66d9ef">DROP</span> <span style="color:#66d9ef">DATABASE</span> DBName </span></span><span style="display:flex;"><span> </span></span><span style="display:flex;"><span><span style="color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010">‚Äì</span><span style="color:#f92672">-</span>Step <span style="color:#ae81ff">2</span> </span></span><span style="display:flex;"><span>RESTORE <span style="color:#66d9ef">DATABASE</span> DBName <span style="color:#66d9ef">FROM</span> DISK<span style="color:#f92672">=</span><span style="color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010">‚Äô</span>E:<span style="color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010">\</span>DBName.bak<span style="color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010">‚Äô</span> </span></span><span style="display:flex;"><span><span style="color:#66d9ef">WITH</span> </span></span><span style="display:flex;"><span><span style="color:#66d9ef">MOVE</span> <span style="color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010">‚Äò</span>DBName_dat<span style="color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010">‚Äô</span> <span style="color:#66d9ef">TO</span> <span style="color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010">‚Äò</span><span style="color:#66d9ef">C</span>:<span style="color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010">\</span>Program Files (x86)<span style="color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010">\</span>Microsoft <span style="color:#66d9ef">SQL</span> Server<span style="color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010">\</span>MSSQL12.MSSQLSERVER<span style="color:#960050;background-color:#1e0010">\</span>MSSQL<span         - generic [ref=e8868]:
          - generic [ref=e8871]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e8872]:
            - generic [ref=e8873]:
              - generic [ref=e8874]: <title>
              - text: Weakest Database Design
              - generic [ref=e8875]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e8876]:
              - generic [ref=e8877]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/weakest-database-design/
              - generic [ref=e8878]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e8879]:
              - generic [ref=e8880]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e8881]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e8882]:
              - generic [ref=e8883]: <pubDate>
              - text: Tue, 21 Apr 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e8884]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e8885]:
              - generic [ref=e8886]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/weakest-database-design/
              - generic [ref=e8887]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e8888]:
              - generic [ref=e8889]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8890]: term="BadDesign"
                - text: ">"
              - text: BadDesign
              - generic [ref=e8891]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8892]:
              - generic [ref=e8893]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8894]: term="SQL"
                - text: ">"
              - text: SQL
              - generic [ref=e8895]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8896]:
              - generic [ref=e8897]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8898]: term="DatabaseDesign"
                - text: ">"
              - text: DatabaseDesign
              - generic [ref=e8899]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8900]:
              - generic [ref=e8901]: <description>
              - text: <p>I have been recently working on a database that hasn‚Äôt been designed but has been hacked together by lots of people over the years.</p> <p>It started life as an Microsoft Access database created by my director to keep track of all the projects that our company does. It was not much more than one table listing everything. At some point the data and frontend was split with the data being stored in SQL Server and the front end being an Microsoft Access ADP.</p> <p>Over the years more and more columns have been added to this table that it long ago became pretty much unmanageable. A few normalized tables exist but for the most part everything is stored in this one table which makes querying it very difficult. At the last count there were 81 columns in this one database table.</p> <p>Attempts to improve this database have been tried before but due to the fact that the whole company basically runs off this database and no one person knows everything that the database needs to do causes any changes to be very difficult. I suspect it may be beyond my abilities but I am going to give it a go.</p> <p>One advantage I have is version control. All the tables and the structure is in version control, so when I break things I can roll them back. Any changes to the front end are also in source control, these are harder to roll back in case of problems but not impossible.</p> <p>I have met with department heads to try and establish which of the 81 columns are being used and which could be dropped. Database design shouldn‚Äôt be a democracy, your databases should be designed in a way to store your data most efficiently. In this case it felt a bit like the database was playing ‚Äúthe weakest link‚Äù with everyone voting off unpopular columns. ‚ÄúYou are the weakest database column. Goodbye!‚Äù After much discussion I have over 30 columns that can be dropped and 10 or so that require further investigation.</p> <p>Using the Visual Studio project of the database, I removed the columns. This generated thousands of errors as most columns are included in loads of views and stored procedures. All these references need removing, so not a small job. This is made worse by the fact that the views and stored procedures are in a mess, and it is very hard to read the T-SQL code and see what is doing what. Part of my next job is going to be tidying up all these queries so I can see what‚Äôs what.</p> <p>The advantage of using the Visual Studio project to do these changes is that I can generate a SQL script of the changes and I can rerun a few times and test restoring different columns as it is unlikely to be a smooth deployment.</p>
              - generic [ref=e8902]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e8904]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e8905]:
          - generic [ref=e8908]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e8909]:
            - generic [ref=e8910]:
              - generic [ref=e8911]: <title>
              - text: Security Camera with Raspberry Pi Camera
              - generic [ref=e8912]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e8913]:
              - generic [ref=e8914]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/security-camera-with-raspberry-pi-camera/
              - generic [ref=e8915]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e8916]:
              - generic [ref=e8917]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e8918]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e8919]:
              - generic [ref=e8920]: <pubDate>
              - text: Wed, 15 Apr 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e8921]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e8922]:
              - generic [ref=e8923]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/security-camera-with-raspberry-pi-camera/
              - generic [ref=e8924]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e8925]:
              - generic [ref=e8926]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8927]: term="PHP"
                - text: ">"
              - text: PHP
              - generic [ref=e8928]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8929]:
              - generic [ref=e8930]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8931]: term="Camera"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Camera
              - generic [ref=e8932]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8933]:
              - generic [ref=e8934]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8935]: term="Bash"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Bash
              - generic [ref=e8936]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8937]:
              - generic [ref=e8938]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8939]: term="RaspberryPi"
                - text: ">"
              - text: RaspberryPi
              - generic [ref=e8940]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8941]:
              - generic [ref=e8942]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8943]: term="Project"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Project
              - generic [ref=e8944]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8945]:
              - generic [ref=e8946]: <description>
              - text: "<p>So my first Raspberry Pi project is a security camera. If you have read my previous Raspberry Pi posts you will know that I have been playing about with the camera but I had one or two problems with Pidora so I am using Raspbian for this example.</p> <p>To take a photo with the camera module you can use the command raspistill, this has lots of options you can view the full list by just running the command with no arguments. I will list a few options I have used.</p> <p>-o filename : this outputs an image to a file with name filename -vf : vertical flip -hf: horizontal flip these are useful if the camera is upside down etc -q number: quality of jpg image between 0 and 100, the default image size is around 3 Mb, I reduced it to quality = 10 which gave me an image size of 300Kb which is more reasonable -a text: annotate you image with some text, I found that the text needed to start with a character, numbers only failed for me.</p> <p>I want to script the creation of images, so I decided to name the files my script created with the time and date.</p> <p>This is fairly easy with a bash script.</p> <pre tabindex=\"0\"><code>DATE=$(date +‚Äù%Y-%m-%d_%H%M‚Äù) raspistill -q 10 -vf -hf -a a$DATE -o /var/www/$DATE.jpg </code></pre><p>The first $DATE is the date I have added to the image itself, because of the problem I encountered with annotating numbers only I have added an extra a to the start of this.</p> <p>It is now very easy to get CRON to run this script every few minutes, I decided to run it every 2 minutes.</p> <p>My next script tidies up so you don‚Äôt get overrun with images.</p> <pre tabindex=\"0\"><code>cd /var/www ls *.jpg &gt; stills.txt mencoder -nosound -ovc lavc -lavcopts vcodec=mpeg4:aspect=16/9:vbitrate=8000000 -vf scale=1920:1080 -o timelapse.avi -mf type=jpeg:fps=24 mf://@stills.txt rm /var/www/*.jpg </code></pre><p>The third line in this script does something really rather clever it creates a video from all the images you have taken. In order for this to work you will need to install mencoder (sudo apt-get install mencoder)</p> <p>This is all rather good but wouldn‚Äôt it be rather cool if this images were uploaded somewhere. If someone was up to no good and they might want to disable your security camera. My first thought was to use something like DropBox, but unfortunately it is not supported by the processor on a raspberry pi. However I have found <a href=\"https://copy.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">copy.com</a> to be rather good for syncing files.</p> <p>To install just run wget <a href=\"http://copy.com/install/linux/Copy.tgz\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">http://copy.com/install/linux/Copy.tgz</a> and extract the file to install the client on your raspberry pi.</p> <pre tabindex=\"0\"><code>./CopyConsole -daemon -u=gary@example.com -p=‚Äômypass‚Äô -root=/home/pi/Copy </code></pre><p>This command syncs the folder you have set in -root with copy.com.</p> <p>The last thing I did was create a php file running on the webserver that allows you to scroll through the different images. I experimented with using javascript to auto scroll through the images but I found the manual way more useful. All the files I have written I have added to my <a href=\"https://github.com/funkysi/RaspberryPi\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">github</a> page.</p>"
              - generic [ref=e8947]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e8949]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e8950]:
          - generic [ref=e8953]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e8954]:
            - generic [ref=e8955]:
              - generic [ref=e8956]: <title>
              - text: The Raspberry Pi Adventure Starts
              - generic [ref=e8957]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e8958]:
              - generic [ref=e8959]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/the-raspberry-pi-adventure-starts/
              - generic [ref=e8960]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e8961]:
              - generic [ref=e8962]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e8963]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e8964]:
              - generic [ref=e8965]: <pubDate>
              - text: Sat, 11 Apr 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e8966]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e8967]:
              - generic [ref=e8968]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/the-raspberry-pi-adventure-starts/
              - generic [ref=e8969]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e8970]:
              - generic [ref=e8971]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8972]: term="Linux"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Linux
              - generic [ref=e8973]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8974]:
              - generic [ref=e8975]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8976]: term="Fedora"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Fedora
              - generic [ref=e8977]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8978]:
              - generic [ref=e8979]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8980]: term="Camera"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Camera
              - generic [ref=e8981]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8982]:
              - generic [ref=e8983]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8984]: term="RaspberryPi"
                - text: ">"
              - text: RaspberryPi
              - generic [ref=e8985]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8986]:
              - generic [ref=e8987]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e8988]: term="Pidora"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Pidora
              - generic [ref=e8989]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e8990]:
              - generic [ref=e8991]: <description>
              - text: "<p>I am currently buzzing with excitement about my Raspberry Pi. I will try to document here what I have done so far.</p> <p>I decided to buy the camera module along with my Pi. It was straightforward to connect them up, lift the connector behind the network port, insert the ribbon cable, push connector back down.</p> <p>Next I connected up Keyboard, Mouse, Monitor, SD Card and Power. And my Pi had life.</p> <p>I was then given a screen full of options to install, Pidora is an OS which is based on Fedora which I have some experience of so I went with that one.</p> <p>After that was installed I was presented with a standard desktop with various programs installed.</p> <p>So far I had not plugged in a network cable because that would mean sitting in the hall next to the router, I thought before I do that lets see if wifi will work. I have a usb wifi adapter that I use with my PC, so I plugged that in.</p> <p>Nothing happened, having some experience of linux I wasn‚Äôt surprised. I went to network connections filled in the name of my wifi connection and its password and it connected. WOW! That was easy.</p> <p>So I then installed <a href=\"http://www.webmin.com/download.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">webmin</a> so I could remotely administer it and updated it with YUM. I also started the SSH service so I can use putty to login to my Pi from the comfort of my laptop. Even better than that I found a SSH client for my smart phone so I can even control my Pi from my phone!</p> <p>EDIT: I forgot that in order to get webmin to work I needed to do the following.</p> <p>mv /etc/redhat-release /etc/redhat-release.bak echo ‚ÄúFedora release 20 (Heisenbug)‚Äù &gt; /etc/redhat-release</p> <p>OK So now I am able to configure settings on my Pi from a browser or use SSH (Secure SHell) to login to run any command I like.</p> <p>Now lets lookup how to use the camera. The <a href=\"https://www.raspberrypi.org/documentation/configuration/camera.md\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">documentation</a> says that the camera first needs enabling using the command raspi-config. This command doesn‚Äôt exist in Pidora. Lets skip it and see if it works anyway. It does! The command raspistill -v -o test.jpg took a picture of my ceiling.</p> <p>Now how do I look at this picture remotely. SSH is a command line only interface, so I can see a 2Mb file has been created. How about installing a web server on my Pi?</p> <p>yum install httpd</p> <p>This install apache which is the default (and very popular) web server.</p> <p>service httpd start</p> <p>This starts the web server. Going to http://[IP] where [IP] is the ip address of your raspberry pi will show you the default apache page.</p> <p>Now if you run raspistill -v -o /var/www/html/image1.jpg it will create your photo on the web server.</p> <p>Not bad for my first steps, the command above could be scheduled and images taken every hour. There is also options for recording video.</p>"
              - generic [ref=e8992]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e8994]: </item>
