                - generic [ref=e9041]: term="Project"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Project
              - generic [ref=e9042]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9043]:
              - generic [ref=e9044]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9045]: term="Mono"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Mono
              - generic [ref=e9046]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9047]:
              - generic [ref=e9048]: <description>
              - text: <p>Many years ago I spent a lot of time learning about electronics. It was great fun, I can‚Äôt remember specific things I built, but learning what resistors and capacitors do was fascinating.</p> <p>I haven‚Äôt really thought about this much as my interests have been concentrated on computers and programming, but recently my interest has been peaked again.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/04/Raspberry_Pi_-_Model_A.jpg" loading="lazy" width="600" height="600" /> </p> <p>The <a href="http://www.codenewbie.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">CodeNewbie</a> and <a href="http://hanselminutes.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Hanselminutes</a> podcasts have been running a month of stuff about making things and doing clever things with hardware called <a href="http://marchisformakers.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">#Marchisformakers</a> , this began to start me thinking about this stuff again.</p> <p>Yesterday a friend of mine was showing me what he had been doing with a Raspberry Pi and Arduino. It is amazing what you can do with these tiny bits of technology and I was very impressed.</p> <p>Now I am thinking what mini project could I play around with and which piece of hardware should I base it on. I don‚Äôt know much about the two platforms yet but I have found a <a href="http://www.codenewbie.org/blogs/everything-you-ever-wanted-to-know-about-arduino-and-raspberry-pi" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">blog</a> post that introduces the two. My current thoughts are to start with the Raspberry Pi, it is a UK technology and it uses a linux OS (which I have some knowledge of).</p> <p>Being a windows developer, most of my programming knowledge is with C# and Visual Studio. To use my existing knowledge I could install and use MONO, which means I can program the Raspberry Pi using C# (see <a href="http://logicalgenetics.com/raspberry-pi-and-mono-hello-world/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">here</a> for more details about MONO on Raspberry Pi).</p> <p>But deciding on a language to use, doesn‚Äôt help me choose a project. I haven‚Äôt even got myself a Raspberry Pi yet so I may decide more once I have had a play around with it. Thoughts so far include getting wi-fi to work on the Raspberry Pi or maybe adding a camera and sticking it somewhere and taking pictures, maybe even build myself a baby monitor (might go down well with the wife if its baby related)</p>
              - generic [ref=e9049]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e9051]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e9052]:
          - generic [ref=e9055]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e9056]:
            - generic [ref=e9057]:
              - generic [ref=e9058]: <title>
              - text: Building a CI Server with TeamCity
              - generic [ref=e9059]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e9060]:
              - generic [ref=e9061]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/teamcity/
              - generic [ref=e9062]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e9063]:
              - generic [ref=e9064]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e9065]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e9066]:
              - generic [ref=e9067]: <pubDate>
              - text: Wed, 01 Apr 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e9068]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e9069]:
              - generic [ref=e9070]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/teamcity/
              - generic [ref=e9071]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e9072]:
              - generic [ref=e9073]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9074]: term="ContinuousIntegration"
                - text: ">"
              - text: ContinuousIntegration
              - generic [ref=e9075]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9076]:
              - generic [ref=e9077]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9078]: term="DevOps"
                - text: ">"
              - text: DevOps
              - generic [ref=e9079]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9080]:
              - generic [ref=e9081]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9082]: term="TeamCity"
                - text: ">"
              - text: TeamCity
              - generic [ref=e9083]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9084]:
              - generic [ref=e9085]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9086]: term="Test"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Test
              - generic [ref=e9087]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9088]:
              - generic [ref=e9089]: <description>
              - text: <p>TeamCity is a Continuous Integration software package which is very easy to install and set up. So easy I managed it over a weekend.</p> <p>First of all I fired up a VM in Azure. I found that a Basic A1 VM was sufficient so running a CI server doesn‚Äôt have to be expensive, alternatively you could always set a Virtual or Physical server on your own network, but that of course takes a bit longer to set up.</p> <p>Before I get too far you are probably asking what is Continuous Integration. A Continuous Integration server takes your code from your source control repository, it then automatically builds it, runs automated tests against it and can even deploy it to production. The main advantages of this is that you can see the health of you code, you can also test different configurations.</p> <p>So once you have a server ready, you need to install a few things. First <a href="https://www.jetbrains.com/teamcity/download/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">TeamCity</a> , just install with the default settings. My project is a Visual Studio project so I also needed to install Visual Studio (They have a free edition which does everything I need now, Thank you Microsoft) and SQL Server Express Edition.</p> <p>Once TeamCity is installed the rest of the config can be made via the web interface. To make it easier I pointed a domain at my VM (a CNAME record is probably better as an Azure IP address may change) and opened port 80 in the Azure config. First create a build config and then create a VCS Root, this is where you specify where your source control is. TeamCity supports Github and bitbucket and probably many others. You can specify which branch you want to checkout so you can test out the latest features you have written.</p> <p>Next you need to configure the steps needed to build your project, whatever you do in Visual Studio can be configured here. You then need to configure how often the build should run, it can be scheduled at specific times, this is how I remember CI servers being configured but now you can also have builds being triggered after commits to source control, very clever.</p> <p>That is just about all I have configured so far. My project has a few NUnit tests written for it, these are scheduled to run after every build. In my case 94 of them are currently failing so I now need to learn how my tests work.</p> <p>There are additional deployment steps that can be configured but I have not investigated these yet. Notifications about what CI is doing is also possible usually by email but there are other options available.</p>
              - generic [ref=e9090]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e9092]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e9093]:
          - generic [ref=e9096]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e9097]:
            - generic [ref=e9098]:
              - generic [ref=e9099]: <title>
              - text: Monitoring Screens
              - generic [ref=e9100]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e9101]:
              - generic [ref=e9102]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/monitoring-screens/
              - generic [ref=e9103]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e9104]:
              - generic [ref=e9105]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e9106]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e9107]:
              - generic [ref=e9108]: <pubDate>
              - text: Wed, 25 Mar 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e9109]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e9110]:
              - generic [ref=e9111]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/monitoring-screens/
              - generic [ref=e9112]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e9113]:
              - generic [ref=e9114]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9115]: term="BigScreen"
                - text: ">"
              - text: BigScreen
              - generic [ref=e9116]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9117]:
              - generic [ref=e9118]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9119]: term="Azure"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Azure
              - generic [ref=e9120]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9121]:
              - generic [ref=e9122]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9123]: term="jQuery"
                - text: ">"
              - text: jQuery
              - generic [ref=e9124]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9125]:
              - generic [ref=e9126]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9127]: term="Javascript"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Javascript
              - generic [ref=e9128]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9129]:
              - generic [ref=e9130]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9131]: term="Nagios"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Nagios
              - generic [ref=e9132]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9133]:
              - generic [ref=e9134]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9135]: term="Monitoring"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Monitoring
              - generic [ref=e9136]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9137]:
              - generic [ref=e9138]: <description>
              - text: "<p>We all know that it is important to monitor your servers and services, so you can spot issues before they become problems. I personally have spent a lot of time configuring <a href=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/2014/09/24/i-love-nagios/\">nagios</a> to email me about issues and I have recently been configuring various different alerts in Azure.</p> <p>My old boss has this idea that I should have a big monitor screen displaying all the vital stats of my servers and services, I personally disagree with this idea and think that notifications on my phone and email alerts are sufficient. He will no doubt correct my thinking when he reads this, but I believe part of his thinking is to make the monitoring of your infrastructure move visible and make it obvious to anyone that walks past that you have your eye on everything.</p> <p>For the purpose of this blog post lets assume he has convinced me and I have convinced my actual boss to spend money on the required technology to do this (No easy feat). What exactly would I display on this screen?</p> <p>I have Google Chromecast that I use for streaming various things to my TV, this is a relatively cheap bit of technology that could allow a TV or monitor to display a web page with the required stats displayed. <img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/03/perf.jpg\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"980\" height=\"349\" /> </p> <p>The two main sources of information that I want to display are New Relic for monitoring my azure websites and Nagios for monitoring my internal servers. New Relic allows you to easily export live performance data as iframes so I quickly threw together a web page full of these graphs. However if you have a static screen on the wall you don‚Äôt want to have to scroll to see different information so I needed to come up with another way to display this information.</p> <p>My first thought was a slide show. There are lots of javascript scripts that cycle through a series of images like a slideshow, this could be adapted to cycle through a series of iframes and display everything I want.</p> <p>My script goes something like this and requires jquery as well as javascript. First of all the script waits for the page to load completely with the ready function, it then defines the urls which will be put into the iframe one at a time. It than counts the number of urls you have. It then loops through changing the contents of the src attribute in the iframe every few seconds, in my example it changes every 9 seconds but once this is used in production you may want to increase this.</p> <div class=\"highlight\"><pre tabindex=\"0\" style=\"color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;\"><code class=\"language-html\" data-lang=\"html\"><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>&lt;<span style=\"color:#f92672\">script</span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">type</span><span style=\"color:#f92672\">=</span><span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;text/javascript&#34;</span>&gt; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span><span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">$</span>(document).<span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">ready</span>(<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">function</span>(){ </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">locations</span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">=</span> [<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;URL1&#34;</span>, <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;URL2&#34;</span>, <span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#34;etc&#34;</span>]; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">len</span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">=</span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">locations</span>.<span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">length</span>; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">iframe</span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">=</span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">$</span>(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#39;#frame&#39;</span>); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">var</span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">i</span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">=</span> <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">0</span>; </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">setInterval</span>(<span style=\"color:#66d9ef\">function</span> () { </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">iframe</span>.<span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">attr</span>(<span style=\"color:#e6db74\">&#39;src&#39;</span>, <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">locations</span>[<span style=\"color:#f92672\">++</span><span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">i</span> <span style=\"color:#f92672\">%</span> <span style=\"color:#a6e22e\">len</span>]); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span> }, <span style=\"color:#ae81ff\">9000</span>); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>}); </span></span><span style=\"display:flex;\"><span>&lt;/<span style=\"color:#f92672\">script</span>&gt; </span></span></code></pre></div><p>Now what information wants to be included in a script like this? Showing too much performance data can almost be as bad as not doing it at all as problems gets drowned out in the noise. For me I have performance of my websites, followed by Nagios problems, followed by the azure status page, followed by memory usage of all my servers and lastly showing number of connections to my databases. Another question to consider is what time scales do you want to graph over, too long and you don‚Äôt see what is happening now, but too short and you may only worry about an intermittent issue?</p>"
              - generic [ref=e9139]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e9141]: </item>

          - generic [ref=e9145]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e9146]:
            - generic [ref=e9147]:
              - generic [ref=e9148]: <title>
              - text: Networking Event
              - generic [ref=e9149]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e9150]:
              - generic [ref=e9151]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/networking-event/
              - generic [ref=e9152]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e9153]:
              - generic [ref=e9154]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e9155]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e9156]:
              - generic [ref=e9157]: <pubDate>
              - text: Sun, 22 Mar 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e9158]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e9159]:
              - generic [ref=e9160]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/networking-event/
              - generic [ref=e9161]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e9162]:
              - generic [ref=e9163]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9164]: term="ITManagers"
                - text: ">"
              - text: ITManagers
              - generic [ref=e9165]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9166]:
              - generic [ref=e9167]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9168]: term="Change"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Change
              - generic [ref=e9169]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9170]:
              - generic [ref=e9171]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9172]: term="Networking"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Networking
              - generic [ref=e9173]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9174]:
              - generic [ref=e9175]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9176]: term="ITBoss"
                - text: ">"
              - text: ITBoss
              - generic [ref=e9177]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9178]:
              - generic [ref=e9179]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9180]: term="Strategy"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Strategy
              - generic [ref=e9181]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9182]:
              - generic [ref=e9183]: <description>
              - text: <p>I recently went to an event called ITBoss organised by <a href="http://www.corecomconsulting.co.uk/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Core Com Consulting</a> . It was really good, helped partly by a free bar and great food.</p> <p>The event was hosted in a pub in central Leeds, so I rushed to the train station from work to get there. And yes I was the first to arrive (Why do I always do that?). The event was targeted at IT Leaders and Managers and was limited to about 20 people.</p> <p>To begin with I just chatted to the hosts and other people as we waited for everyone to arrive. Once we got going we had a short presentation about the need for Strategy. Interestingly the next day I suggested a strategy meeting with my director, so something must have sunk in from this.</p> <p>The main gist of the talk was that IT leaders need to pop there head up from day to day work to look at where they are going, and this should be matched with the overall direction of the company. I agree with this, recently I have been thinking of what direction our infrastructure needs to go in, it is currently just in my head, but at least that is a start. However our company directors are poor at sharing their long term vision, so it is hard for me to know where the company is going. I need to step up and challenge this behavior, so I can deliver the changes that are needed. Not easy but that is what the best IT leaders are doing.</p> <p>After this we broke for food, which was very nice. I had a chat with a couple of people. I found it interesting that one gentleman was surprised that I wanted to get into development. I think I understand why, most of the people in the room where senior managers, while I share their job titles, I don‚Äôt share their salaries. He saw development as a demotion, I see it as a promotion.</p> <p>After food we had some discussion questions. Mine was the first, How to convince others of the need for change? Some interesting ideas where presented, but it is the need to work closely with others, find out their requirements which is the difficult part not anything technical. The other topics of discussion where relating to recruiting people with skills that you have no knowledge of and around the topic of security and privacy in this modern age. Both were very interesting with lots of viewpoints expressed.</p> <p>I enjoyed the evening and hope to go to another at some point. Previous events I have been to have been technical, but lacked the networking that this one had. While I am not very good at networking, at this event it was easy to have a conversation or two with people.</p>
              - generic [ref=e9184]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e9186]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e9187]:
          - generic [ref=e9190]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e9191]:
            - generic [ref=e9192]:
              - generic [ref=e9193]: <title>
              - text: Source Control Fail
              - generic [ref=e9194]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e9195]:
              - generic [ref=e9196]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/source-control-fail/
              - generic [ref=e9197]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e9198]:
              - generic [ref=e9199]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e9200]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e9201]:
              - generic [ref=e9202]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 16 Mar 2015 00:00:00 +0000
              - generic [ref=e9203]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e9204]:
              - generic [ref=e9205]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/source-control-fail/
              - generic [ref=e9206]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e9207]:
              - generic [ref=e9208]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9209]: term="Git"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Git
              - generic [ref=e9210]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9211]:
              - generic [ref=e9212]: <description>
              - text: <p>Every developer uses source control, it is a great tool for keeping track of changes to your code, seeing who has done what.</p> <p>However I keep messing up, my use of it. I am fairly disciplined when creating new features, all my changes will get committed to source control and when I am happy I will deploy these changes to the live system. But as soon as there is a bug, especially one where the client is chasing for a fix, I will deploy a fix as soon as humanly possible on to the live system.</p> <p>At first glance there is nothing wrong with what I have described but what happens the next time I deploy a new feature. Yes the bug the client was complaining about gets deployed with the new feature as the fix was never committed into source control. The client gets angry as the bug he was screaming about is back again.</p> <p>Every change you make to the system <strong>MUST</strong> be committed to source control. If it isn‚Äôt that change will look like it never existed. I have worked with source control for over 5 years why do I keep making this rookie mistake over and over.</p> <p>Troy Hunt has a <a href="http://www.troyhunt.com/2011/05/10-commandments-of-good-source-control.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">blog post</a> about the 10 commandments of using source control. His number two commandment is ‚ÄúIf it‚Äôs not in source control, it doesn‚Äôt exist‚Äù He talks more about code you have written being not saved into source control, but the principal is the same for my example as his.</p> <p>There are ways to automatically deploy from source control, however most of the time you don‚Äôt want your live database being rebuilt because you fixed a typo. Additional steps will need to be implemented and there is still the chance that you might want to bypass these steps to fix the urgent problem. The only way past this problem is for you and everyone on your team to be disciplined and only ever commit to source control first, and only after that deploy live (either automatically or manually)</p>
              - generic [ref=e9213]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e9215]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e9216]:
          - generic [ref=e9219]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e9220]:
            - generic [ref=e9221]:
              - generic [ref=e9222]: <title>
              - text: Azure Traffic Manager
              - generic [ref=e9223]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e9224]:
              - generic [ref=e9225]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/azure-traffic-manager/
              - generic [ref=e9226]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e9227]:
              - generic [ref=e9228]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e9229]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e9230]:
              - generic [ref=e9231]: <pubDate>
              - text: Thu, 12 Mar 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e9232]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e9233]:
              - generic [ref=e9234]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/azure-traffic-manager/
              - generic [ref=e9235]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e9236]:
              - generic [ref=e9237]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9238]: term="Azure"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Azure
              - generic [ref=e9239]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9240]:
              - generic [ref=e9241]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9242]: term="DevOps"
                - text: ">"
              - text: DevOps
              - generic [ref=e9243]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9244]:
              - generic [ref=e9245]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9246]: term="ITAdmin"
                - text: ">"
              - text: ITAdmin
              - generic [ref=e9247]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9248]:
              - generic [ref=e9249]: <description>
              - text: <p>I have spent most of the day tweaking my Azure websites. Lots of fun!</p> <p>Last week unfortunately Azure had some problems and many websites that were running in the North Europe data centre were unavailable for several hours. And you guessed it my websites were hosted here.</p> <p>All hosting providers are going to have downtime from time to time and this is just something you have to take on the chin. The important thing to do in times like these is communicate with your customers about what is going on and that you are doing everything you can to restore service.</p> <p>However Azure has some amazing features that you can configure to help manage when downtime occurs.</p> <p>Azure is Microsoft‚Äôs global cloud platform. And it really is global, there are data centres in North Europe, West Europe, Brazil, Japan, two more in Asia and five in the US. In the event of problems it is highly unlikely that more than one of these would go down at once. If all of these are unavailable, I expect the planet earth is facing some kind of cataclysmic event and the fact that my website is down is not a priority.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="Azure Traffic Manager" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/IC750592.jpg" loading="lazy" width="856" height="449" /> To take advantage of these multiple data centres, Azure has something called a Traffic Manager.</p> <p>Traffic Manager has various settings but I am using it in failover mode. This means that if one website goes down, the next one is used.</p> <p>All you need to do is create a traffic manager, add two or more websites to it (called endpoints) and choose a page that needs to be monitored so Azure knows which websites are up and which are down.</p> <p>If you are using SSL or custom domain names, there are a few extra steps you need to do. Your custom domain name needs pointing at the traffic manager, not the individual websites. The websites themselves have three domain names, the traffic manager address, the azure address and the custom domain name. The SSL certificate can then be assigned to each website that you have added to the traffic manager.</p> <p>That was easy wasn‚Äôt it, and now if a website goes down traffic manager will use the next one. While testing this, the transition to the next website was almost immediate. I did notice that if you had a browser showing the website open during a problem you sometimes got an error page, I think this was probably due to browser caching, reopening a tab or browser fixed this issue.</p>
              - generic [ref=e9250]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e9252]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e9253]:
          - generic [ref=e9256]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e9257]:
            - generic [ref=e9258]:
              - generic [ref=e9259]: <title>
              - text: Tidying my desktop
              - generic [ref=e9260]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e9261]:
              - generic [ref=e9262]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/tidying-my-desktop/
              - generic [ref=e9263]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e9264]:
              - generic [ref=e9265]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e9266]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e9267]:
              - generic [ref=e9268]: <pubDate>
              - text: Wed, 11 Mar 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e9269]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e9270]:
              - generic [ref=e9271]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/tidying-my-desktop/
              - generic [ref=e9272]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e9273]:
              - generic [ref=e9274]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9275]: term="PowerShell"
                - text: ">"
              - text: PowerShell
              - generic [ref=e9276]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9277]:
              - generic [ref=e9278]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9279]: term="Desktop"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Desktop
              - generic [ref=e9280]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9281]:
              - generic [ref=e9282]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9283]: term="ITAdmin"
                - text: ">"
              - text: ITAdmin
              - generic [ref=e9284]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9285]:
              - generic [ref=e9286]: <description>
              - text: <p>My desktop is always a mess. I constantly download files there and forget all about them.</p> <p>Every now and then I copy files into sub directories, so my desktop looks sane for a day or two before it gets out of control again.</p> <p>Why don‚Äôt I write a script that I can schedule to do this for me. Then my desktop will always be tidy.</p> <p>I have written a few simple batch scripts, but of course the best scripting language out there at the moment is PowerShell. Lets use that.</p> <p>Windows provides a nice little utility for writing scripts called the Windows PowerShell ISE, so let&rsquo;s start by loading that up.</p> <p>PS has lots of help included to help you, just run <strong>Get-Help [name of ps command]</strong></p> <p>To move files you can use <strong>Move-Item</strong> which works very similar to copy, specify source and destination. In my case I moved files based on their file extension.</p> <p>Move-Item *.pdf folder</p> <p>Now all I need to do is schedule this script to run either every day or so, or maybe every time I login or switch my computer on.</p> <p>PowerShell can do lots more interesting things which hopefully I will blog about soon.</p>
              - generic [ref=e9287]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e9289]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e9290]:
          - generic [ref=e9293]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e9294]:
            - generic [ref=e9295]:
              - generic [ref=e9296]: <title>
              - text: Database Deployment
              - generic [ref=e9297]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e9298]:
              - generic [ref=e9299]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/database-deployment/
              - generic [ref=e9300]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e9301]:
              - generic [ref=e9302]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e9303]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e9304]:
              - generic [ref=e9305]: <pubDate>
              - text: Thu, 05 Mar 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e9306]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e9307]:
              - generic [ref=e9308]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/database-deployment/
              - generic [ref=e9309]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e9310]:
              - generic [ref=e9311]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9312]: term="Deployment"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Deployment
              - generic [ref=e9313]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9314]:
              - generic [ref=e9315]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9316]: term="Database"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Database
              - generic [ref=e9317]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9318]:
              - generic [ref=e9319]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9320]: term="SQL"
                - text: ">"
              - text: SQL
              - generic [ref=e9321]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9322]:
              - generic [ref=e9323]: <description>
              - text: <p>One of my jobs is adding extra features to our internal databases. There is a fair amount of risk in doing this. I could make a change to one of the queries in the database that stops the rest of the company using it as they need to. This could be a costly mistake, almost as bad as the database server being inaccessible.</p> <p>One way to reduce this risk is to test, test and test the database. First I take a backup of the database and make my changes to that. I can do anything I like to my backup database without worrying that it will affect anyone else. Once I have finished making my changes and I have tested that everything is working exactly as I want, I need to apply my changes to the production database.</p> <p>Until recently I made a note of every change that I have made and then made the same change to the production database. But what if I forget to apply one of my changes to production, I have a broken database on my hands, disaster!</p> <p>But there is a better way to track database changes. SSDT or SQL Server Data Tools.</p> <p>Create a Database project with Visual Studio, you can then point this at your live database. This will scan the database and save scripts for all the Tables, Views, Stored Procedures, Triggers and any other object in the database. This doesn‚Äôt import the data, just the structures that contain the data. So no data protection issues or problems because your database is terabytes in size.</p> <p>Now comes the really cool part, Visual Studio allows you to build a copy of the database from these scripts. All you need to do is edit the scripts and test like you did before. Once you are happy with your changes and everything is working as you want, you can point your visual studio project back at your production database and it will magically deploy all your changes, or if you are as paranoid as me about breaking things, it will create a script that you can thoroughly analyse before running on your production database.</p> <p>I do not know why I never thought of setting this up until recently, it will reduce the number of times I roll out my changes but forget to setup permissions, (these can be scripted) or forget that tiny change I did weeks ago but never rolled out.</p> <p>And of course all the changes that you make can be saved in source control, so easy to see what changes have been made and by whom.</p> <p>This process even works with complicated database structures, in my case I needed to setup three database projects that depend on each other. Dependencies can be setup, and the test databases can even be built with different names for testing on the production server, (although I wouldn‚Äôt recommend it!)</p>
              - generic [ref=e9324]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e9326]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e9327]:
          - generic [ref=e9330]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e9331]:
            - generic [ref=e9332]:
              - generic [ref=e9333]: <title>
              - text: He‚Äôs really not dead as long as we remember him ‚Äì Leonard Nimoy
              - generic [ref=e9334]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e9335]:
              - generic [ref=e9336]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/hes-really-not-dead-as-long-as-we-remember-him/
              - generic [ref=e9337]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e9338]:
              - generic [ref=e9339]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e9340]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e9341]:
              - generic [ref=e9342]: <pubDate>
              - text: Sat, 28 Feb 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e9343]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e9344]:
              - generic [ref=e9345]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/hes-really-not-dead-as-long-as-we-remember-him/
              - generic [ref=e9346]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e9347]:
              - generic [ref=e9348]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9349]: term="Science"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Science
              - generic [ref=e9350]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9351]:
              - generic [ref=e9352]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9353]: term="LeonardNimoy"
                - text: ">"
              - text: LeonardNimoy
              - generic [ref=e9354]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9355]:
              - generic [ref=e9356]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9357]: term="StarTrek"
                - text: ">"
              - text: StarTrek
              - generic [ref=e9358]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9359]:
              - generic [ref=e9360]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9361]: term="Spock"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Spock
              - generic [ref=e9362]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9363]:
              - generic [ref=e9364]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9365]: term="Technology"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Technology
              - generic [ref=e9366]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9367]:
              - generic [ref=e9368]: <description>
              - text: "<p>n the film Star Trek 2: The Wrath of Khan Spock sacrifices himself to save the Enterprise from destruction. What follows is a very moving funeral scene and his coffin is launched into space. McCoy tells Kirk that he is not dead as long as we remember him.</p> <p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/02/Spock_2293.jpg\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"720\" height=\"544\" /> </p> <p>Yesterday the actor Leonard Nimoy passed away and millions of trekkies around the world are taking comfort in those words.</p> <p>Reading social media it is clear that he affected the lives of millions of people with his portrayal of Spock. I have seen tweets from NASA and astronauts saying how they were encouraged by Star Trek. The chip manufacturer Intel even tweeted about his death. I am sure there are many in the science and technology space that could say Mr Spock encouraged them in some way.</p> <p>The portrayal of science and technology in Star Trek had an affect on me. I studied Mathematics, Chemistry and Physics at school, I later did a Physics degree. All because the spark of curiosity about how stuff works was encouraged by a TV show. I remember one time while studying physics learning about the hysteresis curve, then Star Trek the next day mentions detecting changes in the hysteresis curve might solve some problem. Wow the stuff I am learning is in Star Trek!</p> <p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/02/color_nimoy_headshot.jpg\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"393\" height=\"500\" /> </p> <p>Later in my life I got involved in working with computers, and as science officer Mr Spock was the first expert in computers I knew.</p> <p>But Mr Spock was half Vulcan and suppressed his emotions. There have been times in my life where I have tried really hard to suppress my emotions. I can think of a time when a family member has died and I needed to shut myself in a room, similar to Spock in Naked Time, and wrestle with my emotions. In recent years I have had a more Data approach of exploring my feelings and my humanity as a Vulcan lifestyle of suppressed emotion is not healthy.</p> <p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/02/74cc28416b646ae6f87d5a502fbd03b7.jpg\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"500\" height=\"503\" /> </p> <p>Thank you Leonard Nimoy for all that you gave us, although I never met you I can continue to watch and enjoy your work, Live Long and Prosper.</p>"
              - generic [ref=e9369]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e9371]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e9372]:
          - generic [ref=e9375]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e9376]:
            - generic [ref=e9377]:
              - generic [ref=e9378]: <title>
              - text: Source Code for Game of Life
              - generic [ref=e9379]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e9380]:
              - generic [ref=e9381]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/source-code-for-game-of-life/
              - generic [ref=e9382]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e9383]:
              - generic [ref=e9384]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e9385]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e9386]:
              - generic [ref=e9387]: <pubDate>
              - text: Sat, 21 Feb 2015 09:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e9388]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e9389]:
              - generic [ref=e9390]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/source-code-for-game-of-life/
              - generic [ref=e9391]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e9392]:
              - generic [ref=e9393]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9394]: term="Java"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Java
              - generic [ref=e9395]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9396]:
              - generic [ref=e9397]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9398]: term="SourceCode"
                - text: ">"
              - text: SourceCode
              - generic [ref=e9399]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9400]:
              - generic [ref=e9401]: <description>
              - text: <p>Last week I blogged about the Game of Life.</p> <p>Well it took some searching through dead hard drives and old USB storage but I found the program I wrote, and better than that I have figured out how to turn it back into source code.</p> <p>The file date is November 2004 and the source code has no comments so I don‚Äôt know what was going through my head when I wrote it, or even what some of it does.</p> <p>To view the source code download <a href="https://www.funkysi1701.com/images/2015/02/Life.src_.zip">Life.src</a> , to download the finished program download <a href="https://www.funkysi1701.com/images/2015/02/Life.zip">Life</a> .</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="Life" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/02/Life.jpg" loading="lazy" width="595" height="300" /> </p> <p>I am actually surprised I was expected the code to be much worse than it was, I am not saying it is good, but I can see more than one method and I can‚Äôt see any code that obviously is repeated. I can see some terrible variable names. Note to future self don‚Äôt use tmp676_674!</p> <p>Assuming that I wrote this in 2004 what would I have been doing then? It was before I started working in IT. (Hard to imagine I know!) It may even have been before I started living with Keith, before he recruited me for my first IT role. I think I was probably working as an administrator for Defra at this point.</p> <p>If we put 2004 in technical terms, it was before I joined facebook, Office 2003 and XP would have been installed on my PC, and probably felt brand new.</p>
              - generic [ref=e9402]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e9404]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e9405]:
          - generic [ref=e9408]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e9409]:
            - generic [ref=e9410]:
              - generic [ref=e9411]: <title>
              - text: Cloud Computing
              - generic [ref=e9412]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e9413]:
              - generic [ref=e9414]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/cloud-computing/
              - generic [ref=e9415]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e9416]:
              - generic [ref=e9417]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e9418]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e9419]:
              - generic [ref=e9420]: <pubDate>
              - text: Thu, 19 Feb 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e9421]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e9422]:
              - generic [ref=e9423]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/cloud-computing/
              - generic [ref=e9424]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e9425]:
              - generic [ref=e9426]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9427]: term="Clouds"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Clouds
              - generic [ref=e9428]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9429]:
              - generic [ref=e9430]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9431]: term="Azure"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Azure
              - generic [ref=e9432]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9433]:
              - generic [ref=e9434]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9435]: term="Google"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Google
              - generic [ref=e9436]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9437]:
              - generic [ref=e9438]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9439]: term="Computing"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Computing
              - generic [ref=e9440]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9441]:
              - generic [ref=e9442]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9443]: term="OneDrive"
                - text: ">"
              - text: OneDrive
              - generic [ref=e9444]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9445]:
              - generic [ref=e9446]: <description>
              - text: <p>I work for a company that provides a cloud computing website, but what is Cloud Computing?</p> <p><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloud_computing" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Wikipedia</a> defines it as ‚ÄúCloud computing involves deploying groups of remote servers and software networks that allow centralized data storage and online access to computer services or resources.‚Äù</p> <p>Erm. What does that mean? Well in simple terms it means storing you data on a remote server. Any time you submit information onto a website, you are submitting your information to the ‚ÄúCloud‚Äù</p> <p>But there is more that the Cloud can do for you. The search giant Google, which also develops the android mobile phone operating system, have developed a range of cloud computing products. The Google Drive product allows you to upload and even create files, these files are saved into the Cloud, once in the cloud they can be accessed from any device that has an internet connection. No longer do you run the risk of your favourite file being on a computer that won‚Äôt turn on or being on a dead hard drive, save it to the cloud and you will always have access to it.</p> <p>Google isn‚Äôt the only one that does this, Microsoft have OneDrive which they are incorporating into the heart of their operating system, Apple and many other companies have released similar products.</p> <p>This age of cloud computing allows a clearer separation between your data and your device. It won‚Äôt be long before whatever device you are using your files will be there to be worked on. You are in the office working on a spreadsheet, you save it to the Cloud, you can then continue working on it with your tablet while on the road. Just before bed you want to check if you added something to that doc, so you quickly check your phone. How cool is this!</p> <p>But if I put my system administer hat on, Cloud computing goes far further than that. Microsoft Azure allows many of the services you would typically have running on your server, saved into the cloud. This has many advantages and allows you to concentrate on other problems while leaving the cloud to look after these services.</p>
              - generic [ref=e9447]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e9449]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e9450]:
          - generic [ref=e9453]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e9454]:
            - generic [ref=e9455]:
              - generic [ref=e9456]: <title>
              - text: Choosing a Blog Theme
              - generic [ref=e9457]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e9458]:
              - generic [ref=e9459]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/blog-theme/
              - generic [ref=e9460]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e9461]:
              - generic [ref=e9462]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e9463]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e9464]:
              - generic [ref=e9465]: <pubDate>
              - text: Sun, 15 Feb 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e9466]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e9467]:
              - generic [ref=e9468]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/blog-theme/
              - generic [ref=e9469]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e9470]:
              - generic [ref=e9471]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9472]: term="Theme"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Theme
              - generic [ref=e9473]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9474]:
              - generic [ref=e9475]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9476]: term="Blogging"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Blogging
              - generic [ref=e9477]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9478]:
              - generic [ref=e9479]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9480]: term="WordPress"
                - text: ">"
              - text: WordPress
              - generic [ref=e9481]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9482]:
              - generic [ref=e9483]: <description>
              - text: <p>You may have noticed that my blog has a new home. It can now be found on its own domain <a href="https://www.funkysi1701.com">https://www.funkysi1701.com</a> . This change not only gives me more flexibility to make any change I like, it also feels good to have a website again. If you had followed my blog, do keep following it at the new location.</p> <p>I have also been playing about with giving the site a new look, hope you all like it. I have gone for a more image focussed front page. No doubt in a few weeks I will be bored and change the look again.</p> <p>I have recently been reading about blogging and one suggestion is to have a clear theme, or idea of what the blog is about. I am not sure my blog has a clear theme.</p> <p>When I started blogging I was more interested in blogging than thinking about what I was blogging about. The vague theme I worked off was to talk about what I do, to answer the question, &ldquo;What do you do?&rdquo;</p> <p>I think this is a fairly good theme, but it could probably do with some refinement. The best themed blogs are specialist or about something specific. As I am generally learning about development, rather than doing development I think this should be part of what I concentrate my blogs about. A minority of my blogs can continue to be about the other things I spend my time doing, as it‚Äôs always good to have a break from the main ‚Äúmeat‚Äù of the blog every now and then.</p> <p>The people who read my blogs are split between technical people and non-technical people, so I would like to continue to explain what I do in non-technical terms. This is an essential skill for a developer (or SysAdmin) as you will always need to explain what you are doing, or discuss requirements. It is not an easy skill and like development itself, the more I do it the better at it I will become.</p> <p>So watch this space for the blogs to come. I know I will be working with Azure over the next few weeks so maybe some blogs about that, maybe some more SQL blogs or maybe about what I learn next.</p>
              - generic [ref=e9484]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e9486]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e9487]:
          - generic [ref=e9490]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e9491]:
            - generic [ref=e9492]:
              - generic [ref=e9493]: <title>
              - text: "Ten Forward Episode #135 ‚Äì Anti Firbob is Back or Simon‚Äôs Desert Island Trek"
              - generic [ref=e9494]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e9495]:
              - generic [ref=e9496]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/ten-forward-episode-135-anti-firbob-is-back-or-simons-desert-island-trek/
              - generic [ref=e9497]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e9498]:

              - text: funkysi1701

            - generic [ref=e9501]:

            - generic [ref=e9504]:
              - generic [ref=e9505]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/ten-forward-episode-135-anti-firbob-is-back-or-simons-desert-island-trek/
              - generic [ref=e9506]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e9507]:
              - generic [ref=e9508]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9509]: term="StarTrek"
                - text: ">"
              - text: StarTrek
              - generic [ref=e9510]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9511]:
              - generic [ref=e9512]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9513]: term="Podcast"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Podcast
              - generic [ref=e9514]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9515]:
              - generic [ref=e9516]: <description>
              - text: <p>The podcast I recorded the other week has been released, why not have a listen by heading over to <a href="http://www.trekmate.org.uk/ten-forward-episode-135-anti-firbob-is-back-or-simons-desert-island-trek/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">trekmate.org.uk</a> and comment on their forums</p> <p>This week Sina, Chris and Paul welcome Simon Foster, Trek Mate‚Äôs News Editor, to do discuss his Desert Island Trek choices. Paul becomes Firbob, or AntiFirbob, or&hellip;something like that. Boo hiss Firbob. Every one listen and decide ‚Äì Simon or Firbob?</p> <p>You can reach Simon here:</p> <p><a href="https://twitter.com/funkysi1701" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">@funkysi1701</a> </p> <p>Complaints to @firbob1</p> <p>You can reach the rest of the gang here:</p> <p><a href="https://twitter.com/queenkatblue" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">@queenkatblue</a> , <a href="https://twitter.com/chriscantfly" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">@chriscantfly</a> , or <a href="https://www.facebook.com/TenForwardPod" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">facebook.com/TenForwardPod</a> </p>
              - generic [ref=e9517]: </description>
