        - generic [ref=e9520]:
          - generic [ref=e9523]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e9524]:
            - generic [ref=e9525]:
              - generic [ref=e9526]: <title>
              - text: Game of Life
              - generic [ref=e9527]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e9528]:
              - generic [ref=e9529]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/game-of-life/
              - generic [ref=e9530]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e9531]:
              - generic [ref=e9532]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e9533]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e9534]:
              - generic [ref=e9535]: <pubDate>
              - text: Wed, 11 Feb 2015 09:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e9536]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e9537]:
              - generic [ref=e9538]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/game-of-life/
              - generic [ref=e9539]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e9540]:
              - generic [ref=e9541]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9542]: term="Java"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Java
              - generic [ref=e9543]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9544]:
              - generic [ref=e9545]: <description>
              - text: <p>Many, many years ago I tried to learn Java. I didn‚Äôt get very far but one of the things I built was The Game of Life.</p> <p>Unfortunately I can not find the code I wrote, probably a good things as it is probably amusingly bad.</p> <p>Now you are probably asking what is the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conway%27s_Game_of_Life" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Game of Life</a> ? The game of life, sometimes called cellular automation, is a simulation of cells being born and dying. It is sometimes called Conway‚Äôs Game of Life after the British mathematician who devised it in 1970.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/Gospers_glider_gun.gif" loading="lazy" width="250" height="180" /> </p> <p>The game has several rules:</p> <ol> <li>Any cell with less than three neighbours will die on the next turn</li> <li>Any cell with three neighbours lives on to the next turn</li> <li>Any cell with more than three neighbours will die on the next turn</li> <li>Any dead cell with three live neighbours will be born on the next turn</li> </ol> <p>Now I had not thought about this game until the other day when I came across a <code>https://chaosnil.wordpress.com/2015/02/09/new-project-conways-game-of-life-in-every-language/</code> and a <code>https://github.com/chaomodus/gameoflife</code> which sparked my interest again. This version is written in javascript, but the blog mentions a desire to build this program in many different languages. I want to build this with visual studio in C# as it should provide a good training exercise.</p> <p>There are several problems I need to overcome to achieve this, I am currently trying to work out how to &ldquo;draw&rdquo; the cells. My current thinking is that maybe I can code it using characters to display the cells and then replace with pixels once I have the logic correct. Well lots for me to learn!</p>
              - generic [ref=e9546]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e9548]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e9549]:
          - generic [ref=e9552]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e9553]:
            - generic [ref=e9554]:
              - generic [ref=e9555]: <title>
              - text: Great British Code Off
              - generic [ref=e9556]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e9557]:
              - generic [ref=e9558]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/great-british-code-off/
              - generic [ref=e9559]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e9560]:
              - generic [ref=e9561]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e9562]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e9563]:
              - generic [ref=e9564]: <pubDate>
              - text: Sat, 07 Feb 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e9565]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e9566]:
              - generic [ref=e9567]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/great-british-code-off/
              - generic [ref=e9568]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e9569]:
              - generic [ref=e9570]: <description>
              - text: <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="Great British Code Off" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/02/logo.jpg" loading="lazy" width="242" height="157" /> </p> <p>The Great British Bake Off and The Great British Sewing Bee are very popular TV shows. Each week the contestants take part in a baking or sewing challenge and the judges choose the best and the worst, with the worst having to leave. This is very entertaining as you watch the drama between the contestants and the reactions as the judges tell them they are rubbish.</p> <p>Could this simple format be applied to computer programming? I think it could.</p> <p>The only developers I know argue about the best way of tackling different problems, despite being friends. I am going to assume that this is typical behaviour and not unique to them. So for this TV show, we will split the contestants into pairs, that way we would get the added drama of how well they work together.</p> <p>I am still undecided if the pairs stick together each week with one pair leaving or if we randomize the pairs with one person leaves. The second option would cause there to be a group of three every other week, not sure if this would be a benefit or a curse for that group.</p> <p>My friends who are experienced programmers have agreed to be the judges, they both have experience of hiring and firing people, know what to look for in good code, and never agree so should be entertaining enough.</p> <p>On the bake off the contestants don‚Äôt really know how well they have done until the judges cut into their cake and take a bite. For the code off we could not compile the code until the judges run it, would make coding extra difficult as if the contestants are anything like me, I run my code every five minutes to see what affect that change has made.</p> <p>So what challenges can we come up with?</p> <ul> <li>Web Design week</li> <li>Stored Procedure week</li> <li>Mobile App week</li> <li>Loops</li> <li>Logic problems</li> <li>Bugs weeks</li> <li>Performance issues</li> </ul> <p>I think we are onto a winner here. What does everyone else think?</p>
              - generic [ref=e9571]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e9573]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e9574]:
          - generic [ref=e9577]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e9578]:
            - generic [ref=e9579]:
              - generic [ref=e9580]: <title>
              - text: Laziness
              - generic [ref=e9581]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e9582]:
              - generic [ref=e9583]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/laziness/
              - generic [ref=e9584]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e9585]:
              - generic [ref=e9586]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e9587]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e9588]:
              - generic [ref=e9589]: <pubDate>
              - text: Wed, 04 Feb 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e9590]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e9591]:
              - generic [ref=e9592]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/laziness/
              - generic [ref=e9593]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e9594]:
              - generic [ref=e9595]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9596]: term="PowerShell"
                - text: ">"
              - text: PowerShell
              - generic [ref=e9597]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9598]:
              - generic [ref=e9599]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9600]: term="RDP"
                - text: ">"
              - text: RDP
              - generic [ref=e9601]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9602]:
              - generic [ref=e9603]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9604]: term="Lazy"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Lazy
              - generic [ref=e9605]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9606]:
              - generic [ref=e9607]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9608]: term="ITAdmin"
                - text: ">"
              - text: ITAdmin
              - generic [ref=e9609]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9610]:
              - generic [ref=e9611]: <description>
              - text: <p>I am lazy, I won‚Äôt try and deny that. When my alarm goes off in the morning, I will snooze it for twenty minutes or so before getting out of bed.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2015/02/bill-gates-quote.jpg" loading="lazy" width="460" height="298" /> </p> <p>In my work my laziness continues. Remote Desktop (or RDP) is probably my number one laziness tool. For those that don‚Äôt know RDP allows you to connect to another computer and access it like you were sat in front of it. So I can be sat at my desk and RDP into any other computer in the office including any server. However this laziness tool does sometimes require a bit of effort sometimes, powering on the target computer, logging on locally, making sure the user account you are using is allowed to use RDP.</p> <p>Writing a script is another example of a laziness tool. I often get asked to do tedious and long-winded task, because I am lazy I will go out of my way to learn how to write a script to do this, so that I can run this script and do this long-winded task in a matter of seconds. There are loads of different types of scripts from database SQL scripts, to PowerShell scripts that can do almost anything on your server.</p> <p>PowerShell is something Microsoft are really pushing at the moment, you can even write scripts to create new user accounts, so no longer will you have to remember to tick that tickbox for every new user account. And because PowerShell is part of almost all MS technologies you can link Exchange to Active Directory and you don‚Äôt even have to remember the right syntax as PowerShell has a built-in help command to tell you how to run that useful command.</p> <p>As I am now moving into a more developer role can I continue to be lazy? I sure can. Code should be written once and reused as often as possible and this is one of the features of OOP (Object Oriented Programming).</p> <p>It can be as simple as creating a master page so you don‚Äôt need to recreate the same code on every one of your webpages. Or every time you find yourself rewriting the same code again, you plug it into a method so it can be called again and again.</p> <p>But of course the ultimate way to be lazy is of course get yourself some staff and spend all day getting them to do everything. If you are lucky they may even try and adopt some of these lazy ideas.</p>
              - generic [ref=e9612]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e9614]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e9615]:
          - generic [ref=e9618]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e9619]:
            - generic [ref=e9620]:
              - generic [ref=e9621]: <title>
              - text: Podcasts
              - generic [ref=e9622]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e9623]:
              - generic [ref=e9624]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/podcasts/
              - generic [ref=e9625]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e9626]:
              - generic [ref=e9627]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e9628]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e9629]:
              - generic [ref=e9630]: <pubDate>
              - text: Tue, 27 Jan 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e9631]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e9632]:
              - generic [ref=e9633]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/podcasts/
              - generic [ref=e9634]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e9635]:
              - generic [ref=e9636]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9637]: term="ITAdmin"
                - text: ">"
              - text: ITAdmin
              - generic [ref=e9638]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9639]:
              - generic [ref=e9640]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9641]: term="StarTrek"
                - text: ">"
              - text: StarTrek
              - generic [ref=e9642]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9643]:
              - generic [ref=e9644]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9645]: term="Podcast"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Podcast
              - generic [ref=e9646]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9647]:
              - generic [ref=e9648]: <description>
              - text: <p>For a while now I have been listening to podcasts. For those that don‚Äôt know a podcast is an audio file that you can download and listen to, usually about a topic you are interested in. The topics that interest me are obviously Star Trek, Science and Technology and IT stuff. I mainly listen to them in the car when I am driving, but sometimes it will be at home when doing jobs around the house.</p> <p>I think the first podcast I listened to was <a href="http://www.trekmate.org.uk/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Trekmate</a> . Trekmate as the name suggests is about Star Trek, it‚Äôs a few guys talking about Star Trek. It‚Äôs very similar to those conversations you have in the pub with your mates. Trekmate do lots of podcasts, one for almost every flavour of Star Trek out there, I don‚Äôt keep up with all of them, but the ones I listen to I really enjoy.</p> <p>My favourite podcast that is work related is <a href="http://www.runasradio.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">RunAs Radio</a> . If you are a SysAdmin or have an interest in servers or IT you should listen to this. The host Richard Campbell interviews IT experts about a particular piece of technology, one week it will be Exchange, the next Security, and then SQL Server. Often I will learn something that I will want to try out, some weeks I won‚Äôt learn something specific but will give be an insight into which way IT for businesses is going. I think it was probably only after listening to RunAs Radio that are started having more of a long term plan for my IT infrastructure at work.</p> <p>As I have blogged about before I am learning Development so obviously I listen to <a href="http://www.dotnetrocks.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">.NET Rocks</a> . This is hosted by Carl Franklin and Richard Campbell (yes the same guy that does RunAs Radio) who talk to developers about code, learning and IT from a more Developer point of view. This is released 3 times a week so is a bit hit and miss sometimes, but most weeks there will be something relevant to me or worth listening to.</p> <p>A few days ago I did something for the first time, I was a guest on one of the Trekmate pods, TenForward. I reviewed 5 Star Trek episodes. This was a bit of a leap for me as an introvert I don‚Äôt like to be the center of attention and I certainly don‚Äôt like how my voice sounds recorded. Hopefully when released people will like it and I will do lots more of these in the future. Once it has been released I will put a link up here so you can all have a listen.</p>
              - generic [ref=e9649]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e9651]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e9652]:
          - generic [ref=e9655]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e9656]:
            - generic [ref=e9657]:
              - generic [ref=e9658]: <title>
              - text: Pair Programming
              - generic [ref=e9659]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e9660]:
              - generic [ref=e9661]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/pair-programming/
              - generic [ref=e9662]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e9663]:
              - generic [ref=e9664]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e9665]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e9666]:
              - generic [ref=e9667]: <pubDate>
              - text: Mon, 19 Jan 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e9668]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e9669]:
              - generic [ref=e9670]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/pair-programming/
              - generic [ref=e9671]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e9672]:
              - generic [ref=e9673]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9674]: term="PairProgramming"
                - text: ">"
              - text: PairProgramming
              - generic [ref=e9675]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9676]:
              - generic [ref=e9677]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9678]: term="FreeCodeCamp"
                - text: ">"
              - text: FreeCodeCamp
              - generic [ref=e9679]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9680]:
              - generic [ref=e9681]: <description>
              - text: <p>So I have been working through the challenges on the <a href="http://www.freecodecamp.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">freecodecamp</a> website and one of the unique things that this site does is give you the chance to program with another person.</p> <p>I am an introvert and if you were to ask me to pick up the phone and ring someone I will procrastinate a lot before doing it (if I do it at all), I also am not good at speaking with strangers but I have been enjoying the pair programming I have done so far.</p> <p>I have only pair programmed a couple of times so far, so I am no expert. The first time was with someone from North America, it was weird to begin with talking to your computer and hearing an american voice respond, but you soon forget that as you concentrate on the problems you are working on.</p> <p>The second time was with someone from the Netherlands. This time we tackled some trickier problems. Both times I took more of a back seat but I think contributed useful stuff and I certainly learnt a lot from the other person.</p> <p>I think that is the key thing about pair programming, you learn so much about how to look at a problem from another angle, or learn about a function you haven‚Äôt heard of before. If you are reading this and it was you that I pair programmed with a big thank you for spending the time with me, I learnt a lot.</p> <p>I was trying to pair program again tonight but technical problems prevented me. One problem I have found is finding a partner, was hoping to do some yesterday but no one else was around to partner with.</p> <p>I would be interested to learn what companies use pair programming. I imagine a pointy haired boss would say why pay two people to do one job, when you could get them working on different things. However if you want to build up your team and give them loads more skills then pair programming would be great. I also think there are probably some problems that are crying out for pair programming.</p>
              - generic [ref=e9682]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e9684]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e9685]:
          - generic [ref=e9688]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e9689]:
            - generic [ref=e9690]:
              - generic [ref=e9691]: <title>
              - text: Javascript progress
              - generic [ref=e9692]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e9693]:
              - generic [ref=e9694]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/javascript-progress/
              - generic [ref=e9695]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e9696]:
              - generic [ref=e9697]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e9698]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e9699]:
              - generic [ref=e9700]: <pubDate>
              - text: Fri, 16 Jan 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e9701]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e9702]:
              - generic [ref=e9703]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/javascript-progress/
              - generic [ref=e9704]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e9705]:
              - generic [ref=e9706]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9707]: term="JavaScript"
                - text: ">"
              - text: JavaScript
              - generic [ref=e9708]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9709]:
              - generic [ref=e9710]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9711]: term="SourceCode"
                - text: ">"
              - text: SourceCode
              - generic [ref=e9712]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9713]:
              - generic [ref=e9714]: <description>
              - text: <p>I got excited earlier this week as I started playing around with the javascript I have been learning.</p> <p>I thought I would try and create useful javascript that could be applied to an online filestore. Somewhere that you could upload, delete, edit files and folders and various options to do with your files would popup via javascript or jquery code.</p> <p>So far I have created a static HTML page which lists a few dummy files. I have added a button which adds a new row into my table and I have used jquery to highlight any selected files and also when the mouse passes over.</p> <p>If you want to follow my progress I have put my files on <a href="https://github.com/funkysi1701/CodeSamples/tree/master/clouds-js" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">github</a> . It‚Äôs very basic stuff and I have already got a few lines I would like to refactor but not bad for an evenings work. I have lots of feature ideas to add to this page which should help me learn the basics.</p> <p>The trouble with learning all this javascript is that I am starting to get all my programming languages confused. Earlier this week I started writing a for loop in javascript, only problem was I was working on an MS Access ADP (Don‚Äôt ask!) which requires the code in VBA. That is never going to work. Oh well.</p> <p>If anyone knows good ways to stop myself getting my programming languages all confused do let me know.</p>
              - generic [ref=e9715]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e9717]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e9718]:
          - generic [ref=e9721]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e9722]:
            - generic [ref=e9723]:
              - generic [ref=e9724]: <title>
              - text: My Year of Code
              - generic [ref=e9725]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e9726]:
              - generic [ref=e9727]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/my-year-of-code/
              - generic [ref=e9728]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e9729]:
              - generic [ref=e9730]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e9731]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e9732]:
              - generic [ref=e9733]: <pubDate>
              - text: Fri, 09 Jan 2015 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e9734]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e9735]:
              - generic [ref=e9736]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2015/my-year-of-code/
              - generic [ref=e9737]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e9738]:
              - generic [ref=e9739]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9740]: term="JavaScript"
                - text: ">"
              - text: JavaScript
              - generic [ref=e9741]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9742]:
              - generic [ref=e9743]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9744]: term="JQuery"
                - text: ">"
              - text: JQuery
              - generic [ref=e9745]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9746]:
              - generic [ref=e9747]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9748]: term="FreeCodeCamp"
                - text: ">"
              - text: FreeCodeCamp
              - generic [ref=e9749]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9750]:
              - generic [ref=e9751]: <description>
              - text: <p>There is no escaping the fact that we are in 2015 now. My new years resolution is to do more coding.</p> <p>Over Christmas I thought I would have a go at <a href="http://www.codecademy.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.codecademy.com</a> I completed the javascript course and I was just wondering what I should try next when I saw a tweet about <a href="http://www.freecodecamp.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.freecodecamp.com</a> </p> <p>Since then I have been addicted to doing the exercises that they have, almost everyday I have made a bit of progress.</p> <p>But this site is not just about teaching you how to code, it has an active forum where you can ask questions and understand more about what it takes to become a developer.</p> <p>Before I started these exercises I didn‚Äôt know much javascript or jquery but I am starting to learn quite a few commands that hopefully I can put into use at some point. Whatever development I end up doing I am sure I am going to need javascript at some point.</p> <p>One of the tips I have learnt is that you need to practise daily. Did you ever use flash cards to help pass exams? Well there is an electronic version of them now called Anki. Just add a question/answer pair to your deck of cards and review them each day, the ones you find difficult you review more often than the ones you have learnt.</p> <p>Hopefully I can keep this up and later in the year I will be well on way to writing lots of useful code.</p>
              - generic [ref=e9752]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e9754]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e9755]:
          - generic [ref=e9758]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e9759]:
            - generic [ref=e9760]:
              - generic [ref=e9761]: <title>
              - text: "2014 in Review: Achievements and Lessons Learned"
              - generic [ref=e9762]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e9763]:
              - generic [ref=e9764]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2014/looking-back-at-2014/
              - generic [ref=e9765]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e9766]:
              - generic [ref=e9767]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e9768]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e9769]:
              - generic [ref=e9770]: <pubDate>
              - text: Wed, 31 Dec 2014 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e9771]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e9772]:
              - generic [ref=e9773]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2014/looking-back-at-2014/
              - generic [ref=e9774]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e9775]:
              - generic [ref=e9776]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9777]: term="Goals"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Goals
              - generic [ref=e9778]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9779]:
              - generic [ref=e9780]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9781]: term="Azure"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Azure
              - generic [ref=e9782]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9783]:
              - generic [ref=e9784]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9785]: term="ITAdmin"
                - text: ">"
              - text: ITAdmin
              - generic [ref=e9786]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9787]:
              - generic [ref=e9788]: <description>
              - text: <p>As today is New Years eve I thought it would be a good chance to look back over the last year.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2014/12/tangle.jpg" loading="lazy" width="1065" height="909" /> </p> <p>At the start of the year I finally got agreement for the installation of a 30MB leased line. This was an amazing achievement as I had been really struggling to keep everything working on our ADSL connections and the complexity of the connections was starting to cause problems itself.</p> <p>However it was not a smooth process, the site survey revealed a substantial installation cost would be required, however the Council was about to launch a voucher scheme that would give us ¬£3000 off. So most of this was just waiting around for the Council to get things going. By April we had it installed and I have been very happy with the ISP we chose, York Data Service (YDS).</p> <p>Also during April this year was the end of support for Windows XP and Office 2003. This didn‚Äôt impact us too much, mostly due to my constant nagging of the directors to replace our oldest machines. We now only have a couple of machines still running XP and no machines running Office 2003. Most machines are now running Windows 7, I have one Director running Windows 8 for presentations and a few surveyor tablets running windows 8 as well. Like many businesses I am waiting for Windows 10 next year before doing any more substantial replacement of OS.</p> <p>In May it was decided that I would move more into development work, so I got a new desktop PC and Visual Studio. I am very happy with my new machine (subject to dell fixing a problem later today) So far I have only dipped my toe into development work, this is largely due to needing more time to build up others to do what I do.</p> <p>In June I made another huge achievement. I got agreement for a new server. This was our first Server 2012 server and allowed us to make huge strides towards virtualizing our services. Once we had this server up and running I was able to decommission two of our Windows Server 2003 machines well before it goes out of support next year.</p> <p>I am a huge fan of this new server, I have only used a fraction of its memory. Hyper V is really great and I hope to make progress next year into HyperV replication.</p> <p>Also during 2014 we made huge progress with our clouds software. Within the last few weeks it is running on the Azure platform which will not only make it far easier to expand and create new features it will provide us with cost savings. I am looking forward to learning more about Azure as I get deeper into development.</p> <p>Wow I achieved a lot didn‚Äôt I, on top of this I hired a new IT person and trained him up (still more to do), I have also fixed lots of printers, websites, servers (had a server motherboard die!), and made hundreds of changes to our internal databases.</p> <p>I don‚Äôt know what is in store for 2015. I expect a lots of the same with hopefully more focus on developing in Visual Studio, training myself and my department and getting the last few tweaks into our internal servers.</p> <p>I would also like to thank everyone that I have worked with over the last 12 months (you know who you are), as you made a lot of what I have just described possible.</p>
              - generic [ref=e9789]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e9791]: </item>

              - generic [ref=e9853]: <description>
              - text: <p>On Friday night I had the urge to fire up Visual Studio and tomorrow (Monday) I move house.</p> <p>What‚Äôs with that? Why am I in a programming mood when I have boxes to pack and shelves to take apart?</p> <p>For the last few weeks I have been too busy with other things to do much programming or when I had the time I felt more like relaxing than learning anything new.</p> <p>How do I get into the programming zone, what was it about this particular weekend that made me want to? Was it just the fact I had no time to concentrate on it, or is there some more useful factor that controls my desire to code?</p> <p>I can think of a few factors that I should make note of.</p> <ol> <li>Peace and quiet ‚Äì Friday night I had the place to myself so I could concentrate and do whatever I wanted.</li> <li>Ideas ‚Äì Before I started I had some ideas, why don‚Äôt I try doing x. Once I have a coding idea I need to investigate it and see where it goes.</li> <li>Break from routine ‚Äì Friday night was the start of a whole week away from work, this gives me more time to forget about the daily stress of the office and think about other things.</li> <li>Goals ‚Äì Work annoyed me on Friday and if I want to achieve my goal of working in development more then I need to work at it.</li> </ol> <p>I am not sure how I can put these into practise so that I spend more time on development but we will see. One thing I want to achieve in my new home is a quiet place to concentrate and think without distractions, I have a few options which I will investigate over the next few weeks.</p> <p>Anyway need to get back to packing boxes.</p>
              - generic [ref=e9854]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e9856]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e9857]:
          - generic [ref=e9860]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e9861]:
            - generic [ref=e9862]:
              - generic [ref=e9863]: <title>
              - text: If you had ¬£5000 to spend on technology what would you get?
              - generic [ref=e9864]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e9865]:
              - generic [ref=e9866]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2014/if-you-had-5000-to-spend-on-technology-what-would-you-get/
              - generic [ref=e9867]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e9868]:
              - generic [ref=e9869]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e9870]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e9871]:
              - generic [ref=e9872]: <pubDate>
              - text: Sun, 26 Oct 2014 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e9873]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e9874]:
              - generic [ref=e9875]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2014/if-you-had-5000-to-spend-on-technology-what-would-you-get/
              - generic [ref=e9876]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e9877]:
              - generic [ref=e9878]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9879]: term="Servers"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Servers
              - generic [ref=e9880]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9881]:
              - generic [ref=e9882]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9883]: term="Spending"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Spending
              - generic [ref=e9884]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9885]:
              - generic [ref=e9886]: <description>
              - text: <p>I listen to the dot net rocks podcast and they ask this question every show. (If you don‚Äôt listen then you should!)</p> <p>I don‚Äôt know what my answer would be as there are so many gadgets and cool things that I like the sound of.</p> <p>I might get a surface pro 3, it‚Äôs a tablet with attachable keyboard that‚Äôs more powerful than my current laptop. But at ¬£600 it‚Äôs expensive so maybe not. Maybe instead I would install a SSD into my existing laptop to increase disk performance.</p> <p>I‚Äôd like a new car with lots of gadgets built-in. A friend gave me a ride in his new BMW and it‚Äôs nice. Bluetooth so I don‚Äôt have to have an audio cable to listen to podcasts. Parking sensors so no chance the wife will prang it. Built in satnav etc</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2014/google-car.png" loading="lazy" width="599" height="428" /> </p> <p>While we are on the subject of cars eventually I‚Äôd like a google self driving car as I think Google is a better driver than me. Think about it I drive to a friends I have a drink I sleep in the back seat as my car drives me home. Once all cars are automated I believe the roads will be much safer.</p> <p>The last thing I would spend on is an intensive training course on development, I would really like to get further in dev and more training would really help. Specifically something that would help solve my current dev problems. I am sure it is possible for me to learn dev with self-study but that requires a discipline I don‚Äôt think I have, I easily eat my time up with my current job, wife and other interests.</p> <p>I recently had ¬£6500 to spend on improving my employers IT infrastructure. That was really hard. It sounds like a lot of money, but it really isn‚Äôt.</p> <p>Once I started looking at the problems that I wanted to solve and what hardware I wanted I quickly used it all up and that was before I factored in license and software costs. In the end I just had to order what I wanted and hope that on a future date I could spend on other areas. I got a super powerful server that I could virtualize almost all our existing physical servers with it I needed licences, which left me just enough to get a NAS for file storage.</p>
              - generic [ref=e9887]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e9889]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e9890]:
          - generic [ref=e9893]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e9894]:
            - generic [ref=e9895]:
              - generic [ref=e9896]: <title>
              - text: Top IT Interview Questions and How to Answer Them
              - generic [ref=e9897]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e9898]:
              - generic [ref=e9899]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2014/interview-questions/
              - generic [ref=e9900]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e9901]:
              - generic [ref=e9902]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e9903]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e9904]:
              - generic [ref=e9905]: <pubDate>
              - text: Thu, 23 Oct 2014 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e9906]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e9907]:
              - generic [ref=e9908]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2014/interview-questions/
              - generic [ref=e9909]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e9910]:
              - generic [ref=e9911]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9912]: term="ITAdmin"
                - text: ">"
              - text: ITAdmin
              - generic [ref=e9913]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9914]:
              - generic [ref=e9915]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9916]: term="Interview"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Interview
              - generic [ref=e9917]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9918]:
              - generic [ref=e9919]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9920]: term="Technical"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Technical
              - generic [ref=e9921]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9922]:
              - generic [ref=e9923]: <description>
              - text: "<p>I have done a few interviews from both sides of the table, I‚Äôm not very good at either but thought I would have a go at answering my favourite questions.</p> <p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2014/10/how-not-to-ace-the-technical-interview.jpg\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"550\" height=\"454\" /> </p> <p><strong>Describe an IT disaster and what you did to turn it around?</strong></p> <p>The question is all about the turn it around bit. I‚Äôve had lots of answers that emphasise the problem rather than what the candidate did to turn things around.</p> <p>My answer would be: on a Saturday I was rearranging the server room and when I came to turn on our main file server and pdc it wouldn‚Äôt boot. My plans for the weekend went out the window it was all about getting this server back up. I tried the usual unplug everything and reconnect still nothing. I rang a friend to get a second opinion and between the two of us we formulated a plan of action. I then rang my director to tell her that I was having problems and what I was going to try. (keeping people informed is an essential skill)</p> <p>So the server in question was getting power but nothing was happening during boot. The motherboard had died. What I needed to do was connect the raid card to another server so I could copy the data from it to our Nas drive (luckily I had an upgrade plan and this failure had just accelerated it)</p> <p>A few hours later the data was copying and I could breathe again. I told my director that I had fixed things but there would be minor issues on Monday.</p> <p><strong>Describe your strengths and weaknesses?</strong></p> <p>It wouldn‚Äôt be an interview without a strengths and weaknesses question. As an interviewer I want at least one weakness and I want it to actually be a weakness.</p> <p>My strengths are my problem solving skills, I can look at a problem and investigate what is going on and find a solution. If its a technology I haven‚Äôt used before I can read up about it and find out how it works and then use it to solve the issue.</p> <p>My weakness is my interpersonal skills, I am much better at analysing a computer issue than figuring out why one member of my staff is not performing. This is an area that is improving over the last few years I have taken on more responsibility over people and I am learning more about getting the best out of them.</p> <p><strong>Technical Questions</strong></p> <p>I have never included technical questions in one of my interviews until recently and I think it is a good way to gauge ability. I often come out of an interview unsure how well that person would perform under the stresses of my job. If I have something down on paper it is a good start.</p> <p>But the personality that comes through during the interview must also be considered as most knowledge can be taught.</p> <p>A good technical question I have used in the past is write a paragraph explaining DHCP. This question illustrates what their knowledge is like for an essential technology, but it also indicates what their writing style is like. Could the passage they have written be given to a Director or Client?</p> <p>Good IT people need both technical knowledge and the ability to communicate at all levels, I still struggle to know if someone is good or not and even sometimes if I am any good.</p>"
              - generic [ref=e9924]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e9926]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e9927]:
          - generic [ref=e9930]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e9931]:
            - generic [ref=e9932]:
              - generic [ref=e9933]: <title>
              - text: To boldly go where no SQL has gone before Part 2
              - generic [ref=e9934]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e9935]:
              - generic [ref=e9936]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2014/to-boldly-go-where-no-sql-has-gone-before-part-2/
              - generic [ref=e9937]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e9938]:
              - generic [ref=e9939]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e9940]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e9941]:
              - generic [ref=e9942]: <pubDate>
              - text: Tue, 21 Oct 2014 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e9943]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e9944]:
              - generic [ref=e9945]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2014/to-boldly-go-where-no-sql-has-gone-before-part-2/
              - generic [ref=e9946]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e9947]:
              - generic [ref=e9948]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9949]: term="StarTrek"
                - text: ">"
              - text: StarTrek
              - generic [ref=e9950]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9951]:
              - generic [ref=e9952]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9953]: term="SQL"
                - text: ">"
              - text: SQL
              - generic [ref=e9954]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9955]:
              - generic [ref=e9956]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9957]: term="Database"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Database
              - generic [ref=e9958]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9959]:
              - generic [ref=e9960]: <description>
              - text: <p>Let‚Äôs continue looking at a database schema for storing details of every Star Trek Episode. If you are new to databases, a schema is just the design of the structure of the database.</p> <p>We have three tables, Episode, EpisodeWriter and Writer. See my last post for more details of these. It has been suggested that a slight change to this structure would enable storage of more of the creative staff.</p> <p>Lets rename Writer and call it Credit, and rename EpisodeWriter and call it EpisodeCredit. Now any creative staff member involved in an episode can be stored in the Credit table. Lets alter EpisodeCredit and add an extra column called CreditType. CreditType is just a text field that stores the role that creative person had on that episode, it can be anything from Director, Writer, Actor, Science Consultant etc.</p> <p>We now have the ability to store information relating to the episode in the episode table and any creative people in the credit table. What else can we add to the database? How about a table that can be used to record when an episode was last watched. I am probably weird but sometimes I want to watch a Star Trek episode that I like but I haven‚Äôt watched in ages.</p> <p>The last watched table is really simple and just have a datetime field and episodeId. This can be further expanded to have a userId field if you wanted to keep track of what episodes your friends had been watching.</p> <p>Another idea could be to tag episodes with certain themes or topics like Klingon episodes or meaning of life episodes or Kirk talks a computer to death episodes. Again this is fairly simple table containing TagName and EpisodeId.</p>
              - generic [ref=e9961]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e9963]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e9964]:
          - generic [ref=e9967]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e9968]:
            - generic [ref=e9969]:
              - generic [ref=e9970]: <title>
              - text: To boldly go where no SQL has gone before
              - generic [ref=e9971]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e9972]:
              - generic [ref=e9973]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2014/to-boldly-go-where-no-sql-has-gone-before/
              - generic [ref=e9974]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e9975]:
              - generic [ref=e9976]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e9977]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e9978]:
              - generic [ref=e9979]: <pubDate>
              - text: Sun, 12 Oct 2014 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e9980]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e9981]:
              - generic [ref=e9982]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2014/to-boldly-go-where-no-sql-has-gone-before/
              - generic [ref=e9983]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e9984]:
              - generic [ref=e9985]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9986]: term="StarTrek"
                - text: ">"
              - text: StarTrek
              - generic [ref=e9987]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9988]:
              - generic [ref=e9989]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9990]: term="SQL"
                - text: ">"
              - text: SQL
              - generic [ref=e9991]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9992]:
              - generic [ref=e9993]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e9994]: term="Database"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Database
              - generic [ref=e9995]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e9996]:
              - generic [ref=e9997]: <description>
              - text: <p>My last post proved quite popular so I am wondering if I can combine a post about IT and Star Trek.</p> <p>Years ago I used to have lists of Star Trek episodes, which included such information like original air date, production number, episode title and brief description.</p> <p>One thing that was hard to keep track of was how many episodes were written by a specific person. This is because episodes are written by multiple people. A column called writer would then need to contain multiple people, another option would be to have columns called writer1, writer2 etc. This wouldn‚Äôt help either as you wouldn‚Äôt know which column a specific writer had been saved in.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2014/10/manytomany.jpg" loading="lazy" width="559" height="334" /> </p> <p>The relationship between writer and episode is known as a many to many relationship. An episode can have many writers and a writer can have written many episodes. To achieve this structure in a SQL database you will need three database tables as it is not possible to create a many to many join between two tables. The first table will contain all the episodes, the second table will contain all the writers, the third table known as a junction table, will contain the relationship between the two.</p> <p>Let‚Äôs do an example so we can see how this would work. Gene Roddenberry creator of Star Trek wrote the pilot episode ‚ÄòThe Cage‚Äô. So Gene would be added to the writers table with an id of 1 and The Cage would be added to the episode table with an id of 1. In the junction table, it has two columns episode and writer, so we would enter 1 and 1 into these columns.</p> <div class="highlight"><pre tabindex="0" style="color:#f8f8f2;background-color:#272822;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;"><code class="language-sql" data-lang="sql"><span style="display:flex;"><span><span style="color:#66d9ef">Select</span> <span style="color:#f92672">*</span> <span style="color:#66d9ef">from</span> Episode e </span></span><span style="display:flex;"><span><span style="color:#66d9ef">Join</span> EpisodeWriter ew <span style="color:#66d9ef">on</span> e.id <span style="color:#f92672">=</span> ew.EpisodeId </span></span><span style="display:flex;"><span><span style="color:#66d9ef">Join</span> Writer w <span style="color:#66d9ef">on</span> w.id <span style="color:#f92672">=</span> ew.WriterId </span></span></code></pre></div><p>But if Gene Coon and Gene Roddenberry had writing credits on The Cage we would need to add Gene Coon to the writing table and add an extra entry to the episodewriter table.</p> <p>I am going to do more posts based on this as I expand the database structure to include other information, I may go on to create stored procedures for bringing back certain information or I may use this as an example to talk about coding a user interface.</p>
              - generic [ref=e9998]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e10000]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e10001]:
          - generic [ref=e10004]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e10005]:
            - generic [ref=e10006]:
              - generic [ref=e10007]: <title>
              - text: Destination Star Trek
              - generic [ref=e10008]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e10009]:
              - generic [ref=e10010]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2014/destination-star-trek/
              - generic [ref=e10011]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e10012]:
              - generic [ref=e10013]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e10014]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e10015]:
              - generic [ref=e10016]: <pubDate>
              - text: Sun, 05 Oct 2014 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e10017]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e10018]:
              - generic [ref=e10019]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2014/destination-star-trek/
              - generic [ref=e10020]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e10021]:
              - generic [ref=e10022]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e10023]: term="StarTrek"
                - text: ">"
              - text: StarTrek
              - generic [ref=e10024]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e10025]:
              - generic [ref=e10026]: <description>
              - text: "<p>As a break from my usual topics I am going to talk about what I did over the weekend.</p> <p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2014/10670061_10152884492389155_77781042960777157_n.jpg\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"360\" height=\"640\" /> </p> <p>I am a huge star trek fan, so me and my wife Laura went to Destination Star Trek, a convention held in London. This is a picture of us in costume, my wife created a tribble costume (A tribble is an alien race that just consists of a ball of fur) and I am wearing an original series captains uniform. We had a great time.</p> <p>There are several things that made this trip special.</p> <ul> <li><strong>Friends</strong>: After the last convention I remember thinking how much better the convention would be with a group of friends. Shortly afterwards I started listening to the trekmate podcast, eventually this lead to me helping out with their website and making friends via twitter with many of the hosts. This weekend was the first time I met up with them and it was great to put faces to names (or twitter names)</li> <li><strong>Writers and Directors</strong>: Star Trek has a great philosophy. In the future human beings will put their differences aside and work together to explore the galaxy, this is one reason why Star Trek is so popular even after almost 50 years. This philosophy has been created by the writers and other creative staff over the years. My favourite Star Trek film is Wrath of Khan which was directed by Nicholas Meyer, this weekend I got my DVD signed by him and was able to tell him how I still enjoyed that film over 30 years after it was made. He said that he really appreciated me saying that. Listening to his talk later on, it was fascinating to hear his insights into making my favourite film. It is the writers and directors that make our favourite characters who they are, the actors themselves aren‚Äôt allowed to ad lib, all they do is flesh them out with a bit of emotion or a mannerism, it is the writer that create our favourite lines or situations that we remember.</li> <li><strong>Seven of Nine</strong>: During my teenage years I had lots of posters of Seven on my walls. Seven of Nine was the ex-borg that walked around the ship in a skin tight catsuit, but she was also highly intelligent and continued to explore what it was to be human. It was great to have my photo taken with her, even if it was rushed due to the large number of people that wanted their picture taken.</li> <li><strong>Trivia</strong>: On the Friday of the convention, Laura took part in the beginners trivia challenge, she won. On Saturday I took part in the intermediate trivia challenge, I did really badly only got 3 correct, On Sunday I took part in the captain level challenge and I won. I really wasn‚Äôt expecting that, after I did so badly the day before. Thanks Marc Stamper and Destination Star Trek for organising that it was great fun, and also fun to meet the other trekkies who I had been competing against via twitter.</li> <li><strong>Party!</strong>: On Saturday night we went to a party, we had Romulan Ale to drink, we had some of the actors performing songs (James Darren was particularly good), and some of the actors mingled with fans, it was great to see the actors relaxing and if you were lucky you could chat to them, I asked Vaughn Armstrong how he was enjoying the music, he loved it.</li> </ul> <p>This is just a taste of what I got up to, there was lots more, like seeing alien costumes, listening to talks, sitting on a mockup of the bridge. Only one way to end this post, <strong>Live Long and Prosper!</strong></p>"
              - generic [ref=e10027]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e10029]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e10030]:
          - generic [ref=e10033]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e10034]:
            - generic [ref=e10035]:
              - generic [ref=e10036]: <title>
              - text: Windows 9 or do I mean 10
              - generic [ref=e10037]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e10038]:
              - generic [ref=e10039]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2014/windows-9-or-do-i-mean-10/
              - generic [ref=e10040]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e10041]:
              - generic [ref=e10042]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e10043]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e10044]:
              - generic [ref=e10045]: <pubDate>
              - text: Wed, 01 Oct 2014 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e10046]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e10047]:
              - generic [ref=e10048]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2014/windows-9-or-do-i-mean-10/
              - generic [ref=e10049]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e10050]:
              - generic [ref=e10051]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e10052]: term="Windows"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Windows
              - generic [ref=e10053]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e10054]:
              - generic [ref=e10055]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e10056]: term="Microsoft"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Microsoft
              - generic [ref=e10057]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e10058]:
              - generic [ref=e10059]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e10060]: term="ITAdmin"
                - text: ">"
              - text: ITAdmin
              - generic [ref=e10061]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e10062]:
              - generic [ref=e10063]: <description>
              - text: <p>Like many systems administrators I watched as the news came out yesterday about the latest version of windows. What would it be like? What would it be called? Would it be better or worse than previous versions?</p> <p>I was shocked when the name of the new operating system was revealed to be Windows 10. What really!? At first I though someone had tweeted a photoshopped image of the press conference, but no it was really going to be called Windows 10.</p> <p><img class="img-fluid" alt="Windows 10" src="https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2014/10/windows_10_fullwidth.jpg" loading="lazy" width="800" height="478" /> </p> <p>Windows 10 is the next operating system to be released after windows 8, many had been calling it windows 9 or windows Threshold.</p> <p>Microsoft has never had a fixed naming convention for its OSes, so should we really be that surprised at its new name.</p> <ul> <li>Windows 1.0 (1985)</li> <li>Windows 2.0 (1987)</li> <li>Windows 3.0 (1990)</li> <li>Windows 95 (1995)</li> <li>Windows 98 (1998)</li> <li>Windows ME (2000)</li> <li>Windows XP (2001)</li> <li>Windows Vista (2007)</li> <li>Windows 7 (2009)</li> <li>Windows 8 (2012)</li> <li>Windows 10 (2015)</li> <li><em>Windows 11 (2021)</em></li> </ul> <p>One reason Microsoft may have gone with with Windows 10 is because they wanted to signify that the coming Windows release would be the last ‚Äúmajor‚Äù Windows update. What does it mean to be the last major update?</p> <p>If you look at the list of OSes above you will see that between XP and Vista was a huge 6 years, this gap is/has caused a huge headache for IT professionals (me included). Software was written for XP because that is all that was available, when XP moved out of support earlier this year it caused loads as problems as people tried to get this software to work on more modern OSes.</p> <p>If windows 10 is around for a long time we may end up with a similar situation to XP, in that loads of software will run only on it and cause problems if you try and port it to whatever comes next. I am only a trainee developer so I don‚Äôt know what is involved with building an OS, but I would imagine there must be things that are very difficult or almost impossible to fix without ripping them out and starting again which is what happens when a new version of an OS is written.</p> <p>Only time will tell if Windows 10 really is the last version of windows and what will happen to the OS in the future. What ever the case I am downloading a preview so I can have a look (I want my start menu back!)</p>
              - generic [ref=e10064]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e10066]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e10067]:
          - generic [ref=e10070]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e10071]:
            - generic [ref=e10072]:
              - generic [ref=e10073]: <title>
              - text: What is the difference between Development and Operations?
              - generic [ref=e10074]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e10075]:
              - generic [ref=e10076]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2014/what-is-the-difference-between-dev-and-ops/
              - generic [ref=e10077]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e10078]:
              - generic [ref=e10079]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e10080]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e10081]:
              - generic [ref=e10082]: <pubDate>
              - text: Sat, 27 Sep 2014 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e10083]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e10084]:
              - generic [ref=e10085]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2014/what-is-the-difference-between-dev-and-ops/
              - generic [ref=e10086]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e10087]:
              - generic [ref=e10088]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e10089]: term="DevOps"
                - text: ">"
              - text: DevOps
              - generic [ref=e10090]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e10091]:
              - generic [ref=e10092]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e10093]: term="Operations"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Operations
              - generic [ref=e10094]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e10095]:
              - generic [ref=e10096]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e10097]: term="ITAdmin"
                - text: ">"
              - text: ITAdmin
              - generic [ref=e10098]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e10099]:
              - generic [ref=e10100]: <description>
              - text: <p>I want to learn Development and eventually move into a development role. But what is the difference between development and what I already do?</p> <p>Put simply Development or programming is the creation of new programs, websites or databases.</p> <p>IT Operations or System Administration is the administration of existing servers, websites or databases.</p> <p>I have been doing System Administration since I started my job back in 2006. What you do as part of this role can be very simple like setting up new users or computers to something very complex like upgrading the version of Exchange that the company uses for its emails.</p> <p>As part of my role I have done a lot of tasks that could be described as development. I have created databases and built new database structures like tables, views and stored procedures. I have also assisted the development department with testing, setting up visual studio, building websites and databases from code.</p> <p>Can I describe myself as a developer? I would say yes, I have done plenty of work that is development work.</p> <p>Can I get a job as a developer? Possibly but it would depend on the role. I have many of the skills that developers use, but I have limited knowledge in many areas. What I need to do is concentrate my efforts onto the development work I do and delegate as much administration work as I can so my knowledge can increase.</p> <p>A Buzz word in IT at the moment is DevOps. I have lost count of the number of times .NetRocks or RunAsRadio have mentioned it.</p> <p>DevOps is the integration of IT Development and Operations, it emphasises the need for the two departments to work closely together to achieve common goals. In big companies the two departments can pull against each other if you are not careful, but in my case as I do both roles, it would be very difficult for the development side of myself to blame the operations side of myself for a problem.</p> <p>This I think puts me in a good position, I just need to learn more development and I will make a valuable addition to someone‚Äôs development team.</p>
              - generic [ref=e10101]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e10103]: </item>
        - generic [ref=e10104]:
          - generic [ref=e10107]: <item>
          - generic [ref=e10108]:
            - generic [ref=e10109]:
              - generic [ref=e10110]: <title>
              - text: I love Nagios
              - generic [ref=e10111]: </title>
            - generic [ref=e10112]:
              - generic [ref=e10113]: <link>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2014/i-love-nagios/
              - generic [ref=e10114]: </link>
            - generic [ref=e10115]:
              - generic [ref=e10116]: <author>
              - text: funkysi1701
              - generic [ref=e10117]: </author>
            - generic [ref=e10118]:
              - generic [ref=e10119]: <pubDate>
              - text: Wed, 24 Sep 2014 20:00:45 +0000
              - generic [ref=e10120]: </pubDate>
            - generic [ref=e10121]:
              - generic [ref=e10122]: <guid>
              - text: https://www.funkysi1701.com/posts/2014/i-love-nagios/
              - generic [ref=e10123]: </guid>
            - generic [ref=e10124]:
              - generic [ref=e10125]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e10126]: term="ITAdmin"
                - text: ">"
              - text: ITAdmin
              - generic [ref=e10127]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e10128]:
              - generic [ref=e10129]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e10130]: term="Monitoring"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Monitoring
              - generic [ref=e10131]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e10132]:
              - generic [ref=e10133]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e10134]: term="Servers"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Servers
              - generic [ref=e10135]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e10136]:
              - generic [ref=e10137]:
                - text: <category
                - generic [ref=e10138]: term="Nagios"
                - text: ">"
              - text: Nagios
              - generic [ref=e10139]: </category>
            - generic [ref=e10140]:
              - generic [ref=e10141]: <description>
              - text: "<p><img class=\"img-fluid\" alt=\"Nagios\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/cdn-cgi/image/width=800,quality=75/images/2014/nagios.png\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"212\" height=\"50\" /> </p> <p>You may not have heard of Nagios but it has saved my bacon quite a few times.</p> <p>Nagios is an open source server monitoring application that runs on many linux flavours.</p> <p>I can‚Äôt remember exactly when I first installed nagios but I am guessing it was sometime in 2007/8. My boss gave me a book about it (which I never read) and told me to create a system to monitor the companies servers.</p> <p>Nagios is not simple to set up. It relies on setting up various Hosts and services. Hosts are usually physical servers that you want to monitor and services are all the services you want to monitor. As this is a linux program all these can be configured by editing the right config file</p> <p>Nagios is very flexible and can be expanded easily with the use of plugins, if you want to monitor something there is usually a plugin available. If you have a dell server running openmanage software there is even a plugin that allows the temperature of your server to be monitored.</p> <p>If you want to monitor windows servers the use of nsclient++ is a real advantage. This is a simple client that runs as a service on your windows server. This allows nagios to track memory, cpu, disk space, performance and services, in fact almost everything that you would want to monitor.</p> <p>Over the years I have kept a close eye on Nagios and added extra checks as new services were added or problems encountered. A few years ago I dabbled with sending alerts out via SMS message and once I got a smart phone found an app to keep track of Nagios 24/7.</p> <p>But recently I have started wondering if Nagios is the best way to monitor modern servers like 2012 or remote services like Azure. I want something that is easy to expand as your IT infrastructure expands. Something that relies on running on a linux OS requires your IT staff have a knowledge of linux and you keep that server maintained and updated.</p> <p>My question is: Is Nagios still the best way to monitor my servers?</p>"
              - generic [ref=e10142]: </description>
          - generic [ref=e10144]: </item>

            - generic [ref=e10165]:
              - generic [ref=e10166]: <description>
              - text: "<img alt=\"Funky Si profile image\" src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/images/1922276.jpg\" style=\"float: left; padding-right: 15px; height: 150px\" /> <h2 id=\"hey-im-simon-foster\">Hey, I‚Äôm Simon Foster<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#hey-im-simon-foster\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>My online persona is <strong>Funky Si</strong> ‚Äî a nickname from university days that somehow stuck. I&rsquo;m a full-stack developer passionate about building scalable, maintainable applications and robust DevOps practices.</p> <p>With <strong>18+ years</strong> in IT departments (since 2006), I&rsquo;ve worn many hats: software developer, systems administrator, infrastructure engineer, database specialist, and DevOps advocate. My career has evolved from traditional ops work into modern cloud-native development, and I genuinely enjoy the intersection of development and infrastructure.</p> <h3 id=\"what-i-do\">What I Do<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#what-i-do\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <p>I specialize in:</p> <ul> <li><strong>Backend Development</strong>: .NET, C#, SQL Server, scalable API design</li> <li><strong>Cloud &amp; DevOps</strong>: Azure, AWS, Terraform, containerization (Docker/Kubernetes), CI/CD automation</li> <li><strong>Architecture</strong>: Designing systems that are secure, performant, and maintainable</li> </ul> <h2 id=\"certifications\">Certifications<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#certifications\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p><a href=\"https://www.credly.com/badges/adacf718-d696-4254-a68d-5b32f720ac78/public_url\" style=\"float:left; padding-right: 15px;\"><img src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/images/azure.png\" alt=\"Azure Fundamentals\" width=\"150\" /></a> <a href=\"https://www.credly.com/badges/3aab54c8-a109-4018-bcad-dbe0d6a1fc0c/public_url\" style=\"float:left;\"><img src=\"https://www.funkysi1701.com/images/awscp.png\" alt=\"AWS Cloud Practitioner\" width=\"150\" /></a></p> <div style=\"clear: both;\"></div> <h2 id=\"technology-stack\">Technology Stack<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#technology-stack\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>Organized by category:</p> <h3 id=\"languages\">Languages<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#languages\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <ul> <li>C#</li> <li>JavaScript</li> <li>PowerShell</li> <li>SQL</li> </ul> <h3 id=\"frameworks--platforms\">Frameworks & Platforms<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#frameworks--platforms\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <ul> <li>.NET (Framework &amp; Core)</li> <li>Blazor</li> <li>ASP.NET</li> </ul> <h3 id=\"databases\">Databases<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#databases\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <ul> <li>SQL Server</li> </ul> <h3 id=\"cloud--infrastructure\">Cloud & Infrastructure<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#cloud--infrastructure\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <ul> <li>Microsoft Azure (AppService, Functions, DevOps, KeyVault)</li> <li>Amazon Web Services</li> <li>Terraform</li> <li>Docker</li> <li>Kubernetes</li> <li>Helm</li> </ul> <h3 id=\"tools--services\">Tools & Services<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#tools--services\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h3> <ul> <li>Git</li> <li>Azure DevOps</li> <li>GitHub Actions</li> <li>CI/CD pipelines</li> <li>And many more&hellip;</li> </ul> <h2 id=\"featured-technologies--projects\">Featured Technologies & Projects<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#featured-technologies--projects\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>Recent work and areas of focus:</p> <ul> <li><strong>Kubernetes &amp; Helm</strong> - Orchestration and deployment automation</li> <li><strong>OpenTelemetry</strong> - Observability, logging, and distributed tracing</li> <li><strong>Elasticsearch</strong> - Search and analytics</li> <li><strong>Azure Infrastructure</strong> - AppService, Functions, DevOps, networking</li> <li><strong>Infrastructure as Code</strong> - Terraform, ARM templates, Helm charts</li> <li><strong>CI/CD Pipelines</strong> - GitHub Actions, Azure Pipelines</li> <li><strong>AI &amp; Machine Learning</strong> - Exploring applications in modern development</li> </ul> <h2 id=\"community\">Community<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#community\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>I&rsquo;m passionate about sharing knowledge with the tech community:</p> <ul> <li><strong>Blogger</strong> - 11+ years of writing about technology, DevOps practices, cloud architecture, and professional development on my blog</li> <li><strong>Tech Enthusiast</strong> - Continuously learning and exploring emerging technologies like AI, Kubernetes, and observability</li> </ul> <h2 id=\"blog--writing\">Blog & Writing<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#blog--writing\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>I regularly write about topics including:</p> <ul> <li>Cloud architecture and infrastructure as code</li> <li>.NET and C# development best practices</li> <li>DevOps tooling and automation</li> <li>Azure services and cloud deployment patterns</li> <li>Kubernetes and container orchestration</li> <li>Observability, monitoring, and logging</li> <li>Professional development and career growth</li> </ul> <h2 id=\"connect-with-me\">Connect With Me<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#connect-with-me\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p>Want to collaborate, chat about tech, or discuss DevOps and cloud architecture? Connect with me on:</p> <ul> <li><strong>GitHub</strong> - <a href=\"https://github.com/funkysi1701\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">@funkysi1701</a> </li> <li><strong>Twitter/X</strong> - <a href=\"https://twitter.com/funkysi1701\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">@funkysi1701</a> </li> <li><strong>BlueSky</strong> - <a href=\"https://bsky.app/profile/funkysi1701.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">@funkysi1701.com</a> </li> <li><strong>Mastodon</strong> - <a href=\"https://hachyderm.io/@funkysi1701\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">@funkysi1701</a> </li> <li><strong>LinkedIn</strong> - <a href=\"https://linkedin.com/in/funkysi1701\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">funkysi1701</a> </li> <li><strong>Facebook</strong> - <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/funkysi1701\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">funkysi1701</a> </li> <li><strong>Blog</strong> - Explore my latest posts and articles here on this site</li> </ul> <p>Feel free to reach out with questions, collaboration opportunities, or just to chat about technology!</p> <h2 id=\"recommendations\">Recommendations<a class=\"anchor ms-1\" href=\"#recommendations\"><i class=\"fas fa-link\"></i></a></h2> <p><em>Simon is an excellent developer, always looking for new methods and technology to improve existing solutions, along with his own skills. He is open to new ideas, though not afraid to share his thoughts and feedback and guide others to the best solution possible. It‚Äôs worth noting that Simon has vast knowledge on hardware and infrastructure which really does compliment his skill as a developer.</em> - Alasdair Thomson (Head of Business Data Solutions at NPD Travel Retail)</p> <p><em>Simon worked for my company for a number of years and was a very valued member of staff, and later on management. He is an intelligent and conscientious worker who gives over and above on a regular basis. He leads by example and was respected by his peers and the directors of the company. I would not hesitate to recommend Simon both in terms of the quality of his work and his ethics and values in life in general.</em> - Alison Davies (CEO at Eurosafe UK)</p> <p><em>If you want a developer who really understands DevOps, then Si is your man. With a mixture of operations, support, development and management experience, he can bring a balanced skillset to a team, as well as excellent knowledge of Azure, .NET, SQL and the web.</em> - Keith Williams (Development Manager at IRIS for Cascade HR and KashFlow Payroll)</p>"
              - generic [ref=e10167]: </description>
